titleStmt.title: Commentary on Homer's Iliad, Books IV-VI
titleStmt.author: Thomas D. Seymour

div.head: Book 4 (*d)
div.p: In the First Book of the Iliad, Achilles, the mightiest of the Greek warriors before Troy, quarrels with Agamemnon, the leader of the expedition, and withdraws from all part in the fray.
In the Second Book, the Achaeans are armed for battle with the Trojans.

At the beginning of the Third Book, just as the opposing armies are about to meet, Paris challenges Menelaus to a single combat which shall deeide the issue of the war. Priam is called from Troy, and a truce is struck. ‘If Menelaus slays Paris, the Greeks are to take Helen and peaceably return to their homes. If Paris slays Menelaus, the Greeks are to withdraw at once.’ In the single combat, Menelaus disables and overpowers Paris, and is just about to slay him, when the goddess Aphrodite snatches up her Trojan favorite, and deposits him safely in his home. At the close of *g, Menelaus is ranging through the host, seeking Paris, whom (of course) he cannot find; and Agamemnon, declaring that the victory belongs clearly to his brother, demands the surrender of Helen and the treasures which Paris had carried away from Sparta.

The Fourth Book opens with a Council of the Gods in the great hall of Zeus on Olympus. They have watched what has been done on the Trojan plain, and recognize the fact that Menelaus has won the victory. Zeus proposes that the provisions of the treaty be carried into effect,— that the Achaeans withdraw to their homes, taking with them Helen and her treasures. But Hera and Athena cannot consent to any peace which would leave unsacked the hated city of Troy, and they instigate a Lycian archer, a Trojan ally, to break the truce by wounding Menelaus. Then the strife begins anew.
1-219. The wounding of Menelaus.
1-84. Council of the gods. Preparations for a breach of the truce.
cf. oi( de\ qeoi\ pa\r *zhni\ kaqh/menoi a\sterophth=| (lightener)
div.l: qheu=nto (were watching) me/ga e)/rgon *)axaiw=n xalkoxitw/nwn *h 443 f.
div.p: qeoi/: in appos. with oi(. § 24 k.

h)goro/wnto: were in assembly, sc. during the events narrated in the preceding Book; cf. 10-12. The gods assembled in the great hall of Zeus, like retainers in the hall of their feudal lord. For the form, see § 29 c.

xruse/w| ktl.: a more definite statement of pa\r *zhni/ above. The pavement of the great hall was covered with plates of gold. cf. ‘and the floor of the house he overlaid with gold, within and without,’ 1 Kings vi. 30, of Solomon's temple. See on 1.426.
meta/: adverbial, in their midst. § 37 a.
sfi/si: dat. of interest, for them.

*(/hbh: only here in Homer as cup-bearer; but she renders other services to the gods in 5.722, 905. She does not appear as wife of Heracles in the Iliad, but in Od. 11.603 (a late passage), as in Pindar and other poets.

ne/ktar e)w|noxo/ei: cf. oi)noxo/ei ne/ktar *a 598, i(/ppoi boukole/onto g 221, ‘weekly journal’ (diurnus, i.e. ‘daily’). The original meaning of the compound verb was overlooked. The syllabic augment is used since oi)=nos began with *v. § 25 h; G. 104, N. 1; H. 359.
toi/: ou(=toi, § 24 i.
xruse/ois: disyllabic by ‘synizesis.’ § 7.
depa/essi: de/pasi, § 18 c, d; cf. e)pe/essi 6.

deide/xato: were pledging. Cf. plhsa/menos d' oi)/noio de/pas dei/dekt) *)axilh=a *i 224. The gods ‘drank each other's health.’ For the omission of the augment, see § 25 a. For the ending, see § 26 t.
au)ti/ka: at once, straightway; sc. after the close of the single combat described in *g. For the omission of a conjunction, see § 2 n.
*kroni/dhs: for the ‘patronymic,’ see § 21 e.
e)reqize/men: e)reqi/zein, § 26 j. This he does esp. by the proposition of 18.
parablh/dhn: Zeus teasingly compares Aphrodite's constant care of Paris with the neglect of Menelaus by Hera and Athena. For the ending, see § 38 c.
doiai/ [du/o]: emphatic, in contrast with the single defender of Paris, 10.
*menela/w|: dat. with a)rhgo/nes ei)si/, which is equiv. to a)rh/gousi. cf. *e 511, *trw/essin a)rwgoi/ *f 428.
qea/wn: for the uncontracted form, see § 16 d.
*)argei/h: Argos was the chief seat of Hera's worship. cf. o(/de | *(/hras o( kleino\s nao/s Soph. El. 8. cf. also 52.

*)alalkomenhi/s: of Alalcomenae, a Boeotian town where Athena was worshipped with special distinction from the earliest times. These epithets of the two goddesses,—*)alalkomenhi/s reminding of defence and protection (a)lalkei=n),—serve to strengthen the contrast with the ‘smile-loving’ Aphrodite, 10, h(=| ou) de/dotai polemh/ia e)/rga *e 428. Observe the ‘chiasmus’; see § 2 o.
a)ll' h)= toi: but truly.
no/sfi: sc. *menela/ou.
kaqh/menai: implies inactivity, in contrast with parme/mblwke.
ei)soro/wsai: closely connected, as cause, with te/rpesqon, delight in looking on.
tw=|: that one, i.e. Paris. The mention of his name is unnecessary, since the gods have been watching the single-combat.
au)=te: on the other hand.
filommeidh/s: by assimilation for filo-smei-dhs. See § 12 e.
parme/mblwke: from parablw/skw. See §§ 11 a, 12 g.

au)tou=: from himself, from his body. Const. as ablatival gen. with a)mu/nei. See § 3 d; cf. *zeu\s kh=ras (fates) a)/munen| paido\s e(ou= *m 402 f. For au)to/s referring to a man's body, cf. au)tou\s de\ e(lw/ria teu=xe ku/nessin *a 4. See § 2 v.
kai\ nu=n: introduces a special instance under the general statement of ai)ei/. cf. *a 107, 109, *e 603 f.
e)cesa/wsen: sc. qana/toio (cf. h)e/ min e)k qana/toio saw/somen *x 175) or pole/moio.
o)io/menon ktl.: cf. *o 728, u 21.
ni/kh: sc. e)sti/. cf. the words of Agamemnon, ni/kh me\n dh\ fai/net' a)rhifi/lou *menela/ou *g 457.
*menela/ou: for the gen., see G. 169, 1; H. 732 a.

o(/pws ktl.: how this shall be, i.e. what we shall do. Cf. 2.252. Zeus does not here indicate his preference,—still less his determination. He does not assume that the articles of the truce of *g are to be carried out. A loophole of escape has been left since the oath ran (3.281 ff.) ‘if Menelaus shall slay Alexander,’ and this condition had not been literally fulfilled.
ta/de e)/rga: the ‘hiatus’ is merely apparent. See §§ 9 f., 14 a; cf. 18.
cf. Od. 24.475 f., with teu/ceis for o)/rsomen, and ti/qhsqa for ba/lwmen. These verses explain the second ‘hemistich’ of 14.—h)/, h)=: see § 3 m a.
po/lemon ktl.: cf. 82, 18.242. For the use of nearly synonymous nouns, see § 1 s, and on 3.2.
o)/rsomen: aor. subjv., cf. ba/lwmen. For the short mode vowel, see § 27 a.
filo/thta: contrasted by its position before the verse-pause, with po/lemo/n te above.
ba/lwmen: bring, cause. Cf. ti/qhsin 83.

ei) d' au)= ktl.: Zeus is not serious in this proposition. He knows what the answer of the goddesses will be; and, as for himself, his promise to Thetis, that he would secure honor and satisfaction for Achilles, can be kept only by the continuance of hostilities. He is merely teasing (e)reqize/men 5) Hera and Athena. Hence he grants Hera's wish for the destruction of Troy more willingly than appears on the surface.
to/de: i.e. the latter of the alternatives presented above,—peaceful reconciliation.
pa=si: made prominent before the verse-pause. Obs. the same position of pa/ntes 29.
fi/lon ktl.: Hera cannot be expected to listen quietly to this.
h)= toi me/n: correl. with de/ 19. cf. 3.168 f.
me/n: long by ‘position.’ See §§ 41 m, 14 a.

oi)ke/oito: may be inhabited, may still stand, or (more freely) men may still dwell in the city of Priam. cf. oi( d' a)/lloi ... nai/oite *troi/hn *g 73 f. Trisyllabic by ‘synizesis.’ § 7 a. *pria/moio: *pria/mou, § 17 a.
*)argei/hn: a standing epithet of Helen, because of her former Peloponnesian home. cf. 2.161.
a)/goito: may take home as his wife. Obs. the force of the mid. voice. cf. 3.72, 404.
e)pe/mucan: e)pi/ here signifies thereat, at his words.
*)aqhnai/h ktl.: in appos. with ai(.
Parenthetical.
plhsi/ai: sc. a)llh/lais.
ai(/ g' h(/sqhn: equiv. to h(/menai.
kaka\ de\ ktl.: an independent, instead of a participial (mhdo/menai), clause. See § 3 t.
*trw/essi: Aeolic form for *trwsi/. § 18 c.
*)aqhnai/h: prominent by its position before the pause.
a)ke/wn: seems strictly a participle, but it became stereotyped, and is here used as an adverb. a)ke/ousa is used 1.565, 569. For an adv. with h)=n, cf. 277, 319, *a 416, *z 131.
ou)de/ ti ei)=pen: freq. in Homer, the last clause of the verse repeats the meaning of the earlier clause in more definite, or at least in different, form.—Athena was too angry to speak.

This verse is nearly parenthetical. The beginner will be greatly helped if he learns to notice how often the second half of a verse or one or more verses are parenthetical—used to give life to the picture, without adding anything necessary to the information of the hearer.
skuzome/nh ktl.: const. closely with a)ke/wn h)=n.
de/: a causal particle would have made the relation of the clauses more distinct. See § 3 q.
xo/los ktl.: cf. Od. 8.304.
xo/los: a burst of anger, while ko/tos is a grudge, and mh=nis is enduring wrath. The Attic o\rgh/ is not found in Homer.
h(/|rein: the impf. is more descriptive than the aor. would be. Athena was growing more and more angry. cf. ou)de/ min u(/pnos| h(/|rei *w 4 f.—For the n-movable, see § 12 n.
*(/hrh|: for the dative, see § 3 g a.
ou)k ktl.: i.e. her wrath ‘boiled over.’
proshu/da: sc. mi/n.
25 = *a 552, *q 462, *c 330, *p 440, *s 361. This sent. and the following are exclamatory.
poi=on: predicate. See H. 1012 a. “What is this which,” etc.
pw=s ktl.: a question of surprise, equiv. to the prosaie assertion, ‘it is in no way possible,’ ‘it cannot be.’
alion, a)te/leston: in vain, ineffectual. Pred., after qei=nai make (§ 2 v). cf. ou)/ toi e)/peiq' a(li/h o(do\s e)/ssetai ou\d) a)te/lestos b 273.
po/non: amplified by 27 f.
i(drw=: i(dro/a, i(drw=ta, § 18 e.
o(/n: acc. of kindred meaning. G. 159; H. 715b. The article would be needed here in prose. o(/n is long by ‘position,’ since i(/drwsa (doubtless, Eng. sweat) began with a consonant. cf. me/n 18.
mo/gw|: equiv. to moge/ousa, cf. ta\ qe/san moge/ontes *)axaioi/ *m 29.

kame/thn de\ ktl.: a ‘paratactic’ independent clause, in close connexion with mo/gw|. cf. nou=son a
a\ strato
 w)=rse kakh
, o)le/konto de\ laoi/ *a 10; see § 3 n, q.

lao/n: soldiery, sc. that of the Achaeans who went to Troy. The prime author of the expedition is picturesquely represented as herself driving through Greece, rousing the people to avenge the indignity wrought by Paris.

kaka/: as a calamity. In appos, with the whole sentence. cf. Hector's words to Paris, gunai=ka a)nh=ges ... patri/ te sw=| me/ga ph=ma (bane) 3.48 ff. The plural may indicate the separate woes which the war occasioned. cf. o(/t' e)s *au)li/da nh=es *)axaiw=n| h)gere/qonto (gathered), kaka\ *pria/mw| kai\ *trwsi\ fe/rousai *b 303 f.
toi=o/ te paisi/n: and to his sons. toi=o here, like Attic au)tou= refers to the preceding noun; cf. 6.283. Obs. the repetition of the name, instead of the pronoun, in 31, 35, 47.

e)/rde: the position is prominent. Concessive, but in an angry tone: “You may do it.” But a warning is added at once, in which, for emphasis with reference to 17, the neg. is placed first: “but by no means.”
qeoi\ a)/lloi: in appos. with pa/ntes, which has the emphatic position before the verse-pause (cf. 17).
th/n: const. with prose/fh.
me/ga: adverbial, with the participle. See § 38 b.
o)xqh/sas: inceptive aor., bursting into a rage, in a fit of vexation.
nefelhgere/ta: cf. 5.522. Zeus is the god of all atmospheric and heavenly phænomena. See on 2.146; cf. 75.—For the ending -ta, see § 16 b.
daimoni/h: the connection alone determines the tone and meaning of this adjective. cf. 2.190, 200. Here, strange goddess.
ti/: in what, how?
se/: direct obj. of r(e/zousin, of which kaka/ is cognate accusative. See G. 165; H. 725.
*pri/amos ktl.: here and 35 with reference to Hera's words, 28.
o(/ te ktl.: equiv. to o(/ti te ktl., that thou dost. Cf. 1.244.
su/ ge: thou, i.e. with thy fierce anger.
ei)selqou=sa: entering the conquered city.

w)mo\n ktl.: “eat alive.” A vivid representation of fierce rage and passionate longing for revenge. cf. w)mofa/gos as an epithet of wild beasts. cf. 22.347, where Achilles wishes that his soul would urge him w)/m' a)potamno/menon kre/a e)/dmenai of Hector; 24.212 f., where old Hecaba would fain eat the liver of Achilles; tou/tous, h)/n pws dunw/meqa, kai\ w)mou\s dei= katafagei=n Xen. An. iv. 8. 14; ou)de/na du/nasqai kru/ptein to\ mh\ ou)x h(de/ws a)\n kai\ w)mw=n e)sqi/ein au)tw=n Xen. Hell. iii. 3. 6; ‘If the men of my tabernacle said not, “Oh that we had of his flesh! we cannot be satisfied,”’ Job xxxi. 31; non media de gente Phrygum exedisse nefandis urbem odiis satis est Verg. Aen. v. 785 f.
w)mo/n: predicate.
xo/lon ktl.: cf. Od. 3.145.
Obs. the ‘asyndeton.’ See § 2 l, m.
e)/rcon ... e)qe/leis: cf. n 145, p 67, w 481, *x 185.

mh\ ktl.: not a final sentence, but an independent ‘prohibitory’ clause, added to the principal sentence, for which it gives the reason. “Do as you please, since I will not allow this matter to be the cause of a quarrel on Olympus.”

tou=to/ ge nei=kos: this strife, at least. In a contemptuous tone. Contention over human affairs was unworthy of the gods; cf. ei) dh/ sfw (i.e. Zeus and Hera) e(/neka qnhtw=n e)ridai/neton w(=de *a 574. Hence the contrast with me/g' e)/risma 38. But see on 17.
met' a)mfote/roisi: an emphatic repetition of soi\ kai\ e)moi/, which is itself a poetic h(mi=n.
39 = *a 297, *e 259, *i 611, *p 444, 851, *f 94, etc. A formula to call attention to the following words.
e)ni/: e)n, § 37 d a.
memaw/s: eagerly. Const. with e)qe/lw. cf. 5.143.
th/n: added impressively, in appos. with po/lin. “That one, I mean, in which (o(/qi),” etc. Thus the article introduces the rel. clause; cf. 5.320, 332.
toi/: const. with e)ggega/asin, as ethical dative.
mh\ diatri/bein: do not attempt to check.
to\n e)mo\n xo/lon: that wrath of mine. Cf. 40.
e)a=sai: sc. to fulfil my desires.
dw=ka: I granted, sc. to satisfy thy anger. The aor. is used as freq. of an act which has just preceded. The perf. might be used in English.

e(kw\n ktl.: a much-quoted ‘oxymoron.’ “Freely, yet with unwilling heart.” e(kw/n is the opposite of bi/h|. Zeus pretends that only for the sake of Hera he consents to the sack of Troy, which had been long ago decreed.
ai(\ ga/r: the rel. clause precedes the demonstrative (ta/wn ktl. 46) with some emphasis. cf. 6.421.
ga/r: introduces the explanation of a)e/konti/ ge qumw=|.
u(p' h)eli/w|: cf. 5.267.
a)stero/enti: for the epithet, see § 1 p.
naieta/ousi: (dwell) are. This verb retains in the Mss. and current texts its uncontracted and unassimilated form. See § 29 b; cf. 6.370, 497.
po/lhe: po/leis, § 18 q.
ta/wn: of these; partitive gen. with the superlative idea in peri\ tie/sketo. Or, what is after all not very different, peri\ tie/sketo may be understood as having comparative force.
peri\ kh=ri: exceedingly in heart, with my whole heart.
tie/sketo: was honored; nearly equiv. to the perf., has been honored. The ‘iterative’ idea is here lost. See § 36 a.
i(rh/: obs. the Homeric gender of *)/ilios. § 2 x.
e)ummeli/w: for the inflexion, see § 17 c; unless it is from e)umme/lios. For the ‘possessive’ compound, see G. 132, 3; H. 586.
daito\s e)i/shs: the language of human life is applied to the life of the gods. That feast was ‘equal’ in which each had a fair share. See on 1.468.

loibh=s ktl.: in explanatory appos. with daito/s. The sacrifice is a feast to which the gods are invited. This invitation lays the divinities under obligations to confer favors in return; cf. Od. 1.60 ff.
to/: refers to loibh=s ktl., but is attracted to the number of the pred., ge/ras. See H. 631; cf. G. 135, N. 4.
h(mei=s: emphatic, we gods.
bow=pis: an epithet almost peculiar to Hera. See on 1.551.
These verses are simply introductory to the principal thought, in 53.
h)= toi me/n: the corresponding clause begins with a)lla/ 57. “I will yield in other cases, but you must allow me to carry out my purpose with regard to the destruction of Troy.”
polu/: adverbial, far.
*)/argos: see on *)argei/h 8.
eu)rua/guia: freq. in Homer three nouns are so placed in a verse that while but one has an adj., this adj. with its noun fills the second ‘hemistich.’ See on 2.498.
*mukh/nh: for the singular, see § 19 j.

ta\s diape/rsai: concessive. “These you may sack.” For the inf. as imv., cf. diatri/bein 42. In this verse has been found a reference to the conquest of these cities in the Dorian invasion of Peloponnesus.
ta/wn ktl.: ‘asyndetic’ repetition of the preceding verse. See § 2 m.
ta/wn: the gen. depends on pro/sqe. Before these, i.e. for their protection.
i(/stamai: the pres. is used as if the time were already at hand.
megai/rw: synonymous here with fqone/w. sc. ta\s diape/rsai.
fqone/w: subjv. with ei) (§ 3 c a), in future sense.
ou)k: not mh/, since with ei)w= [e)a/w] it forms but one idea, forbid, seek to prevent. Cf. ei) ... ou)k e)qe/lwsin *g 289.
a)nu/w: present, in fut. sense, shall accomplish. Nearly equiv. to a)nu/saimi.
e)pei\ h)=: since truly, because.
fe/rteros: cf. 1.281, 545 ff.
a)lla\ xrh\ ktl.: after stating her concessions, 53 ff., Hera defines her claim and rights.
e)mo/n: made emphatic by the following pause.— qe/menai [qei=nai] ktl.: cf. 26.
ge/nos: descent, race. Cf. et mi genus ab Iove summo Verg. Aen. vi. 123.
moi/: not e)moi/, since the stress rests on ge/nos.
presbuta/thn: i.e. timiwta/thn, most honored. Hera is called pre/sba qea/ *e 721. Predicate “My rank is the most exalted of all the daughters of Cronus.” See on 6.185.
a)mfo/teron: used adverbially to introduce the rest of the verse. cf. 145, 3.179.
geneh=|: causal, “because of my descent,” parallel to the clause ou(/neka ktl.— cf. ast ego, quae divom incedo regina, Iovisque| et soror et coniunx Verg. Aen. i. 46 f.
ke/klhmai: am called, i.e. am. This use of ‘verbs of calling’ is freq. in classi cal writers as well as in the Bible. cf. a(/gion tou= *kuri/ou klhqh/setai St. Luke ii. 23, 3.138.

su\ de\ ktl.: still dependent on ou(/neka. This takes the place of a rel. clause explaining the sh/ of 60. “The wife of thee who dost rule.” su/ thus repeats the thought of sh/, and naturally has the first place in the clause. See on 6.127; cf. 9.437 ff.
me/n: correl. with de/ 64.
u(poei/comen: prob. aor. subjv. (‘hortatory’), although it may be fut. repeating the promise of Hera, 53 f., and that of Zeus, 37 f.
Parenthetical and subordinate.
soi\ ... e)moi/: explains a)llh/loisin. Obs. the ‘chiasmus.’ § 2 o.
e)pi\ e(/yontai: will assent. No opposition could avail against Zeus and Hera united.
qa=sson: ocius, right soon, “the sooner the better.”
*)aqhnai/h|: Athena not infreq. acts as Hera's subordinate. cf. *a 195, *b 156 ff., *e 713, *q 351.
e)pitei=lai: for the inf. as imv., cf. diape/rsai 53.
peira=n: parallel to e)lqei=n.
u(perku/dantas: exulting, sc. in consequence of the success of Menelaus in the single combat with Paris.
a)/rcwsi pro/teroi: shall be the first to begin. Cf. pa/mprwtos u(fai/nein (weave, frame) h)/rxeto mh=tin| *ne/stwr *h 324.
pro/teroi ktl.: cf. o(ppo/teroi pro/teroi u(pe\r o(/rkia (contrary to the compacts) phmh/neian (commit a hostile act) 3.299.
ou)d' a)pi/qhse: for the ‘litotes,’ see § 2 r.
path\r ktl.: cf. 1.544, divom pater atque hominum rex Verg. Aen. i. 65, pater deum hominumque Livy i. 12, divumque hominumque parentem Ovid Met. xiv. 807.
au)ti/ka: for the ‘asyndeton,’ cf. 5.
e)/pea: cognate accusative.
meta\ ktl.: into the midst, etc. This explains e)s strato/n. cf. 103, 1.222.
73 = *t 349, *x 186, w 487.—w(\s ei)pw/n: saying this, by these words.
pa/ros memaui=an: Athena was eager to go, even before she received instructions to do so, since she was of one mind with Hera. cf. 20 ff.
bh=: e)/bh, § 25 b.
a)i/casa: starting up. —This was Athena's third descent during the action of the Iliad.

oi=on: masc., pred. with a)ste/ra. —“Like the star which Zeus sends.” The rapidity of Athena's course, and perhaps, the brilliancy of her appearance, are likened to a meteor. cf. u)/rousen *)apo/llwn,| a)ste/ri ei)do/menos me/sw| h)/mati: tou= d' a)po\ pollai\| spinqari/des (sparks) pwtw=nto, se/las d' ei)s ou)rano\n i(=ken Hom. Hy. Ap. 440 ff.
h(=ke: gnomic aor., freq. in comparisons. § 2 k.
*kro/nou pa/is: see on nefelhgere/ta 30.
pa/is: for the disyllabic form, see § 6 a. Only six times in Homer must the nom. of this word be a monosyllable.
te/ras: pred., as a portent.
eu)re/i: broad, far-stretching.
law=n: soldiers, as usually in Homer.
lampro/n: the thought is amplified by the rest of the verse. See § 1 h.
tou=: ablatival gen. with a)po\ i(/entai.

i(/entai: for the pres., cf. 278, 423, 5.903.—Homeric usage does not compel the belief that the poet thought of Athena as actually emitting sparks. This verse is intended simply to enliven the mention of the meteor. See § 2 e.
tw=| e)ikui=a: like to this (sc. a)ste/ri). This resumes the thought of 75, after the two ornamental verses.
e)ikui=a: tetrasyllabic. See § 31 g.
h)/icen: used of the beginning of the motion, while e)/qore, 79, marks its close.
cf. 3.342 f.—me/sson [me/son]: substantival.

qa/mbos ktl.: cf. *y 815, *w 482, g 372. This refers to the astonishment of the army at the sudden appearance of Athena; but she is not recognized as a goddess, since immediately on reaching the earth she assumes the human form.
Obs. the ‘chiasmus.’

e)uknh/midas: the greave, about the lower leg, seems to have been one of the most characteristic parts of the Achæan armor. Perhaps, however, the Trojans too wore greaves, but the epithet did not fit into the verse in connexion with them.
ti\s: represents public opinion.
ei)/pesken: for the form, see § 36 b.
i)dw/n: casting a glance.
cf. 15 f.—All onlookers knew that this appearance was a portent, but they could not interpret it.
h)= r(a: surely, as we see. Inference from the phenomenon. The first horn of the dilemma is considered the more probable.
kako/s: destructive, evil.
ti/qhsin: cf. qei=nai 26.
a)nqrw/pwn: limits tami/hs pole/moio arbiter of war. a)nqrw/pois might have been used.
85-147. Athena persuades the Trojan archer Pandarus to shoot an arrow at Menelaus, but she herself keeps the son of Atreus from serious hurt.
a)/ra: “as I said,” referring to 81.
a)ndri/: the final vowel is long before an initial *v. See §§ 14 a, 18 a; cf. po/sei+ w(=| *e 71.
*trw/wn: the rhvthm of the verse connects this with o(/milon.
*laodo/kw|: named only here. Ten of his brothers are mentioned in the Iliad. See on 2.822.—The phrase reminds one of (*laodi/kh|) *)anthnori/dao da/uaoti *g 122.
*pa/ndaron: cf. Pandare, qui quondam iussus confundere foedus
div.l: in medios telum torsisti primus Achivos Verg. Aen. v. 496 f. cf. 2.824 ff.
div.p: a)nti/qeon: without any indication of moral quality. cf. a)mu/mona 89.
dizhme/nh: the goddess seeks, like any mortal.
ei)/ pou e)feu/roi: if haply she might find. This explains dizhme/nh. A wish from the heart of Athena. cf. *n 760, e 439.
eu(=re: for the ‘asyndeton,’ cf. 327, *b 169, *e 355. The emphasis upon this word makes less noticeable the absence of the conjunction. The way is prepared for eu(=re by e)feu/roi 88.
a)mu/mona ktl.: cf. *s 55, *f 546.
a)mu/mona: blameless, i.e. of noble birth, or of great physical strength or beauty. See on a)nti/qeon 88.
a)mfi/: sc. e(/stasan, from e(stew=ta [e(stw=ta].
a)spista/wn: i.e. heavy-armed. Equiv. to Attic o(plitw=n. See on korusth/n 457.
law=n: in appos. with a)spista/wn.
*ai)sh/poio: cf. 2.825.
proshu/da: cf. 24.
A mere introduction to the request. The following verse repeats the thought definitely.
ti\: cognate acc., at all.
pi/qoio: potential opt., without a)/n. See G. 224 N. 1; H. 872 e.

tlai/hs ktl.: forms, with ‘chiasmus,’ the conclusion to the wish of 93, which is expressed in interrogative form. “If you would follow my advice, you would then,” etc. Cf. ou)k a)\n dh\ mei/neias a)rhi/filon *mene/laon ;| gnoi/hs oi(/ou fwto\s e)/xeis qalerh\n para/koitin *g 52 f.
*menela/w|: const. with the following e)pi/, at Menelaus. See § 3 h b.
proe/men: proei=nai, § 34 e.

*trw/essi: “in the eyes of the Trojans.” cf. *b 285, h)= ga/r ke/ sfi ma/la me/ga ku=dos a)/roio *i 303, tw=| me e)/a kle/os e)sqlo\n e)ni\ *trw/essin a)re/sqai *r 16, nu=n dh\ nw=i e)/olpa ...| oi)/sesqai me/ga ku=dos *)axaioi=si proti\ nh=as *x 216 f. H. 771. Or, the dative may here be the ‘agent,’ with the passive idea which is implied in the verse.
de/: may have the third place in the clause, when the first two words are closely united.
ma/lista: the following ‘hiatus’ is justified by the pause. See § 9 b.
basilh=i: prince. So Nausicaa is called basi/leia, z 115.
ton=: const. with para\ fe/roio.
dh/: surely.
pa/mprwta: first of all, chiefly.
ai)/ ken ktl.: equiv. to e)a\n *mene/laos tw=| be/lei sou dmhqh=|. A picturesque paraphrase for death.
*mene/laon: receives prominence from the following verse-pause. He is the special enemy of Paris, whom he has just overcome, 3.340-382. Obs. the repetition of the name in 100.
a)rh/ion: const. with ui(o/n.
sw=| ... dmhqe/nta: parenthetical. In thought, antecedent and subordinate to e)piba/nta.
purh=s ktl.: cf. pollou\s de\ purh=s e)pe/bhs' a)legeinh=s *i 546.
e)piba/nta: supplementary partic. after i)/dh|. Pred. with *mene/laon as subject.
a)legeinh=s: a)lgeinh=s.
*menela/ou: partitive gen. with o)i/steuson. G. 171, 1; H. 739.
*)apo/llwni: Apollo was the patron-god of Lycia, and god of the bow.

lukhgene/i: the root luk is the same as that of lux. The sun-god Apollo is ‘child of the light.’ cf. ai)qrhgenh/s as epithet of Boreas, 15.171; and luka/bas year, Od. 14.161. In this epithet is prob. also a reference to Apollo as the Lycian (*au(kios) god.
a)rnw=n e(kato/mbhn: Homer does not hold strictly to the original meaning of ‘hecatomb.’ cf. 1.65 f., 6.93, 115.

prwtogo/nwn: first-born. Cf. ‘All the firstling males that come of thy herd and of thy flock thou shalt sanctify unto the Lord thy God: thou shalt do no work with the firstling of thy bullock, nor shear the firstling of thy sheep. Thou shalt eat it before the Lord thy God year by year in the place which the Lord shall choose, thou and thy household. And if there be any blemish therein, as if it be lame or blind, or have any ill blemish, thou shalt not sacrifice it unto the Lord thy God.’ Deuteronomy xv. 19-21.
i(erh=s ktl.: explains oi)/kade. cf. 70, 180.
a)/stu^: for the final vowel, retaining its short quantity before *zelei/hs, see § 41 i e.
*zelei/hs: this use of the gen. with a)/stu is familiar enough in English, e.g. ‘city of Boston.’ See G. 167 N.; H. 729 g; cf. 406.
tw=| ktl.: cf. soi\ de\ fre/nas a)/froni pei=qen *p 842. For the dat., see § 3 g a.
a)/froni: since he suffered himself to be deceived by the promise, 95 ff.
au)ti/ka: cf. 5.
e)su/la: sc. from its case, though some understand it ‘from his shoulder.’
i)ca/lou: quickspringing, agile.
ai)go/s: the capra ibex, or ‘steinbock.’ cf. Od. 14.50.—Gen. of material with to/con. The full expression would have required kera/wn. cf. i(ma/ntas boo/s *y 684.
a)gri/ou: introduces the following story, since the ‘steinbock’ cannot be taken by pursuit, but only by ambush. See § 1 h.
o(/n: obj. of beblh/kei. This const. is the easier since the second hemistich of this verse and 107 are parenthetical.
u(po\ ste/rnoio: below, on the belly. The goat stood on a higher position than the hunter. For the gen., cf. u(p' a)nqerew=nos e(lou=sa *a 501 (of Thetis supplicating Zeus).
tuxh/sas: hitting. Cf. *(ippo/maxon ba/le doupi\ kata\ zwsth=ra tuxh)sas *m 189. § 3 v.
dedegme/nos: lying in wait. Cf. to/coisi dedegme/nos a)/ndras e)nai/rw (slay) *q 296, *o 745. prodokh=|sin contains the same root.
beblh/kei ktl.: cf. e)/blhto pro\s sth=qos *p 753, *o 250. This is a more definite statement of u(po\ ste/rnoio above.
u(/ptios: upon his back. Predicate; see § 38 a. Ammals thus wounded generally fall in this way.
tou=: const. with e)k kefalh=s. cf. tou= d' a)po\ me\n kefalh=s ko/ruq) ei(/leto *o 125.
e(kkaidekadwra: the horns were marked with rings which made the hand-breadths or palms more distinct.
pefu/kein: had grown, were.

a)skh/sas: skilfully working. Cf. o( d' e)/peita boo\s ke/rasin peri/xeuen (sc. xruso/n)| a)skh/sas g 437 f. Const. with h)/rare, skilfully joined,—uniting the butt-ends of the horns by a metal piece (ph=xus *l 375).
keraoco/os te/ktwn: mentioned only here in Homer. te/ktwn was not yet restricted to the sense of ‘carpenter’; cf. te/xnh.
h)/rare: sc. a)llh/loiin.
pa=n: refers to to/con, the product of the work which has been described: cf. to\ me/n 112.
leih/nas: i.e. he smoothed off the rings of the horns. cf. lei=os, lēvis.
xruse/hn: disyllabic. cf. xruse/ois 3.
korw/nhn: the hook at one end of the bow, to receive the loop of the string which was fastened to the other end of the bow.
kai\ ... kate/qhke: cf. *w 271, i 329, *z 473.
kai/: returns to the story of 105.
to/: sc. to/con. See on pa=n 111.
kate/qhke: Pandarus laid the bow down, since he wanted to take an arrow from his quiver.

tanussa/menos: when he had strung it.—poti\ gai/h| a)gkli/nas [a)nakli/nas]: subord. to tanussa/menos. To string the bow required much exertion, and one end of the bow (naturally) was rested on the ground.
pro/sqen: in front, before him, sc. in order that the Greeks might not see that Pandarus was stringing his bow and preparing to shoot.
sxe/qon: held. Cf. 1.219.
de/: “while.” See § 3 q.
pri/n: adverbial, anticipating the conj. pri/n 115. See G. 240, 1; H. 955 a; cf. *e 218, 288, *a 97, *b 354 f.
a)nai+/ceian: sc. as the Greeks would have done, if they had seen what this Lycian archer was about. The forces were seated, cf. 3.326.
blh=sqai: for the aor. mid. as passive, see § 32 d; cf. blh/menos 211. blhqh=nai is not used in Homer.
cf. dixit et aurata volucrem sagittam| deprompsit pharetra cornuque tetendit Verg. Aen. xi. 858 f.
fare/trhs: from the quiver. Ablatival gen. with su/la.
ptero/enta: prob. so called because of the feathers with which it was winged. cf. 5.171, (*lu/kioi) ei=xon o)istou\s kalami/nous (of reed) a)pte/rous Hdt. vii. 92.
melaine/wn: darkness was always hateful to the Greeks, and associated with death. cf. qana/tou me/lan ne/fos *p 350. See on 461.

The Epic poet gives many details, it is true, but he does not need to say that Pandarus took the bow from the ground. Similarly 2.55, the poet neglects to mention that Agamemnon rose to address the council; but the king must have risen, for he seats himself at 2.76.
kateko/smee: i.e. brought into the right posi tion, fitted the arrow to the string.
pikro/n: biting, bitter.
e(/lke: is followed by a pause, and the two accs. are to be construed with labw/n.
neu=ra: equiv. to neurh/n 123. § 19 i.

Mark the ‘chiasmus.’—This verse explains the preceding e(/lke, and gives the result of that action. cf. 5.417.—Statius translates, cornua contingit mucrone et pectora nervo Thebaïd ix. 866.—When the bow-string is drawn back to the breast, the iron arrow-point (si/dhron) is brought near to the bow. cf. Vergil's far inferior imitation, et duxit longe, donec curvata coirent| inter se capita et manibus iam tangeret aequis,| laeva aciem ferri, dextra nervoque papillam| extemplo teli stridorem audiit Aen. xi. 860 ff.
si/dhron: only here in Homer of an arrow-point.
kuklotere/s: circular, round. Proleptic. The bowman bent the bow until it formed a sort of circle,— e)/teinen w(/ste kuklotere\s ei)=nai.

li/gce: ‘onomatopoetic,’ representing the sound to the ear. cf. 420, e)/klagcan d' a)/r) o)istoi/ *a 46, effugit horrendum stridens adducta sagitta Verg. Aen. ix. 632.—For the ‘personification,’ cf. E 99, w)/|xeto kh=la qeoi=o *a 53; Aristotle Rhet. iii. 11. Observe the triple division of the verse, and the double ‘chiasmus.’ bio/s and neurh/, i)/axen and a)=lto receive prominence from the order of words.
o)cubelh/s: cf. o)cu\ pa/gh be/los 185.
meneai/nwn: cf. (dou=ra) lilaio/mena xroo\s a)=sai (glut themselves) 11.574.

‘Apostrophe’ to Menelaus. The poet seems to be led partly by the convenience of the verse, for Menelaus and Patroclus in the Iliad and ‘the divine swine-herd’ Eumaeus in the Odyssey are most frequently thus addressed by him, while the more distinguished characters are never so apostrophized. cf. 146, *h 104, *n 603, *y 600. But no one should fail to notice the tender interest which seems to be implied in such an ‘apostrophe’ here. cf. Milton's address to Eve: ‘O much deceived, much failing, hapless Eve,| Of thy presumed return! event perverse!| Thou never from that hour in Paradise| Found'st either sweet repast or sound repose,’ Par. Lost ix. 404 ff.—se/qen [sou=]: const. with lela/qonto.
lela/qonto: 2d aorist. § 25 j.
a)qa/natoi: in appos. with qeoi/, and added here for the sake of contrast with prw/th ktl.
prw/gh: first of all, chiefly. Cf. pa/mprwta 97. Athena comes to the aid of Menelaus because she favors the Greeks, and had not intended that the leader should be seriously harmed.
a)gelei/h: the giver of booty (lhi/s). A standing epithet of Athena as goddess of war. cf. *e 765, *z 269, *)aqhnai/h| lhi/tidi *k 460.
toi/: const. with a)/munen, as dat. of interest.
pro/sqe: see on 54.
sta=sa: taking her stand.
be/los ktl.: cf. 1.51. For the quantity of the ultima of be/los, see § 41 m.
e)xepeuke/s: cf. pikro/n 118.

to/son me/n: so far, indeed. This is made definite by the contrast which follows in 132; cf. *s 378, *x 322, *y 454. Athena warded off the arrow only in so far as she guided it to a spot where the armor was thickest (double) and thus afforded the best protection.
xroo/s: body, Attic sw/matos. § 2 v.

w(s o(/te: does not correspond to to/son, but introduces an independent comparison, which illustrates the loving watchfulness of the goddess. The phrase has lost its original force (as the mother when), and is used almost exactly like w(s. § 2 j. Cf. w(s d' o(/te ti/s te dra/konta i)dw\n pali/norsos a)pe/sth *g 33, ‘As when a prowling wolf| ... Leaps o'er the fence with ease into the fold,| ... So clomb this first grand Thief into God's fold,’ Milton, Par. Lost, iv. 183 ff.; ‘As when to them who sail| Beyond the Cape of Hope,’ etc., ib. iv. 159 ff.; ‘As when a vulture on Imaus bred
div.l: ... So on this windy sea of land, the Fiend
Walked up and down,’ ib. iii. 429 ff.

div.p: paido/s: from her child. Ablatival genitive.
e)e/rgh|: for the subjv., cf. 141, *e 598, *z 507, *b 147; see G. 233 N. 2; H. 914 *b b.—o(/te le/cetai [o(/tan le/chtai]: sc. pai=s. cf. le/xos couch.
u(/pnw|: to sleep; as a ‘dat. of approach.’ cf. ko/lpw| *z 136.
au)th/: h( (Athena) is still the subject, but this subj. is made prominent in contrast with the more negative act of 130.
o(/qi: thither where.

zwsth=ros: a leather belt, faced with metal, which bound the cuirass. The clasps (o)xh=es) or buckles seem to have been at the side, where both front and back plates of the cuirass met. zw/nh is a woman's girdle.
133 = Od. 3.415.—su/nexon [sunei=xon]: joined, met. Intrans., cf. g 478. e)/xw and its compounds are often intrans. in Attic, but rarely in Homer.
diplo/os ktl.: i.e. the arrow was met by the double cuirass, since it hit where the front and back pieces met and overlapped.
e)n: const. with e)/pese, equiv. to e)ne/pese. cf. 217; *q 485, *l 297, *p 276, *f 9.
a)rhro/ti: well-joined, closely fitting.
di_a/ for the length of the penult, see § 41 q.
e)lh/lato (e)lau/nw): for the tense, cf. h)rh/reisto 136.
h)rh/reisto (e)rei/dw): was forced, by the violence of the shot. Almost like an aorist.

mi/trhs: a broad band of metal, doubtless lined with soft cloth, worn about the body, protecting the lower abdomen below the rather short breastplate. The arrow hit where cuirass and mitra lapped. cf. 187, 216, 5.857, 707.
e)fo/rein: [e)fo/rei] for the final n, cf. h(/|rein 23.
e)/ruma: pred. as a protection.
e(/rkos ktl.: cf. 299, 5.316. For the ablatival gen., see § 3 d.
h(\ ... e)/ruto: parenthetical.
oi(=: dat. of interest; not elsewhere found with this verb.
plei=ston: adv., most, chiefly. Cf. 19.287.
e)/ruto: warded off, sc. o)isto/n. cf. 5.538.
ei)/sato: aor. of ei(=mi, § 34 f. This repeats h)rh/reisto, after the rel. clause.
kai\ th=s: this too, sc. mi/trhs.
a)kro/taton: const. with xro/a, the outer flesh. Cf. a)/krhn r(ino/n (skin) Od. 22.278.
e)pe/graye: cf. e)pigra/yai te/rena (tender) xro/a nhle/i xalkw=| *n 553.

fwto/s: of the man, i.e. Menelaus. Equiv. to Attic au)tou=. This noun is not necessary, but is in the Epic manner of fulness. cf. tw=| (sc. e)/gxei) da/mnhsi (overcomes, sc. Athena) sti/xas a)ndrw=n| h(rw/wn, toi=si/n te kote/ssetai *q 390 f.
e)/rreen: e)/rrei, from r(e/w.
w)teilh=s: only here and 149 for e(/lkos, of a wound inflicted by a missile. cf. 190, 217. It is used strictly of a wound from a weapon held in the hand. cf. ou)ta/zw.
e)le/fanta: ivory. The elephant is not mentioned in Homer.
foi/niki: evidently some variety of red; but it is impossible to determine the exact shade and tint, whether crimson or purplish.
mih/nh|: stain, paint. The ivory was striped with red. cf. Indum sanguineo veluti violaverit ostro| siquis ebur Verg. Aen. xii. 67 f.
142-145. These verses simply give life to the picture. See § 2 e.
*mh|oni/s: in apposition with gunh/.
*ka/eira: fem. of *ka/r.

parh/ion: cheek-piece, cf. pareia/ cheek. These thin plates of colored ivory were used as ornaments for the bridle, much as rosettes and the like are used now. Attic fa/lara. cf. fa/lara e)/xontos peri\ tw=| i(/ppw| *i)dai/ou tou= grafe/ws pa/gkala Xen. Hell. iv. I. 39. For a similar use of ivory, cf. 5.583.
i(/ppwn: equiv. to i(/ppeion.
qala/mw|: store-room. Cf. 6.288.
pole/es: polloi/, § 20 f.
h)rh/santo: ‘gnomic’ aorist. § 2 k. Cf. 75.
fore/ein: sc. for their horses. cf. *zeu\s *(/ektori dw=ken (sc. ph/lhka, helmet)| h(=| kefalh=| fore/ein *p 799 f.
basilh=i: in contrast with pole/es.
a)/galma: w(=| tis a)ga/lletai.
a)mfo/teron: cf. 60.—‘Chiasmus’ again.
e)latg=ri: in Homer, as it happens, only of the driver in a chariot race; cf. *l 702, *y 369. cf. e)lau/nw and i(pphla/ta 387.

toi=oi: pred., as such, thus. See § 38 a; cf. 280.—mia/nqhn [e)mia/nqhsan]: an isolated form in Homer. Possibly mi/anqen should be read (§ 26 v), with the ultima treated as long before the verse-pause; possibly the form follows the analogy of the dual (cf. h(/sqhn 21). But diele/ghn is found in dialectic inscriptions for die/legon (3d pl.).
te i)de/: a freq. hiatus, justified by the verse-pause. cf. 382, 6.469.
u(pe/nerqen: picturesque Epic detail, contrasting sfura/ with knh=mai. cf. *e 122, *b 218.
148-219. Agamemnon's distress at the hurt of Menelaus. The surgeon Machaon is summoned.
r(i/ghsen: inceptive aor., cf. gh/qhsen 283, *g 259.
neu=ron: i.e. the thong which bound the arrow-point to the shaft.
o)/gkous: the three barbs, cf. 5.393.
e)kto/s: sc. w)teilh=s.
e)o/ntas: connected in thought with both nouns, though it agrees only with the nearer.
a)/yorron: cf. a)/yorroi proti\ *)/ilion a)pone/onto *g 313; but this is adv., again. The ultima is long before oi(=. § 41 m.
qumo/s: courage, in contrast with r(i/ghsen 150.
toi=s: i.e. Menelaus and those about him. Dat. of interest. G. 184. 3 N. 2.
baru/: strictly a cognate acc. with stena/xwn, but used adverbially. See § 38 b.
xeiro/s: gen. of the part touched. G. 171. 1; H. 738.
fi/le: for the long penult, cf. dia/ 135, fi/le *e 359, fi=lai *e 117, e)fi/lato *e 61.
kasi/gnhte: the final syllable is treated as long before the pause. § 41 p.
qanaton: pred. with o(/rkia e)/tamnon. cf. kaka/ 28.
e)/tamnon: The victim's throat was cut. cf. *g 292, *t 197, 266. See on 2.124. cf. foedus icere, ferire foedus.—“The truce which I made was death to thee.”
oi)=on: agrees with se/, obj. of prosth/sas.—“Placing thee before all, to fight,” sc. in the single combat with Paris.
pro/: does not suffer elision. § 10 b.
w(/s: thus, refers to the content of 156, and explains 155.
kata\ pa/thsan: trod under foot, trampled upon, broke. Equiv. to Attic katapath/santes. § 3 t.
pista: a standing epithet of oaths, even when they are broken.
ou) me/n pws: (but) surely in no way, by no means. Const. with a(/lion. ‘Adversative asyndeton,’ § 2 m, me/n being nearly equiv. to the Attic me/ntoi.
a(/lion: predicate, of no effect.
o(/rkion: only here in the singular. This with the ai(=ma, spondai/, and deciai/ formed the o(/rkia of 157.
a)/krhtoi: the wine for solemn libations was not mixed with water, as was usual for drinking.
e)pe/piqmen: for the form, see § 31 c.
*)olu/mpios: in the sing. always refers to Zeus, who was the special guardian of oaths and treaties. cf. *dio\s o(/rkia *g 107.

ou)k e)te/lessen: cf. ou)k ei)w= 55. The neg. is closely connected with the verb. cf. ou)k a)te/leston 57, 168.—“Left unfulfilled,” sc. o(/rkia, without punishing the offenders in accordance with the imprecation of 3.298 ff.
e)k: to the full. Const. with telei=.
de/: in ‘apodosis.’ cf. 262; see § 3 n. “Yet.” cf. a)lla/ *a 82.
kai\ o)ye/: concessive. Even though late.

su\n mega/lw|: with heavy loss, grievously. The notion of ‘accompaniment’ is here passing over into that of ‘manner.’ For the neuter adj. as subst., cf. e)s me/sson 79. cf. su\n kakw=| mega/lw| oi( nikw=ntes a)palla/ssontai Hdt. vii. 9. 2.
a)pe/tisan: gnomic aor., parallel to the pres. telei=. cf. raro ... scelestum
div.l: deseruit pede Poena claudo Hor. Carm. iii. 2. 31 f. —“The breach of faith will surely be punished.”

div.p: In explanatory appos. with su\n mega/lw| 161.
kefalh=|si: heads, lives. The men of a sacked town were slain; their wives and children were reduced to slavery. cf. 237239, 9.593 f.
163-165 = 6.447-449, where they seem better placed. Here the verses show pious confidence in the just retribution of the gods. In *z, they are the expression of Hector's dreadful foreboding.
to/de: refers to the next verse.—The following hiatus is merely apparent.
e)/ssetai: prominent at the opening of the verse, marks the confidence of Agamemnon's prediction.

o)lw/lh|: nearly equiv. to a future. See § 3 b.—Ille dies veniet quo Pergama sacra peribunt.— Scipio is said to have repeated this verse at Carthage, thinking of Rome, in view of the transitoriness of human glory.
sfi/: for the dat. after e)pi/, cf. *menela/w| 94.
u(yi/zugos: high-throned, explained by ai)qe/ri nai/wn. Epithet of Zeus as the most exalted ruler. cf. daimo/nwn se/lma (bench) semno\n h(me/nwn Aesch. Ag. 192 f.
ai)qe/ri: the peaks of Olympus tower above the clouds. See on 1.44, 195.

au)to/s: himself. Zeus will not entrust to others the punishment for such base treachery. cf. the ‘prayer of St. Chrysostom,’ au)to\s kai\ nu=n (thyself now also) tw=n dou/lwn sou ta\ ai)th/mata pro\s to\ sumfe/ron plh/rwson.
e)pissei/h|sin (e)pi-sei/w): for the mode, cf. o)lw/lh| 164. For ss, see §§ 12 b, 41 j a fin. sei/w is to seu/w, as plei/w to ple/w or pleu/w.
e)remnh/n (e)/rebos): gloomy, dark, as causing fear and destruction. cf. fqisi/mbroton ai)gi/da l 297. The aegis was prob. a symbol of the thunder cloud.
th=sde: i.e. the present.
a)pa/ths: gen. of cause. cf. xwo/menon gunaiko/s *a 429, kou/rhs xwo/menos *b 689, th=s a)xe/wn *b 694.—ta\ me\n ktl.: resumes the thought of 161, and prepares the way for the contrast of 169.

ou)k a)te/lesta: i.e. surely accomplished. cf. 57. Agamemnon seems not to be thinking chiefly of the destruction of Troy by the Achaeans, since he contemplates the humiliating withdrawal of their army on the death of Menelaus. He trusts in the justice of Zeus that the Trojans shall be punished in the future.

169-182. Agamemnon's first thought was of the danger to which his brother was exposed by entering into a single combat with one of this perfidious people. He now vividly and affectionately depicts the results of Menelaus's death.—“The Trojans will be punished, but of what advantage is that to me?”
se/qen: ‘objective gen.’ with a)/xos, grief for thee.
ai)/ ke: e)a/n.—po/tmon ktl.: fulfil the destiny, equiv. to po/tmon e)pi/sph|s *z 412.—For the fulness of expression, see § 1 s.
kai/: and, adds a further result of the leader's death.
e)le/gxistos: most disgraced. From e)/legxos shame, as e)/xqistos from e)/xqos. § 22 b.

poludi/yion: cf. *)/argos a)/eide, qea/, poludi/yion, the beginning of the ‘cyclic’ Thebaïd; o(/tan pot' *)/argous diyi/an e)/lqw xqo/na Eur. Alc. 560. The eastern part of the plain of Argos and the whole region of Mycenae are ill supplied with water. Hence arose the myth of the artificial conduits of Danaüs, on Egyptian models, and the story of the occupation of his daughters the Danaïds in Hades.
mnh/sontai ktl.: the expedition had been undertaken in order to regain Helen for Menelaus. On the latter's death, the Greeks would remember the claims of their own families, and would return.
cf. 2.160 f.—ka/d [kata/]: const. with li/poimen.
eu)xwlh/n: pred., as a triumph, a boast. For the const., cf. 75 f., 137, 197.
li/poimen *(ele/nhn: really gives the cause for e)le/gxistos i(koi/mhn 171.
se/o: sou=, § 24 a.
pu/sei (pu/qw, puteo): “will cover.”

e)n *troi/h|: in the Troad. The Greeks who fell before Troy were, naturally, buried at once. Only 7.334 f. (doubtless interpolated) is mention made of the possibility of taking the bones back to Greece.
a)teleuth/tw| ktl.: “with our end unachieved.”
e)piqrw/skwn: sc. in mockery. cf. dum Priami Paridisque busto| insultet armentum Hor. Carm. iii. 3. 40 f.

*menela/ou: the name shows more feeling than the pron. sou= would have done. See on *a)xillh=os poqh\ i(/cetai *a 240 (Achilles's own words). The epithet is added in a sort of contrast with the contempt implied in e)piqrw/skwn.
ai)/qe: introduces a wish. G.251, 1; H. 870 a.
e)pi\ pa=si: in every case, always.
xo/lon: see on 23.—For the irony of the wish, cf. ai) ga\r dh\ tossou=ton o)nh/sios (enjoyment) a)ntia/seien| w(s ou(=to/s pote (sc. Odysseus) tou=to (sc. to/con) dunh/setai e)ntanu/sasqai f 402 f.
kai\ nu=n: now too, with reference to e)pi\ pa=si 178.
a(/lion: pred. with strato/n. cf. 158.
kai\ dh/: and already, explains 179.
oi)ko/nde: see on i(erh=s 103.

su\n keinh=|sin nhusi/: with empty ships, i.e. without Helen and the spoils of war, and with heavy loss. cf. ai)sxro/n toi dhro/n te me/nein keneo/n te (empty-handed) ne/esqai *b 298, oi)/kade nisso/meqa (sc. the comrades of Odysseus) kenea\s su\n xei=ras e)/xontes k 42.
lipw/n: cf. 175.
a)gaqo/n: generally with boh/n (war-cry), as epithet of Menelaus. cf. 220.
w(/s: repeats w(=de 176.

to/te ktl.: cf. *q 150, *z 282, *r 417. Formula of a wish for speedy death. cf. sed mihi vel tellus optem prius ima dehiscat Verg. Aen. iv. 24, eu)/xomai muri/as e)me/ ge kata\ gh=s o)rguia\s gene/sqai Xen. An. vii. *i 30, ou) be/ltio/n e)stin u(po\ th
 *xa/rubdin kai\ to
 *kwkuto
 kai\ muri/as o)rguia\s kata\ gh=s du=nai, h)\ pesei=n ei)s toiou=ton bi/on Julian Orat. vi. 198 c.
eu)rei=a: a standing epithet.
qa/rsei mhde/ ti: with a second imv., as *k 383, *w 171.—pw/ [pw/s]: at all. Cf. 234, 3.306.
deidi/sseo: frighten, sc. by thy anxiety. Not intrans., as 2.190.
‘Causal asyndeton.’
ou)k e)n kairi/w|: not in a vital spot. The Homeric heroes knew well what wounds were likely to cause death.
pa/gh (ph/gnumi): e)pa/gh.
pa/roiqen: local.
zwsth/r: cf. 132.
panai/olos: all-gleaming, from the bright metal plates.

zw=ma (zw/nnumi): the lower part of the cuirass about which the girdle was drawn. Obs. the suffixes of zw=-ma and zws-th/r. G. 129, 2; 129, 4; H. 550; 553, 1. This is called qw/rhc, less definitely, in 133 ff.
mi/trh: see on 137.
th/n: h(/n.
ka/mon [e)/kamon]: wrought. Cf. 5.338, 735.
The rhythm of the verse accords with the anxiety of Agamemnon.
fi/los: as vocative. H. 707.
w)=: between the adj. and its substantive. cf. diotrefe\s w)= *mene/lae *k 43.
e(/lkos: placed first in the verse, since the healing of the wound is the only care, now that the king knows that the arrow hit no vital part.
e)pima/ssetai (mai/omai, mas): shall probe, shall heal.

fa/rmaka: herbs, drugs. Cf. vi/z' u(/dati liarw=| (warm), e)pi\ de\ r(i/zan (root, wort) ba/le pikrh/n,| xersi\ diatri/yas (rubbing it fine), o)dunh/faton (painkilling), h(/ oi( a(pa/sas| e)/sx' o)du/nas *l 846 ff.—pau/sh|si [pau/sh|]: free, sc. se/. For the mode, cf. e)pissei/h|sin 167.
o)duna/wn: ablatival. cf. 5.909.
h)=: he spoke. The subject of this verb is regularly continued as the subj. of the following.
*talqu/bion: Agamemnon's principal herald. cf. *a 320, *g 118, *h 276, *t 196, 250, 267, *y 897.
qei=on: cf. kh/rukes, *dio\s a)/ggeloi h)de\ kai\ a)ndrw=n *a 334.
o(/tti ta/xista: w(s ta/xista, quam celerrime.

*maxa/ona: cf. 2.731 f., 11.505 ff., 833 ff. Machaon and his brother Podalirius were the only professional surgeons in the Achaean camp, but both were leaders in battle as well as surgeons. The best surgery of those days was rude, and every man knew the elements of the art.
fw=ta: in appos. with *maxa/ona, and further explained by the rest of the verse. cf. 5.649.
*)asklhpiou=: Asclepius clearly is not a god in Homer's time, but only a skilful pupil of Chiron.
i)/dh|: examine.
*mene/laon ktl.: cf. 98, 115, 205.
o)isteu/sas: nearly equiv. to o)istw=|.
to/cwn: for the gen. with ei)dw/s skilled in, cf. 310, *e 11, 549, *z 438, ku/ne ei)do/te qh/rhs *k 360.
*luki/wn: i.e. the army of Sarpedon, as the most important of the Trojan allies. cf. 6.78. See on 2.876.
tw=| ... pe/nqos: in appos. with the whole sent.; cf. 28, 155.—‘Chiasmus.’
tw=|: him, sc. balo/nti.
a)/mmi: h(mi=n, § 24 a.
oi(=: const. with a)pi/qhsen.
bh= [e)/bh]: set out.
kata\ lao/n: marks no definite direction. cf. 126, 209, kata\ nh=as *b 47.
*tri/khs: cf. 2.729, where this name is spelt *tri/kkh. A city in Western Thessaly, with one of the oldest sanctuaries of Asclepius.
i(ppobo/toio: Thessalian horses and cavalry were always noted for their excellence.
cf. 3.250.—This verse has a vigorous movement. The pause after the first syllable gives an ‘anapaestic’ (march) rhythm to the rest of the verse.
o)/rso: 2d aor., while o)/rseu 264 is the 1st aorist. § 35.
i)/dh|: here is middle, but i)/dh|s is read by some.
tw=|: for the dat., see § 3 g.
o)/rinen: aroused, moved, touched, used of pity, anger, and terror.
ba/n [e)/bhsan]: sc. Machaon and the herald.

kata/, a)na/: clearly do not indicate opposite directions. a)na\ strato/n differs only metrically from kata\ strato/n in such expressions, and the second ‘hemistich’ here is in appos. with kaq' o(/milon.
*mene/laos ktl.: “was the wounded Menelaus.”
blh/menos: “who was wounded,” nearly equiv. to beblhme/nos. For the passive meaning, see on blh=sqai 115.
au)to/n: himself, the principal personage at this time.
a)ghge/rato: from a)gei/rw. § 25 k. Cf. stant lecti circum iuvenes Verg. Aen. x. 837.
o(/ssoi ktl.: optimi quique.
kuklo/se: in(to) a circle, in a ring.
o( de/: i.e. Machaon. Here begins the ‘apodosis.’ cf. 161, 221.
pari/stato: stepped to his side. Nearly like pare/sth. cf. 233, *b 244, *e 570.
i)so/qeos fw/s: always, as here, at the close of the verse, and in appos. with the subj. of the verb.
a)rhro/tos: cf. 134.

pa/lin: const. with e)celkome/noio although a pause intervenes. This is added as a more definite statement of e)c.—a)/gen [e)a/ghsan, from a)/gnumi]: the barbs broke as they were pulled back against the metal belt. This reminds the hearer how serious the wound would have been if the arrow had not been guided by Athena to a well protected spot.
i)/den: cf. i)/dh| 205.
e)/mpese: cf. 134.
e)kmuzh/sas: Machaon sucked out the blood, which was generally wiped or washed off, as *e 416, 798, *l 830, 845 f., or checked by a charm (e)paoidh/), as Od. 19.457.
e)pi/: adv. with pa/sse. cf. *e 401, 900, *l 515, 830.
a(/ra: marks the progress to the next step in the action. cf. the prose use of e)/peita or ou(/tws after a participle.
ei)dw/s: as a skilled man, skilfully. Cf. a)skh/sas 110.
oi(=: ‘dat. of interest’ (cf. tw=| 208) with patri/, which is an indirect object. cf. 5.116.—Equiv. to a(\ tw=| patri\ e)/dwke *xei/rwn.
fi/la frone/wn: (thinking loving thoughts), with friendly heart. Cf. e)u\ frone/wn *a 73, a)gaqa\ frove/wn a 43.

*xei/rwn: the wise centaur (dikaio/tatos *kentau/rwn *l 832) of Mt. Pelion, the teacher of Asclepius and Achilles, and the kind friend of Peleus. Later stories made him the trainer of the Argonaut Jason and many other heroes. Homer nowhere indicates that Chiron was a quadruped, as he was acc. to the later myths.
220-421. Renewed preparations for battle. Agamemnon visits the various divisions (e)pipw/lhsis). This forms a supplement to the picture of the Achaean army which is given in Books A and B.
220-250. Agamemnon orders the advance of the army.
e)pi/: const. with h)/luqon, came on.—The Trojans move first. This may be simply from the Greek point of view. But they see that the conflict is inevitable, and prefer to ‘take the offensive.’
oi( de/: i.e. the Achaeans.
au)=tis: they had laid off at least their shields and helmets, at 3.114, on the cessation of hostilities, to witness the single combat.
kata/: const. with e)/dun [e)/dusan], donned.

mnh/santo ktl.: i.e. they were eager to fight. cf. *q 252, *c 441, *o 380, xa/rmhs| *trw=es mimnh/skonto *n 721 f., a)lla\ mnhsw/meqa xa/rmhs *o 477, *t 148, x 73, *mene/laos a)nw/gei *)axaiou\s| no/stou mimnh/skesqai g 141 f. To ‘remember the return’ is to enter upon it; to ‘remember flight’ is to take flight.
bri/zonta: sleepy, sluggish.
i)/dois: videres. Potential of the past. See G. 222, N. 3; H. 896; cf. 3.220.
Note the cumulation of synonymous expressions.
ou)k e)qe/lonta: unwilling, disinclined. This ou)k balances the neg. in the preceding ou)de/.
kudia/neiran: this epithet is applied to the a)gorh/, in 1.490.
i(/ppous me/n: correl. with au)ta\r o( 231.
poiki/la xalkw=|: bright with the bronze plates with which the chariot was decorated. cf. *e 239, *k 322, 393.
tou\s me/n: repeats the me/n of 226. cf. 5.842, 844.
a)pa/neuqe: at one side, i.e. behind the line of combatants.—e)/xe [ei)=xe]: coincident in time with e)pepwlei=to 231. Impf. of continued action.
fusio/wntas: snorting in their impatience.
*eu)rume/dwn: only here in Homer. Acc. to Paus. ii. 16. 5, he was slain with Agamemnon at Mycenae. Nestor's charioteer has the same name, *q 114, *l 620.

polla/: urgently, earnestly. Cognate acc., as adv., with e)pe/telle. cf. *e 197, *z 207.—parisxe/men [pare/xein]: sc. i(/ppous kai\ a(/rmata. To keep near at hand, ready to receive him in any emergency, but of course behind the line of battle.
o(ppo/te ken: o(/tan.
gui=a: hands and feet. In appos. with mi/n.
la/bh|: subjv., though after a secondary tense, preserving the form of the original command. cf. 334.
pole/as: cf. pole/es 143.
dia/: const. with pole/as. dia/ and a)na/ do not suffer ‘anastrophe.’ § 37 c. This may have been in order to avoid confusion with *di/a (*zeu/s) and a)/na (voc. of a)/nac).
koirane/onta: commanding, going as commander. Cf. 250.
au)ta/r: see on 226.
pezo/s: pred. with e)w/n, on foot.
e)pepwlei=to ktl.: cf. au)to\s de\ (sc. Agamemnon) kti/los (ram) w(\s e)pipwlei=tai sti/xas a)ndrw=n *g 196. Hence comes the Greek title of this Fifth Book.
kai/ r(a: and so, proceeding to the details of koirane/onta.
ou(\s me\n speu/dontas: contrasted with ou(\s au)= meqie/ntas 240. The contrast of the partics. is strengthened by their position before the verse-pause.
i)/doi: ‘iterative’ optative. See G. 233; H. 914 *b; cf. 240, *b 188, *k 489. This corresponds to the ‘iterative’ impf. qarsu/neske 233 (§ 36).
taxupw/lwn: a standing epithet of the *danaoi/, as i(ppo/damoi is of the *trw=es.
parista/menos: cf. 212. For the metrical quantity of the ultima, cf. me/n 18.
pw/: cf. 184. meqi/ete: cf. *m 409, *n 116. mh/ shows this to be imv. here.
a)lkh=s: ablatival gen. of separation. cf. 240, 351, 6.330.
e)pi\ yeude/ssi: on the side of liars, i.e. of the Trojans who have broken their oaths. cf. e)parh/gein and e)parwgo/s.
yeude/ssi (yeudh/s): equiv. to yeu/sth|sin.—e)/ssetai [e)/stai]: for the elision, cf. fai/netai 278.
tw=n: this is followed by a more exact division into two classes, introduced by h)= toi and au)=te. “Their own bodies will lie unburied; their wives and children will be carried into captivity.”
au)tw=n: contrasted with a)lo/xous and te/kna.
gu=pes e)/dontai: cf. au)tou\s de\ e(lw/ria teu=xe ku/nessin| oi)wnoi=si/ te dai=ta *a 4 f., *p 836, *s 271, *x 42. See on 1.4.
gu=pes: in ‘chiastic’ relation to h(mei=s 238. cf. 5.235 f.
fi/las: a standing epithet, even on an enemy's lips. See on 313.
a)/comen: sc. as captives. See on 162.
nh/essin: nausi/n, § 18 c.
e(/lwmen: aor. subjv., equiv. to fut. perfect.
meqie/ntas: see on 232, 234.
stugerou=: the Homeric epithets of war represent it as a hated thing.
neikei/eske (neike/w): cf. qarsu/neske 233. For the length of the antepenult, see § 29 i.
e)legxe/es: coward caitiffs. Cf. e)le/gxea *b 235.
se/besqe: sc. a)llh/lous. cf. 5.530.
ti/fq) [ti/ pote] ou(/tws: this second question explains the former. “Do you feel no shame in standing thus inactive?”
e(/sthte: an isolated perfect form, for e(/state. Some read e)/sthte, and illustrate the use of the aorist by *ai)nei/a ti/ su\ e)/sths g 179.
teqhpo/tes: dazed. Cf. 21.29.
nebroi/: the Homeric personification of cowardice. cf. the Eng. ‘hare.’— cf. kuno\s o)/mmat e)/xwn kradi/hn d' e)la/foio (deer) 1.225.
ai(/ t' e)pei\ ou)=n: cf. 3.4.
pole/os: broad.
pedi/oio: local gen., on the plain.
qe/ousai: const. closely with e)/kamon, weary with running.
meta\ fresi/: much like e)ni\ fresi/. fre/nes are attributed to a brute animal, also *p 157, *r 111. The word is used primarily in an anatomical sense.
w(/s: resumes ou(/tws 243.
h)=: doubtless. A sarcastic suggestion.
*trw=as: const. primarily with me/nete. The inf. is added in explanation; cf. ti/s e)/ridi cune/hke ma/xesqai *a 8. But this comes near to the const. of acc. with infinitive.
e)/nqa: cf. o(/qi 132. The clause is equiv. to nhw=n.
ei)ru/atai [ei)/runtai]: lie drawn up.

e)u/prumnoi: only here, but it is a fitting epithet, since the ships were drawn up on shore with their bows toward the sea, and the sterns were a prominent part of the camp. cf. i(/stato nei=kos e)pi\ prumnh=|si ne/essin *n 333.

u(pe/rsxh| xei=ra: a poetic figure of protection. cf. *e 433, *i 420, *w 374, o(\s *xru/shn a)mfibe/bhkas *a 37, and the Old Testament figures.—“You seem inclined to do nothing for your own safety, but to leave all to Zeus.”

251-421. Agamemnon visits the several divisions of his army. Five corps are enumerated: I. Idomeneus, 251271; II. The Ajaxes, 272-291; III. Nestor, 292-325; IV. Menestheus and Odysseus, 326-363; V. Diomed and Sthenelus, 364-418.

e)pi\ *krh/tessi: at the Cretans, i.e. to the place where the Cretans were. cf. 273.—The Cretans stood in the line on the right of the Lacedaemonians (Menelaus), and on the left of the Salaminians (Ajax). cf. 3.230, where Idomeneus is noticed immediately after Ajax.
ou)lamo/n: connected with ei)/lw press, throng, and like it with initial *v.
qwrh/ssonto: sc. when Agamemnon reached them.
‘Asyndeton.’ An amplification of 252.
*)idomeneu/s: cf. *a 145, *b 405, 645 ff. Idomeneus was one of the older leaders, and was highly esteemed by Agamemnon. See on 1.145.

e)ni\ proma/xois: equiv. to prw/tas, corresponding to puma/tos 254. sc. w)/trune fa/laggas.—sui+\ ktl.: for the comparison of a hero to a brute, see on 2.480, where Agamemnon is likened to an ox. Ajax also is likened to a wild boar, 17.281, and even to a stubborn ass, 11.558. cf. 5.783.
a)lkh/n: warlike spirit, in general.
gh/qhsen: inceptive. Joy entered his heart. Cf. r(i/ghsen 148.
meilixi/oisin: cf. 241, kertomi/oisi (cutting) proshu/da *a 539, o)neidei/oisin *x 497, e)pe/essi malakoi=si *a 582.
257-263: These verses simply prepare the way for 264. cf. 8.161 ff., 9.53 ff.

peri/: exceedingly, adv., with ti/w, forming a superlative idea which is followed by the partitive gen., *danaw=n. cf. 46, 375, *a 258, *e 325, *h 289, *i 38, peri\ pa/ntwn ti=on e(tai/rwn *s 81, peri\ d' ai)/sula (dreadful deeds) r(e/zeis| a)ndrw=n *f 214. G. 191, VI. 5. 1; H. 803, 1 b.
“Both in action and in the council, in war and in peace.” cf. *a 145, *b 405.
daiti/: illustrates a)lloi/w| e)/rgw|. For the elision of the final i, see § 18 a; cf. 5.5. For the retraction of the accent of the elided syllable, see § 10 d; cf. po/ll) 229.
o(/te ke/rwntai: a)/n is not needed in these cond. rel. clauses of Homer. G. 233; 223 N. 2; H. 914 a. cf. 261 f., 263, 130 f.
gerou/sion: equiv. to gero/ntwn. cf. gerou/sion o(/rkon oath of the senators 22.119. Aldermanic, i.e. the wine offered to the ge/rontes.
ke/rwntai: pres. subjv. mid. of ke/ramai (kera/nnumi). Mix for themselves, though the service was performed by subordinates.
ei) pi/nwsin: for the lack of a)/n, see § 3 c a; cf. 259 f.
ka/rh komo/wntes: for the epithet, see on 2.11.
*)axaioi/: i.e. the ‘elders’ or princes assembled in Agamemnon's tent. *)axaioi/ differs only metrically from *danaw=n 257 and *(argei/wn 260.
daitro/n: measured portion, mess. Cf. ‘And he took and sent messes unto them from before him; but Benjamin's mess was five times so much as any of theirs,’ Genesis xliii. 34.
de/: in apodosis, cf. 161.—plei=on [ple/wn]: full. Contrasted with daitro/n.—For the same honor, cf. *q 162, *m 311.
pie/ein: follows the verse-pause, explanatory of the first hemistich. To this is added a general clause.
a)nw/gh|: subjv., as following a principal tense. In the parallel passages, the opt. is required, after a secondary tense. cf. *q 189, q 70.
a\ll' ... polemo/nde: cf. 19.139.
a)lla/: introduces an exhortation, breaking off from what has preceded. —o)/rseu [o)/rseo, o)/rsou]: cf. o)/rso 204.
oi(=os: such as.
pa/ros: at other times.
ma/la me/n: cf. 318.
e)ri/hros: helpful, trusty. From e)ri and h)=ra (in e)pi\ h)=ra fe/rwn *a 572).
to\ prw=ton: first, once. Cf. e)c ou(= dh\ ta\ prw=ta diasth/thn *a 6.
u(pe/sthn (u(fi/sthmi): equiv. to u(pesxo/mhn, which the heroic verse would not admit. cf. u(pe/sxeto kai\ kate/neusen w 335, for the third person; u(po/sxeo kai\ kata/neuson *a 514.
kate/neusa: a nod was the solemn confirmation of a promise. See on 1.514.

su/n: const. with e)/xeuan, confuderunt, confused, broke. Cf. confundere foedus, quoted on 88.—Note the variety of expressions for the breach of truce. cf. 67, 157, *dio\s o(/rkia dhlh/shtai *g 107, u(pe\r o(/rkia phmh/neian *g 299.
ge/: gives emphasis to the whole clause.
e)/xeuan: for the 1st aor. without s, see § 30 i.
*trw=es: added with considerable feeling. cf. e)/rde 29.
au)=: in turn, on the other hand; cf. 417.
kh/dea: griefs, sc. for the death of loved ones.
o)pi/ssw: hereafter.
See on 236.—This repeats the thought of 269, but lays stress on pro/teroi, instead of on *trw=es.
272-291. The Ajaxes.
kh=r: cf. 326, *s 557, xwo/menos kh=r *a 44; see § 1 v.
*ai)a/ntessi: the two Ajaxes (Telamonian Ajax, 2.557, and the lesser, Locrian, Ajax, 2.527) stood side by side in battle. cf. 12.343 ff., 13.43 ff., 701 ff., 16.719 ff.
tw/: sc. *ai)/ante.
korusse/sqhn: cf. qwrh/ssonto 252.
de\ ne/fos: for the short vowel treated as long before ne/fos, see § 41 j, k.

ne/fos pezw=n: cf. *y 133, kua/neon *trw/wn ne/fos *p 66, yarw=n (starlings) ne/fos *p 755, a)mfi\ de\ pto/lin ne/fos| a)spi/dwn pukno\n fle/gei Eur. Phoen. 250 f., insequitur nimbus peditum Verg. Aen. vii. 793, rex peditum equitumque nubes iactat Livy xxxv. 49, ‘So great a cloud of witnesses,’ Hebrews xii. 1.—This incidental metaphor suggests the following comparison.
w(s o(/te: introduces a comparison, as 130, but here is joined with the indicative. See on 130.

a)po\ skopih=s: where the goats feed on the rocky slope.—The goatherd and his flock are not necessary to the comparison, but are introduced in order to enliven and give a touch of human interest to the scene, just as landscape painters are wont to introduce some bit of life. § 2 e. Cf. 455, pa/nta de/ t' ei)/detai a)/stra, ge/ghqe de/ te fre/na poimh/n *q 559, x 306.
e)rxo/menon ktl.: coming over the sea, toward the on-looker.

u(po\ ktl.: driven by the blast of Zephyrus. This wind came to the plain of Troy from the cold mountains of Thrace, and was to the Homeric poet no mild ‘Zephyr,’ but a blustering, stormy wind. See on 2.147.
tw=|: i.e. the goatherd.

a)/neuqen e)o/nti: for the adv. const. with e)o/nti, see on dh/n *z 139; cf. w(/s 319.— The poet takes his stand with the herd. See on e(/kaqen de/ te fai/netai au)gh/ *b 456.—mela/nteron ktl.: this seems to be a combination of two expressions, mela/nteron h)/ and me/lan h)u/te ktl.
fai/netai: for the elision of ai, see § 10 a; cf. e)/ssetai 235.
i)o/n (ei)=mi): repeats e)rxo/menon.
a)/gei: brings. su\n lai/lapi would give nearly the same sense, but without so much animation.
This verse only completes the picture. It has no place in the strict comparison.
r(i/ghsen, h)/lase: gnomic aorists, cf. 143.
u(po\ spe/os: under (cover of) a cave, into a cave.
toi=ai: as such, i.e. so dark and threatening. This refers to w(s 275, and is explained by 282. cf. toi=oi 146.
e)s: for its position between adj. and subst., see § 1 l.
pukinai/: puknai/. cf. 392.

pefrikui=ai: bristling. Restless movement is implied in the verb. cf. *h 62, e)/fricen ma/xh e)gxei/h|sin *n 339, fri/ssousin a)/rourai *y 599, horrentia pilis agmina Hor. Sat. ii. *i. 13, sparsis hastis longis campus splendet et horret Ennius Sat. 15; h(/ te fa/lagc h( *makedonikh\ puknh\ kai\ tai=s sari/ssais (pikes) pefrikui=a Arrian Anab. iii. 14. 3, ‘Bristled with upright beams innumerable| Of rigid spears, and helmets thronged, and shields,’ Milton Par. Lost vi. 82 f.; ‘horrent arms,’ ib. ii. 513.
sfe/as: monosyllabic. § 7 a.
sfw=i: acc. obj. of o)trune/men.
ga/r: introduces the next verse, cf. *m 326, *w 223, a 301.
au)tw/: yourselves, of your own impulse.
288 = *b 371, *h 132, *p 97, d 341, h 311, r 132, s 235, w 376. An appeal to the three chief divinities in an ardent wish.
pa=sin: emphatic. Masc., not neuter. For the dat., cf. tw=| 208.
tw=|: in that case, then.
xersi\n u(/po: for u(po/ with the dat., in its transition from local to causal sense, see § 3 h g.
292-325. Nestor.
e)/nqa: then. A particle of transition in the story.
e)/tetme: equiv. to eu(=re.—ligu\n ktl.: cf. 1.248.
*puli/wn: see on 2.591.

a)gorhth/n: equiv. to Attic r(h/twr.—Nestor, the oldest and wisest of the Achaeans, brought against Troy a larger force than any other chieftain, except Agamemnon. See 2.591 ff. He stood with his Pylians on the right of the Locrians, and on the left of the Athenians; cf. 273, 327.
ou(/s: possessive pronoun.
ste/llonta: marshalling. Cf. kosme/w, Attic ta/ssw.
These Pylians do not appear elsewhere, except possibly Alastor in 13.422. Nestor's sons, Antilochus and Thrasymedes, are not named here.
a)mfi\ ktl.: const. with e(ta/rous 294.
*)ala/stora: the preceding hiatus is justified by the verse-pause.

i(pph=as: knights, horsemen,— but on chariots, not as cavalry. sc. e)/sthse from 298; cf. 253 f.—Nestor was a skilled tactician, 2.362 ff., 553 ff., and here are found the beginnings of Greek military tactics.
pole/as ktl.: in appos. with pezou/s. Many brave men. Cf. *w 204, 520, w 427.
e(/rkos ktl.: to be a defence, etc. Cf. 137. Const. with both i(pph=as and pezou/s.
e)/men: ei)=nai, § 34 g.

kakou/s: worthless, unwarlike,—without moral quality.—This passage was often used as an illustration by the ancient rhetoricians: weak arguments were to be sandwiched between the stronger arguments which should begin and close the speech.—cf. kai\ ga\r e)n tw=| pole/mw| tou/s te prw/tous a)ri/stous dei= ta/ttein kai\ tou\s teleutai/ous, e)n me/sw| de\ tou\s xeiri/stous i(/na u(po\ me\n tw=n a)/gwntai, u(po\ de\ tw=n w)qw=ntai Xen. Mem. iii. *i. 8.
ou)k e)qe/lwn: invitus. cf. 224.
a)nagkai/h|: of necessity. a)nagkai/h: a)na/gkh: : *)aqhnai/h: *)aqh/nh.
i(ppeu=sin me/n: implies a pezoi=s de/, which is not given.—a)nw/gein [h)nw/gei]: plpf. as imperfect.
sfou/s: sfete/rous, § 24 a.
e)xe/men: check, so as not to advance beyond the line of battle.
klone/esqai: be disordered.
o(mi/lw|: local, in the throng.

mhde/ tis: and let no one. This is in close connexion with 302 (as if that had been sfou/s tis e(/kastos i(/ppous e)xe/tw), and forms the transition to direct discourse, which is elsewhere introduced by some formula. cf. h(=s a)/r' a)nw/gein| toceu/ein: “o(\s me/n ke ba/lh|” ktl. *y 854 f., parh/ggeilen au)toi=s perime/nein th\n e)paggeli/an tou= patro\s h(\n h)kou/sate/ mou Acts i. 4.

i(pposu/nh|: “skill in fighting on chariots.” Horsemanship was as important an accomplishment for the Homeric heroes as for the knights of the Middle Ages. —h)nore/hfi [a)ndrei/a|]: for the ending, see § 15 a.
oi)=os: i.e. as pro/maxos, explained by pro/sq' a)/llwn. cf. 3.16, 22. —In general, the Homeric heroes fought independently and severally, and made hardly an effort to maintain a regular line.
pro/sqe: local, cf. propa/roiqen o(mi/lou makra\ biba/nta (striding) 3.22.
mhde\ ktl.: nor let him draw back, sc. behind the line.
a)lapadno/teroi ktl.: sc. otherwise, if this order is not obeyed.
ga/r: introduces the reason for the command.
a)po\ w(=n o)xe/wn: on his chariot, cf. *e 13, *o 386, e)pista/menoi a)f' i(/ppwn ma/rnasqai i 49 f. For oi(=s u)/xesin a)po\ tou/twn k(/khtai. In contrast with oi)=os pro/sq' a)/llwn.
w(=n: possessive pron., as is indicated by the preceding ‘apparent hiatus.’ See §§ 9 f, 14 a; cf. ou(/s 294.
e(/tera: i.e. hostile.
i(/khtai: reach, sc. with the spear, when the enemy approached so near.
e)/gxei ktl.: cf. *e 851, memaw=tes o\rekth=|sin meli/h|sin *b 543.
e)pei\ h)=: cf. 56.
ou(/tws: in contrast to 303 f.
oi( pro/teroi: as subst., those men of old. Cf. *e 637, *i 524, *y 332.
e)po/rqeon: trisyllabic.
Explanatory of w(=de 308.
to/nde: i.e. that which has been described.
no/on: plan, rule.
qumo/n: will, purpose.
pa/lai: long ago. Const. with ei)dw/s. Nestor was no novice in war.
pole/mwn: for the gen., see on to/cwn 196; cf. sciens pugnae Hor. Carm. i. 15. 24.
See on 255.
See on 1.201. This formula is repeated no less than fifty times in Homer. See § 1 w.
fwnh/sas: lifting up his voice.
ei)/qe: const. with e(/poito—qumo\s ktl.: cf. 360, q 178, l 566, u 9, 217, y 215.
qumo/s: spirit.
fi/loisin: a standing epithet of words which denote relationship, or a part of the human body, or the mind.

gou/nata: the knees were to the Homeric warriors the seat of physical strength. In them, physical weakness is early shown. cf. Eng. ‘weakkneed.’ See on 5.176; cf. o(ppo/te min ka/mato/s te kai\ i(drw\s gou/naq' i(/koito *n 711, bla/betai de/ te gou/nat) i)o/nti *t 166, ka/matos d) u(po\ gou/nat) e)da/mna *f 52. Hector as a suppliant begged Achilles u(pe\r yuxh=s kai\ gou/nwn *x 338.
e(/poito: kept pace with, “did the bidding of,” the spirit.—bi/h kti.: cf. *h 157, *l 670, *y 629, c 468, 503.

o(moi/ion: generally understood as common, which comes to all alike. Most freq. as an epithet of war and strife (444). The form o(moi=os is never so used. The meaning which is given above is unsatisfactory, since not all men live to old age or engage in war.
o)/felen ktl.: of an unattainable wish. G. 251, 2, N. 1; H. 871 a.
e)/xein: sc. gh=ras.
su/: sc. o)/feles.
kourote/roisi: const. with meta/ in metei=nai.
i(ppo/ta: i(ppeu/s. For the ending, see § 16 b; cf. i(pphla/ta 387, nefelhgere/ta 30.
ma/la me/n: cf. 266.
w(\s e)/men: toiou=ton ei)=nai. “That I were so strong as I was when,” etc. —For w(/s with e)/men, cf. a)/neuqen 277.— For similar memories of Nestor, see 7.132 ff., 11.670 ff., 23.629 ff.
*ereuqali/wna: an Arcadian champion, whom Nestor slew in battle on the banks of the Celadon,—a river which the Phoenicians called Jardanus (cf. ‘Jordan’). The story is told in full in 7.132 ff.
kate/ktan: for the form, see § 35.

Non omnia possumus omnes. This maxim appears in fuller form, a)ll' ou)/ pws a(/ma pa/nta dunh/seai au)to\s e(le/sqai *n 729, cf. ou) pa/ntessi qeoi\ xari/enta didou=sin q 167. cf. non omnia nimirum eidem di dedere Livy xxii. 51, Maharbal to Hannibal.—“No man has at the same time the wise experience of old age and the fiery vigor of youth.”
Asyndeton, since this is an illustration of the preceding principle. § 2 m.

ei) ktl.: conditional only in form. “As I was then,” etc. Cf. ei) de\ su\ kartero/s e)ssi kti. *a 280, ei)/ tis ou)=n para/klhsis e)n *xristw=|, ei)/ ti paramu/qion a)gaph=s, ei)/ tis koinwni/a pneu/matos ... plhrw/sate/ mou th\n xara/n St. Paul, Ep. Philip. ii. 1.—e)/a [h)=n]: the quantity of the ultima is uncertain; it is treated as long before the verse-pause. cf. 5.887.
nu=n au)=te: but now. au)=te in this use hardly differs from au)ta/r. cf. 1.237.
o)pa/zei: attends, like a companion, or even like a pursuing enemy. cf. *q 103. gh=ras is personified.
kai\ w(/s: “even though so old and infirm.”
boulh=| kai\ mu/qoisi: cf. n 298, p 420.
to/: see on to/ 49.
ai)xma/s: acc. of ‘kindred formation.’ cf. 27. The Attic would use the article ta/s.
oi(/ per: they who, i.e. since they, giving the reason for the preceding clause.
o(plo/teroi: i.e. more vigorous. —gega/asin [gego/nasin]: are.
bi/hfin: cf. h)nore/hfi 303.
326-363. Menestheus and Odysseus.
For the ‘asyndeton,’ cf. 89.
*petew=o: for *petea/oo. See § 17 c.
*menesqg=a: this Athenian leader was said to be the best kosmh=sai (marshal) i(/ppous te kai\ a)ne/ras a)spidiw/tas, *b 554, but he and the Athenians have no prominence in the action of the Iliad.
a)mfi/: sc. e(/stasan.
*)aqhnai=oi: the Athenians stood on the right of the Pylians, and on the left of the Cephallenians.
mh/stwres (mh/domai) ktl.: cf. *e 272, *z 97.
au)ta/r: “while.” § 3 q.
o(: short before plhsi/on. § 41 i b.
polu/mhtis: for the epithets of Odysseus, see § 4 c; cf. 358.
*)odusseu/s: in appos. with o(. cf. *)aqhnai/h ktl. 20. —The hero of the Odyssey; one of the shrewdest of the Achaean leaders.
pa/r: at his side, near at hand. § 37 b.
*kefallh/nwn: the common name for the subjects of Odysseus.
e(/stasan: contrasted with ki/nunto (cf. Attic e)kinou=nto), and so followed by an explanation, with ga/r.
sfi/n: i.e. Menestheus and Odysseus. Nearly equiv. to Attic au)tw=n, with lao/s. cf. tw=| 208.
a)kou/eto: mid., only here in Homer.
a)uth=s: i.e. the token of the beginning battle.— These Cephallenians were at a considerable distance from the centre of action.
i(ppoda/mwn: knightly. ‘Horsetamers’ has indeed the same root (dam-), but has very different associations.
oi( de\ ktl.: gives the result of the preceding clauses. Since the cry of battle had not been raised, and the strife was only just beginning, these were waiting.
o(ppo/te: for the time when. Cf. de/gmenos o(ppo/te nau=fin a)formhqei=en *)axaioi/ *b 794, of the Trojan scout.
pu/rgos: tower, i.e. column, as 347. cf. ta/cis, ta/gma.
a)/llos: clearly these Cephallenians do not expect to be the first to begin the conflict.
*trw/wn: gen. after a ‘word of aiming.’ cf. *menela/ou 100, w(rmh/qh d' *)aka/mantos *c 488 rushed at Acamas.
a)/rceian: for the pl. after a ‘collective word’ (pu/rgos), cf. w(\s fa/san h( plhqu/s *b 278. G. 135, 3; H. 609.
nei/kessen: for the ss, see § 12 a.
See on 284.

ui(e/: the final syllable of the voc. is not infreq. treated as long, cf. 155, *e 359, *p 21; this is generally to be explained by a following pause. Here, ui(o/s might be read, cf. fi/los 189. § 41 p.
kakoi=si do/loisi: cunning, instead of brave strength.
kekasme/ne: from kai/numai.

kerdaleo/fron: cf. 1.149.—The character of Odysseus in post-Homeric times was largely in accordance with these epithets. cf. the words which are put into his mouth, o(/tan ti dra=s ei)s ke/rdos, ou)k o)knei=n pre/pei Soph. Phil. 111.—Obs. the alliteration (k). § 2 a.—Not a word is said here about Menestheus, 327; nor does that chief make any reply.
kataptw/ssontes: cf. 224, 5.254, 476.
a)fe/state: stand aloof, sc. ma/xhs.

Chiastic arrangement of clauses: meta\ prw/toisi e)o/ntas answers to mi/mnete d' a)/llous, and 342 to a)fe/state 340.—me/n [mh/n]: emphasizes the preceding word. cf. *n 47, *o 203, *t 92. Contrasted with nu=n 347.
e)o/ntas: attracted from the case of sfw=in to the acc. which already in Homer's time was most freq. with the infinitive. cf. *a 541, *b 113, *e 716.
342 = *m 316.—e(sta/men [e(sta/nai]: stand ready.

kaustei/rhs (kai/w): cf. de/mas (like) puro\s ai)qome/noio *l 596, ma/xh e)noph/ te dedh/ein *m 35, *)idomenh=a i)/don flogi\ ei)/kelon a)lkh/n *n 330, flogi\ ei)/kelon *(/ektora *n 688, ei) puri\ xei=ras e)/oike g 372. The same figure is prob. in dh/ion 281.
prw/tw: emphatic.

a)koua/zesqon: perh. a reference to a)kou/eto 331. Here followed by two gens.; cf. ke/klute/ meu mu/qwn k 189, but the examples are not strictly parallel.— Sarcastic. “When I invite you to a feast, you are ready enough to listen and come.”

ge/rousin: cf. 259 f. The number of the Gerontes in the Achaean camp is uncertain; prob. only six besides the Atridae. cf. 2.404 ff. Menestheus was not one of these, but doubtless often other chiefs were invited to these feasts, cf. 10.217.
e)fopli/zwmen *)axaioi/: the dinners given by the commander-in-chief were in the name and at the expense of the whole army. cf.261, 8.161 ff., 17.249 f.
fi/la: pred. to kre/a and ku/pella. The inf. e)/dmenai is added in explanation. cf. ai)ei/ toi ta\ ka/k' e)sti\ fi/la fresi\ manteu/esqai *a 107.
o)ptale/a: the Homeric heroes eat no boiled, but only roast, meat. Plato in his Republic, III. 404 c, calls attention to the fact that Homer does not make his Greeks take kettles to Troy.
oi)/nou: const. with ku/pella.
o)/fr' e)qe/lhton: as long as you like. Cf. 263.
nu=n de/: contrasted with 341. “But the fact is.”
fi/lws: gladly, h(de/ws, a)spasi/ws q 450. A reference to fi/la 345. Only here in Homer, see § 38 h. Cf. angustam amice pauperiem pati Hor. Carm. iii. 2. 1.
kai\ ei) ktl.: this clause is obj. of o(ro/w|te [o(ra/oite, o(rw=|te].
u(mei/wn: u(mw=n, § 24 a. Gen. with propa/roiqe.
maxoi/ato: ma/xointo, § 26 t.
u(po/dra: (perh. from under the brows), askance, fiercely. Found only with i)dw/n, and always after the first trochee of the verse. cf. torva tuentem Verg. Aen. vi. 467.
fu/gen: escaped.

se/, e(/rkos o)do/ntwn: i.e. thy teeth. e(/rkos is in appos. with se/, cf. gui=a 230. — cf. ‘slide through my infant lips;| Driving dumb silence from the portal door,’ Milton Vacation Exercise 4 f.; ‘Within my mouth you have engaol'd my tongue,
div.l: Doubly portcullis'd with my teeth and lips,’ Shakspere Rich. II. i. 3. 166. —Odysseus soon distinguishes himself, and shows the falsity of the reproaches which have been cast upon him. In 14.82 ff., he rebukes Agamemnon, in turn, for his willingness to withdraw from before Troy. See on 365 f.

div.p: pw=s dh/: how, pray; with what right. “What do you mean by saying that we” etc. This is equiv. to the assertion, “What you say is absurd and false.” — pole/moio meqie/men [meqie/nai]: sc. h(me/as. cf. 240. — o(ppo/te e)gei/romen [e)gei/rwmen]: “whenever we shall rouse.” A rejoinder to 344. — Rarely does a new sent. begin, as here, at the bucolic diaeresis, except when the topic is changed, as A 348, 430.
e)pi/: upon, against. See § 3 h b.
e)gei/romen ktl.: cf. *b 440, *q 531, *s 304.
353 = 9.359. The first half-verse also *q 471, w 511. — A poetic and picturesque way of saying, “I will fight bravely.” See on 98.
o)/yeai: in contrast with fh/|s 351, — prominent at the head of the apodosis.
h)/n ktl.: Odysseus heaps up synonyms in his vexation.

*thlema/xoio ktl.: as a third person might speak of Odysseus, instead of e)me/. cf. Odysseus's oath, mhd' e)/ti *thlema/xoio path\r keklhme/nos ei)/hn 2.260. Some have found here in the name *thle/-maxos a play upon pro-ma/xoisi. — mige/nta (m<*>/gnumi): aor. partic., without reference to time ‘prior to the action of the principal verb.’ Inceptive aorist.
su\ de\ ktl.: this repeats the thought of the question in 351.
a)nemw/lia: predicate. a)nemw/lia/ e)sti tau=ta a(\ su\ ba/zeis.

xwome/noio: supplementary participle. For the gen. with gnw= [e)/gnw], cf. 310, 2.348, the Attic gen. with ai)sqa/nomai, ou)de\ trape/zh|| gnw/thn a)llh/lwn f 35 f., gnwso/meq' a)llh/lwn kai\ lw/ion (better) Od. 23.109. The gen. ‘expresses Agamemnon's observing a fact about Ulysses, viz. that he was angry.’
