pa/lin ktl.: retractavit, took back what he had said, i.e. he spoke in another tone; cf. 359. cf. palina/greton *a 526, pa/lin e)re/ei *i 56 gainsay.

358 = *b 173, *q 93, *i 308, 624, *k 144, *y 723, and 15 times in the Odyssey. — Contrast 339. — Agamemnon replies in the same number of verses as Odysseus had used; see on 412. — Obs. that Menestheus is not mentioned here; see on 339.
neikei/w: [neikw=]: for the form see on 241. “I do not mean to rebuke.”
periw/sion: unduly, beyond measure.
keleu/w: urge.
h)/pia: kindly, friendly, — not hostile. sc. e)moi/. — ta\ ktl.: “we agree in what is to be done.”
a)ll' i)/qi: this is on its way to become a mere interjection like a)ll' a)/ge 418, but its literal force may be preserved here, sc. ei)s ma/xhn. cf. *z 341, *g 432.
tau=ta: i.e. what has been said. It is explained by the following clause
o)/pisqen ktl.: “we will make all this right hereafter; we have no time now for explanations and apologies.” Cf. *z 526, x 55.
ta\ de\ pa/nta: sums up again the preceding clause.
metamw/nia qei=en: give to the winds.
qei=en: cf. qei=nai 26.
364-418. Diomed and Sthenelus.
cf. 89 f., 327 f., 5.376. — The Argives (in the narrow sense of the term) under Diomed stand on the right of the Cephallenians. cf. 8.91 f., 11.312-401.

*diomh/dea: tetrasyllable, by synizesis. cf. *tudh= 384. For Diomed's forces, see 2.559-568. He brought 80 ships to Troy and was one of the mightiest heroes, good both in counsel and in action. The Fifth Book and a large part of the Sixth Book are devoted to his exploits (*diomh/dous a)ristei/a). He voices the sentiments of the Greeks, in 7.399 ff.; he was the first to stay his horses and recover from the rout, 8.254 ff.; he (like Odysseus, see on 350) rebukes Agamemnon's lack of confidence, 9.31 ff., cf. 9.695; he goes with Odysseus by night into the Trojan camp, and slays the Thracian king Rhesus, 10.219 ff.; he is wounded by Paris in the third day of battle, 11.369 ff., but recovers in time to take part in the games in honor of Patroclus in which he gains the first prize in the chariot race, Od. 23.499 ff., and contends with Telamonian Ajax in heavy armor, 23.812 ff.
e)/n te ktl.: but one thought. “On his chariot drawn by horses.” cf. 5.794.
kollhtoi=sin: firmly-joined, well built.

pa\r de/ oi(: while at his side, i.e. as h(ni/oxos qera/pwn. The charioteers of princes were of noble families and on most intimate relations with the chiefs. The qera/pwn corresponded in general to the knight's esquire in the Middle Ages.
*sqe/nelos: short form for *sqene/laos, which has the same meaning as *dhmosqe/nhs.
*kapanh/ios: of Capaneus. See § 21 k. The adj. is equiv. to a gen., as in *nhlhi/y ui=(i 2.20.
to\n me/n: i.e. Diomed, the principal personage.
ui(e\ ktl.: cf. 2.23, 11.450. — The very address indicates the contrast which is developed in the following verses. Hence *tude/i 372, with emphasis, instead of patri/.
o)pipeu/eis: scan.

pole/moio gefu/ras: the bridges of war, or, better, the dikes of war. This expression has been explained in many ways. Perhaps it is best taken as to\ metai/xmion, the space between the two lines of battle, with the armies like a raging river on either side.
me/n: mh/n, cf. 341.
fi/lon h)=en: h(/ndane, was pleasing. Cf. *a 107, 541, *e 891, *h 31, *r 556, a 82, i 211.
ptwskaze/men: subject. — “Tydeus was not wont to skulk.”
polu\ pro/: far in advance.
dhi/^oisi: either h is shortened before i (§ 5 g), or i is pronounced as y (§ 7 a).
ma/xesqai: sc. fi/lon h=)en from the negative clause above.
i)/donto: for the voice, see § 32 a. No distinction is perceptible between this and i)/don (1st pers.) below.
poneu/menon: equiv. to maxo/menon, in battle. po/nos in Homer is used chiefly of the toil of war. For the contraction (eo to eu), see §§ 6 b, 29 g.
ga/r: introduces the reason why Agamemnon introduces the testimony of others, instead of speaking for himself.
peri/: see on 257.
g)= toi: believe me. —The fol lowing incident shows the warlike spirit of Tydeus.
a)/ter pole/mou: apart from war, i.e. not as an enemy but as a friend, with an entreaty (379).
cei=nos: as a guest.

*polunei/kei: ill-fated son of the ill-fated Oedipus. His brother Eteocles had driven him from Thebes, and he came as a suppliant to Argos just when Tydeus came thither, as an exile from his Aetolian home (cf. 399). The Argive king, Adrastus, received the two princes and gave to each a daughter in marriage. Adrastus and Tydeus then aided Polynices to raise the armies (lao\n a)gei/rwn) of the ‘Seven against Thebes.’
oi(/ r(a: i.e. Tydeus and Polynices.
e)strato/wnto: were on the expedition. Const. with pro\s tei/xea.
r(a/: points back to e)strato/wnto.
ma/la: for the length of the ultima, see § 41 j a.
do/men: dou=nai, § 26 j.
oi( de/: i.e. the people of Mycenae, where Thyestes (2.106 f.) then ruled.
e)/qelon: were minded.
e)ph/|neon ktl.: cf. 23.539.
e)/treye: turned aside, dissuaded, sc. the Myceneans from their purpose to take part in the war. cf. ou)k a)/n me tre/yeian o(/soi qeoi/ ei)s' e)n *)olu/mpw| *q 451.
parai/sia: opposed to e)nai/sima. Very likely, lightning on the left side. cf. 2.353.
oi( de/: a return to the oi( of 378.
w)/|xonto: were gone. For the following hiatus, cf. 147.
pro/: adv. with e)ge/nonto, made more definite by o(dou=, came forward on the way.

*)aswpo/n: acc. of ‘limit of motion.’ See § 3 i; G. 162; H. 722. This const. is freq. with i(/kw, i(ka/nw, i(kne/omai, but rare with bai/nw, ei=)mi, e)/rxomai. The Asopus is a Boeotian river, forming ‘the boundary between the territories of Thebes and Plataea.’ Here the Argive army halted and sent Tydeus as ambassador (a)ggeli/hn) to present their claims to the king, Eteocles. cf. 5.803, and Diomed's prayer to Athena: spei=o/ moi (attend me), w(s o(/te patri\ a(/m' e(/speo *tude/i di/w|| e)s *qh/bas, o(/te te pro\ *)axaiw=n a)/ggelos h)/|ein.| tou\s d) a)/r) e)p) *)aswpw=| li/pe xalkoxi/twnas *)axaiou/s,| au)ta\r d meili/xion (peaceful) mu=qon fe/re *kadmei/oisin *k 285 ff. cf. also 3.205 f., for a similar embassy of Odysseus and Menelaus.
lexepoi/hn: grass-bedded, grassy.
e)/nq' au=)te ktl.: apod. to 382.
a)ggeli/hn: equiv. to a)/ggelon.
e)pi/: const. with stei=lan. sc. to Thebes.
*tudh=: *tude/a. See § 6 c, and cf. the synizesis of *diomh/dea 365.

*kadmei+/wnas: equiv. to *kadmei/ons, 388, 391. cf. *darda/nioi, *b 819, and *dardani/wnes *h 414. See § 21 h. The Cadmeans were named from the mythical founder of Boeotian Thebes. cf. *)erexqei+/dai as a freq. poetic appellation for the Athenians.

*bi/hs ktl.: a periphrasis for “the mighty Eteocles.” See § 2 s; cf. 5.638, 781. Eteocles is not mentioned elsewhere in Homer. The Theban nobles were assembled, after the fashion of the heroic times (cf. 1 ff.), feasting in the palace, when Tydeus came and was invited to join in the banquet. cf. 5.805.
ou)de/: not even.
cei=nos: guest, i.e. stranger.
i(pphla/ta: cf. i(ppo/ta 317.
o(/ ge: resumes Od. 4.385.
prokali/zeto: called forth, challenged, sc. to the athletic games which followed the feast (cf. Od. 8.98 ff.).
pa/nta: neuter, cognate acc., in all things, in every contest. Cf. 5.807.
e)ni/ka: was victor.
e)pi/rroqos: cf. e)pita/rroqos *e 808. This aid of Athena does not detract from the glory of the achievements, since only the brave are thus helped by the gods.
xolwsa/menoi: sc. at the stranger's success.
ke/ntores (kente/w goad) ktl.: elsewhere they are called plh/cippoi. cf. 5.102.
pukino/n: crowded, i.e. strong. cf. 281, *z 187, dei/sht' *)argei/wn pukino\n lo/xon *w 779.
lo/xon ei(=san (i(/zw): cf. 6.189.
a)/gontes: intransitive. It is not strictly ‘pleonastic,’ but serves to fill out the picture. See on i)w/n *a 138.
kou/rous: in appos. with lo/xon.
In appos. with h(gh/tores. The names have a bloody sound.
*ai(moni/dhs: reminds of Antigone's cousin and lover, Haemon.
me/n: cf. 341.
kai\ toi=sin ktl.: “he overcame these too (as well as his opponents in the games, 389), and slew them.”
e)fhken: the perf. passive of e)fi/hmi is e)fh=ptai, cf. 6.241.
pa/ntas ktl.: cf. 6.190.
e(/na d' oi)=on: one alone, sc. to bear the tidings of the disaster. cf. ou)ke/t' e)/peit) o)i/w (I think) ou)d' a)/ggelon a)pone/esqai| a)/yorron proti\ a)/stu *m 73 f.
*mai/ona: acc. to Statius, in his Thebaïd, Maeon was an augur and priest of Apollo. A scholiast conjectured that he was a herald, and thus his person was inviolable.
a)/ra: resumes e(/na ktl. above.
qew=n: a general expression, instead of *zhno/s. cf. 408, 157, 6.183.
tera/essi: cf. depa/essin 3.
piqh/sas: listening to, obeying. Portents warned Tydeus not to slay Maeon. cf. 381.
*ai)tw/lios: Tydeus was son of Oeneus, king of Calydon in Aetolia. See on 377.
to\n ui(o/n: “this son of his.”
cf. 5.800. —ei(=o [ou(=, au(tou=] xe/rha: inferior to himself. Predicate. “The son whom he begot is inferior in bravery, although better in the council.”
ma/xh|: local, in battle. Obs. the ‘chiasmus’ again; cf. 197, 416.
ai)desqei/s: abashed. Obs. the correspondence of this, at the opening, to ai)doi/oio at the close of the verse, and the spondaic rhythm.
e)niph/n: for the acc., see G. 158 N. 2; H. 712; cf. 5.530.
yeu/deo: yeu/dou, § 26 p.
sa/fa: being contrasted with yeu/deo, must mean trustworthy, true.
h(mei=s: WE, whom you call cowards.
toi/: “let me tell you,” “you ought to know.”

me/ga: far, adv. with a)mei/nones. me/ga strengthens all degrees of comparison; see on 1.78. — cf. Tydides melior patre Hor. Carm. i. 15. 28, ou(/tws h(mei=s polu\ belti/ous tw=n a)ndrw=n eu)xo/meq' ei=)nai Aristoph. Thesmophor. 810. Diomed and Sthenelus had both been among the ‘Epigoni’ who had taken Thebes, ten years after the first disastrous expedition in which the fathers of both had served as commanders. The first Theban expedition is barely alluded to elsewhere in Homer, and the poet only in this passage mentions the war of the ‘Epigoni.’
h(mei=s: emphatic ‘anaphora’ of the subject, with explanatory asyndeton.
kai/: const. with ei(/lomen. “We not merely (like our fathers) besieged Thebes, but also captured it.”
*qh/bhs: for the gen., see on 103. For the sing., see on *mukh/nh 52.
e(/dos: cf. naieta/ousi 45.
pauro/teron: smaller, sc. than our fathers. cf. pau=ros de/ oi( (i.e. Nireus) ei(/peto lao/s *b 675.
a)gago/nte: dual, since Sthenelus thinks only of himself and Diomed.
u(po\ tei=xos: up under the wall, i.e. to the foot of the wall. cf. u(po\ *)/ilion h)=lqen *b 216. Possibly with reference to the height of the Cadmean citadel.
a)/reion: comp., better, i.e. stronger. Cf. 15.736. In sharp contrast with pauro/teron at the beginning of the verse.
peiqo/menoi: cf. piqh/sas 398. This is in close connexion with the principal thought, ei(/lomen 406. cf. h(mei=s de\ mega/loio *dio\s peiqw/meqa boulh=| *m 241.
a)rwgh=|: instrumental, by the aid.
cf. au)tw=n ga\r sfete/rh|sin ktl. a 7, of the comrades of Odysseus; Od. 10.437.

a)tasqali/h|sin: blind follies, contrasted with 408. The leaders of the first expedition against Thebes were represented as being for the most part hot-headed, self-willed, impious men, — esp. Capaneus, the father of Sthenelus. cf. (*kapaneu\s) pu/rgois d' a)peilei= dei/n) a(\ mh\ krai/noi tu/xh:| qeou= te ga\r qe/lontos e)kpe/rsein po/lin| kai\ mh\ qe/lontos fhsi/n: ou)de\ th\n *dio\s| e)/rin (i.e. lightning) pe/doi skh/yasan (falling) e)mpodw\n sxeqei=n.| ta\s d' a)strapa/s te kai\ kerauvi/ous bola\s| meshmbrinoi=si (mid-day) qa/lpesin prosh/|kasen Aeschylus Septem 409 ff., Soph. Antigone 126 ff. In return for his boasting, Capaneus was struck and slain by the lightning of Zeus.
tw=|: therefore.
mh/ pote: never.
moi/: “I beg of you.”
o(moi/h| timh=|: in like honor, i.e. in so high honor, sc. with us, — while Agamemnon had counted the fathers worthy of far higher honor than the sons.
e)/nqeo: 2d sing. aor. imv. with mh/. Not the Attic usage. cf. mh\ katadu/seo *s 134, mh/ tis a)kousa/tw p 301, mh\ xo/lon e)/nqeo qumw=| w 248.
te/tta: “old fellow,” in an affectionate, though reproving, tone. Nothing indicates that Sthenelus was actually older than Diomed.

siwph=| h(=so: sit in silence, keep quiet. The literal meaning of h(=so is not to be pressed, since e(stew=te 366 shows that they were standing. — The whole speech of Diomed shows self-restraint and prudence. The poet thus reminds the hearer that the hero was distinguished a)gorh=|. This speech has the same number of verses as that of Sthenelus, 404 ff. See on 358, 3.161, 301.
*)agame/mnoni: for the dat. after a word of opposition, see G. 186, N. 1; H. 772.
o)tru/nonti: pred. partic. with nemesw=. Equiv. to o(/ti o)tru/nei. cf. 5.872, nemessh/saito/ ken a)nh\r| ai)/sxea po/ll' o(ro/wn (if he should see) Od. 1.228 f.

tou/tw|: the prominence of this and its repetition two lines below mark the identity of the person chiefly interested. In English, the first clause would be subordinate. “As glory will attend him in the one case, so grief will come upon him in the other case.” Only the second of these clauses has any independent force in the connexion here; 415 f. are simply for contrast. cf. 6.227-229.
ku=dos: is emphatic in itself, and opposed to pe/nqos by the position of each, before the verse-pause.
pe/nqos: sc. e)/ssetai.
*)axaiw=n: prob. gen. of cause, but it may be gen. absolute. § 3 f.
a)ll' a)/ge: cf. a)ll' i)/qi 362.
qou/ridos: cf. qou=ros as an epithet of Ares, 5.30.
419 = 16.426, cf. *g 29, *e 111, 494, *z 103, *l 211, *m 81, *n 749. Diomed enters the battle as a ‘hoplite.’
deino/n: adv., cognate acc. cf. 425, 6.470.
e)/braxe: cf. e)/klagcan d' a)/r) o)istoi/ . . . au)tou= kinhqe/ntos *a 46 f., arma| horrendum sonuere Verg. Aen. ix. 731 f.
o)rnume/nou: as he started.
u(po/: const. with ei(=len. This refers to the weakness of his knees; see on 314. cf. u(po/ te tro/mos (trembling) e)/llabe gui=a *g 34, tro/mos u(ph/luqe gui=a *u 44.
talasi/frona/ per: even a stout-hearted man.
ken ei(=len: would have seized, sc. if he had been there. cf. 539. In prose, this might have been stated as a consequence, “so that,” etc.
Here ends the *)epipw/lhsis of Agamemnon. That he returns at once to his special division, is assumed.

422-456. Both armies advance and the battle begins. This scene could follow immediately either 2.483 or 2.785. The single combat of Menelaus and Paris, with its accompaniments, has been little more than an episode.
w(s d' o(/te: introduces a comparison. cf. 130, 141, 275. It is here used with the pres. ind., of an ordinary occurrence. cf. 452, *l 492, *p 364, *t 357, *f 12, *y 692, 760.
poluhxe/i: cf. qa/lassa/ te h)xh/essa *a 157, polufloi/sboio qala/sshs *a 34.

ku=ma: collective; one ware as a representative of all. cf. fluctus uti primo coepit cum albescere vento,| paulatim sese tollit mare et altius undas| erigit, inde imo consurgit ad aethera fundo Verg. Aen. vii. 528 ff., id. Georg. iii. 237 ff.
e)passu/teron: in quick succession, one after another. Cf. *e 141, *a 383. This is the point of comparison, and has the same position in the verse as e)passu/terai 427.
*zefu/rou ktl.: see on 276.
u(/po: for the accent, see § 37 c. For the const., see § 3 f g.
po/ntw|: on the high sea. Local, like xe/rsw| 425.
me/n te: correl. with au)ta/r. cf. 442, *g 330, *l 476, 481, a 215.
koru/ssetai: lifts its head. Lit. puts on its crest, in which is contained another metaphor.
e)/peita: secondly, next.
424-426 are not necessary for the comparison, but give it great animation.
r(hgnu/menon: cf. Eng. ‘breaker,’ ‘Break, break, break.’
mega/la: cf. deino/n 420.
a)/kras: headlands. Cf. oi( de\ cu/nisan mega/lw| a)lalhtw=| (cf. 436).| ou)/te qala/sshs ku=ma to/son boa/a| poti\ xe/rson,| ponto/qen o)rnu/menon pnoih=| *bore/w a)legeinh=| *c 393 ff.
kurto/n: curved, beetling. Const. with i)o/n moving.
korufou=tai: towers aloft.
a)poptu/ei ktl.: the third scene in the life of the wave. cf. h)i/ones (shores) boo/wsin e)reugome/nhs (vomiting) a(lo\s e)/cw *r 265.
a(lo/s: salt sea.
*danaw=n: const. with fa/lagges.
ki/nunto: cf. 332.
oi(=sin: his own men. See on w(=n 306. cf. toi=sin e(/kastos a)nh\r shmaine/tw, oi(=si/ per a)/rxei *b 805.
e(/kastos: each leader acted independently. See on 304.
h(gemo/nwn: reserved for this place, in contrast with oi( d' a)/lloi, sc. *danaw=n.
i)/san: h)=|san, § 34 f.
ke fai/hs: you would have said. Cf. 223, 421, 3.220.
e(/pesqai e)/xonta: the partic. contains the principal idea, cf. e(sth/kasin memakui=ai 434 f.
sigh=|: resumes a)kh/n 429. In close connexion with deidio/tes, which gives the reason for the silence.

deidio/tes: agrees with oi( a)/lloi. The intervening clause is parenthetical. This verse indicates good discipline in the Achaean army. cf. oi( d' a)/r) i)/san sigh=| me/nea pnei/ontes *)axaioi/ *g 8, ou) ga\r kraugh=| a)lla\ sigh=| . . . kai\ h(suxh=| . . . prosh=|san Xen. An. i. 8. 11.
shma/ntoras: commanders. Cf. 2.805, quoted on 428.
a)mfi/: const. with pa=sin, “on the breasts of all.”

ta\ [a(\] ei(me/noi (e(/nnumi): qui bus induti. The hiatus is ‘apparent.’ § 14 a. For the acc. with the passive of a ‘verb of clothing,’ see 7.724 a. The second half-verse in each of the vs. 432-435 is nearly parenthetical.
At the opening of the Third Book, the Trojans are represented as advancing with the clamor of a flock of cranes, while the Achaeans met them in silence.

*trw=es: the principal subject, opposed to the Greeks. But the comparison is continued until the subj. is forgotten, and it is resumed in *trw/wn a)lalhto/s 436. For this change of const., cf. 5.135 f., 6.510 f., 15.271 ff., 17.755 ff., Od. 13.81 ff.
w(/s te: as. § 2 j. w(/ste, so that, is not Homeric.

polupa/monos (pa/omai): rich in possessions, wealthy. Cf. polukth/mwn *e 613. Wealth in the heroic times consisted chiefly in flocks and herds (cf. ‘chattel’ with ‘cattle’); secondarily in ornaments and clothing. Land seems to have been owned, partly in common and partly in severalty, but had no great value.
au)lh=|: farm-yard. Cf. 5.138. For comparisons following in quick succession, see § 2 g.
muri/ai: for the accent, see § 2 w.
a)melgo/menai: a-milking, yielding.
leuko/n: for the epithet, see § 1 p. It has nothing to do with the special circumstances of the case.

a)zhxe\s memakui=ai (mhka/omai): bears the weight of the comparison. The two other partics. are circumstantial, a)melgo/menai adding a detail to the picture, and a)kou/ousai giving the reason for memakui=ai. — Two examples of ‘apparent hiatus.’
*trw/wn: see on *trw=es 433.
a)lalhto/s: war-cry, slogan. a)lala/ and e)leleu= (both anapaests, ˘˘ <*>) corresponded nearly to ‘hurrah!’
a)na\ strato/n: the shout passed through the army.
o)rw/rein (o)/rnumi): cf. pefu/kein 109; see on h(/|rein 23.
qro/os: cry.
i)/a: one, the same. For the form, see § 23 a. For the meaning, cf. mi/a *g 238.

gh=rus: speech. Cf. polloi\ ga\r kata\ a)/stu me/ga *pria/mou e)pi/kouroi,| a)/llh d' a)/llwn glw=ssa poluspere/wn (widely scattered) a)nqrw/pwn *b 803 f. In these two passages the poet indicates more distinctly than elsewhere the consciousness of a difference of speech between the nations of the Trojan allies. But he nowhere intimates that the Trojans and Achaeans spoke different languages.
polu/klhtoi: called from many a land, of many nations.
e)/san: h)=san, § 34 g.
tou\s me/n: i.e. the Trojans.

*)/arhs: Ares was the national god of the Thracians, and came with them to the help of the Trojans. cf. 5.461 f., oi(=os de\ brotoloigo\s *)/arhs polemo/nde me/t- eisin,| tw=| de\ *fo/bos fi/los ui(o\s . . .| e(/speto: . . .| tw\ me\n a)/r' e)k *qrh/|khs ktl. *n 298 ff., Od. 8.361.

glaukw=pis: gleaming-eyed. A fitting epithet for the goddess of war. cf. deinw\ de/ oi( (i.e. Athena) o)/sse fa/anqen *a 200. Her epithet *palla/s belongs to her as the Lance-wielder (cf. pa/llw, *p 142). She is coupled with Ares also *e 430, *n 127 ff., 17.398. cf. *u 69, *f 391 ff.

*deimo\s ktl.: sc. w)=rsan. Poetic personifications. For *deimo/s and *fo/bos (Flight), see *l 37, *n 299 (see above, on 439), 15.119 (where they harness the horses of Ares). Acc. to Hesiod, Theog. 934, they are the sons of Ares and Aphrodite. cf. hic Mars omnipotens animum virisque Latinis| addidit . . .| immisitque Fugam Teucris atrumque Timorem Verg. Aen. ix. 717 ff.
*)/eris: is impartial. She enjoys the conflict for its own sake, and cares not who are victorious. cf. 5.518.
kasignh/th: i.e. as having the same character.

f. A vivid picture of the growth of strife from an insignificant beginning. This figure is transferred by Vergil to Fama: parva metu primo, mox sese attollit in auras| ingrediturque solo et caput inter nubila condit Aen. iv. 176 f. — cf. 424.
cf. ‘Satan alarmed| Collecting all his might dilated stood:| . . . His stature reached the sky, and on his crest| Sat Horror plumed,’ Milton Par. Lost iv. 985 ff.
ou)ranw=|: ‘dat. of approach.’ cf. ko/lpw| *z 136.
e)sth/rice: gnomic aor., side by side with the present. The pres. describes, while the aor. narrates.
kai/: and, “while.”
kai\ to/te: then too, as she had many times before.
o(moi/ion: see on 315.
kaq' o(/milon: see on 209.
o)fe/llousa: increasing, in order to increase. It expresses the purpose of e)rxome/nh.
446-456. Beginning of the general conflict.
This verse introduces the brief description of the general conflict.
oi( de/: i.e. Achaeans and Trojans.
e)s xw=ran ktl.: equiv. to o(mo/se e)xw/rhsan.
cunio/ntes: see on a)/gontes 392.
su/n: const. with e)/balon, dashed together, clashed.
r(inou/s: hides, i.e. shields. Equiv. to a)spi/des 448.
su\n de/: sc. e)/balon.
me/nea a)ndrw=n: the might of men. Cf. *e 506, nu\c e)lqou=sa diakrine/ei me/nos a)ndrw=n *b 387, d 363.
o)mfalo/essai: bossy. Some shields had a single o)mfalo/s or boss in the middle. Agamemnon's shield had twenty knobs of tin, and one of ku/anos, *l 34.
e)/plhnto (pela/zw): met.
pe/len: arose. Descriptive imperfect.

o)llu/ntwn ktl.: of the slaying and the slain. In appos. with a)ndrw=n, referring to oi)mwgh\ ktl. in ‘chiastic’ order, — eu)xwlh/ being connected with o)llu/ntwn, and oi)mwgh/ with o)llume/nwn. cf. ‘Of shout and scream the mingled din| And weapon-clash and maddening cry| Of those who kill and those who die,’ Scott Rokeby v. 31; pipto/ntwn sto/nos kai\ a)nairou/ntwn megalauxi/a Appian Bell. Pun. 45.

kat) o)/resfi [o)rw=n]: down from the mountains. For the form o)/resfi, see § 15 a. — cf. w(s d' o(po/te plh/qwn potamo\s pedi/onde ka/teisin| xeima/rrous kat) o)/resfin, o)pazo/menos *dio\s o)/mbrw| *l 492 f., aut rapidus montano flumine torrens| sternitagros, sternit sata lateta boumque labores| . . . stupet inscius alto| accipiens sonitum saxi de vertice pastor Verg. Aen. ii. 305 ff., ubi decursu rapido de mon tibus altis| dant sonitum spumosi amnes et in aequora currunt ib. xii. 523 f.

cumba/lleton: ind., since the short mode-vowel of the subjv. is rarely found in the present. § 27 c. Dual of the two torrents which come from different directions, and meet like two opposing armies. cf. su\n e)/balon 447.
Const. the second half-verse closely with the second half-verse of 453.
xara/drhs: gorge, chasm.

thlo/se: made more definite by e)n ou)/resin. Const. with e)/klue, heard to a great distance, instead of at a great distance. Cf. du/nasai de\ su\ pa/ntos' a)kou/ein *p 515, peu/qeto ga\r *ku/pronde me/ga kle/os *l 21.
dou=pon: in this din lies the point of comparison.
e)/klue: gnomic aorist.
poimh/n: see on 275.
cf. w(\s tw=n e)k nhw=n ge/neto i)axh/ te fo/bos te *p 366.
tw=n: of course not to be const. with misgome/nwn. Ablatival gen. with i)axh/. cf. klaggh\ ge/net' a)rgure/oio bioi=o *a 49.
misgome/nwn: as they came together. Pred. partic. with tw=n.
ge/neto: for the length of the ultima, see § 14 j; cf. me/ga i)/axon 506.
po/nos: see on poneu/menon 374.
457-544. A succession of single-combats. The Achaeans prevail until the Trojans are roused by Apollo.

The story of the Iliad is a story of strife between individuals or of the conflicts of small groups of men, — not of the strategical movements of large masses of troops. The common soldier is of very little consequence in any way before Troy. The battle is decided by a few mighty men of valor.
prw=tos: primus.

*)anti/loxos: a doughty son of Nestor, and special friend of Achilles. The youngest of the Greek leaders. cf. the words of Menelaus, *)anti/lox' ou)/ tis sei=o new/teros a)/llos *)axaiw=n,| ou)/te posi\n qa/sswn (swifter, taxu/s) ou)/t' a)/lkimos w(s su\ ma/xesqai *o 569 f. He was afterwards slain by the Aethiopian Memnon, acc. to Od. 4.187 f.
*trw/wn: const. with a)/ndra.
e(/len: took, i.e. slew. Equiv. to e)/kteine, e)/pefne, e)nh/rato, and e)na/rize.
korusth/n: equiv. to ai)xmhth/s, *e 197; a)spisth/s, 90; a)spidiw/ths, *b 554; qwrhkth/s, *m 317; Attic o(pli/ths.
*)exe/pwlon: a Sicyonian of this name is mentioned 23.296.
p(a/: “as I said,” marks this clause as a repetition of 457. cf. 398, 501, 5.79.
fa/lon: in appos. with to/n. See H. 625 c; cf. 350, o)/sse 461, sth=qos 480.
i(ppodasei/hs: cf. ippioxai/thn *z 469, i(ppo/komoi ko/ruqes *n 132, cristaque hirsutus equina Verg. Aen. x. 869.
ph=ce: sc. *)anti/loxos e)/gxos.
o)ste/on ei)/sw: much like ei)s o)ste/on, although strictly ei)/sw is adv., and o)ste/on is acc. of ‘limit of motion.’ cf. *)/ilion ei)/sw *a 71.
ai)xmh/: spear-point.

to\n de\ ktl.: the poet has a large variety of expressions for death. cf. 469 f., 482, 504, 517, 522 f., 531, 5.47, 68, 75, 82 f, 155, 163 f., 166, 190, 250, 296, 310, 553, 654, 659, 696. See on e(/len 457.
sko/tos: of the darkness or night of death. cf. 5.47, 68, 82 f., 310, 659, 696, also in aeternam clauduntur lumina noctem Verg. Aen. x. 746.
o)/sse: see on fa/lon 459.
h)/ripe: from e)rei/pw.
w(s o(/te: see on 141.
w(s o(/te pu/rgos: sc. in respect to size. cf. (*ai)/as) fe/rwn sa/kos h)u/te pu/rgon *h 219.
podw=n: see on xeiro/s 154.
e(/lke: mark the change to the impf., of continued, attempted, action.
u(pe\k bele/wn: out from under the shower of missiles. e)k bele/wn, *c 130, is out of the range of missiles.
lelihme/nos: eagerly.
mi/nunqa: short-lived. Cf. 478. For an adv. with ge/neto, cf. ai)=sa mi/nunqa/ per, ou)/ ti ma/la dh/n *a 416, w(/s 319, ou)d' a)/r) e)/ti dh\n h)=n *z 139 f.
oi(=: dat. of interest, his attempt.
nekro/n: obj. of e)ru/onta, which agrees with the obj. of i)dw/n.
*)agh/nwr: son of Antenor. One of the bravest of the Trojans. cf. *l 59, *f 545 ff.
pleura/: pl. of the whole side (ribs). cf. to/ca *e 215, o)/xea *e 745, nw=ta (back) *b 308, pro/swpa (face) 18.414. For the inflexion, instead of pleurai/, cf. neu=ra 122.

par' a)spi/dos ktl.: appeared from beside the shield, i.e. from under cover of the shield. cf. *mene/laos a)rh/ios ou)=ta *qo/anta| ste/rnon gumnwqe/nta par' a)spi/da, lu=se de\ gui=a *p 311 f., par' a)spi/dos gumnwqe\n a(rpa/sai do/ru Aesch. Septem 607. — e)cefaa/nqh [e)cefa/nh]: from e)kfaei/nw.
custw=|: strictly, spear-shaft, then spear.
to\n me/n: i.e. Elephenor.
li/pe qumo/s: his life left. Cf. qumou= deuome/nous *g 294, li/pe d' o)ste/a qumo/s *m 386, peso/nta de/ min li/pe qumo/s *p 410. cf. also 524, *e 685, to/n ge li/ph| yuxh/ te kai\ ai)w/n *p 453.
e)p' au)tw=|: over the man himself, i.e. over his body, in contrast with the departed qumo/s. See on au)tou= 11.
de/: for its position, see on 96.
e)/rgon: like po/nos (see on poneu/menon 374), chiefly of the toil of war. cf. 539, 6.522.
e)tu/xqh: from teu/xw.
lukoi\ w(/s: like wolves, sc. in fury. cf. *l 72, *p 156 ff., 352 ff.
w(/s: meaning as always follows its noun in Homer, and has the acute (or grave) accent. cf. 482.
a)nh\r a)/ndra: a poetic a)llh/lous. cf. soi\ kai\ e)moi/ 38.
e)dnopa/lizen: shook. Prob. a metaphor from wrestling. — cf. implicuere inter se acies legitque virum vir Verg. Aen. xi. 632.
ui(o/n: the i of the diphthong has passed into the y- sound, and disappeared. See § 5 g; cf. *z 130. u(o/s is freq. in Attic inscriptions.
*simoei/sion: named from the river Simoïs, as *)idai=os, *e 11, from Mt. Ida; *skama/ndrios, *e 49, from the Scamander, and *sa/tnios, *c 443, from the Satnioïs.
*)/idhqen: for Trojan herds and flocks on the slopes of Mt. Ida, cf. 2.821 and *e 313, *z 25, *l. 105 f., *u 91, *w 29.
katiou=sa: from ka/teimi.

*simo/entos: cf. *e 774, kai\ *simo/eis o(/qi polla\ boa/gria (scuta virum) kai\ trufa/leiai (galeasque)| ka/ppeson e)n koni/h|si kai\ h(miqe/wn ge/nos a)ndrw=n (fortia corpora) 12.22 f., Verg. Aen. i. 100 f.
tou/neka: tou= e(/neka, § 8.
ka/leon: sc. tokh=es of the child's mother.

qre/ptra (tre/fw): formed like lu/tra, loetra/. G. 129, 5; H. 554. Attic trofei=a, Lat. alimenta. Const. with a)pe/dwke, repaid the loving care. Cf. 17.301. Neglect of duty towards parents, acc. to Hesiod, is a crying sin of the ‘Iron age,’ ou)de/ ken oi(/ ge| ghra/ntessi (cf. gh=ras) tokeu=sin a)po\ qrepth/ria doi=en, Opera 187 f.
u(po/: const. with doupi/. § 3 h g.
dame/nti: agrees with oi(= 478.
prw=ton: masc., pred. with i)o/nta. “As he came first,” i.e. e)n proma/xois.
sth=qos: see on fa/lon 459.
para\ mazo/n: by the nipple. Cf. *q 121, 313, *o 577, *r 606, x 82.

a)ntikru/s: explained by di) w)/mou, which follows in a kind of apposition. See on pa/lin 214, thlo/se 455. cf. 500, 5.67, 74, 189, 687. Similarly, e)n koni/h|si 482 is repeated by xamai/, after the verse-pause.
xamai/: xama=ze to the ground might be expected, but this, like e)n koni/h|si, has ‘reference to the state of rest which follows the motion.’ G. 191 N. 6; H. 788.
ai)/geiros w(/s: i.e. tall, stretched on the ground. cf. 5.560. The final syllable of ai)/geiros is long by ‘position,’ because w(/s originally had an initial consonant (prob. *v).
ei(amenh=|: lowlands.
e(/leos: mead. Gen. of ‘the place to which the action belongs.’ cf. pedi/oio 244. e(/los is not swamp, marsh in Homer.
pefu/kh|: for the subjv. in comparisons, cf. e)e/rgh| 131, mih/nh| 141.

lei/h: lēvis, smooth. Cf. leih/nas 111. sc. ta\ me\n a)/lla, explained by the rest of the verse. Perhaps the lower branches and twigs had been cut off as fodder for goats. For the position of lei/h, cf. h(gemo/nwn 429.
e)pi/: const. with pefu/asin, have grown upon, are upon.
a)krota/th|: const. with oi(=.
th/n: dem. after a cond. rel. clause. cf. *e 139, *f 260, *y 519.
a(rmatophgo\s a)nh/r: chariot-maker. For the combination of nouns, cf. a)nh\r boulhfo/ros *a 144, xalkh=es a)/ndres 187, te/ktones a)/ndres *z 315.
ai)/qwni: shining, of the well-sharpened and worn ax.
sidh/rw|: here of the ax, as in 123 for arrow-point.
e)ce/tame (e)kte/mnw): fells. Gnomic.

i)/tun: felloe. The soft wood of the poplar could easily be bent and fashioned. In itself, it would not seem well adapted to the service here indicated, but perhaps it was sufficiently strengthened by the bronze ‘tire’ (e)pi/sswtra *e 725). — ‘Acc. of effect’ with ka/myh|. G. 159 N. 3; H. 714.
ka/myh|: Subjv., although after e)/tame, since the gnomic aor. is grammatically equiv. to a present. cf. 443, 5.524.
a)zome/nh: drying, seasoning, as the wood must before it is fit for use.
par' o)/xqas: along the bank. Cf. 6.34.
toi=on a)/ra: so then, resumes 482. cf. toi=ai 280.
*)avqemi/dhn: *)anqemioni/dhn would be expected, cf. 473. See § 21 e.
tou=: i.e. Ajax. Gen. with a)ko/ntisen. cf. *menela/ou 100.
*)/antifos: slain by Agamemnon, 11.101 ff.
ai)oloqw/rhc: cf. zwsth\r panai/olos 186, ai)olomi/trhn *e 707.
kaq' o(/milon: cf. 126.
doupi/: ‘dat. of instrument.’ Of course the acc. might have been used.
For the asyndeton, cf. 5.657.
tou= ktl.: him he missed.
o( de/: emphatic repetition of the preceding subject. cf. 1.191.
beblh/kei: plpf. of the immediate result of his action. cf. bebh/kein *z 495.
e(te/rwse: i.e. to the Achaean side.
e)ru/onta: cf. 467. The rhythm of the verse aids greatly, as it often does, in marking the true construction.
a)mf' au)tw=|: i.e. over the very corpse which he was trying to drag away that he might strip off the armor. cf. 470, 5.299.
tou=: causal gen. with xolw/qh. See on a)pa/ths 168.
*)oduseu/s: for the loss of a d, see § 41 vh; cf. *)axileu/s 512.
qumo/n: cf. kh=r 272.
a)poktame/noio: const. closely with tou=, because of his death. For the mid. aor. used as passive, see on blh=sqai 115.
xolw/qh: the mid. is used without difference of meaning in 501. § 32 d.
kekoruqme/nos: armed. For q before m, see § 12 d.
496 = *e 611, *r 347; cf. *l 577, *n 183, 403, 516. — sth= [e)/sth]: inceptive, took his stand.
ma/l' e)ggu/s: sc. *leu/kou.
i)w/n: see on a)/gontes 392.
faeivw=|: this epithet is due to the bronze point (ai)xmh/, cf. 6.319 f.) and butt (saurwth/r, *k 153).
a)mfi\ e(/: about him.
u(po/: const. with keka/donto. This is made more definite by a)ndro\s ktl.
keka/donto (xa/zomai): for the reduplication, see § 25.
a)ndro/s: for the ablatival gen., see § 3 f b.
ou)x: const. closely with a(/lion. cf. 5.18. ‘Litotes.’ § 2 g.
Democoön evidently had charge of his father's stock-farm at Abydus.
o(/s oi(: for the ‘quantity’ of o(/s, see § 41 m; cf. me/n 18.
par' i(/ppwn: in appos. with *)abudo/qen. See on a)ntikru/s 481.
r(a/: see on r(a/ 459. — e(ta/roio [e(tai/rou]: for the gen., cf. tou= 494. For the a^, see § 5 h.
ko/rshn: equiv. to kro/tafon. This comes with emphasis at the close of the sent., and in close connexion with the rest of the verse.
h(: refers to douri/, but the poet already has in mind ai)xmh/, which follows in apposition.
504 = *e 42, 540, *n 187, *r 50, 311, w 525; cf. 5.58. cf. corruit in volnus, sonitum super arma dedere Verg. Aen. x. 488.
e)p' au)tw=|: cf. 470.
u(po/: before him. Const. with xw/rhsan. cf. u(po\ keka/donto 497. u)po/ does not suffer ‘anastrophe’ here, since it does not immediately follow the word to which it belongs.
te/: is expected after pro/maxoi. For the freedom of position, cf. a(/ma t' w)ku/moros kai\ o)izuro/s *a 417.

fai/dimos *(/ektwr: the poet does not imply that Hector was not one of the pro/maxoi, but rather that he is the most distinguished of them. cf. *zeu\s d' e)pei\ ou)=n *trw=a/s te kai\ *(/ektora nhusi\ pe/lassen *n 1, ‘Peter and the apostles’ Acts v. 29.
me/ga: cognate accusative. For the length of the ‘ultima,’ see on ge/neto 456.
e)ru/santo: contrast with the pres. e)ru/onta 492.
neme/shse: inceptive. “Indignation seized him” at the retreat of the Trojans.
*perga/mou: i.e. from his temple on the citadel. cf. *e 446, *h 83, *z 297. This temple was one of Apollo's homes, and from it he looked forth on the field of battle. cf. *e 460, *h 21.
ke/kleto (ke/lomai): for the reduplication, cf. keka/donto 497.
a)u/sas: much like fwnh/sas 284, but implying more noise and effort.
o)/rnusqe: rouse yourselves. Cf. *e 102, *m 440, *y 707.
xa/rmhs: for the gen., cf. a)lkh=s 234, pole/moio 240, *e 348.
*)argei/ois: for the Argives, before the Argives.
ou): emphatic by its position. “By no means.”
li/qos: stone, of stone.
xrw/s: subject. — cf. kai\ ga/r qhn tou/tw| (i.e. Achilles) trwto\s (may be wounded) xrw\s o)ce/i xalkw=| *f 568.
a)nasxe/sqai (a)ne/xw): “so that they could endure without hurt.”
tamesi/xroa (te/mnw, xrw/s): cf. 23.803.
ballome/nolsin: const. with sfi/, when they are hit.
ou) ma\n ou)de/: no indeed, nor.
*)axileu\s ktl.: cf. 16.860. For the form with one l, see on *)oduseu/s 494.
e)pi\ nhusi/: i.e. in the camp.
pe/ssei: digests, broods over. Cf. *a 81, *b 237, qew=n e)k kh/dea pe/ssei *w 617, kh/dea muri/a pe/ssw *w 639.
pto/lios: equiv. to a)kropo/lews. cf. e)n po/lei a)/krh| *z 297.
w)=rse: cf. 439.

*tritoge/neia: Trito-born. Whether this means ‘born on the banks of the Trito,’ a Boeotian stream, or ‘born of Trito,’ no one can say. Homer nowhere shows acquaintance with the myth of Athena in full armor springing from the head of Zeus, nor does he assign any mother to the goddess. cf. 5.875, 880.
e)rxome/nh: pres., of a continued act. cf. 445.
meqie/ntas ktl.: cf. 240, 351.
*diw/rea: an Epean leader, cf. 2.622.
moi=ra ktl.: sc. damh=nai. Fate fettered him, i.e. compelled him to meet this peril which brought him death. cf. *e 83, 613, 629, *t 87, *f 83, l 292.

xermadi/w|: possibly a stone from a sling, though the sling is mentioned but once in Homer (13.600). The heroes threw stones in general only when for some reason they could not use spear or sword. cf. *e 302, *q 321, *m 380, *p 735, *u 285.
blh=to: see on blh=sqai 115.
knh/mhn: the active const. would be e)/bale *diw/rea knh/mhn, and when the passive const. is used the acc. of the part remains unchanged. cf. H. 725 c.
*qrh|kw=n: European Thracians, living between the Hebrus and the Hellespont.
*pei/roos: cf. 2.844.
*ai)no/qen: from Aenus, at the mouth of the Hebrus.
a)mfote/rw te/nonte: the poet thought of the sinews as working in pairs.

a)naidh/s: shameless, heartless, pitiless. For the personification, cf. 5.593, *n 139, au)=tis e)/peita pe/donde kuli/ndeto la=as a)naidh/s l 598, of the stone which Sisyphus was engaged in rolling up hill in Hades, qa/natos a)naidh/s Theognis 207. See on 126.
a)/xpis: adv., completely.
u(/ptios: supinus. cf. 108, prhne/es 544.
ka/ppesen: kate/pesen.
xei=re: arms. Cf. *e 81, *z 482.
e(ta/roisi: to his comrades, as appealing for help. For the dat., cf. ou)ranw=| 443, pedi/w| *e 82, h)e/ri *e 356, li/mnh| *e 709.
qumo/n: cf. 470.
a/popnei/wn: for the form, cf. veikei/eske 241.
pe/r: gives emphasis to e)/balen.
ou)=ta: 2d aorist. § 35.
par' o)mfalo/n: cf. para\ mazo/n 480.
d' a)/ra: and so.
xu/nto: aor. mid. as passive. cf. blh=to 518.
xamai/: cf. 482.
xola/des: i.e. ta\ e)/ntera. — For the ‘alliteration’ (x) cf. 339.
to\n de\ ktl.: cf. 461.
to/n: i.e. Diores.
to/n: i.e. Piroüs.
a)pessu/menon (a\poseu/w): as he rushed away. He started back, without turning around. For the ss, see § 12 b.
pa/gh ktl.: cf. 185, *e 616, *u 486. The wounds in Homer are either very slight or (for the most part) fatal. The region of the heart does not seem to have been considered especially vital.
e)k: const. with e)spa/sato.
e)spa/sato: sc. a)risterh=|. cf. *e 621, *z 65.

e)ru/ssato ci/fos: drew his sword, sc. deciterh=|. The mid. voice of the verb (like the dat. of interest, see § 3 g) freq. expresses the idea of personal interest which may be rendered by the possessive pronoun. cf. *m 190, *c 496, *u 284, *f 116, 200, *x 306, 367.
tw=|: instrumental, with this.
peri/sthsan: 2d aor. intrans.

a)kro/komoi: i.e. their hair was bound in a knot on top of the head, perhaps like that of the American Indians. cf. apud Suevos, usquead canitiem, horrentem capillum retro sequuntur, ac saepe in ipso solo vertice religant Tac. Germ. 38. See on 2.11.
534 = 5.625. — The repetition of kai/ brings each epithet into bold relief, in contrast with w)=san. “Although he was tall and mighty.”
sfei/wn: sfe/wn, sfw=n au)tw=n.
xassa/menos: yielded and. Cf. u(po\ keka/donto 497.
teta/sqhn (tei/nw): lay stretched. Plpf. of a continued state. cf. 544.
o( me/n: i.e. *pei/roos 520.
o( de/: i.e. *diw/rhs 517.
h(gemo/nes: for its position, cf. h(gemo/nwn 429.
periktei/nonto: for the use of the prep., cf. *z 419, *m 245.
ou)ke/ti: no longer, as perhaps might have been the case before. The conflict has become more fierce and bloody.
o)no/saito: potential of the past. cf. 223. o)/nomai in Homer is not simply blame, find fault with, but find fault with as insufficient. Cf. *n 127, 287, *r 399, *w 241.
metelqw/n: if he had come among them. This specification adds life to the picture.

a)/blhtos (ba/llw), a)nou/tatos (ou)ta/w): nec eminus nec cominus ictus, “unhit by an arrow, and unhurt by sword or spear.” i.e. if one could look on without danger, — but no one would be safe on such a field except under the special protection of the mighty goddess of war. — cf. suave etiam belli certamina magna tueri| per campos instructa, tua sine parte pericli Lucretius, ii. 5 f.
kata\ me/sson: cf. 79, 5.8.
a)/goi de/: the rel. const. is abandoned. The condition assumed for dineu/oi is stated in an independent form. cf. *a 10, *z 480.
xeiro/s: by the hand. Cf. podw=n 463.
e/lou=sa: the following hiatus is excused by the pause.
bele/wn ktl.: cf. 17.562.
ga/r: refers to o)no/saito 539.
h)/mati kei/nw|: dat. of time without e)n. G. 189; H. 782.
prhne/es: proni. cf. *b 418, *p 379. The opposite of u(/ptios, 522, which is used only of single individuals, except 11.179.

div.head: Book 5 (*e)
div.p: The battle which was begun in the Fourth Book, on the 22d day of the action of the Iliad, is continued through the Fifth and Sixth Books, and this day ends with 7.380.

The connexion between the two books is close. The Fourth Book has prepared the way for the conflicts of the Fifth Book; and Pandarus, who broke the truce, 4.93 ff., pays the penalty for his treachery by his death at 5.290 ff.

The subject of the Fifth Book is announced at once, — the ‘Bravery of Diomed’ of Argos. The poet has prepared the way for this ‘Bravery’ by the scene at the close of the *)epipw/lhsis, *d 419 ff. The valor which Agamemnon doubted, 4.370 ff., is now manifested by mighty deeds.

The Greek title, *diomh/dous a)ristei/a, in classical times covered not only the Fifth Book, but also a considerable part of the Sixth Book. See Hdt. ii. *i *i 6, where 6.289-292 is quoted as found e)n *diomhde/os a)ristei/h|.
1-453. The Achaeans press forward victoriously.
1-94. Valorous deeds of the still unwounded Diomed.
e)/nq' au)=: but then. The transition to a new scene involves a sort of contrast with what has preceded. cf. 471, *m 182, *p 477. cf. also e)/nq' au)=te 541, *z 234.
au)=: here nearly equiv. to de/.

*palla\s *)aqh/nh: this goddess of war (cf. pa/llw brandish) had roused the Argives, 4.439, 515. She now reappears suddenly, without any information as to where she has been or what she has been doing. cf. the interpositions of Hephaestus, 23, of Aphrodite, 312, and of Apollo, 344. Athena had always cared for Tydeus (cf. 800 ff. and 4.390), and his son Diomed was one of her chief favorites.
me/nos: here seems to refer to physical might.
e)/kdhlos: conspicuous. Cf. e)kpaifa/ssein 803, e)kprepe/) e)n polloi=si kai\ e)/coxon h(rw/essin *b 483 (of Agamemnon).
*)argei/oisi: in appos. with pa=sin, rather than dat. with meta/. § 1 g.
ge/noito: for the following ‘hiatus,’ see on 4.147.
kle/os ktl.: cf. *s 121, n 422.
a)/roito: cf. 4.95.
Obs. the ‘asyndeton.’
dai=e/ oi(: kindled for him. dai=e is trans., as *i 211, *s 206, 227, h 7. cf. 7.

a)ka/maton: unwearying. A standing epithet. — cf. ardet apex capiti cristisque a vertice flamma| funditur et vastos umbo vomit aureus ignis.| non secus ac liquida si quando nocte cometac| sanguinei lugubre rubent aut Sirius ardor Verg. Aen. x. 270 ff.

a)ste/ri ktl.: i.e. *sei/rios or the Dogstar. cf. 22.26 ff., where it is called ku/n' *)wri/wnos. Its ‘heliacal rising,’ about the middle of July, marked the height of o)pw/ra. The fruit season naturally comes much earlier in Greece than in the northern states of America or in England. Homer seems to know primarily but three seasons, — e)a/r (from about the middle of February), o)pw/rh (from about the summer solstice), and xeimw/n (from the latter part of October). Summer, in contrast to winter, is called qe/ros, and sometimes qe/ros may be the early summer and o)pw/rh the late summer. Of course, the bounds of the seasons were not definitely fixed. Aeschylus speaks of ‘winter,’ ‘flowery spring,’ and ‘fruitful summer’ (qe/ros), Prom. 454 ff.
o)pwrinw=|: cf. (a)ste/ri) o(/s r(a/ t' o)pw/rhs ei)=sin *x 27.
o(/s te: “when it.”
lampro/n: for the cognate acc. used adverbially, cf. deino/n *d 420.
pamfai/nh|si: for the subjv. without a)/n in a general hypothetical sent., see on e)e/rgh| *d 131.
leloume/nos ktl.: cf. a)/rkton q' , h(\n kai\ a)/macan e)pi/klhsin kale/ousin| . . . oi)/h d) a)/mmoro/s e)sti loetrw=n *)wkeanoi=o e 273 ff.
*)wkeanoi=o: gen. of place. G. 179, 2; H. 760. cf. 6.508.
This verse resumes and repeats 4, after the comparison.
toi=on: the ultima is long by ‘position.’ § 41 m.
a)po\ ktl.: cf. *r 205, k 362.
w)/mwn: corresponds to a)spi/dos 4, as krato/s to ko/ruqos. cf. tou= d' a)po\ me\n kefalh=s ko/ruq) ei(/leto kai\ sa/kos w)/mwn *o 125.
kata\ me/sson: i.e. between the two armies.
o(/qi ktl.: “in the thickest throng.” cf. 93, *l 148, *o 448, *f 528, *d 302.
h)=n de/ tis: a favorite beginning of an Epic story. cf. *z 152, *b 811, urbs antiqua fuit Verg. Aen. i. 12.

*da/rhs: later ages made this Dares the teacher of Hector, and the author of a ‘Phrygian Iliad,’ older than Homer. Aelian V. H. xi. 2. The Latin work which purports to be a translation of that of Dares, is doubtless only a few centuries old.
a)fneio/s: rich, like the priest at Ismarus, Od. 9.201 ff.
a)mu/mwn: see on 4.89.

i(reu/s: no priests are mentioned in the Greek camp. Each was at tached to a special sanctuary, which he could not leave. The prayers and sacrifices for the army were offered by the king. See on 1.62.

*(hfai/stoio: Hephaestus and Athena (6.88, 269, 297) were worshipped in Troy, although they opposed the Trojans in their conflicts with the Greeks (20.33 ff.). The Trojans in general adored the same divinities (Zeus, Apollo, Aphrodite, etc.) as the Greeks, just as they do not seem to have been distinguished by dress or custom. The poet, indeed, nowhere indicates a difference even in language; Greeks and Trojans converse together with perfect freedom.
h)/sthn (ei)mi/): only here in dual. Elsewhere h)=san even after du/w. cf. 4.393.
*)idai=os: named from Mt. Ida, like his ‘homonym’ the herald Idaeus (3.248). See on 4.474.
ma/xhs: for the gen., see on to/cwn *d 196.
oi=: i.e. Diomed. Const. with e)nanti/w. See G. 186; H. 772.
a)pokrinqe/nte: separated, sc. from their companions. Their chariot was in advance of the Trojan line. This was careless; cf. 4.303 ff. — The following ‘hiatus’ is justified by the verse-pause.
e)nanti/w: “to meet him.” Predicate. cf. 497, a)nti/os h)=lqe qe/wn *z 54, a)nti/oi e)/stan a(/pantes *a 535.

a)f' i(/ppoiin: for the const., see on 4.306. The convenience of the verse determined the use of the dual; the poet did not care to lay stress upon the exact number of the horses here any more than in 19. — The ultima of i(/ppoiin is treated as long before the verse-pause. § 41 p.
a)po\ xqono\s ktl.: on the analogy of a)f' i(/ppoiin. Diomed dismounted from his chariot at 4.419.
pezo/s: on foot. Predicate. § 38 a.
14 = *g 15, *e 630, 850, *z 121, *l 232, *n 604, *p 462, *u 176, *f 148, *x 248, *y 816. A formula to introduce the single combat of two warriors.
sxedo/n: for the use of an adv. with h)=san, see on a)ke/wn *d 22; § 3 j.
e)p' a)llh/loisin: const. with i)o/ntes. For the idea of hostility in e)pi/ (upon), see § 3 h b.
pro/teros: sc. *diomh/dous. cf. u(/steros 17.
proi+/ei ktl.: cf. 3.346.
16-18 = 16.478-480 (with *pa/troklos for *tudei+/dhs).
*tudei+/dew [*tudei/dou]: const. with w)=mon, as is indicated by the rhythm as well as by the sense.
au)to/n: certainly very much like the Attic use as a personal pron., him; though some would translate himself, and find a contrast with the spear.
*tudei+/dhs: clearly in appos. with d. cf. 4.20, and see § 24 k.
ou)x a(/lion: see on 4.498. But here the verse-pause, following ou)x, gives it emphasis in contrast with the action of Phegeus.

metama/zion: strictly an adj. with sth=qos, — but half in appos. with it, since it is separated from it by the verse-pause. Equiv. to metacu\ tw=n mazw=n. cf. e)pomfa/lion *h 267 (equiv. to e)p' o)mfalw=|), e)pixqoni/wn *d 45 (equiv. to e)pi\ xqoni/), e)fe/stioi *b 125 (which is explained by oi(\ vai/ousi kata\ pto/lin, equiv. to e)f' e(sti/a|). In general, ‘adjectives formed from a prep. and a subst. are equiv. to the prep. and the substantive.’ — cf. 4.480.
w)=se: sc. by the cast of his spear. cf. 11.143, 320.
a)f' i(/ppwn: equiv. to e)c o)xe/wn. See on 111.
*)idai=os: here served as charioteer.

a)po/rouse: sprang down. This is explained in the second half-verse. cf. a)no/rousen . . . lipw\n e(/dos *i 193 f. — cf. ‘And the Lord discomfited Sisera, and all his chariots, and all his host, . . . so that Sisera lighted down off his chariot, and fled away on his feet,’ Judges iv. 15.
e)/tlh: did he have the heart.

peribh=nai: take his stand over. Cf. a)mfi\ bai=ne 299, o(\s *xru/shn a)mfibe/bhkas *a 37. The figure is taken from a beast standing over (bestriding) her young. cf. a)mfi\ d' a)/r) au)tw=| bai=n), w(/s tis peri\ po/rtaki (calf) mh/thr *r 4.
a)delfeiou= [a)delfou=] ktame/noio: his slain brother. For the aor. mid. used as passive, see on 4.115.

ou)de\ ktl.: cf. 2.703, 726. The first neg. belongs to the whole sentence; the second is const. closely with au)to/s. — This fact as stated by the poet was also the prevailing motive in the mind of Idaeus when he left his brother.
me/lainan: see on 4.461.
a)lla/: ei) mh/ would have been regular.
*(/hfaistos: in general, this god aided the Achaeans, but he saves Idaeus because of the services of the warrior's father. cf. 10 f. — The second half-verse explains and amplifies e)/ruto.
w(s dh/: namely in order that.
oi(=: i.e. Hephaestus. Ethical dative.
a)kaxh/menos: for the accent, see § 31 e.
i(/ppous: strongly contrasted with the warriors.
e)cela/sas: sc. out of the throng of combatants.

kata/gein: to lead down, to lead back. Inf. of purpose. The coast was thought of as lower both than the ‘high seas’ and the inland plain. In most districts of Greece the ground rises rapidly from the sea.
e)pi\ nh=as: equiv. to e)s strato/n. The ships drawn up on shore were such a prominent part of the Greek camp that ‘to the ships’ often means ‘to the tents.’
*trw=es: the form of the sent. seems to be changed. See on 4.433. Or, this prominent word is placed before e)pei/ which strictly should begin the clause. cf. 6.237; see § 1 k.
ui(=e: object; at once divided into to\n me/n, to\n de/.
to\n me/n: i.e. Idaeus.
a)leua/menon: taking to flight. Coincident in time with i)/don. For the form, see § 30 i.
kta/menon: slain.
par' o)/xesfin: by the empty chariot.
o)/xesfin: for the form, cf. sth/qesfin 41, and see § 15 a.
pa=sin ktl.: cf. *p 280, *s 223. See on 4.208. Here the Trojans are stimulated to fear and flight.

a)ta\r ktl.: Athena plots to remove Ares, the friend of the Trojans (see on 4.439), from the field of battle, in order to give free course to her favorite, Diomed. This action of Athena is not wholly satisfactory, however, since she is everywhere represented as far mightier than Ares, and after a time she aids Diomed in wounding Ares and driving him from the field, 827-867.
xeiro/s: for the gen., cf. 4.154.

*)=ares, *)/ares: this verse is often quoted for the change of quantity in the penult of this name. See § 41 f b. Nowhere else in Homer is a word repeated immediately. Euripides and the Latin poets were rather fond of such repetition. ‘O Postume, Postume.’ — For the epithets without conj., see § 1 n, o. ‘The epithets paint three stages of war: attack, death, storming of the city.’

ou)k a)\n dh\ ktl.: should we not, etc., “shall we not,” etc. A question in the sense of an exhortation. “Let us suffer these mortals” etc. Cf. ou)k a)\n dh\ mei/neias a)rhi/filon *mene/laon *g 52. Corresponding to this, is the use of the hortatory subjv. in the second clause, 34.
*trw=as me/n: correl. with nw=i de/ 34.
ma/rnasqai: for the elision of ai in verb-endings, see § 10 a.
o(ppote/roisi: indir. question, as if ‘caring little’ had preceded.
o)re/ch|: subjv., nearly as future. § 3 b.
xazw/mesqa: for the ending, see § 26 s.

*dio\s ktl.: Athena can hardly be in earnest here, since only at the beginning of *q does Zeus forbid the gods to take part in the conflicts. This is only a pretext, but Ares seems to be persuaded that he must not interfere with whatever plans Zeus has in mind.
cf. 18.389. Athena returns to Diomed at 121. Ares does not take part in the fight again until 461. He now is seated on the left of the battle which rages between the Scamander and the Simoïs.
kaqei=sen: generally treated as aor. of kaqi/zw seat.

h)io/enti: high-banked. Cf. ai)pa\ r(e/eqra (*skama/ndrou) *f 9, u(po\ krhmnou/s *f 26, u(yhlh\n ba/len o)/xqhn *f 171, o)/xqas pa\r potamoi=o *skama/ndrou *l 499. — For the short vowel before *sk, see § 41 i. e.
37-83. Six Greek leaders slay each a man.
e)/klinan: turned to flight. The connexion makes this appear the immediate result of the withdrawal of Ares, but Diomed had been successful before too; cf. 27 ff.
e(/le: slew. Cf. 576; see on 4.457.
h(gemo/nwn: added as a sort of after-thought, limiting the too broad e(/kastos.
*)odi/on: cf. 2.856 f.
prw/tw|: sc. *)odi/w|. Dat. of interest with ph=cen.
strefqe/nti: just as he turned. Circumstantial participle.
metafre/nw|: local dat. with e)n ph=cen. cf. 8.95, *o 650, *x 283. Obs. the force of the verse-pause, indicating the right const. at the first glance.
ph=cen: sc. *)agame/mnwn.
41 = 57, *q 259, *l 448, x 93. — sth/qesfin [sthqe/wn]: see on o)/xesfin 28.
e)/lassen: sc. do/ru as object.
See on 4.504.
d: a)/ra: but next, referring to prw=tos 38. For this use of a)/ra to mark the continuation of a series, cf. 2.522. — Phaestus and his father are mentioned only here.
e)nh/rato (e)nai/rw, e)/nara spoils): despoiled, i.e. slew.
*mh/|onos: for the Maeonians (later called Lydians) in Homer, see on 2.864. The skill of Maeonian women is indicated in 4.141 f.
o(/s: refers to *fai=ston. See on 60.
*ta/rnhs: said by a scholiast to be the site of the later Sardis, in Lydia, on the Tmolus.
ei)lhlou/qein: e)lhlu/qei. cf. 204, 4.520.
nu/ce: from nu/ssw pierce, wound.

e)pibhso/menon: as he mounted. For the aor., cf. strefqe/nti 40. For the ‘variable vowel,’ see § 30 j. — Phaestus had dismounted, as was frequent or usual, in order to fight on foot; but now he leaps into his chariot in order to flee. See on 4.419, 229.
h)/ripe: cf. 4.462.
stugero\s ktl.: cf. *n 672, *p 607. See on 4.461.
su/leuon: only here of despoiling a slain enemy.
qera/pontes: attendants, comrades.
Strophius and his son do not appear elsewhere.
*skama/ndrion: for the name, see on 4.474.
ai(/mona: skilled. For the following gen., see on ma/xhs 11.
*mene/laos: Menelaus evidently is able to fight, in spite of his wound at 4.139 f.
o)cuo/enti (o)cu/s): sharppointed, keen.

di/dace ktl.: all unusual skill was to the mind of the poet the direct (au)th/) gift of some divinity. cf. mantosu/nhn h(/n oi( po/re *foi=bos *)apo/llwn *a 72, *pa/ndaros w(=| kai\ to/con *)apo/llwn au)to\s e)/dwken *b 827, dw=ken *)aqh/nh| e)/rga t' e)pi/stasqai perikalle/a b 116 f.
pa/nta: all, all kinds of. The poet assumed all ordinary limitations. cf. 60.
ou)/resin: local, on the mountains.
to/te: receives emphasis from the verse-pause as well as from ge/. cf. 6.16.
xrai=sme: helped, availed Cf. 1.28, 589. Always in a negative sentence.
i)oxe/aira (i)o/s, xe/w): who showers arrows, “the archer goddess.” cf. be/lea xe/onto *q 159.
e(khboli/ai: his long-shots. For the pl., cf. a)nalkei/h|si *z 74. See on 1.205.
to\ pri/n ge: in former days. Cf. *n 105, *p 208, fre/nes h(=|s to\ pa/ros per| e)/kleo *w 201.
ke/kasto: from kai/numai (kad) excel. Cf. (*telamw/nios *ai)/as) e)gxei/h| d' e)ke/kasto *b 530.
mi/n: obj. of ou)/tase. meta/frenon below resumes mi/n, and is in partitive appos. with it.
pro/sqen e(/qen: before him(self). cf. 80.
e(/qen: ou(=. §§ 15 e, 24 a. Used 18 times in Homer; more freq. than e(/o or eu(=.
prhnh/s: pronus. For the pred. adj., cf. 4.544. See § 38 a.
*mhrio/nhs: the attendant and associate of Idomeneus. See 4.254.
*fe/reklon: a short form of *fereklh=s. cf. *pa/troklos, which has forms from *patrokle/hs. See on *sqe/nelon *d 367.

*te/ktonos: unless this name is freely invented to suit the situation (Carpenter, son of Joiner), as is entirely reasonable, it would imply hereditary taste and skill in working in wood. cf. the name of the Ithacan bard, *fh/mios *terpia/dhs, x 330 f., and that of the Phaeacian bard, *dhmo/dokos, q 44.
o(/s: refers to the chief person, to *fe/reklon. cf. 44, 77, 2.872.
dai/dala: obj. of e)pi/stato. teu/xein is added in explanation.
pa/nta: see on 52.
e)fi/lato [e)fi/lhse]: the i of the stem is lengthened regularly; cf. ga^me/w, e)/ghma. cf. fi=lai 117.

*)aqh/nh: Athena is not only goddess of war. She presides over all manner of artistic accomplishments. cf. *i 390, b 116, z 233, u 72, q 493, Pindar Ol. vii. 51. She retains her warepithet *palla/s even in such connexions.
o(/s ktl.: this second rel. sent. referring to *fe/reklon 59, gives a special instance and proof of his possession of the skill just ascribed to him.
kai/: also, as well as many other things. It modifies the whole sentence. See on 1.249.
e)i/sas: shapely, well-balanced.

a)rxeka/kous: the epithet gives a kind of personification to the ships. For the repetition and amplification of the thought of the first word, in the rest of the verse, cf. ou)lome/nhn, h)\ muri/) *)axaioi=s a)/lge) e)/qhken *a 2, nh/pioi, oi(\ kata\ bou=s *(uperi/onos *)heli/oio| h)/sqion a 8, and, also, i(/ppous a)qlofo/rous, oi(\ a)e/qlia possi\n a)/ronto *i 124, e)/lafon beblhme/non, o(/n t' e)/bal) a)nh/r *l 475. See § 1 h. — cf. au(=tai de\ ai( ne/es (sent by Athens to the aid of the Ionians) a)rxh\ kakw=n e)ge/nonto *(/ellhsi/ te kai\ barba/roisi Hdt. v. 97, ille dies primus leti primusque malorum| caussa fuit Verg. Aen. iv. 169.
oi(= t' au)tw=|: and for himself (in particular). Phereclus pays the penalty for his work.
e)pei/: introduces an explanation of tekth/nato.
qew=n e)k: const. with qe/sfata, “the oracles of the gods.” cf. e)k *dio\s h)ei/dhs to\n e)mo\n mo/ron *x 280.
qe/sfata: i.e. the prophecy that calamity would befall Troy, if Paris brought a wife from Greece.
o(/te ktl.: half parenthetical.
kate/marpte: sc. mi/n. “Was on the point of overtaking him,” so that he could use his spear to advantage.
diw/kwn: Phereclus fled with the other Trojans, 37.
beblh/kei: see on 4.492.
ka/ta: the accent is thrown upon the penult since the noun precedes and decio/n is added as a mere detail. cf. *ca/nqou a)/po dinh/entos *b 877.
h(: see on h( *d 502.
diapro/: forward and through. Adv., with h)/luqe [h)=lqe]. cf. 7.260, 12.404.
cf. 13.652 (with o)isto/s for a)kwkh/).
a)ntikru\s ktl.: see on a)ntikru/s *d 481. kata\ ku/stin: along the bladder.
u(p' o)ste/on: along under the bone.
a)kwkh/ (cf. acu): in appos. with h(. cf. *tudei+/dhs 18.
gnu\c ktl.: he fell on his knee. gnu/c is always connected with some form of e)rei/pw. For the adv., from go/nu, cf. la/c, pu/c. § 38 g.
oi)mw/cas: the groan was coincident in time with the fall, e)/ripe.
a)/ra: cf. 43.
*me/ghs: an Epean leader. See on 2.627.
*)anth/noros ui(o/n: seven of Antenor's eleven sons were slain in the battles of the Iliad. Antenor was the Trojan Nestor. See on 2.822.
o(/s r(a ktl.: nearly equiv. to o(/n r(a no/qon per e)o/nta ktl. me/n and de/ mark a contrast.
pu/ka: carefully.
*qeanw/: Antenor's wife; daughter of the Thracian king Cisses, 11.223 f., and priestess of Athena, 6.298 ff. The Thracians and Trojans were closely allied.
i)=sa ktl.: in appos. with pu/ka.
i)=sa: cognate accusative.
xarizome/nh: the pres. partic. often expresses purpose, as here.
po/sei+: for the length of the last syllable, see on ge/neto *d 456.
to\n me\n ktl.: a fuller statement of 69.
kefalh=s: partitive gen. with i)ni/on.
kata\ i)ni/on: on the nape of the neck.
a)n' o)do/ntas: through the teeth.
u(po/: adv., below.
yuxro\n xalko/n: “cold steel.”

e(/le: seized, of the convulsive movement of the death struggle. cf. e)n koni/h|si pesw\n e(/le gai=an a)gostw=| (hand) 11.425, gai=an o)da\c ei(=lon (“bit the dust”) 22.17. See on 2.418. — Obs. the large variety of expressions for death; 42, 47, 58, 68, 83. See on 4.461.
*eu)ru/pulos: a prominent Thessalian hero. See on 2.736. cf. 7.167, 8.265.
*(uyh/nora (a)nh/r): see on to/n 79, where this construction is resumed. This hero is mentioned only here.
o(/s: prob. refers to *dolopi/onos, though the reference is doubtful. See on o(/s 60.
*skama/ndrou a)rhth/r: sacrifices of bulls, rams, and, possibly, of horses were paid to rivers and rivergods. cf. 21.131 f., 23.146 f.
a)rhth/r (a)ra/omai): cf. *xru/shn h)ti/masen a)rhth=ra *a 11.
qeo\s ktl.: prob. not simply a personal distinction, but chiefly respect paid to the office.
w(/s: the ‘comparative’ w(s in Homer always has an accent and is placed after its noun. cf. 4.482. Seldom is elision allowed before it, as here.
to\n me\n ktl.: resumes the thought of 76, after the rel. clauses. See on 4.459.
a)/ra: cf. 45.
metadroma/dhn: equiv. to metadramw/n. § 38 c. Cf. parablh/dhn *d 6.

e)/lase: struck. Used only like ou)ta/w of wounds inflicted in the hand-to-hand conflict (cominus). It is thus contrasted with ba/llw, but like the latter, it is followed by two accs. (of the ‘whole’ and ‘part’), to/n and w)=mon.
fasga/nw| ktl.: cf. *k 456, x 98.
a)po\ e)/cese (ce/w): hewed off, cut off smooth.
xei=ra: arm, clearly; cf. w)=mon 80. cf. 4.523.
pedi/w|: to the plain. Dat. of approach. See on 4.523. cf. xamai\ (humi) pe/se *n 578.
kata/: const. with e)/llabe.
o)/sse: in partitive appos. with to/n.
83 = *p 334, *u 477. — See on 4.461. cf. qana/tou de\ me/lan ne/fos a)mfeka/luyen *p 350.
e)/llabe: for the form, see § 25 f.
krataih/: sc. as having sway over all mortals.

84-94. Introduction to the strict a)ristei/a of Diomed. ‘Since 9, seven Trojans have been slain by seven Achaeans. In the series beginning with Agamemnon, 38, Peloponnesians have alternated with Greeks from Crete or Thessaly. The wounds inflicted have been various, but all on fleeing Trojans.’
pone/onto: cf. poneu/menon *d 374.

*tudei+/dhn: by ‘anticipation,’ as the obj. of gnoi/hs, instead of *tudei+/dhs as subj. of metei/h. H. 878. cf. h)/|dee a)delfeo\n w(s e)ponei=to *b 409 “he knew how busy his brother was,” ‘I know thee who thou art,’ St. Luke iv. 34.
gnoi/hs: potential of the past. cf. 4.223. “You would not have known.”
pote/roisi: with which of the two. This is explained by the following verse. Diomed was as near the Trojan line as to his own friends.
metei/h: opt. of indirect discourse, for me/testi.
h)e/, h)=: po/teron, h)/. § 3 m a.

87-94. In this comparison, cause and effect — the raging Diomed (8891) and his victory (92-94) — are closely united. For the comparison, cf. 4.452 ff., 15.624 ff., aggeribus ruptis cum spumeus amnis| exit oppositasque evicit gurgite moles,| fertur in arva furens Verg. Aen. ii. 496 ff.
xeima/rrw|: i.e. a stream from heavy rains or melting snows, in contrast with u(/data a)ena/onta. In appos. with potamw=|. See 11.492 f., quoted on 4.452.
w)=ka: const. with r(e/wn. This seems to be referred to in e)lqo/nt' e)capi/nhs 91. cf. w)kuro/w| 598.
e)ke/dasse: disiecit, scatters, shatters. Gnomic aorist.
gefu/ras: dams, dikes, levees. — cf. nec validi possunt pontes venientis aquaï| vim subitam tolerare Lucretius i. 484 f.
e)erme/nai (from root ser): united, i.e. in unbroken succession along the banks. This refers to e)ke/dasse 88, and corresponds to pukinai/ 93.
i)/sxei [e)/xei]: sc. after the river has overflowed its banks.
a)lwa/wn: const. with e(/rkea, enclosures of the gardens.
e)lqo/nta: const. with to/n 89.
o(/te ktl.: cf. 12.286.
e)pibri/sh|: presses upon, falls heavily.

*dio\s o)/mbros: Zeus sends rain. See on nefelhgere/ta *d 30. cf. u(=e *zeu/s *m 25, o(/te labro/taton xe/ei u(/dwr| *zeu/s *p 385, *k 6, *l 493, *p 459. — For the ‘subjective’ gen., cf. nou=son *dio/s i 411 disease sent by Zeus, ku/mata a)ne/mwn *b 396, u(p' *eu)rusqh=os a)i/qlwn *q 363. See on 2.396.
u(p' au)tou=: beneath itself, “before the force of the stream.”
e)/rga ktl.: cf. minu/qei (waste away) de/ te e)/rg' a)nqrw/pwn *p 392.
w(/s: refers to e)oikw/s 87. — pukinai/ [puknai/]: see on 89. In effective contrast with klone/onto. See on 4.534.
a)/ra: “as you may well suppose.”
95-165. Diomed is wounded by Pandarus, but is strengthened and encouraged by Athena.
*luka/onos ktl.: i.e. Pandarus. cf. 4.88 f.
qu/nonta: suppl. partic. after e)no/hse. klone/onta is in appos. with this. The two partics. repeat 87 (qu=ne) and 93 (klone/onto).
pro\ e(/qen: cf. pro/sqen e(/qen 56. Here again the versepause shows the const., connecting this phrase closely with klone/onta.
e)pi\ *tudei+/dh|: cf. e)p' a)llh/loisin 14.
to/ca: Homer knows no distinction between to/con and to/ca. cf. u)/xea (28), a(/rma (231) and a(/rmata (192), me/garon (6.377) and me/gara (193). See on 4.468.
tuxw/i: cf. tuxh/sas *d 106.
gu/alon: breastplate. In appos. with the obj. of ba/le.
e)/ptato (pe/to:mai): cf. 4.125.
a)ntikru\s ktl.: cf. *l 253, *u 416.
die/sxe: intrans., held its way, went through, so as to come out on the other side of the shoulder. cf. di) w)/mou d' o)/brimon e)/gxos| e)/sxen *n 519. Equiv. to dih=lqe.
tw=| d' e)pi/: and over him, i.e. Diomed. cf. e)peu/xetai 119. The accent of e)pi/ is not drawn back since it does not immediately follow the word with which it is construed. § 37 c.
o)/rnusqe: cf. 4.509.
ke/ntores i(/ppwn: cf. 4.391. The Trojans are called i(ppo/damoi, *d 509 and often.

a)/ristos *axaiw=n: cf. 414, 839, 6.98. The poet must not be criticised too strictly and prosaically, as if he were making an official report of the war; he must not be charged with inconsistency for giving here to Diomed the preëminence which he elsewhere gives to Achilles or Telamonian Ajax. cf. 6.252, where the poet calls Laodice ‘the most beautiful of Priam's daughters,’ and 13.365, where the same expression is used of Cassandra.
ou)de/ e(/ fhmi: cf. *l 589, *s 132, o 213.
dhqa/: cf. 587.
a)nsxh/sesqai (a)ne/xw): contrasted with be/los da/massen 106. cf. a)nasxe/sqai *d 511.
ei) e)teo\n ktl.: cf. ei) e)teo/n ge so/s ei)mi, path\r d' e)mo\s eu)/xeai ei)=nai i 529. “If in truth, as I believe, I followed the god's voice in coming hither, and thus may expect his assistance.”
w)=rsen: sc. to strife against the Greeks.
a)/nac ktl.: i.e. Apollo, the god of archery, who had given him his bow. cf. 4.101, 2.827.
*luki/hqen: i.e. from Zeleia in Trojan Lycia. cf. *d 103, *b 824. From these Trojan Lycians, the Southern Lycians of Sarpedon (471, 629) are to be distinguished.
eu)xo/menos: (boasting), exulting. Cf. *q 198, *n 619. cf. also eu)xwlh/ *d 173, 450.
ou): the neg. is separated from its verb, and placed first, in order to form a strong contrast to the assertion of Pandarus. “By no means.”
pro/sq' i(/ppoiin: const. with e)/sth.
*sqe/nelon: i.e. his esquire who had kept near him with his chariot. cf. 4.227 ff., 365 ff.
*kapanh/ion: the adj. is equiv. to the gen. of *kapaneu/s, and to *kapanhia/dh 109, which is more constantly used as a ‘patronymic.’ § 21 k.

o)/rso, katabh/seo: standing ‘asyndeton.’ The first imv. is more general; the second, the more special, is in a kind of appos. with the first. § 2 m. Cf. 4.204. For o)/rso, without variable vowel, see § 35; for katabh/seo with the variable vowel of the 2d aor., cf. e)pibhso/menon 46.
pe/pon: “my dear fellow.” An affectionate form of address. cf. 6.55.
a)/ra: marks w(\s e)/fh as a repetition of prose/fh 108. See on 45.
kaq' i(/ppwn: cf. katabh/seo 109. Opposed to a)nabai/nw, *g 261, as e)c o)xe/wn *d 419 to e)sbai/nw, 837, and a)f' i(/ppwn 19 to e)pibai/nw, 255.
a)=lto ktl.: cf. 4.419.
pa/r: const with sta/s.

diampere\s ktl.: “drew clean through and out.” Generally the arrow was drawn back, but in this case the point had gone so far through the shoulder (100) that the barbs would not allow it to be drawn back.
a)nhko/ntize (a)kw/n dart): shot up. Cf. ai(/matos d) a)porroai/ (from a victim at the altar) | e)s oi)=dm) e)shko/ntizon ou)/riai ce/nw| Eur. Hel. 1587 f.
streptoi=o xitw=nos: cf. 21.31. Prob. a linen tunie with firmly twisted threads.

boh\n a)gaqo/s: this phrase is applied chiefly to Diomed and Menelaus, since with their names it makes a convenient close to the verse after the pause between the two short syllables of the third foot. cf. 320, 347, 432, 596, 855, ktl. §§ 4 c, 40 d. The leader's voice was much more important in the conflict in the times when no trumpets were used.

115 = d 762, z 324; cf. 10.278. — The usual formula for a prayer is, as here, (1) the address, (2) the grounds for the request, and (3) the petition. cf. klu=qi/ meu, a)rguro/toc' . . . ei)/ pote/ toi xari/ent) e)pi\ nho\n e)/reya ktl. *a 37 ff.

ei)/ pote ktl.: the ground for the request is here not, as in the passage just quoted, some service which the suppliant had rendered, but the kindly disposition which the divinity had shown previously. cf. h)me\n dh/ pot' e)meu= pa/ros e)/klues eu)came/noio| . . .| h)d) e)/ti kai\ nu=n moi to/d) e)pikrh/hnon e)e/ldwr *a 453 ff., a)lla\ tui=d' [th=|d)] e)/lq), ai)/ pota [ei)/ pote] ka)te/rwta| e)/klues Sappho i. 5 f., ‘Captain or Colonel or Knight in arms,| Whose chance on these defenceless doors may seize,| If deed of honor did thee ever please,| Guard them, and him within protect from harms,’ Milton Sonnet iii. 1 ff. See 10.285 ff., quoted on 4.383.
kai/: also.
fi/la frone/ousa: see on 4.219.
pare/sths: cf. 4.390.
nu=n au)=te: now in turn.
nu=n: opposed to pote/, as e)me/ to patri/.
au)=te: used much like a)lla/ or de/ in the conclusion of a condition.

fi=lai: for the long penult, see on 61. This general petition is explained by the following verse. ‘The poet could not make Diomed invoke Athena to punish Pandarus for the breach of the treaty, since she herself had urged the Lycian to shoot the arrow.’ Possibly the Greeks did not know what warrior wounded Menelaus; cf. 4.113 f.
me/: subj. of e(lei=n (cf. 37).
e)s o(rmh\n ktl.: within the range of my spear. The second half of this verse is precedent to, and a condition of, the first half-verse, and is added parenthetically.
e)lqei=n: the subj. of this inf. is supplied from a)/ndra, which is made definite by the following rel. clause.

fqa/menos [fqa/sas]: (anticipating,) first. Diomed has a wrong to avenge. — The aor. partic. here is clearly coincident with the time of the principal verb. e)/fqh balw/n also would have been good Greek, and is found Od. 22.91.
e)peu/xetai: cf. 101.
ou)de\ ktl.: cf. 103.

cf. e)meu= zw=ntos kai\ e)pi\ xqoni\ derkome/noio *a 88, zw/ei kai\ o(ra=| fa/os h)eli/oio *s 61, *ce/rchs me\n au)to\s zh=| te kai\ ble/pei fa/os Aeschylus Persians 297. The opposite is lei/pein fa/os h)eli/oio, *s 11. In the Eumenides of Aeschylus, 323, a)laoi=si (blind) kai\ dedorko/sin stands for ‘dead and living.’
121-165. Diomed slays four pairs of Trojans.
e)/klue: refers to klu=qi 115.
gui=a: see on 4.230. It is explained by the second half-verse, which is added in apposition.
u(/perqen: const. with xei=ras, in contrast with po/das.
i(stame/nh: nearly equiv. to sta=sa.
e)pi/: against. Cf. 14. Const. with ma/xesqai.
ma/xesqai: used as imperative.
e)/n toi sth/qessin: in thy breast.
h(=ka (i(/hmi): the Greek idiom often uses the aor. of an action immediately preceding, where the English uses the pres. or perfect.
oi(=on ktl.: explanatory of patrw/ion 125.
sake/spalos (sa/kos, pa/llw): formed and accented like e)gxe/spalos. The shield-wielder. Used like a)spisth/s of a brave knight. cf. talau/rinon 289, and see on korusth/n *d 457.
i(ppo/ta: see on 4.317. This forms a convenient ‘tag’ to follow the ‘bucolic caesura’ at the close of the fourth foot, with *ne/stwr, *phleu/s, *fuleu/s, and *oi)neu/s. See on 114; § 40 i.
*tudeu/s: cf. 4.372 ff.
127-132 prepare the way for 330 ff.

a)xlu\n ktl.: Athena opened Diomed's eyes that he might not engage in conflict with the gods who favored the Trojans, who might be inclined to lure him on to an unequal strife. cf. aspice — namque omnem, quae nunc obducta tuenti| mortalis hebetat visus tibi et umida circum| caligat, nubem eripiam Verg. Aen. ii. 604 ff., ‘but to nobler sights| Michael from Adam's eyes the film removed| Which that false fruit that promised clearer sight| Had bred, then purged with euphrasy and rue| The visual nerve, for he had much to see,’ Milton Par. Lost xi. 411 ff.; ‘Then the Lord opened the eyes of Balaam, and he saw the angel of the Lord standing in his way, and his sword drawn in his hand,’ Numbers xxii. 31; ‘And the Lord opened the eyes of the young man; and he saw: and, behold, the mountain was full of horses and chariots of fire round about Elisha,’ 2 Kings vi. 17.
e)ph=en: was upon them.
e)u/: clearly.
gignw/skh|s: subjv. in a final clause, though after a secondary tense, since e(/lon is equiv. to ai(re/w. See on h(=ka 125. cf. kath/lqomen . . . i(/na mh/ ti pa/qh|sin *u 126.
tw=|: therefore.
nu=n: emphatic, with reference to 127.
qeo/s: of course in human form.
peirw/menos: trying, tempting to a dangerous strife. cf. 407, 6.129 ff., Od. 8.225 ff. — sc. seu=.
qeoi=s: plural after the sing. qeo/s 129, since the thought groups together all the divinities, with but a single exception. cf. ta\ de\ pa/nta *d 363, referring to ei)/ ti kako/n *d 362.
a)ntikru/: with short ‘ultima,’ as 819. The adv. gives emphasis to the idea of rashness. cf. a)/nta ma/xesqai *t 163.
toi=s a)/llois: those others, added emphatically as a limiting after-thought, at the close of the sent. and the beginning of the verse, in order to prepare the way for the following contrast.
*)afrodi/th: elsewhere also the last word in the verse is contrasted with the first word. cf. Od. 1.33.
e)/lqh|si: e)/lqh|.
ou)ta/men: cf. ou)=ta *d 525.
a)pe/bh: Athena withdrew from Diomed, but seems to have remained on the battle-field. Mark her activity at 290. At 418 ff. she is again on Olympus.
e)cau=tis: again, with reference to a)naxwrh/sas 107.
i)w/n: went and. ‘Aoristic.’
e)mi/xqh: here in hostility, as 4.354. cf. 143.

pri/n per: pe/r serves to contrast pri/n strongly with the following dh\ to/te. cf. sfw=in de\ pri/n per tro/mos e)/llabe fai/dima gui=a,| pri\n po/lemo/n t' i)de/ein *q 452 f., where the emphasis is not one of expressed contrast.
dg\ to/te ktl.: the const. of the previous line is deserted, and the partic. memaw/s is left in the air. The poet began as if he were to say e)mene/hne. See on *d 433, *z 511.
tri\s to/sson: thrice so great. Cf. tri\s to/ssa *a 213.
w(/s te: as. § 2 j.
le/onta: the lion appears in 25 of the longer comparisons of the Iliad, cf. 161, 554, and in other briefer comparisons, cf. 782.
a)grw=|: on the farm, in the country, as opposed to ‘town.’ So in the Odyssey, the stalls and pens for the herds and flocks of Odysseus are at a distance from his dwelling.
e)p' ei)ropo/kois ktl.: “keeping watch over” etc. Const. closely with poimh/n. cf. 6.424.
xrau/sh|: wounds, shall have wounded. For the subjv., cf. pamfai/nh|si 6.

au)lh=s: wall of the farm-yard. Cf. i 184, c 5. But au)lh=s 142 is the farm-yard itself; cf. 4.433. — This verse and the following contain the point of the comparison: the lion and Diomed are not weakened but rendered more fierce by their wounds.
w)=rsen: ‘gnomic’ aorist.
140-142. These verses picture the results of the lion's fury.
kata\ ktl.: the herdsman hides in his hut and does not attempt further to defend his flocks (ou) prosamu/nei).
ta\ d' e)rh=ma: mh=la seems to have been in the poet's mind. For the accent of e)rh=ma, see § 2 w.
fobei=tai: are driven, flee before the lion.
ai(: sc. o)/ies. So in 16.353 ai(/ refers to mh=la.

a)gxisti=nai: in close succession, one upon the other. Cf. toi\ d' a)gxisti=noi e)/pipton| nekroi\ o(mou= *trw/wn . . . kai\ *danaw=n *r 361 f. Predicate. § 38 a. Cf. e)passu/terai *d 427, purai\ neku/wn kai/onto qameiai/ *a 52.
ke/xuntai (xe/w): lie in heaps. The lion does not leave the farm-yard until he has killed all the flock, — even forgetting his own hunger in his fury.
au)ta\r o(: for the following hiatus, cf. au)ta\r o( e)/gnw *a 333. See § 9 b.
e)mmemaw/s: impetuously.
baqe/hs [baqei/as, § 20 c]: with reference to the high wall. cf. baqei/hs e)/ntoqen au\lh=s i 239.
mi/gh: resumes e)mi/xqh 134. For the form, see § 33 f.
*)astu/noon: another Trojan of this name is mentioned 15.455.
f. Diomed hit one and struck the other.
plh=ce: corresponds to balw/n 145. For the transition to the finite const., see §§ 1 e, 3 t.
a)po\ ktl.: shows the mighty force of the blow.
e)/ase: suffered to lie, without stripping them of their armor.
metw/|xeto: went after, i.e. turned upon. cf. bh= meta/ 152.
*polu/idon (veid-): a suitable name for a seer's son. See on *)astua/nakta *z 403.
o)neiropo/loio: cf. a)ll' a)/ge dh/ tina ma/ntin e)rei/omen h)\ i(erh=a| h)\ kai\ o)neiropo/lon, kai\ ga/r t) o)/nar e)k *dio/s e)stin *a 62 f.
This and the following verse are half parenthetical.
toi=s ou)k ktl.: “these never returned; never again did their father interpret their dreams for them.”

e)kri/nato: the technical word for the interpretation of dreams. cf. o)neirokri/tas Theoc. xxi. 33, o( prw=tos tw=n e)nupni/wn krith/s Aesch. Persians 226, fau/lws e)kri/nate ib. 520, *)oneirokritika/.
a)lla/: adversative to what is implied above. “These did not return, but were slain by Diomed.”
sfe/as: monosyllabic; metrically equiv. to sfa=s. § 7 a.
e)cena/ricen: equiv. to e)nh/rato 43.
*ca/nqon: prob. a short form for *canqo/dwros, named from the river. cf. *skama/ndrion 49. *ca/nqos, however, may stand for *ca/nqippos (cf. the name of Socrates's wife).
*qo/wna: to be distinguished from two other Trojans of the same name, *l 422; *m 140, *n 545.
*fai/nopos: Phaenops, also, has one or two ‘homonyms’; cf. 17.312, 583.
thluge/tw: “dearly beloved.”

e)pi\ ktea/tessi [kth/masi]: over his treasures, i.e. as heir and guardian of his wealth. For the const., cf. ei)ropo/kois o)i/essin 137. cf. kai/ me fi/lhs' , w(s ei)/ te path\r o(\n pai=da filh/sh|| mou=non thlu/geton polloi=sin e)pi\ ktea/tessin *i 481 f.

lipe/sqai: to be left, “one who should remain.” Inf. of result. Aor. middle as passive. The Greeks like the ancient Hebrews dreaded the thought of leaving their home and goods to strangers. Thus when Leonidas went to Thermopylae he chose for his ‘three hundred,’ not young men without families, but men who had sons to succeed them. cf. the feeling of Abraham: ‘And Abram said, “Lord God, what wilt thou give me, seeing I go childless, and the steward of my house is this Eliezer of Damascus?” And Abram said, “Behold, to me thou hast given no seed: and, lo, one born in my house [i.e. a slave] is mine heir,”’ Genesis xv. 2 f.
e)na/rize: descriptive imperfect.
a)mfote/rw: acc. of the person deprived, with e)cai/nuto, cf. 20.458. See G. 164; H. 724. It is added in order to form a contrast with pate/ri.
lei=pe: he left grief, in taking from him his sons.
ou): modifies zw/onte as well as de/cato, since the partic. bears the most important thought. cf. 150.
ma/xhs: the gen. is const. with the following e)k. cf. *menela/w| *d 94, const. with the following e)pi/ in composition.
e)knosth/sante: in a sort of appos. with zw/onte.

xhrwstai/: i.e. distant relatives, kinsmen, who had to care for the bereaved widow (xh/rh). Almost equiv. to strangers. Cf. oi)/ktire d' , w)=nac, pai=da to\n so/n, ei) ne/as| trofh=s sterhqei\s sou= dioi/setai mo/nos| u(p) o)rfanistw=n mh\ fi/lwn Soph. Ajax 510 ff.
dia/: adv., const. with date/onto.
la/be: seized, overtook.
ei)n e(ni\ ktl.: cf. 609, 11.103, 127. sc. one as spearman and the other as charioteer.
ei)n: e)n. cf. 446; see § 37 d.
e)c a)/ch|: for the subjv. in comparisons, see on 4.131. — The ‘hiatus’ before a)/ch| is simply apparent. § 9 f.
po/rtios ktl.: calf or cow, beast young or old.
boskomena/wn: feeding, pastured. The pl. unites the two preceding nouns; or the partic. is attracted from the case of bousi/ to that of po/rtios and boo/s.
w(/s: thus, i.e. with such irresistible force.
tou\s a)mfote/rous: both of these.
e)c i(/ppwn: see on kaq' i(/ppwn 111.
bh=se [e)/bhse]: threw. For the causative sense of the first aor. of this verb, cf. 1.144. See H. 500.
kakw=s: (destructively,) fiercely.
a)e/kontas: unwilling, i.e. in spite of all that they could do. cf. u(pe/sxeto de\ me/ga e)/rgon,| e)k *troi/hs a)e/kontas a)pwse/men (drive off) ui(=as *)axaiw=n *n 366 f.
e)su/la: cf. e)su/leuon 48.
oi)=s: possessive pronoun.
meta\ nh=as ktl.: to drive to the camp. See on 26.
166-273. Aeneas and Pandarus against Diomed and Sthenelus.
a)lapa/zonta: pred. partic.; originally ‘circumstantial’ (as he was laying waste), rather than ‘supplementary’ (saw him laying waste).
i)/men: i)e/nai.
a)/n: a)na/. See on 4.209.
sth= . . . au)toi=o: cf. *i 193, h 21, p 166.
