a)nti/on hu)/da: here only const., like proshu/da, with two accs.: e)/pos (cognate) and mi/n (dir. obj.). Elsewhere this phrase has only the acc. of the person addressed.
pou= ktl.: not a question for information, but an expression of surprise that Pandarus did not use his bow to advantage against Diomed.
i)de/: cf. 3.
kle/os: fame for skill in archery.
w=(|: with respect to which, in which. This refers to the principal idea, to/con. cf. 60.
se/o ge: emphatic; than thee, the famed bowman.
tw=|d' a)ndri/: for the dat., cf. *menela/w| *d 94.
e)/fes: aor. imv. of e)fi/hmi. cf. 188, au)toi=si be/los e)fiei/s *a 51.
xei=ras a)nasxw/n: a poetical picturesque eu)ca/menos. — For this, the usual attitude in prayer, see on 1.450.
o(/s tis: refers to a)ndri/. Who in the world.
o(/de: here. Cf. kei=nos 604.
krate/ei: holds sway.
kai\ dh\ ktl.: cf. 8.356.
dh/: already.
*trw=as: for the acc. of the person affected (direct obj.) with e)/orgen, see G. 165; H. 725 a.
gou/nat' e)/lusen: a formula for depriving of strength and life. See on 4.314.
kotessa/menos (ko/tos, kotes-): for the ss, see § 30 d. This word is repeated and explained by the following clause.

i(rw=n: because of sacrifices not offered. cf. ei)/ t' a)/r) eu)xwlh=s (for a vow unperformed) e)pime/mfetai ei)/ q' e(kato/mbhs *a 65, misqou= xwo/menoi, to\n u(posta\s ou)k e)te/lessen *f 457. For the causal gen., cf. 4.168.
mhni/sas: cf. xwsame/nh *i 534, xolwsame/nh *i 538.
xaleph/: grievous.
e)/pi: for e)/pesti. § 37 c a. The ‘copula’ is omitted more freely when the limiting adv. (here e)/pi) is expressed.
pa/nta: in all things. Neuter, adverbial. cf. 4.389.
e)i/skw (i)=sos): I think him like.

a)spi/di: by his shield. The heroes' shields were not all alike. The shield of Agamemnon was peculiar in its bosses and in the arrangement of them (see on 4.448); that of Telamonian Ajax was of unusual size and thickness (7.219 ff.); that of Nestor was covered with gold (8.192 f.); that which Hephaestus made for Achilles was adorned with many scenes and figures (18.478 ff.). But nowhere does Homer intimate that each shield had a special device, such as was found on later shields. In the Seven against Thebes of Aeschylus, Tydeus had the full moon as a device for his shield; Hippomedon had the ‘fire-breathing Typhon’; Parthenopaeus, the Sphinx, etc.
au)lw/pidi: prob. refers to the eyeholes in the visor of the helmet.
i(/ppous ei)soro/wn: parallel to the datives above. Diomed was not in his chariot, yet had i<*> near at hand. cf. 107, 134, 249.

sa/fa ktl.: “I am not really sure that he is not a god,” in view of his superhuman achievements. This refers to the words of Aeneas, 175 ff.; but Pandarus inclines to the other view, that this is Diomed.
o(/ g' a)nh/r: that man. Sc. e)sti/
fhmi/: say. Cf. 181.
ui(o/s: in appos. with a)nh/r.
a)/neuqe qeou=: cf. non haec sine numine divom| eveniunt Verg. Aen. ii. 777, ou) pa/ntwn a)e/khti qew=n z 240.
ta/de: cognate acc. with mai/netai. Nearly equiv. to w(=de.
a)qana/twn: is followed by a distinct pause.

ei)lume/nos ktl.: the most prominent part of his body is mentioned as representing his whole form. cf. (*)apo/llwn) ei(me/nos w)/moiin nefe/lhn *o 308, a)mfi\ d' a)/r) a)/rrhkton nefe/lhn w)/moisin e(/santo (sc. oi( qeoi/) 20.150, nube candentes humeros amictos| augur Apollo Horace Carm. i. 2. 31 f.
tou/tou: from him. Ablatival gen. of separation with e)/trapen a)/llh| turned in another direction. Cf. 4.130 ff.
kixh/menon: pres. partic., as it was about to hit.
h)/dh ktl.: cf. 97 ff.

kai/ min: this animated repetition from 188 gives prominence to the separate clauses, and prepares the way for the effective contrast, e)/mphs ktl. 191. cf. kai/ min gouna/somai kai/ min pei/sesqai o)i/w *a 427, h)= me\n dh\ ma/la polla\ ponh/sato no/sfin e)mei=o| kai\ dh\ tei=xos e)/deime (built) kai\ h)/lase (ran) ta/fron e)p' au)tw=|| . . . a)ll) ou)d) w(\s du/natai sqe/nos *(/ektoros i)/sxein *i 348 ff.
e)fa/mhn: thought.
*)aidwnh=i ktl.: cf. 1.3, 6.487, *)ai/da| proi+a/yai doro\s a)/gran Aesch. Sept. 309, demittimus Orco Verg. Aen. ii. 398.
*)aidwnh=i: for the form, see § 19 f.
e)/mphs: equiv. to o(/mws, which is not Homeric.
qeo/s nu ktl.: so some god is full of anger (grudge), who makes the arrows of Pandarus of no effect. Inferential asyndeton.
koth/eis: cf. kotessa/menos 177.

cf. 14.299. — The repeated failure of Pandarus with his bow makes him wish that he had not brought this bow, but had come as a knight, with horses and chariot. This thought of his mind (indicated, but not fully expressed) introduces the following story.
pare/asi (ei)mi/): cf. e)/asin 267. See § 34 g. — tw=n [w(=n] ktl.: the opt. with ke/ is regular after a negative principal clause.
pou/: doubtless. Ironical, of that which he knows well.

*luka/- onos: shows more feeling than patro/s would have done. cf. the words of Achilles, h)= pot' *)axillh=os poqh\ i(/cetai ui(=as *)axaiw=n *a 240; and those of Oceanus to Prometheus, ou) ga/r pot' e)rei=s w(s *)wkeanou=| fi/los e)sti\ bebaio/tero/s soi Aesch. Prom. 296 f., 3.223. See on 1.240.
prwtopagei=s: for the first time put together. Chariots seem to have been taken to pieces (at least occasionally) when out of use. cf. 722 ff.
neoteuxe/es: newly made. A repetition of the preceding thought in a different form. cf. a(/lion, a)te/leston *d 26.
pe/ptantai: sc. in order to protect from the dust. cf. a(/rmata d' eu)= pepukasme/na (well-covered) kei=to *b 777, a(/rmata d' a)\m bwmoi=si (platforms) ti/qei, kata\ li=ta peta/ssas *q 441.
para\ de/ sfin: while by their side.
sfi/n: i.e. chariots. With this, e(ka/stw| is in apposition. cf. *k 473, o(/tti ken u)/mmi kako\n pe/mph|sin e(ka/stw| *o 109.
di/zuges: the chariots of men and gods were regularly drawn by two horses. Only occasionally was a third (parh/oros *p 471) added.
cf. *q 564. — kri= [kriqa/s]: barley. The most common grain of Greece.

o)lu/ras: always plural. For the food of the Homeric horses (lwto/s, se/linon, kri=, ku/peiron, u)/lurai, puro/s, zeiai/), see on 2.776. — This whole enumeration serves to emphasize the wish that one of these chariots had been brought to Troy.
h)= me/n: truly, indeed.
ma/la polla/: very urgently. See on 4.229.
ai)xmhta/: for the form cf. i(ppo/ta 126.
e)rxome/nw|: “as I left home to come hither.”
e)/ni: for the ‘anastrophe’ of the accent, cf. ka/ta 66.
poihtoi=sin: this implies the adv. ‘well.’ cf. (a)/ggea) tetugme/na (well-wrought), toi=s e)na/melgen (milked) Od. 9.223.
‘Appositive asyndeton.’ See § 2 m. e)ke/leue repeats e)pe/telle.

i(/ppoisin: this contains the chief thought. Pandarus should have come as a knight, not pezo/s, on foot, as an archer. The dat. is to be const. with e)mbebaw=ta, since i(/ppoi kai\ a(/rmata forms but a single thought. cf. 4.366.
cf. a)/rxeu) *)argei/oisi ktl. *b 345.

*trw/essi: Trojans in the widest sense of the term; cf. *trwsi\ me\n h(gemo/neue me/gas koruqai/olos *(/ektwr *b 816. *trw=es, tw=n au)=t' h)=rxe *luka/onos a)glao\s ui(o/s *b 826. For the dat. of interest, cf. *trw/essi 211, *murmido/nessin a)/nasse *a 180.
201 = *x 103, i 228. cf. l 358, u 381. — h)= toi ktl.: indeed (yet) it would have been far better.
ke/rdion: formed from ke/rdos. § 22 b.
h)=en: sc. piqe/sqai.
feido/menos: “since I desired to spare.” Pandarus was afraid that his horses might lack food.
deuoi/ato: de/ointo. For the preservation of the u of the stem, cf. a)kouh/ *p 634 with the Attic a)koh/. See § 5 f.

a)ndrw=n ktl.: “in case the men should be shut into the city,” i.e. in case of a siege. cf. Hector's address to the Trojans, h)= ou)/ pw keko/rhsqe (sated, wearied) e)elme/noi e)/ndoqi pu/rgwn *s 287, *trw/wn ei)s a)/stu a)le/ntwn *x 47. — ei)wqo/tes ktl.: cf. 196.
e)/dmenai: edere, ēsse.
a(/dhn: only here with the original length of the penult.
li/pon: sc. i(/ppous kai\ a(/rmata e)n mega/roisi *luka/onos.
pezo/s: i.e. as a foot soldier. cf. 13.
ei)lh/louqa: cf. 44. — In this verse, five feet close with the end of a word.
to/coisin pi/sunos: cf. a)lki\ pepoiqw/s 299, i(pposu/nh| pepoiqw/s *d 303. — a)/ra: “as I see now.” Pandarus judges from his failures.

ou)k e)/mellon: were not fated. The poet may use the plural verb, not only with a neut. subj., but where the subj. (to/ca) refers to but one thing (to/con), though the ‘bow and arrows’ may be grouped together.
doioi=sin [duoi=n]: for the form, see § 23 b.
a)risth/essin: from a)risteu/s chief, prince. This does not always differ widely from a)/ristos. cf. ai)e\n a)risteu/ein ktl. *z 208.
e)fh=ka: cf. e)/fes 174.
*tudei+/dh|: cf. 95 ff.
*)atrei+/dh|: cf. 4.93 ff.
a)treke/s: adv., really. Cf. 4.140.

e)/sseua (seu/w): caused to flow, drew. Cf. su/to d' ai(=ma kelainefe/s *f 167. For the 1st aor. without tense-sign, cf. a)leua/menon 28. — h)/geira (e)gei/rw) ktl.: “but I only aroused them to the greater fury, instead of putting an end to their fighting.” This was true strictly only in the case of Diomed; cf. 135 ff.
tw=| r(a: so you see, therefore. Freq. at the beginning of a verse tw=| introduces the logical inference from the previous verses.
kakh=| ai)/sh|: for an evil fate. Cf. the words of Thetis to Achilles, tw=| se kakh=| ai)/sh| te/kon e)n mega/roisin *a 418. — The thought returns to 204.
a)po\ passa/lou: so Penelope takes the bow of Odysseus from the peg, where it hangs in a case, Od. 21.53 f.
h)/mati tw=|: only here separated from the o(/te of the clause which explains it. The phrase always stands at the beginning of the verse, except 6.345.
*trw/essi: cf. 200.

fe/rwn xa/rin: equiv. to xarizo/menos. cf. th=| ga\r e)/x) (thither he drove) h(=| r(a polu\ plei=stai klone/onto fa/lagges,| *(/ektori kai\ *trw/essi xarizo/menos *o 448 f., *(/hfaistos h)=rx' a)goreu/ein| mhtri\ fi/lh| e)pi\ h)=ra fe/rwn *a 571 f.

ei)/ ke: with fut. ind. cf. ei)/ k' *)axilh=os e(tai=ron taxe/es ku/nes e(lkh/sousin *p 557 f., ei)/ ke teleuth/sei kako\n h)=mar o 524. — This verse and the following indicate the desire of Pandarus to see his home, to which he was fated not to return.
a)/loxon: she is nowhere named in Homer.
u(yerefe\s ktl.: cf. *t 333, h 225, t 526.
214 = Od. 16.102. cf. the curse of Odysseus, mhke/t' e)/peit) *)odush=i ka/rh w)/moisin e)pei/h *b 259.
au)ti/k' e)/peita: explained by the following conditional clause.
ta/moi: may cut. ‘Permissive’ optative.
a)llo/trios: stranger, enemy, alienus. Perh. here not very different from a)/llos. — “I hope I may die if I don't.”

ta/de to/ca: this bow (here). Much more picturesque than ‘my bow.’ cf. St. Paul's words, au)toi\ ginw/skete o(/ti tai=s xrei/ais (necessities) mou kai\ toi=s ou)=sin met' e)mou= u(phre/thsan (ministered) ai( xei=res au(=tai Acts xx. 34.
faeinw=|: for the epithet, cf. e)n puro\s au)gh=| *i 206, teu=c' a)/ra oi( qw/rhka faeino/teron puro\s au)gh=s *s 610. The following hiatus is justified by the ‘Bucolic diaeresis.’ §§ 9 b, 40 h.
qei/hn: opt. of an event conceived not very vividly as possible. Pandarus was perfectly ready to throw the bow into the fire.
a)nemw/lia: to no purpose, useless. Cf. *d 355, nhpu/tie, ti/ nu to/con e)/xeis a)nemw/lion au)/tws *f 474.
mh\ dh\ ou(/tws: with imv. as mh\ dh\ ou(/tws kle/pte no/w| *a 131 f. For the ‘synizesis,’ see § 7 a.
pa/ros ou)k: with following pri/n ge. cf. 288.
e)/ssetai a)/llws: i.e. will be better.
a)/llws: for the adv. with e)/ssetai, cf. sxedo/n 14.

e)pi/: const. with tw=|d) a)ndri/. — nw/ (nos): subj. acc. of peirhqh=nai. For the contrasted nw/ and tw=|de, side by side, cf. soi\ me
 para\ kai\ kakw=| e)sqlo
 e)/qhken o 488, th=| para\ me
 klisi/hn puri\ ka/tqesan t 55, e)n de\ su\ toi=sin pefh/seai (shalt be slain) x 217, su/n te du/) e)rxome/nw, kai/ te pro\ o( tou= e)no/hsen *k 224.
a)ntibi/hn: originally cognate acc. with e)lqo/nte. cf. e)rize/menai basilh=i| a)ntibi/hn *a 277 f., *menela/w|| a)nti/bion po/lemon polemi/zein *g 434 f.

su
 e)/ntesi: const. with peirhqh=nai. cf. ei) me
 dh\ a)nti/bion su
 teu/xesi peirhqei/hs *l 386, a)mfi\ po/lin su
 teu/xesi peirhqw=men *x 381. (su
 e)/ntesi differs only metrically from su
 teu/xesi.) The arms are conceived as attendants of the person; cf. su
 i(/ppoisin 219. In *a 389, su
 nhi/ is used almost as instrumental, by ship.
221-223 = *q 105-107. — o)xe/wn: of a single chariot. See on 97.
e)pibh/seo: 1st aor. imv.; cf. katabh/seo 109. — i)/dhai: i)/dh|. § 26 p.
oi(=oi: explained by the second half-verse.

*trw/ioi i(/ppoi: the horses of Tros. Cf. 265 ff., i(/ppous de\ *trw/|ous u(/page (sc. *diomh/dhs) zugo/n, ou(/s pot' a)phu/ra| *ai)nei/an, a)ta\r au)to\n u(pecesa/wsen *)apo/llwn *y 291 f. For the adj., cf. *nhlh/iai i(/ppoi *l 597. — Tros was the father of Ilus and Ganymade, and the grandfather of Priam. He gave his name to *troi/h, as his son Ilus gave his name to the city of *)/ilios. — pedi/oio: prob. best const. with e)pista/menoi (cf. ma/xhs 11), though generally const. as local gen. with the following infinitives (cf. e)/rxontai pedi/oio *b 801).

Explanatory of e)pista/menoi pedi/oio. — e)/nqa kai\ e)/nqa: this way and that, of two opposed directions. This is explained here by the second halfverse. — Obs. the large preponderance of dactyls in this passage (221-225).
kai/: also. This marks a special case under the general statement about the excellence of the steeds.
ei)/ per ktl.: if really again, as Aeneas is not inclined to believe, as would appear from 218 ff. cf. 232.
e)pi/: const. with o)re/ch|. cf. 335.

cf. *p 479, z 81. — “You may drive, or wield the spear; just as you please.” — Aeneas came on foot to Pandarus, cf. 167; but (what is not expressly stated by the poet here) his charioteer followed him, and now Aeneas takes the reins and offers his charioteer's place to Pandarus. See on 108.
sigalo/enta: shining. Perhaps polished by some ‘blacking,’ but more prob. adorned with thin plates of bright metal.
cf. 16.480. — The principal idea, in contrast to 226, is in o)/fra ma/xwmai, sc. as paraiba/ths. cf. a)\n d' e)/ban e)n di/froisi paraiba/tai h(ni/oxoi te *y 132. — “I will fight.”

to/nde de/deco (de/xomai): receive his attack. Cf. *d 107. de/deco is not used like de/cai 227. Homer uses words in different senses, but often in different forms. cf. bebolhme/nos *i 9 smitten (in a figurative sense), dis tressed, with beblhme/nos *a 592 hit (literally), wounded.
melh/sousin ktl.: forms the conclusion to the preceding clause. “If you will meet his onset, I will look out for the horses.”
melh/sousin: for the ‘chiastic order,’ see § 2 o.
e)/xe: keep. See on 226. But with e)/x' h(ni/a, h(ni/oxos may be compared.
ma=llon: better, more willingly.
u(f' h(nio/xw| ktl.: Aeneas did not often serve as charioteer on the battle-field, but his horses knew his voice (234), and doubtless he had often driven them.
kampu/lon: with reference to the bent a)/ntuges. See on 262. cf. a)gku/lon a(/rma *z 39, which differs only metrically from this expression.
oi)/seton: nearly equiv. to a)/ceton. A part of the load of the twowheeled chariot seemed to rest on the pole, and thus on the horses.
febw/meqa: trans., we must flee.
mh\ ktl.: an independent expression of anxiety in a warning tone. In later Greek, such clauses followed a verb of fearing. “I fear lest fright come upon them and they delay.” See *p. 867.
math/seton: aor. subjunctive.
ou)d' e)qe/lhton: forms but a single idea, and be unwilling.
e)kfere/men: prob. trans., sc. h(ma=s as object. But cf. ai( *fhrhtia/dao podw/kees e)/kferon (dashed ahead) i(/ppoi *y 376.
nw=i: prob. obj. of ktei/nh|. For the intrans. use of e)pai+/cas, cf. 323, 584.

cf. *r 496. — au)tw\ ktl.: the thought begun with nw=i 235, is amplified and divided. See on 4.237. cf. w(=de/ sf' e)gke/falos (brain) xama/dis r(e/oi w(s o(/de oi)=nos,| au)tw=n kai\ teke/wn *g 300 f.
ktei/nh|: still depends on mh/. — e)la/ssh|: sc. away. cf. ou) ga/r pw/ pot' e)ma\s bou=s h)/lasan (drove off, sc. oi( *trw=es), ou)de\ me\n i(/ppous *a 154.
te/) [sa/]: tea/. For the ‘recession’ of the accent, see § 10 d.
poiki/la: see on 4.226. — For the rhyme, fwnh/santes, ba/ntes, see § 2 a.

e)mmemaw=te: “full of eagerness for the fight.” cf. 142. Const. with e)/xon. The dual is found convenient for the verse, and is used although the plural was used with the two preceding partics. and the verb. For the free interchange of dual and plural, cf. e)/xontas 245 with a)/ndre 244, and tw\ h)=lqon 275. See G. 135, 3; H. 634.
241-273. Sthenelus advises retreat to the line of chariots, but Diomed advances against Aeneas.
*sqe/nelos ktl.: see on 4.367.
e)pi\ soi/: see on 124.
o( me/n: nom., as if a)/ndre e)pi\ soi\ me/masan ktl. had preceded.
to/cwn: for the gen., cf. ma/xhs 11.
*pa/ndaros: in appos. with o( me/n.
247 = 468. cf. g 208. — *ai)nei/as de/: instead of o( de/, correl. with o( me/n 245. — ui(o/s: pred. with e)kgega/men [e)kgegone/nai], is descended as a son from.
cf. Od. 3.209, where Aeneas himself tells the story of his family, and gives his family tree.
mh/thr de/ oi(: but his mother. The form of the sent. is changed; a gen. is expected, correl. with *)agxi/sao.

cf. a)ll) a)/ge dh\ feu/gwmen e)f) i(/ppwn *w 356. — xazw/meqa ktl.: Diomed had been fighting on foot among the foremost champions, 134 ff. Sthenelus, who had kept near him with his chariot (see on 183), now drove up and urged him to mount the chariot and withdraw to a less exposed position. They did not think of leaving the field altogether, as mhde/ moi ou(/tws ktl. shows.
mh/ pws: that thou mayest not, lest perchance.

mh/ ti ktl.: “do not say one word more in order to urge me to flee.” A ‘pregnant’ construction; cf. peu/qeto ga\r *ku/pronde me/ga kle/os *l 21, o( me\n fu/gad' au)=tis u(postre/yas e)bebh/kein *a 446. Diomed gives the name ‘flight’ to the withdrawal from the line of the foremost fighters (250).
ou)de/: neither. Const. with the whole clause. — “I don't think you will persuade me, either.”
ou) ga\r ktl.: for it is not in my blood, not in my nature.
a)luska/zonti ktl.: fight as a skulker. Cf. *z 443, ou) ga\r o)i/w| a)ndrw=n dusmene/wn e(ka\s (far away) i(sta/menos polemi/zein *n 262 f. — The partic. follows the case of moi/.
e)/ti ktl.: cf. Od. 21.426.
o)knei/w: o)kne/w. § 29 i.
a)lla/: but rather.

kai\ au)/tws: even as I am, i.e. on foot, without chariot. cf. eu)= nu kai\ h(mei=s i)/dmen, o(/ toi kluta\ teu/xe) e)/xontai:| a)ll' au)/tws (i.e. without arms) e)pi\ ta/fron i)w\n *trw/essi fa/nhqi *s 197 f. See § 24 h.
au)tw=n: gen. with an adv. of place. G. 182, 2; H. 757.
trei=n (tremo): flee.
e)a=|: monosyllabic by ‘synizesis.’ cf. a)ll' e)w=men *k 344, ou)k e)a/sousin *f 233.
pa/lin: back, local. It marks a return to the same point from which one set out.
au)=tis: again.
h(mei/wn: h(mw=n. Found four times in Homer.
ei) ktl.: if even one or other of them escape, surely both will not get away. For the repetition of ge/ in the same sent., cf. 288, 827.
See on 4.39.
‘Appositive asyndeton,’ as is usual after the verse which has here preceded.
poulu/boulos: rich in counsel. Cf. o(ppo/te ken polu/boulos e)ni\ fresi\ qh/sei *)aqh/nh p 282.
“If I slay the men, do you look out for the horses.”
ktei=nai: explains ku=dos o)re/ch|.
su\ de/: here begins the conclusion of the condition. See § 3 n.
tou/sde: ‘deictic’; pointing to his own horses, which Sthenelus had brought. cf. ta/de 215.
au)tou=: right here.
e)rukake/ein: used as imperative.

e)c a)/ntugos: cf. 322. The a)/ntuc was the bent rod which formed the upper and outer rim of the chariot frame, at the side and in front of the charioteer. By it the warrior or charioteer could steady himself, and to it the reins were tied when the driver left the chariot. The pl. is sometimes used, because the a)/ntuc was on both sides of the chariot, or because two rods were used, one above the other. cf. 728, kai\ a)/ntuges ai( peri\ di/fron *l 535.
tei=nas: binding firm.

*ai)nei/ao: const. with i(/ppwn, which, in turn, is to be const. with e)pai+=cai. — memnhme/nos: mindful, sc. of Diomed's orders. Intrans. cf. w(=de tis u(mei/wn memnhme/nos a)ndri\ maxe/sqw *t 153, a 343, d 151.
e)k: const. with *trw/wn, out of the reach of the Trojans.
toi/: “let me tell you.”
geneh=s: ablatival genitive. sc. ei)si\n *trw/ioi i(/ppoi.
h(=s: of which, bred from which. Sc. i(/ppous, cf. 268.
*trwi/: made prominent by pe/r.

ui(=os poinh/n: as recompense for his son Ganymede, who (acc. to the later story) was carried by the eagle of Zeus to Olympus that he should serve as cup-bearer. This is the only Homeric allusion to the story. Beauty was hereditary in the royal family of Troy. Not to speak of Paris, Priam's brother Tithonus was so beautiful that Eos, the goddess of the Dawn, took him to be her spouse, and secured immortality for him from the gods. Tros was the grandson of Dardanus. See Od. 3.215 ff.
ou(/neka ktl.: Zeus gave these horses to Tros because they were the best.
u(p' h)w=: along under the morning light. Cf. u(p' au)ga\s h)eli/oio b 181.
th<*>s geneh=s: “horses from this stock.” cf. 265.
e)/kleyen: gained by stealth.
la/qrh|: cf. la/qrh| *)axillh=os *w 72. — *laome/dontos: Laomedon was first cousin of Capys, Anchises' father.
qh/leas: qhlei/as. cf. *(/hrh qh=lus e)ou=sa *t 97.
tw=n: gen of source with e)ge/nonto. — oi(=: to him.
gene/qlh: pred. appos. to the subj. e(/c.
For the ‘asyndeton,’ cf. 6.197 f.
tou\s me\n te/ssaras: (the others, namely four,) four of these.
au)to/s: “for himself.” cf. i(/ppous d' au)to\s e)/xe . . . e)n mega/roisin| . . . dw=ke de\ to/con *f 30 f., e)/pos ti/ ke muqhsai/mhn,| h)= au)to\s keu/qw *f 193 f.
e)pi\ fa/tnh|: cf. 6.506.
tw\ de\ du/o: but the other two.
mhstw=ri: cf. 4.328. He inspired the spirit of flight in the enemy.

ei) tou/tw ktl.: in case we should take these two. Evidently the horses could not be taken until their masters were overcome. This would bring honor. — For the opt. with ei)/ ke, cf. ei)/ ken qa/nato/n ge fu/goimen *a 60, ei)/ per ga/r k' e)qe/loimen . . . a)riqmhqh/menai a)/mfw *b 123 f.
274-333. Death of Pandarus. Aeneas is wounded by Diomed, but saved by Aphrodite. Sthenelus captures the horses of Aeneas.
This verse is found 8 times in the Iliad, 16 times in the Odyssey. It forms a transition at the close of a conversation.
tw/: i.e. Pandarus and Aeneas. cf. 240.
h)=lqon e)lau/nonte: for the combination of dual and plural, cf. 239 f.

kartero/qume: the prominence given to the stout-hearted endurance of the enemy seems to be in close connexion with the thought of the following verse, which is to be understood as an exclamation of surprise.
h)= ma/la: in truth. Concessive. “It is true that,” etc.
pikro\s o)isto/s: cf. 99. In appos. with be/los, forming a sort of contrast with the principal verb, ou) dama/ssato. See on 4.534.
nu=n au)=te: but now. With nu=n and e)/peita, au)=te is used like au)ta/r. See on 117. — The verse-pause contrasts e)gxei/h| with be/los w)ku/. — ai)/ ke ktl.: if haply I may hit thee.
tu/xwmi: tu/xw. § 26 a.
280 = *g 355, *h 244, *l 349, *p 516, *x 273, 289. cf. w 519, 522. — a)mpepalw/n: reduplicated aor. (§ 25 j) from a)napa/llw. — cf. adducto contortum hastile lacerto| immittit Verg. Aen. xi. 561 f.
ai)xmh/: spear-point. Cf. 4.461.
be/blhai: cf. i)/dhai 221. — kenew=na: for the acc., see on knh/mhn *d 519. — diampere/s: clean through, — no mere scratch.
a)nsxh/sesqai: cf. 104, *d 511. be/los is supplied from be/blhai, as the obj. of the infinitive.

e)/dwkas: aor. with reference to the preceding moment when the wound was inflicted. See on h(=ka 125. cf. Hector's words on the departure of Agamemnon, oi)/xet' a)nh\r w(/ristos, e)moi\ de\ me/g) eu)=xos e)/dwken| *zeu\s *kroni/dhs *l 288 f.
286 = 11.384. cf. g 430. — tarbh/sas: dismayed. The use of the aor. is like that in dei/sas 298. “Terror did not come over him.”
“You missed me, but I will not let you try again.”
h)/mbrotes: h(/martes. Aeolic aorist. § 12 g.
ou)d' e)/tuxes: reply to ai)/ ke tu/xwmi 279.
a)ta\r ktl.: reply to ou)de/ s' o)i/w 284, and hence sfw=i is emphasized by ge/.

pri/n ge h)/: sooner than. This pri/n is a conj., and corresponds to the adv. pri/n at the beginning of the verse. cf. 218, ou)d' o(/ ge pri\n *danaoi=sin a)eike/a loigo\n a)pw/sei,| pri/n g) a)po\ patri\ fi/lw| do/menai e(likw/pida kou/rhn *a 97 f.
289 = g 78, *x 267. — ai(/matos a)=sai: paints the savage nature of Ares.
ai(/matos: gen. of material, with a word of fulness.
talau/rinon (tala/*vrinos): shield-bearing. See on sake/spalos 126. Epithet only of Ares.
w(\s fa/menos: cf. 835.

i)/qunen *)aqh/nh: cf. 4.132. The goddess who incited Pandarus to a breach of the truce (4.86 ff.) now helps to overpower him. Without her aid, the lance, hurled by a man standing on the ground, could hardly have taken this course, — entering near the eye, and issuing near the nape of the neck. Possibly Pandarus was stooping.
r(i=na: ‘limit of motion.’

leukou/s: a standing epithet, like that in ga/la leuko/n 902. See § 1 p. It is used more distinctively, of the wild boar, qh/gwn (whetting) leuko\n o)do/nta *l 416, su=s h)/lase leukw=| o)do/nti t 393. — e)pe/rhsen: sc. be/los as subject.
tou=: i.e. Pandarus. Const. with glw=ssan.

a)po/: const. with ta/me. cf. 214, a)po\ stoma/xous a)rnw=n ta/me nhle/i xalkw=| *g 292, a)p' a)sfa/ragon (windpipe) meli/h (ashen spear) ta/me xalkoba/reia *x 328. — glw=san prumnh/n: the tongue at the root. Commentators have found here a special punishment for the tongue of Pandarus which had boasted too much.
e)cesu/qh (seu/w): rushed out, came out. The aor. pass. is often used as an intrans. active verb. See § 32 d.
ai)o/la: gleaming. Cf. sa/kos ai)o/lon e(ptabo/eion *h 222, (qw/rhka) ai)/nut' a)po\ sth/qesfi panai/olon *l 374. This is repeated in more definite form by pamfano/wnta. See on 613.
pare/tressan (tre/w): sprang in fear to the side, shied.
296 = *q 123, 315. — au)=qi: cf. au)tou= 262. — yuxh\ ktl.: life and strength. Cf. qumou= deuome/nous: a)po\ ga\r me/nos ei(/leto xalko/s *g 294. — me/nos: cf. 2.
a)po/rouse: leaped off, sprang down from his chariot in order to defend the corpse of his comrade.

e)rusai/ato: the technical term for the capture (dragging) of an enemy's dead body. cf. kai/ nu/ ken ei)/russe/n te (sc. *(/ektwr *patro/kloio nekro/n) kai\ a)/speton (unspeakable) h)/rato ku=dos *s 165, oi( d' a)llh/lous o)le/kousin,| oi( me\n a)muno/menoi ne/kuos pe/ri teqnhw=tos,| oi( de\ e)ru/ssasqai poti\ *)/ilion h)nemo/essan *s 172 ff.
a)mfi\ ktl.: cf. *p 4. — a)mf) au)tw=|: about himself, i.e. over (bestriding) the dead body. See on 21, 4.493. cf. (dai/mones) luth/rioi a)mfiba/ntes po/lin Aesch. Septem 159.
oi(=: const. with e)/sxe pro/sqe, stretched out for him, i.e. for his defence.
to/n: him, with following generalizing o(/s tis, whoever should. Cf. 332.
tou= ge: i.e. the dead Pandarus. Gen. because of the adverbial idea in a)nti/os. G. 180, 1; H. 754 f. cf. 256, ei) mh/ tis *danaw=n nu=n *(/ektoros a)nti/os ei)=sin *h 98.

302 = *q 321. — smerdale/a_; for the cognate acc., cf. lampro/n 6, smerdale/a ktupe/wn *h 479. For the length of the last syllable, see on ge/neto *d 456. — xerma/dion: for the Homeric use of stones in battle, see on *d 518. — xeiri/: dat. of instrument.
me/ga e)/rgon: a great thing. Cf. the use of me/ga xrh=ma in later Greek,
fe/roien: potential opt. without a)/n.

304 = *m 449, g 287. cf. *m 383, *a 272, q 222 ff. — The poet's contemporaries are thought of as a degenerate race, when compared with the heroes of the Trojan war. Homer appears as a laudator temporis acti, and clearly shows his appreciation of the distance of time which separates him from the events of which he sings. The ‘sagas’ of all nations and times picture the men of former ages as stronger, better, and happier than the men of the present. cf. saxum antiquum, ingens, campo quod forte iacebat,| limes agro positus, litem ut discerneret arvis;| vix illud lecti bis sex cervice subirent,| qualia nunc hominum producit corpora tellus;| ille manu raptum trepida torquebat in hostem Verg. Aen. xii. 897 ff. The theory of progress and development from a ruder and more helpless state, hardly appears before Aeschylus.
pa/lle: swung, preparatory to throwing it. Two men of Homer's time could not carry it, but Diomed swung it easily.
tw=|: with this.
e)/nqa ktl.: defines kat' i)sxi/on more exactly.
te/: correl. with te/ 306. cf. ei)/ per ga/r te xo/lon . . . katape/yh| (digest),| a)lla/ te kai\ meto/pisqen e)/xei ko/ton *a 81 f. See on a)lla/ *a 82; § 3 o.
kotu/lhn ktl.: parenthetical.
mi/n: i.e. the part of the i)sxi/on which has just been defined.

pro\s de/: and besides. Cf. soi\ de\ ma/l' e(/yom) (follow) e)gw/: po/ti d) au)= kai\ e)gei/romen a)/llous *k 108. — a)/mfw te/nonte: both sinews which (in the Homeric view of anatomy) connect thigh bone and socket of the hip joint. See on 4.521.

w)=se [w)qe/w] d) a)po/: a)pe/wse de/. For the adv. use of the prep., cf. 19. For the accent of a)po/, see on u(po/ *d 505. — r(ino/n: the skin, — though the mention of the cuticle is certainly odd at the close of the story.
e)/sth: he stopped, — in contrast with sinking entirely upon the ground. cf. sth= de\ gnu\c e)ripw/n, to/con de/ oi( e)/kpese xeiro/s *q 329. — gnu/c: see on 68.
gai/hs: gen. of place. G. 179, 2; H. 760.
nu/c: here of a swoon. cf. a)xlu/s 696; and *l 356, *c 439, *x 466. Elsewhere of the darkness of death. See on 4.461.
kai/ nu ktl.: cf. 388. Potential of the past, where the Attic would have used a past tense of the ind. with a)/n. § 3 c e; GMT. 440; H. 896.
312 = *g 374. — o)cu/: keenly, i.e. quickly.

mh/thr: added in appos. with *)afrodi/th, and amplified by the rest of the verse. Thus this word forms a sort of connecting link between 312 f. cf. i)xw/r 340, *tudei+/dhs 362, *ai)nei/an 378, nh/pios 406, a)tre/mas 524, *)alfeiou= 545, ou)lome/nhn 876, *(/hrhs 893, *sidoni/wn *z 290, *skaia/s *z 393; and the similar use of ta/wn 320, deinh/n 739, h(rw/wn 747, dei/santas 863, deidio/ta *z 137, prw=ton *z 260. § 1 h.
boukole/onti: cf. *z 25, *ai)nei/as, to\n u(p' *)agxi/sh| te/ke di=) *)afrodi/th,| *)/idhs e)n knhmoi=si qea\ brotw=| eu)nhqei=sa *b 820 f.

e)xeu/ato: the mid. expresses an idea of interest which can be rendered by the possessive pronoun. “Threw both her arms.” cf. a)/nta pareia/wn sxome/nh holding before her cheeks Od. 1.334. — cf. a)mfixuqei\s pate/r' e)sqlo/n p 214. — For the 1st aor. without s, cf. 4.269.
oi(=: const. with ka/luyen, as dat. of interest. cf. 300.
ptu/gma: fold. The pe/plos was open at the side, and full enough to allow the wearer to use it in this way.
ka/luyen: equiv. to kalu/ptousa proe/sxe. cf. 507, *ai)/as d' a)mfi\ *menoitia/dh| sa/kos eu)ru\ kalu/yas| e(sth/kein *p 132 f., pro/sqen de\ sa/kos ste/rnoio ka/luyen *x 313.
e(/rkos bele/wn: on 4.137.
e)/men: cf. *d 299. — taxupw/lwn: cf. 4.232.
xalko/n: often of the sword (as the Eng. uses ‘steel’), but here and freq. of the bronze-tipped spear. cf. 17, 330.
balw\n ktl.: cf. *a 381, *m 150. — balw/n: by hitting.
e)k: const. with e(/loito.

Vergil makes Aeneas refer to this escape from the hands of Diomed, o Danaum fortissime gentis,| Tydide! mene Iliacis occumbere campis| non potuisse tuaque animam hanc effundere dextra Aen. i. 96 ff. — Aeneas was saved by Poseidon, a week later, from the hands of Achilles in a more extraordinary fashion: *ai)nei/an d' e)/sseuen (sc. *poseida/wn) a)po\ xqono\s u(yo/s' a)ei/ras.| polla\s de\ sti/xas h(rw/wn, polla\s de\ kai\ i(/ppwn| *ai)nei/as u(pera=lto qeou= a)po\ xeiro\s o)rou/sas,| i(=ce d) e)p) e)sxatih\n polua/ikos pole/moio g 325 ff.

u(pece/feren: was bearing out from under the impending danger. cf. 377, 6.57 f., deidio/tes: tutqo\n ga\r u(pe\k qana/toio fe/rontai *o 628; also 4.465. — Aeneas was unable to walk, on account of the wound in his hip.
pole/moio: “battle-field.”
ui(o\s *kapanh=os: cf. 241 ff.
sunqesia/wn: cf. sunqesi/ai te kai\ o(/rkia *b 339. Equiv. to e)fetme/wn 818. The Attic sunqh/kh is not Homeric.
ta/wn [tw=n, i.e. tou/twn]: see on mh/thr 313, th/n *d 41.
no/sfin ktl.: cf. 10.416.
floi/sbou: cf. polufloi/sboio qala/sshs *a 34.
*ai)nei/ao: const. with i(/ppous.
e)pai+/cas: intrans. cf. 235. — This capture of the horses of Aeneas is referred to in 8.105 ff., 23.291 f.
dw=ke: sc. i(/ppous.
*dhipu/lw|: mentioned only here.
o(mhliki/hs: of his equals in age, comrades. Abstract for concrete. cf. of Helen (lipou=sa) o(mhliki/hn e)rateinh/n *g 175, o( ga\r o(mhliki/hn e)ke/kasto b 158. — oi(=: i.e. Sthenelus.
o(/ti ktl.: cf. t 248. — fresi/n: local, in his breast. cf. (of Thersites) e)/pea fresi\n h(=|sin a)/kosma/ te polla/ te h)/|dh *b 213. — a(/rtia h)/|dh: was of one mind.
nhusi\n ... e)laune/men: cf. *l 274, *o 259.
nhusi\n e)/pi: “to the camp.”
e)laune/men: preferred to e)lau/nein before the Bucolic diaeresis. cf. e(ce/men 473, polemize/men 520. § 39 g. —Inf. of purpose, loosely added; “for driving.”
w(=n: reflexive possessive, his own.
e)/labe: sc. from the a)/ntuc. cf. 322.
h(ni/a ktl.: cf. 226.

*tudei+/dhn: acc. after the prep. in me/qepe i(/ppous “he drove his horses after.” cf. 632, *patro/klw| e)/fepe i(/ppous *p 724. — kraterw/nuxas: with no special emphasis after mw/nuxas 321, and kalli/trixas 323, but filling a different metrical space.

*ku/prin: Aphrodite bears this name in Homer only in this Fifth Book. cf. 422, 458, 760, 883. But in Od. 8.362 ff. she has a sanctuary at Paphos. The same name is given to her in the ‘Homeric Hymn’ to Aphrodite. This has been urged as one of several indications of a Cyprian origin of the poet of E.
gignw/skwn: sc. as the result of 127 f. — o(/ t): o(/ti te. cf. 433.
a)/nalkis: “without a)lkh/.”
ta/wn ai(/ te: cf. to\n o(/s tis 301.
a)ndrw=n: const. with po/lemon. cf. *d 84, ma/xhn katadu/menai a)ndrw=n *g 241, a)ndrw=n te ptole/mous *w 8.
ka/ta: for the retraction of the accent, see § 37 c.
koirane/ousin: cf. 824.
*)aqhnai/h: notably the chief divinity of war in Homer.
*)enuw/: a female counterpart of Ares, who is *)enua/lios, *b 651; cf. 592. cf. the Roman Bellona.
334-453. Aphrodite is wounded by Diomed, and taken to Olympus in the chariot of Ares. Aeneas is carried to the Pergamus by Apollo, and healed there.
e)ki/xane: sc. *ku/prin. For the impf., cf. 65.
kaq' o(/milon: cf. 528; on *d 209. — o)pa/zwn: pressing forward. Cf. 16.462.
e)poreca/menos: thrusting out, reaching out. Cf. 4.307. Const. closely with op)/tase. The partics., as often, add to the picturesqueness of the description.
a)/krhn xei=ra: more definitely described in 339. cf. 458.

ou)/tase: wounded by a thrust from the lance. Always of a wound inflicted by something held, not thrown. See on *d 540. — meta/lmenos: leaping after, in order to inflict the wound. cf. e)pa/lmenos o)ce/i douri/ *a 421, douri\ meta/lmenos *c 443.

a)blhxrh/n: tender, delicate. The opposite of paxei/h| 309. cf. 425. — This epithet is added as an afterthought, and is in close connexion with the rest of the verse. — xroo\s [xrwto/s, § 18 e] ktl.: pierced (against) the flesh.
a)mbrosi/ou: the robe of Artemis also is a)mbro/sios *f 507, and that of Helen is nekta/reos *g 385.
xa/rites: the natural attendants and servants of the goddess of love. — Athena made her own clothes; cf. 735.
ka/mon: cf. 4.187.
prumno/n: as substantive.
qe/naros: i.e. the fleshy, hollow part of the hand, near the wrist.
i)xw/r: only here and 416, of the blood of the gods. — This corrects and limits the statement of the preceding verse. See on 313.
r(e/ei: flows. In a different sense from r(e/e 339. See on de/deco 228.
qeoi=sin: dat. of interest; not local. — cf. ‘From the gash| A stream of nectarous humor issuing flowed| Sanguine, such as celestial spirits may bleed,’ Milton Par. Lost vi. 331 ff., of Satan.
ga/r: introduces an explanation of i)xw/r as a more accurate statement of ai(=ma.

ou) pi/nousi: this ‘asyndeton’ is natural in any language. “They do not eat; they do not drink.” cf. ou) ga\r e)moi\ pei/qesq' , ou) *me/ntori poime/ni law=n w 456. — The gods eat immortality (a)mbrosi/a).
ai)/qopa: cf. 4.259.
tou/neka: cf. *d 477. — a)nai/mones (ai(=ma): i.e. without human blood. Equiv. to the later a)/naimoi. — kale/ontai: are called, i.e. are. cf. ke/klhmai *d 61.
me/ga, a)po/: for the ‘quantity’ of the ultimas, cf. ge/neto *d 456. a)po*ve/o seems to have become nearly a)poue/o, — the ‘vau’ being vocalized and becoming attached to the preceding syllable.
i)a/xousa: the following hiatus is justified by the pause. — ka/mbalen [kate/balen]: let fall.
meta\ xersi/n: (between, i.e.) in his arms. Equiv. to e)n xersi/n. — e)ru/ssato: guarded, protected. Cf. *l 363, g 450, c 279, x 372.
*foi=bos *)apo/llwn: the most faithful supporter and defender of the Trojans.
th|= d' e)pi/: see on 101.
ei)=ke pole/mou: yield, withdraw from the fray. Cf. Helen's words to Aphrodite, qew=n d' a)po/eike keleu/qou *g 406.
pole/mou: for the gen., see on xa/rmhs *d 509.
h)= ou)x: as one syllable. § 7 a.
a(/lis: sc. e)sti/. Is it not enough?
h)peropeu/eis: cf. Helen's words, daimoni/h, ti/ me tau=ta lilai/eai h)peropeu/ein; *g 399. Hector calls Paris h)peropeuta/ *g 39.

su/ ge: emphasized with reference to 349. “You have no place on the battle-field; your work is to lead astray weak women.” The emphasis may be rendered by an adv. expression: “But if you, nevertheless.”
pwlh/seai: frequentative of pe/lomai. Shalt often come. The fut. in a future cond. is esp. common when the condition contains a ‘threat or warning.’ GMT. 447.
h)= te: then, in truth. Cf. Od. 1.288.
“The goddess would be so hurt that she would thenceforth shudder at the very mention of war.” — pu/qhai [pu/qh|]: cf. ma/xhs e)pu/qonto kai\ a)/lloi *o 224.
352-430. Flight of Aphrodite and her reception on Olympus.
a)lu/ousa: frantic, beside herself, with pain.
a)pebh/seto: this ‘mixed’ aor. (§ 30 j) secures a dactyl before the Bucolic diaeresis. cf. 745; see on e)laune/men 327. — tei/reto de/: “for she was distressed.”

podh/nemos: cf. qei/ein (in running) d' a)ne/moisin o(moi=oi *k 437, of the horses of the Thracian Rhesus. Iris is a)ello/pos *q 409. — Iris here acts on her own impulse, as in 3.121, where she brings Helen to the Scaean Gate, and 23.198 ff., where she calls the winds to rouse the fire in the pyre of Patroclus.
melai/neto (sc. *)afrodi/th): lit. was dyeing herself dark red, as the blood (me/lan ai(=ma *d 149) flowed. Much like miai/neto. — xro/a [xrw=ta]: sc. xeiro/s.
e)p' a)ristera/: sc. of the Greek line. On the bank of the Scamander; cf. 36.
h)e/ri ktl.: the spear seemed to lean on a thick bank of mist which concealed the god and his belongings. cf. 776.

i(/ppw: the verb is suited only to e)/gxos. A similar verb is implied for i(/ppw. See § 2 t. — Ares had taken his chariot with him, like the mortal chieftains and the other warlike divinities who descended from Olympus in order to take part in the battle. cf. 720 ff., 8.382 ff., 13.23 ff., 15.119 ff.
gnu\c ktl.: on 68.
kasignh/toio: const. with i(/ppous. The second half-verse of 357 is closely joined to that of 358.
polla/: for the cognate acc., cf. 528, polla\ d' e)/peit) a)pa/neuqe kiw\n h)ra=q) o( geraio/s *a 35. For the length of the ‘ultima,’ see § 41 j.
xrusa/mpuxas: cf. 720.
fi/le: on *d 155. — ko/misai ktl.: care for me, “bring me home,” sc. by giving his horses.
do\s de/: a change of construction. Instead of te/, which is expected, de/ is used, forming a sort of contrast. dou/s might have been used in prose.
cf. *q 456, *ou)lumpo/nd' , o(/qi fasi\ qew=n e(/dos a)sfale\s ai)ei\| e)/mmenai z 42 f.
a)/xqomai: only here with such a cognate acc. ou)de\n h)/xqeto Xen. An. i. I. 8 is clearly different.

o(/: ‘acc. of effect’ with ou)/tasen. cf. 795, ou)lh/n (scar), th/n pote me\n su=s h)/lase leukw=| o)do/nti t 393, e(/lkea a(/ ken ma/rpth|si (fasten upon) kerauno/s *q 405, e(/lkea o(/ss' e)tu/ph *w 421. G. 159, 3; H. 714.
a)nh/r: made more definite by the following verse. On fw=ta *d 194.
nu=n ge: “now, at least, to judge from my experience.”
kai\ *dii/: even with Zeus, if the latter should oppose him in the fight.
a)/ra: so, “as she had requested.”
e)/bainen: was on her way. Durative.
h)=tor: for the acc., cf. kh=r 399, *d 272.
pa\r de\ ktl.: cf. 3.262.
e)/baine: sc. e)s di/fron, as h(ni/oxos. cf. parabebh/kee de/ oi( (i.e. Xerxes) h(ni/oxos Hdt. vii. 40.
kai\ h(ni/a ktl.: cf. *p 482, *w 441, g 483. — la/zeto: cf. 4.357.
ma/sticen ktl.: cf. z 82. — e)la/an [e)la=n, § 29 c]: sc. i(/ppous as object.

e(/dos: acc. of ‘limit of motion.’ cf. ‘ere he arrive| The happy ile,’ Milton Par. Lost ii. 409 f., ‘those powers that the queen| Hath raised in Gallia have arrived our coast,’ Shakspere 3 Henry VI. v. 3. 8, ‘But ere we could arrive the point pro posed,’ id. Julius Caesar i. 2. 110. — cf. 360.
e)/sthse: stationed, stopped. Cf. sth=sen *d 298.

para/: the tables of men stood beside them, not in front of them, in Homeric times. Thus si=ton pare/qhke a 139 is the natural expression for “placed food before him.” The terms are transferred to horses. cf. u(mi=n (i.e. the horses of Hector) pa\r prote/roisi meli/frona puro\n (wheat) e)/qhken *q 188.
e)n gou/nasi: cf. 6.81 f. Aphrodite prob. did not sit down in her mother's lap, but hid her face there, sinking on the floor.

*diw/nhs: only here in Homer. She was worshipped with Zeus and shared his temple at Dodona. Strabo vii. 329, however, says that her worship at Dodona was not original. She seems to have been another form of Hera. Aphrodite is called *diwnai/a by Theocritus, xv. 106. — Homer knows nothing of the story of Aphrodite's birth from the foam of the sea, any more than he does of Athena's springing in full armor from the head of Zeus (on 4.515).
a)gka/s: in her arms. Perhaps an old locative, for a)gka/si.
e)la/zeto: clasped.
qugate/ra: on me/ga 343.
372 = *a 361, *z 485, *w 127, d 610, e 181. — For the formula, see § 1 s.
se/, toia/de: for the two accs., — of person (dir. obj.) and thing (cognate), see G. 165; H. 725 a.
e)/rece: for the single r after the augment, see § 25 g.
*ou)raniw/nwn: for the patronymic form, see § 21 a. — Dione assumes that no mortal would have dared to inflict the wound.
w(s ei): much like Attic w(/sper. ei) is not necessary, but makes prominent the fact that the comparison is a mere conception of the mind.
r(e/zousan: const. with se/.
e)nwph=|: before the eyes. “An open offender,” “caught in the act.”
filommeidh/s: cf. 4.10. The epithet is not particularly appropriate here.
ou(/neka ktl.: reply to 374. “This was my only offence.”
u(pece/feron ktl.: cf. 318.
*ai)nei/an: for the appos. of the name, with a following amplify ing clause, cf. *tudei+/dhs 362; see on 313.
ga/r: introduces an explanation of 376. “The strife is no longer between Trojans and Achaeans, but between the Danaans and the gods.”
fu/lopis: cf. 4.15.
*danaoi/: the change from *)axaioi/ 379 is only for metrical convenience; it has no rhetorical force nor significance of meaning.
di=a qea/wn: cf. *z 305, di=a gunaikw=n *g 423. The gen. is partitive, since di=a is superlative in meaning.
cf. *a 586. — a)na/sxeo (a)ne/xw): be patient.
khdome/nh: follows the natural gender of te/knon. cf. 638, h(=lqe d' e)pi\ yuxh\ *qhbai/ou *teiresi/ao| xru/seon skh=ptron e)/xwn l 90 f.

A frequent Homeric method of consolation. ‘Misery loves company.’ Solamen miseris socios habuisse malorum. Dione comforts her daughter by recounting the examples of Ares, Hera, and Hades, who had suffered worse than she. Thus in Soph. Ant. 944 ff., the chorus compare Antigone's fate to that of Danaë, of Lycurgus, and of Cleopatra.
ga/r: refers to te/tlaqi.

e)c a)ndrw=n: const. with tlh=men, which has a passive idea. u(po/ might have been used. G. 191, I. 3; H. 798 c. — Athena not only hated Ares and Aphrodite, but had aroused Diomed to attack them. cf. 405, 873 f.
tlh= [e)/tlh] me/n: cf. tlh= de/ 392, 395. A repetition in detail of tlh=men 383, and hence needs no connexion by a conj. with the preceding.

*)=wtos, *)efia/lths: cf. kai/ r() e)/teken (sc. *)ifime/deia) du/o pai=de, minunqadi/w d<*> gene/sqhn,| *)=wto/n t) a)nti/qeon thlekleito/n t) *)efia/lthn,| ou(\s dh\ mhki/stous qre/ye zei/dwros a)/roura| kai\ polu\ kalli/stous meta/ ge kluto\n *)wri/wna:| e)nne/wroi (nine years old) ga\r toi/ ge kai\ e)nneaph/xees h)=san| eu)=ros, a)ta\r mh=ko/s ge gene/sqhn e)nneo/rguioi (nine fathoms).| . . . *)/ossan e)p' *ou)lu/mpw| me/masan qe/men, au)ta\r e)p) *)/ossh|| *ph/lion ei)nosi/fullon, i(/n) ou)rano\s a)mbato\s ei)/h l 307 ff. — Possibly this story was an allegory, — the god of war bound for a full year by the farmer's sons, in the interests of the crops.
*)alwh=os: rather of Poseidon, acc. to Od. 11.306.
dh=san: cf. desmw=| e)n a)rgale/w| de/deto o 232.

xalke/w|: disyllabic. ke/ramos clearly must have come to mean simply jar, before it could be used of a bronze jar. cf. xru/sei) a)la/bastra Theoc. xv. 114. See on ne/ktar e)w|no- xo/ei *d 3. — e)n kera/mw|: in (earthenware, i.e.) a jar. The great earthen jars which have been found on the Acropolis at Athens and by Dr. Schliemann at Hissarlik, correspond in size to modern casks. Such a one served Diogenes as a chamber (his ‘tub’). cf. the story of ‘Ali Baba and the Forty Thieves.’
de/deto: lay bound. Cf. pe/fantai 531.
cf. 311. — The hiatus is justified at the verse-pause. The second half-verse may be taken as in appos. with the subj. of a)po/loito.
a)=tos: cf. 289.

mhtruih/: sc. of Otus and Ephialtes, who, like the step-mothers of the fiction of all times, hated her predecessor's sons. — In the heroic times men in general were not expected to marry again after the death of the first wife.
*(erme/a|: Hermes was wellfitted by his cunning for all deeds of stealth. cf. g 35, *w 24.
e)ce/kleyen: brought out by stealth.
teiro/menon: worn out, exhausted.
de/: the Eng. idiom expects ga/r, for this clause explains teiro/menon.
e)da/mna: was overpowering, was weakening.

kratero\s ktl.: cf. *)amfitru/wnos ui(o\s me/nos ai)e
 a)teirh/s l 270. — Heracles is called here the son of Amphitryo, but in 396 he is ui(o\s *dio/s. So Helen is daughter of Tyndareüs, 3.140, and again *dio\s e)kgegaui=a *g 199. — This story is borrowed from old songs about Nestor and Heracles. Acc. to one myth, Heracles made war on Neleus (Nestor's father), to whose aid Hera and other gods came; but, aided by Zeus and Athena, Heracles overcame all his foes. cf. a)gaqoi\ de\ kai\ sofoi\ kata\ dai/mon' a)/ndres| e)ge/nont). e)pei\ a)nti/on| pw=s a)
 trio/dontos *(hrakle/hs sku/talon ti/nace xersi/n,| a(ni/k) a)mfi\ *pu/lon staqei\s h)/reide *poseida=n| h)/reide/n te/ nin a)rgure/w| to/cw| pelemi/zwn| *foi=bos, ou)d) *)ai/das a)kinh/tan e)/xe r(a/bdon,| bro/tea sw/maq) a(=| kata/gei koi/lan e)s a)guia
| qnasko/ntwn Pind. Ol. ix. 28 ff.
triglw/xini: three-barbed. Cf. *d 151, *l 507.
kai/: belongs to the whole thought, and marks the effect of beblh/kei. — a)nh/keston (a)/kos, cf. 402): only here and 15.217.
e)n toi=si: among these, sc. suffering divinities (383). cf. o(ppo/te ken tou/tous kte/wmen, . . . e)n de\ su\ toi=sin e)/peita pefh/seai x 216 f.
w)ku/n: cf. o)cu\ be/los *d 185, be/los w)ku/ 106.
wu(to/s: that same, i.e. Heracles. This ‘crasis’ only here. § 8.

e)n pu/lw| ktl.: in the gateway, among the dead. This seems to refer to the time when Heracles fetched up the three-headed dog Cerberus for Eurystheus, while Hades, surrounded by the dead, stood in the portal of the nether world and would prevent his passage. But it may refer to the same contest as that in which Hera was wounded. See on 392.
o)du/nh|sin ktl.: cf. r 567, m' a)xe/essi/ ge dw/seis t 167, au)to\n e)gw\ *moi/saisi dw/sw Pind. Pyth. iv. 67.
dw=ma *dio/s, *)/olumpon: the former is put first as the more specific.
kh=r: cf. h)=tor 364. — o)du/nh|si ktl.: cf. o)du/nh de\ dia\ xroo\s h)=lq' a)legeinh/ *l 398, (xei\r) o)cei/h|s o)du/nh|sin e)lh/latai *p 518. — peparme/nos (pei/rw): pierced.
h)lh/lato: had been driven, was in. Cf. de/deto 387. — kh=de ktl.: cf. 11.458.
tw=|: for him.
e)pi/: const. with pa/sswn. cf. 4.218.

*paih/wn: the Healer of the gods. Elsewhere in Homer only 899 and Od. 4.232. He was identified later with Apollo or Asclepius. cf. a)/lloi *paiw=nos polufarma/kou e)/rgon e)/xontes| i)htroi/ Solon xii. 57.
o)dunh/fata: lit. painkilling.
h)ke/sato: sc. to/n from tw=|.
ou)/ ti: not at all, by no means. Cf. ou)de/n. — Hades might be wounded and hurt, as Aphrodite was; but being a god, he was immortal. cf. Apollo's words to Achilles, ou)/ toi mo/rsimo/s ei)mi *x 13.

sxe/tlios, o)brimoergo/s: nom. of exclamation, in vexation at Heracles. G. 157 N.; H. 707 b. cf. nh/pios 406. Such adjective-exclamations are generally followed, as here, by a clause which gives the reason for the exclamation.
ou)k o)/qeto: here followed by a supplementary participle. cf. the const. of ai)sxu/nomai.
o(\s ktl.: this rel. clause is added without a conj., since it is explanatory, introducing an example of the preceding statement.

e)/khde: troubled, wounded. Cf. 400. — Obs. that Heracles's weapon in Homer is the bow. He is said not to have appeared in literature with a club before Stesichorus, — but representations of him so armed are found on very early coins.
soi\ d' e)pi/: e)pi\ de\ soi/. On 124.
a)nh=ke: cf. a)niei=sa 422, a)ne/ntes 761.
nh/pios: cf. 2.38, demens! qui nimbos . . . simularet Verg. Aen. vi. 590 f. For its position in the verse, see § 1 h.
to/: refers to the fg. verse. cf. 665, where to/ is explained by a following infinitive, 4.163.
ma/l' ou): not at all. Cf. Thersites' words, a)lla\ ma/l) ou)x *)axilh=i xo/los fresi/n *b 241. — dhnaio/s (dh/n diu): only here. For the thought, cf. 6.130 ff.
o(\s ma/xhtai: for the subjv. without a)/n in a general cond. sent., cf. 4.131, 141.

poti\ [pro\s] gou/nasin: at his knees, “gathering about him.” Const. closely with pai=des. — pappa/zousin: the Phaeacian princess Nausicaa addresses her father pa/ppa fi/le z 57. cf. tw=| d' ou)/ ti gunh\ kai\ nh/pia te/kna| oi)/kade nosth/santi pari/statai m 42 f. — “His children do not rejoice in his return from the war,” i.e. he does not return. cf. 150.

e)lqo/nta: the force of the neg. covers the partic. as well as the finite verb. The partic., as freq., contains the more important thought. cf. Thetis's words of her son, to\n d' ou)x u(pode/comai au)=tis| oi)/kade nosth/santa *s 440 f.
tw=|: therefore.
nu=n: Dione applies the general principle (407409) to the present case.
ei) kai\ ktl.: cf. *n 316, q 139, x 13.
mh/: lest, introduces a warning, an ‘object-clause’ of fraze/sqw. — a)mei/nwn sei=o [sou=]: i.e. some such god as Apollo; cf. 437. cf. mh/ ti/s toi ta/xa *)/irou a)mei/nwn a)/llos a)nasth=| s 334.
mh/: warns against the consequences if some mightier god should enter the combat.
dh/n: long. Const. with goo/wsa. — peri/frwn: thrown by the rhythm with *)adrhsti/nh.

*)adrhsti/nh: for the fem. patronymic, see § 21 i. Cf. also *eu)hni/nh, *i 557, daughter of Euenus; and *)wkeani/nh (of the Styx) Hesiod Theog. 389. — Diomed's father, Tydeus, acc. to 14.121, married a daughter of Adrastus, king of Argos. Thus Diomed seems to have married his aunt; as Iphidamas married his mother's sister, 11.226. But perhaps *)adrhsti/nh may be used for grand-daughter of Adrastus, as *ai)aki/dhs, *b 860, is applied to Achilles, the grandson of Aeacus. In the latter case, Aegialea would be Diomed's cousin.
e)c u(/pnou: const. with e)gei/rh|. All in the house are roused by her lamentations.
oi)kh=as: need not in Homer be equiv. to oi)ke/tai in the later sense, but household. Cf. 6.366.
to\n a)/riston ktl.: the expression which would be in Aegialea's mind, while poqe/ousa, — but also natural enough, at this juncture, on Dione's lips.
Impressive formal designation (suggested by po/sin 414), in appos. with *ai)gia/leia 412.
a)mfote/rh|sin: sc. xersi/n. G. 139 N.; H. 621 c.
a)po/: const. with o)mo/rgnu. cf. a)pomo/rcato da/kru *b 269, a)/mfw xei=r' a)pomo/rgnu *s 414, a)pomorcame/nw koni/hn *y 739.
i)xw=: acc. of i)xw/r 340. It assumes a nom. i)xw/s.
xeiro/s: ablatival gen., from the hand of Aphrodite.
a)/lqeto xei/r: sc. at the mere touch of Dione. — Obs. the ‘asyndeton’ and the ‘chiastic’ relation to the preceding clause. cf. 4.491.
au)=te: on the other hand.
ei)soro/wsai: cf. 4.4. These goddesses had watched the whole scene between Dione and her daughter.

*)aqhnai/h ktl.: cf. 4.20. — When Athena returned to Olympus, the poet does not say. See on 133. Diomed has been acting independently since 290, but in accordance with her directions. Her departure from the battle-field makes possible the interference of Ares; cf. 461, 510.
kertomi/ois: cf. 4.6.
e)re/qizon: teased, in return for Zeus's mocking words, 4.7-12. — The pl. is used, though only Athena speaks.
toi=si: dat. of interest. i.e. Zeus, Athena, and Hera.

*zeu= pa/ter, h)= r(a/ ti: cf. 762, *h 446, *q 236. — h)= r(a ktl.: cf. *d 93. h)= r(a is much like Attic a)=ra, but expresses more feeling. — “Will you be angry,” i.e. do not be vexed. cf. Od. 1.158. Athena does not ask for information.

h)= mala dh/: surely now, the truth really is. Ironical. cf. h)= ma/la dh\ *trw=es megalh/tores, ou(/s per e)/pefnon,| au)=tis a)nasth/sontai *f 55 f., Achilles's words at sight of Lycaon whom he had sold to Lemnos, but who had returned. — The reference to Aphrodite's relation to Helen is obvious.
e)/kpagla ktl.: conceived mighty love. Cf. Aphrodite's words to Helen, mh\ xwsame/nh se meqei/w (give thee up),| tw=s (thus) de/ s' a)pexqh/rw, w(s nu=n e)/kpagla fi/lhsa *g 414 f.
tw=n tina ktl.: in familiar conversational style repeats tina\ *)axaiia/dwn 422, after the humorous 423. cf. 79.
karre/zousa: cf. kate/recen 372. For the form, see § 11 b.
*)axaiia/dwn ktl.: this clause, in appos. with tw=n, heightens the contrast of the hypothetical situation with the truth, — the mighty Diomed with his spear.

pero/nh|: brooch, by which the robe (pe/plos) was fastened at the shoulder and down the side. This is made prominent by the verse-pause. — “Not by a spear was she wounded, but she scratched her hand on a breastpin!”
a(raih/n: delicate little. Cf. 337.
kalessa/menos: calling to him.
xruse/hn: because of the goddess's golden ornaments. cf. Venus aurea Verg. Aen. x. 16. Similarly, Ares is xa/lkeos, 704, because of his bronze armor and arms.

Plutarch, de aud. poet. 36 a, says that these verses ou)de\n diafe/rei tou= ‘gnw=qi sauto/n.’ cf. nescio quo pacto, tibi ego possim, mihi tu dicere: te/knon e)mo\n . . . mete/rxeo e)/rga lo/goio Cic. ad Att. xiv. 13.
polemh/ia: equiv. to a gen., and contrasted with ga/moio. cf. qei=on *z 180.

tau=ta: i.e. polemh/ia e)/rga. — qow=|: quick, swift, with reference to readiness for action in war. cf. 536, 571, 8.215, (Ares) kalo/s te kai\ a)rti/pos q 310. — melh/sei: will be a care. Cf. 6.492. — “Ares and Athena will see to the war; you need not trouble yourself about that.”
The whole scene, 370-430, is intended to afford a relief to the descriptions of conflicts on the battlefield.
431-469. Renewed battle. Diomed and Apollo. Apollo and Ares.
431 = 274. — The story returns to Diomed. cf. 347.
gignw/skwn: concessive. The clearness of vision which Athena had bestowed (127), enabled Diomed's eyes to penetrate the cloud (345) which concealed Apollo and Aeneas.
u(pei/rexe xei=ras: on 4.249. cf. 344, where Apollo holds Aeneas in his arms. — In later Greek, u(pere/xoi or u(pere/xei would have been used. GMT. 674, 1.
a)/ra: “as was clear” from his attack on Aeneas under these circumstances.
ou)de/: not even. This was not in opposition to the letter of Athena's injunction, 129 f.
a(/zeto: revered.
a)po/: const. with du=sai. cf. ei(/mata a)podu/s e 343. — du=sai: differs from du=nai as bh=sai from bh=nai.
tri/s: cf. 136, *z 435, tri\s me\n mermh/rice, . . . tri\s de\ ktu/pe (thundered) mhti/eta *zeu/s *q 169 f.
e)/peita: then, points back to e)po/rouse 432, which is here repeated.

tri\s de/: for the repetition of tri/s, see on 4.415. cf. tri\s me
 e)p' a)gkw=nos (projecting corner) bh= tei/xeos u(yhloi=o| *pa/troklos, tri\s d' au)to
 a)pestufe/licen *)apo/llwn *p 702 f., tri\s me
 e)/peit' e)po/rouse poda/rkhs di=os *)axilleu\s| e)/gxei xalkei/w|, tri\s d) h)e/ra tu/ye baqei=an g 445 f., tri\s me
 e)/peit' e)po/rouse, . . . tri\s d) e)nne/a fw=tas e)/pefnen *p 784 f.
oi(= e)stufe/lice a)spi/da: struck for him the shield, i.e. struck Diomed's shield, in order to thrust him back.

438 = *p 705, 786, g 447; cf. *x 208. — to\ te/tarton: the preceding tri/s has prepared the way for the dem. to/. cf. *b 329. — dai/moni i)=sos: sc. in his superhuman strength. cf. g 493, *f 18. — e)pe/ssuto ktl.: cf. 459, 884, 21.227.
e)pe/ssuto: for the form, see §§ 25 f, 35.
cf. *p 706, g 448. — deina\ o(moklh/sas: with a terrible shout. A strengthened fwnh/sas. cf. *d 508, *z 54. — de/: in apod. after o(/te. § 3 n. Cf. *d 221. — prose/fh: sc. mi/n.

fra/zeo: bethink thyself. Cf. fra/sai *a 83, fra/zeo, *pouluda/ma, kai/ moi nhmerte\s e)ni/spes *c 470. — The rhyme with xa/zeo may be intended, but prob. not. cf. 3, 239, 560, *z 143, — mhde/: const. with e)/qele. cf. *a 277, *b 247.

i)=sa frone/ein: have equal spirit, “think thyself the equal.” cf. i)=son e)moi\ fa/sqai kai\ o(moiwqh/menai a)/nthn *a 187. — ou)/ pote ktl.: cf. e)pei\ ou)/ poq' o(moi/hs (i.e. much greater) e)/mmore timh=s| skhptou=xos basileu/s *a 278 f.

xamai\ ktl.: forms but one idea, like e)pixqoni/wn (cf. a)nqrw/pwn xamaigene/wn Pind. Pyth. iv. 98); contrast qeoi=sin e)pourani/oisi *z 129. Hence te/ has the third place in its clause; cf. boh\n a)gaqo/n te *poli/thn *w 250.

444 = *p 711. — a)leua/menos: avoiding. Cf. oi)/xetai ei)s a(/la di=an, a)leua/menos xo/lon ai)pu/n *o 223, ou)d' a)\n e)gw\ *dio\s e)/xqos a)leua/menos pefidoi/mhn| ou)/te seu= ou)/q' e(ta/rwn i 277 f. (Polyphemus to Odysseus).
*perga/mw|: on *d 508. — ei)n: cf. 160. For the dat. after a verb of motion, cf. 346, 370, 583; see G. 191 N. 6; H. 788.
o(/qi ktl.: a more definite statement of the thought of the first half-verse. cf. 791, 804, 837.
*lhtw\ ktl.: Apollo's mother and sister share his home. So also at Delphi.
i)oxe/aira: on 53.
a)du/tw| [a)/-du-ton]: neut. adj. as subst., the sanctum sanctorum. Mentioned only here and in 512.
ku/dainon (ku=dos): i.e. strengthened. On 906.

ei)/dwlon (‘idol’): a wraith. — Vergil amplifies: tum dea nube cava tenuem sine viribus umbram| in faciem Aeneae — visu mirabile monstrum —| Dardaniis ornat telis clipeumque iubasque| divini adsimulat capitis, dat inania verba,| dat sine mente sonum gressusque effingit euntis:| morte obita qualis fama est volitare figuras| aut quae sopitos deludunt somnia sensus.| at primas laeta ante acies exultat imago Aen. x. 636 ff.
au)tw=|: himself, i.e. in person, as contrasted with teu/xesi in arms. § 1 h fin.
toi=on: i.e. *ai)nei/a| i)/kelon.
a)mfi\ sth/qessi: const. with boei/as.

boei/as (sc. a)spi/das): fem. adj. as subst., oxhide shields. This is the general term, with which a)spi/das and laish/ia are in partitive apposition. The shields were mainly of leather, though they frequently had an outer layer of bronze. cf., of the renowned shield of Ajax, 7.220 f., quoted on 619.
eu)ku/klous: well-rimmed. Of the parallel rods about the edge.

laish/ia: targes, smaller shields of rough, untanned hide, without layers of bronze. cf. kai\ ge/rra e)/labon daseiw=n bow=n w)mobo/eia Xen. An. iv. 7. 22, (*ki/likes) laish/ia/ te ei)=xon a)nt' a)spi/dwn, w)moboe/hs pepoihme/na Hdt. vii. 91, (*ko/lxoi) a)spi/das de\ w)moboi+/nas smikra\s ei)=xon ib. 79.
ptero/enta: so called because of the fluttering piece of leather which hung from the targe and afforded some protection to the lower part of the bearer's body and the upper part of his legs.
454-710. The Trojans press forward, aided by Ares. Aeneas returns to the field.
dh\ to/te: cf. 136
ou)k a)\n dh/: on 32.
ma/xhs: ablatival gen. with e)ru/saio, drag from the battle. This assumes Diomed's death. cf. (ei) de\) e)/lqoi teqnhw\s kai/ min e)rusai/meqa xa/rmhs *r 161.
= 883 f.; cf. *r 601, x 277. — sxedo/n: cominus.
xei=ra: partitive appos. with *ku/prida. — e)pi\ karpw=|: at the wrist. Cf. 336 f.
au)tw=| moi: Attic e)mautw=|. § 24 c.
e)pe/ssuto ktl.: cf. 438.

Only once does Apollo take an active part in the battle, viz. 16.788 ff., where he strikes Patroclus with the flat of his hand. Elsewhere he satisfies himself with ‘moral’ aid and encouragement to the Trojans.
*trw/|as: adj. contracted from *trwi/as.

*)aka/manti: slain by Ajax, 6.6 ff. — Ares himself was a Thracian. cf. (*)/arhs and *fo/bos fi/los ui(o/s) tw\ me\n a)/r' e)k *qrh/|khs *)efu/rous me/ta qwrh/ssesqon *n 301, Gradivumque patrem, Geticis qui praesidet arvis Verg. Aen. iii. 35. So Ares withdraws to Thrace, just as Aphrodite goes to Cyprus, Od. 8.361.
h(gh/tori^: only here, 11.572, and Od. 10.234, is a vowel left short before a mute and a liquid at this point of the verse.
e)s ti/: to what point, how long, quousque? Equiv. to me/xri ti/nos, which appears in Homer only in te/o me/xris *w 128.
ti/ e)/ti: the i of ti/ is never clided.
*)axaioi=s: dat. of agent with the passive ktei/nesqai, as with da/mnasqai *q 244, u(poklone/esqai *f 556.
h)= ei)s: for the ‘synizesis,’ cf. 349.
a)mfi\ pu/lh|s: about the gates. Cf. e(/stasan a)mfi\ *menoitia/dh| *r 267.
kei=tai a)nh/r: cf. 16.558. A motive to urge the sons of Priam to vigorous action.
floi/sboio: cf. 322.
saw/somen: ‘hortatory’ subjunctive.
470-518. Sarpedon and Hector. Ares and Aeneas, who is now restored to strength.
w(\s ei)pw/n: with these words.
me/nos ktl.: might and courage.
e)/nq' au)=: on 1.

*sarphdw/n: leader of the Lycians. The bravest of the allies, and regarded by the Trojans as e(/rma po/lhos *p 549 prop of the city. His ‘family-tree’ is described in 6.152 ff. He led in the attack on the Achaean camp in M, and was slain by Patroclus, 16.480 ff.
ph=| ktl.: a rhetorical question. cf. ph=| dh\ sunqesi/ai te kai\ o(/rkia bh/setai h(mi=n; *b 339.
e)/xeskes: for the ‘iterative’ formation, see § 36 b.

fh=s [e)/fhsqa] pou: thou saidst, methinks. A gentle jest. cf. Achilles's words, *(/ektor, a)ta/r pou e)/fhs *patroklh=) e)cenari/zwn| sw=s e)/ssesqai *x 331 f. — The ‘asyndeton’ shows the speaker's excitement.
e(ce/men: that thou wouldst keep safe. Prob. a play upon Hector's name (Keeper, Protector). § 2 c. — For the form, cf. e)laune/men 327.
This verse makes a)/ter law=n more definite.
gambroi=si: here, sisters' husbands.
Possibly an allusion to the absence of Paris from the conflict.
tw=n: an adversative de/ is expected; its place is taken by nu=n.
i)de/ein, noh=sai: a Homeric pair. § 1 s.
du/namai: for the elision of ai, see § 10 a.

ku/nes w(/s: for the order of words and the ‘quantity’ of the last syllable of ku/nes, cf. *d 471, 482. — a)mfi\ le/onta: about a lion, around which men form a circle at a distance but they do not dare attack him. cf. a)mfi\ de\ to/n ge (i.e. le/onta) ku/nes t' a)/ndres te nomh=es| polla\ ma/l) i)u/zousin (shout) a)po/proqen ou)d' e)qe/lousin| a)nti/on e)lqe/menai . . . w(\s tw=n ou)/ tini qumo\s e)to/lma| a)nti/on e)lqe/menai *menela/ou *r 65 ff.

oi(/ per ktl.: “who are only allies.” — e)/neimen [e)smen]: are therein, i.e. in the city, with reference to po/lin 473. cf. e)ggega/asin *z 493. — Agamemnon says, 2.130 ff., a)ll' e)pi/kouroi| polle/wn e)k poli/wn e)gxe/spaloi a)/ndres e)/neisin,| oi(/ me me/ga pla/zousi kai\ ou\k ei)w=s) e)qe/lonta| *)/ilion e)kpe/rsai.
Sarpedon names himself as an example of the disinterested devotion of the allies.
e)pi/kouros ktl.: “though only an ally.”
h(/kw: am come. Only here and Od. 13.325.
cf. 2.877. — Suggested by thlo/qen 478.
thlou=: adv. with e)sti/. cf. 630, dh\n h)=n *z 131.
*ca/nqw|: the Lycian Xanthus is not to be confounded with the Trojan Xanthus or Scamander, 6.4.
The thought makes prominent the sacrifice of personal interests which Sarpedon had made for the sake of the Trojans.
e)/nqa: there. — ka/d [kata/, § 11 b]: sc. e)/lipon from 480. cf. w)/rnuto d' *)agame/mnwn . . . a)\n d) *)oduseu/s (sc. w)/rnuto) 3.267 f.
ta/ te: “the like of which.”
o(\s ktl.: sc. h)=|, whoever has them not. Equiv. to o(\s e)pideu/htai. — The whole second hemistich means simply “delightful,” “desirable.”

a)lla\ kai\ w(/s: “but although I have nothing to gain here, and all that is dear to me is far away,” “though I have no wrongs to avenge on the Trojans, nor any fear of them.” cf. Achilles's words, ou) ga\r e)gw\ *trw/wn e(/nek' h)/luqon ai)xmhta/wn| deu=ro maxhso/menos, e)pei\ ou)/ ti/ moi ai)/tioi/ ei)sin:| ou) ga/r pw/ pot) e)ma\s bou=s h)/lasan ou)de\ me\n i(/ppous *a 152 ff.
a)ndri/: “with my man,” in single combat.
maxh/sasqai: inceptive aor., enter the fight.
a)ta\r ktl.: and yet have I here, etc. This repeats in emphatic form the thought which had been summed up in kai\ w(/s. Sarpedon contrasts his situation with Hector's.
toi=on: of the kind. Sc. e)sti/n.
fe/roien, a)/goien: cf. the familiar a)/gein kai\ fe/rein, ferre et agere, of things and living booty.
The two clauses, in reverse order, form an exact contrast to 482. — tu/nh [su/]: opposed to e)gw/n.
e(/sthkas: with the notion of inactivity.
a)ta/r: corrects the foregoing assertion, only to heighten it by an ou)de/ not even.
w)/ressin: dat. of interest. cf. a)ndra/sin 779, toi/ *d 129.
mh/ pws ktl.: do not become, etc.
a(lo/nte: dual, of the two parties, Hector and his men; cf. 485. See on 4.407. cf. w)ke/es i(/ppoi| a)/cant) (breaking) . . . li/pon a(/rmat' a)na/ktwn *p 371, since each chariot had two horses.
pana/grou (a)/gra prey): cf. stegano\n di/ktuon, w(s mh/te me/gan| mh/t' ou)=n nearw=n tin) u(pertele/sai Aesch. Ag. 345 f.
e(/lwr ktl.: cf. au)tou\s de\ e(lw/ria teu=xe ku/nessin *a 4, (*sarph/dona) ka/l- lipes [kate/lipes] *)argei/oisin e(/lwr kai\ ku/rma gene/sqai *p 151, g 271.

e)kpe/rsousi: for the fut., after an apprehension expressed by mh/ and the subjv., cf. mh/ pws i(/ppous te trw/sh|s . . . xa/rma de\ toi=s a)/lloisin e)/ssetai *y 341 f., mh/ min kertome/wsin (mock), e)moi\ d) a)/xos e)/ssetai ai)no/n p 87. — e)u\ naiome/nhn ktl.: cf. *n 815. — u(mh/n [u(mete/rhn]: cf. sfou/s *d 302, a(mo/n *z 414. § 24 a, d.
ta/de pa/nta: cf. 6.441. Esp. what is intimated in 487-489.

nu/ktas ktl.: a freq. verse-close. ‘Night’ is placed before ‘day,’ since the calendar day began with sunset, in Greece as among the Hebrews. cf. ‘And the evening and the morning were the first day,’ Genesis i. 5.
h)=mar: the change from pl. to sing. has no special significance.

On the comparatively free relations of the allies, cf. Glaucus's words, tw=| nu=n ei)/ tis e)moi\ *luki/wn e)pipei/setai a)ndrw=n,| oi(/kad' i)/men *r 154 f. Sarpedon and his Lycians do not seem to have been bound by treaty, nor to be in receipt of regular pay.

nwleme/ws e)xe/men: “to stand firm.” Const. with lissome/nw|. For the intrans. use of e)xe/men, cf. *m 433, *n 679, *w 27. — a)poqe/sqai: parallel to e)xe/men. — “Put off rebuke (such as Sarpedon had administered) by brave actions.”
e)niph/n: cf. 4.402.
da/ke (da/knw) fre/nas: cf. qumodakh\s mu=qos Od. 8.185.
*(/ektori: dat. of interest.
o)ce/a dou=re: the epithet of dou=re is always plural. cf. *g 18, *l 43, *p 139, m 229, x 125.
dou=re: the two spears which the Homeric heroes often carried into battle.
strato/n: sc. *trw/wn.

497 = *r 343. — oi(/: i.e. the Trojans, contained in strato/n 495. — e)leli/xqhsan: turned about, rallied. the passive is simply intrans. here; cf. fo/bhqen 498, xa/rhsan 514, strefqe/nte 575. — e)nanti/oi: cf. 12. — e)/stan [e)/sthsan]: inceptive, as usual.
*)axaiw=n: for the gen. after a local adj., see G. 181 N.; H. 754 f.
cf. *o 312. — a)olle/es (ei)/lw): crowded, i.e. in close order. cf. a)lh/menai 823.
a)/xnas: Attic a)/xura, cf. a)xurmiai/ 502. — fore/ei: frequentative, keeps bearing.
i(era/s: sc. to Demeter. Flour is called a)lfi/tou i(erou= a)kth/ *l 631. — a)lwa/s (a)loa/w): threshingfloor. These were in the open air. For the pl., cf. o)xe/wn, dw/mata, to/ca.
a)ndrw=n: prob. limiting gen. with a)lwa/s. — likmw/ntwn: cf. likmhth=ros e)rwh=| *n 590. The threshed grain was tossed into the air by a broad shovel (ptu/on *n 588), doubtless against the wind.

canqh/: the epithet seems to be borrowed from the ripened grain. cf. foiniko/pezan *da/matra Pind. Ol. vi. 94 f., rubicunda Ceres Verg. Georg. i. 297, flava Ceres ib. 96, where Servius says flava propter aristarum maturitatem. But many of the divinities and heroes had blonde hair.
*dhmh/thr: mentioned also *b 696, *c 326, *f 76, e 125. She is not an important divinity in Homer. — The goddess is here said to do what men do in her service.
e)peigome/nwn ktl.: i.e. the strong winds blow away the chaff.
u(poleukai/nontai: grow white below, i.e. on the ground, covered gradually with chaff. In this lies the point of the comparison, cf. leukoi\ ge/nonto 503.
o(/n: ‘acc. of effect’ with e)pe/plhgon. See on 361.
di) au)tw=n: through themselves, i.e. through their ranks.
polu/xalkon: the vault of heaven was thought of as a metallic firmament. cf. xa/lkeon ou)rano\n i(=ke *r 425, sidh/reon ou)rano\n i(/kei o 329. — e)pe/plhgon (plh/ssw): for the redup., see § 25 j.
a(/y ktl.: as they (i.e. the horses of the Trojans) mingled again in the fray. Cf. 497.
i(po\ ktl.: explains the first half-verse.
u(po\ e)/strefon: sc. i(/ppous. — h(nioxh=es: sc. *trw/wn.
oi( de/: i.e. the Trojan warriors.

me/nos ktl.: cf. *d 447, *z 502, me/nos d) i)qu\s fe/ron au)tw=n *p 602, a)ll) i)qu\s fe/re xalko/n g 108. — a)mfi/: const. with e)ka/luye. cf. 315, *zeu\s d' e)pi\ nu/kt) o)loh\n ta/nuse (stretched) kraterh=| u(smi/nh| *p 567.
ma/xh|: const. with a)rh/gwn. cf. kai/ te/ me/ fhsi ma/xh| *trw/essin a)rh/gein *a 521.
e)fetma/s (e)fi/hmi): cf. 456 f.

xrusao/rou: of golden sword. Cf. 15.256. Besides bow and quiver, Apollo wore a sword, like the Homeric heroes. The gleaming gold was borrowed from the sunbeams. — a)nw/gein [h)nw/gei]: cf. 455 f. But Ares was busy with this work at 461, and nothing is said there of the departure of Athena as a motive for his action.
qumo\n e)gei=rai: cf. 496, 517, o(/ (i.e. Zeus) sfisin ai)e\n e)/geire me/nos me/ga *o 594. — i)/de [ei)=de]: sc. *)apo/llwn.
oi)xome/nhn: when? On 418.
*danaoi=sin: dat. with pe/len a)rhgw/n (which is distinguished by its accent from a)rh/gwn 507). On 4.7.
au)to/s: i.e. Apollo, as contrasted with his instructions to Ares.
ma/la pi/onos: with reference to the votive offerings and other treasures stored there. An allusion to the wealth of the temple of Apollo at Delphi, is found in 9.404 f.
a)du/toio: on 448.
poime/ni: for the dat., cf. *(/ektori 493.
meqi/stato: stepped into the midst. Cf. pari/stato 570, *d 212. — xa/rhsan: for the aor. pass. as mid., cf. e)leli/xqhsan 497.
515 = *h 308. — zwo\n ktl.: “safe and sound.”
meta/llhsan (‘metal’): sc. mi/n, about his rescue.
ge me/n: equiv. to me/ntoi, and takes the place of a conjunction. § 2 m.
ou)/ ti: at the close of the verse since, for emphasis, the verb is placed at the head of the clause.
po/nos: toil of war. On *d 374. — a)/llos: something else, sc. than curiosity. In appos. with po/nos. — a)rguro/tocos: the epithet serves as a proper name. cf. glaukw=pis n 389, h)rige/neia x 197.
e)/geiren: but without leaving his position on the Pergamos; cf. 460.
*)/eris ktl.: cf. 4.440.
519-589. The Achaeans hold their ground. Achievements of Agamemnon, Aeneas, and Antilochus.
tou\s de/: but those. Made definite by *danaou/s 520.
au)toi/: “without urging.” Contrasted with w)/trunon at the beginning of the verse.
bi/as: cf. bi/as a)ne/mwn a)leei/nwn *p 213. — i)wka/s: onsets.
nefe/lh|sin: clouds often hang for days about a mountain summit. The point of comparison is in the steadfast persistence of clouds and men.
*kroni/wn: as nefelhgere/ths. cf. 4.30.
nhnemi/hs: in a calm, explained by o)/fr' eu(/dh|si ktl. below. Temporal gen. (not freq. in Homer); cf. nukto/s n 278, h)ou=s *q 525. G. 179. 1; H. 759.
e)p' a)kropo/loisin ktl.: cf. Od. 19.205.
a)tre/mas: motionless. Made more definite by the following clause.

eu(/dh|si: cf. (*zeu\s) koimh/sas d' a)ne/mous *m 281, (a)ne/mous *zeu\s) e)ke/leuse kai\ eu)nhqh=nai a(/pantas e 384, ‘As when from mountain-tops the dusky clouds| Ascending while the north wind sleeps, Milton, Par. Lost ii. 488 f. — e)/sthsen, on which this depends, is ‘gnomic,’ and thus syntactically equiv. to a present.
a)/llwn: not attrib. with a)ne/mwn, but the latter is added in apposition. See on mh/thr 313.
zaxreiw=n: fiercely driving.
te: for the ‘quantity,’ see on 4.274; cf. 23.133, 366.
skio/enta: shadowy. Epithet of mountains, in 1.157.

a)e/ntes (a)/hmi): explanatory of pnoih=|sin, and equiv. to pne/ontes. cf. di/skoisin te/rponto kai\ ai)gane/h|sin (hunting-spears) i(e/ntes d 626, kh/desin (griefs) terpw/meqa . . . mnwome/nw o 399 f., th=s au)th=s e(/nek' a)ggeli/hs, e)re/onte gunaiki/ p 334.
e)/mpedon: the point of comparison. cf. a)tre/mas 524.
a)n' o(/milon: cf. 334; on 4.209.
e)foi/ta: cf. 595.
polla/: cf. 358; on 4.229.
cf. *o 561. — w)= fi/loi ktl.: cf. 6.112.

a)ne/res e)/ste: far better than a)ndrei=oi e)/ste! — h)=tor e(/lesqe: only here. But cf. a)/lkimon h)=tor e)/xwn *p 209, ai)dw= qe/sq' e)ni\ qumw=| *o 561, a)lla\ me/gan poiei=sqe kai\ a)/lkimon e)n fresi\ qumo/n Tyrtaeus viii. 17.
530-532 = 15.562-564. cf. me/xris teu= kata/keisqe; ko/t' a)/lkimon e(/cete qumo/n,| w)= ne/oi; ou)d) ai)dei=sq) a)mfiperikti/onas; Callinus i. 1 f.
ai)dome/nwn ktl.: partitive gen., “of men filled with due sense of honor.” — ‘Asyndeton,’ since this verse supplies a motive for 530.
pe)fantai (fo/nos): are slain, lie dead. Cf. de/deto 387.
feugo/ntwn: from those who flee. Ablatival gen. of source with o)/rnutai.
a)lkh/: strength for defence. — Cf. 4.245.
douri/: either acc. or dat. may be used with a)ko/ntise. cf. 4.496.
pro/mon: equiv. to pro/maxon. Const. as attrib. adj. with a)/ndra. cf. a)/ndres strathgoi/, ktl.
*ai)nei/w: for the form, see § 16 c.
o(mw=s: equiv. to o(moi/ws. Followed by a ‘dat. of likeness.’
qoo/s: on 430. — e)/ske [h)=n]: for the iterative formation, cf. 472.
meta\ ktl.: explains qoo/s.
ma/xesqai: acc. of specification. cf. 6.460.
r(a/: marks this verse as a repetition of 533. On 4.459.
538 = *r 518, w 524; cf. *d 138. — ei)=sato: the preceding hiatus is justified by the Bucolic diaeresis. cf. 542.
539 = *p 519. — neiai/rh| (ne/os?): for the fem. ending, cf. i)oxe/aira 447.
zwsth=ros: on 4.132.
e)/lassen: sc. *)agame/mnwn. cf. 41.
See on 4.504.
e)/nq' au)=te: cf. 471.

These chieftains are not mentioned in the ‘Catalogue of the Ships.’ — cf. e)s *fhra\s d' i(/konto (sc. *thle/maxos kai\ *nestori/dhs *peisi/stratos) *dioklh=os poti\ dw=ma,| ui(e/os *)ortilo/xoio, to\n *)alfeio\s te/ke pai=da g 488 f.
*fhrh=|: the modern Kalamata, at the head of the Messenian Gulf. Called *fhrai/ in Od. 3.488; see § 19 j.
a)fneio\s bio/toio: cf. 6.14. The gen. is ‘after an adj. of fulness.’ cf. dives opum Verg. Aen. i. 14. G. 180. 1; H. 753 c.
ge/nos: acc. of specification; by birth. Cf. 896.
*)alfeiou=: in appos. with potamoi=o. See on 313. — The wellknown river which flows from Arcadia, through Elis, past Olympia.
eu)ru/: cognate acc. as adverb.

pole/essi: polloi=s. § 20 f. — a)/ndressin [a)ndra/sin]: dat. of interest with a)/nakta, as often with a)na/ssw. cf. *puqodw/rou a)/rxontos *)aqhnai/ois Thuc. ii. 2. 6, *damofi/lw a)/rxontos *boiwtoi=s Cauer Delectus Ins. Graec. 294.
a)/ra: seems to refer to ui(=e *dioklh=os 542.
*dioklh=a: for a short vowel lengthened before the stem of me/ga (72 times in Homer), cf. 27; see § 41 k, l.
diduma/one: cf. di/dumoi.
*)orsi/loxos: the Greek grandson of all times was wont to be named for his grandfather. cf. Cimon, Miltiades, Cimon, Miltiades; Niceratus, Nicias,. Niceratus.
ma/xhs ktl.: cf. 11.
h(bh/sante: “coming to the vigor of youthful manhood.”
e)u/pwlon: on 102.
cf. Achilles's words, a)lla\ soi/, w)= me/g' a)naide/s, a(/m) e(spo/meq), o)/fra su\ xai/rh|s,| ti/mhn a)rnu/menoi *menela/w| soi/ te, kunw=pa *a 158 f.
ti/mhn: retribution, satisfaction, esp. the return of Helen and of the treasures which were carried away by Paris.
tw\ de/: repeats the pron. of tw\ me/n 550, marking the identity of the fate of both.
te/los qana/toio: a periphrasis for qa/natos. cf. 3.309. Distinguish fa/nh bio/toio teleuth/ *h 104.
oi(/w ktl.: “these two like young lions.” tw/ seems to point forward to le/onte.
korufh=|sin: local. cf. ta/rfesin 555.
e)trafe/thn: intrans., grew up.
u(po\ mhtri/: “under their mother's protection and care.”
baqei/hs ktl.: cf. 15.606.
tw\ me\n a)/ra: corresponds to the like beginning of 550.
staqmou\s ktl.: cf. 138 ff., oi)=ma le/ontos e)/xwn, u(/s te staqmou\s kerai+/zwn| e)/blhto pro\s sth=qos *p 752 f.
kai\ au)tw/: themselves also, even as the flocks have been destroyed by them.
e)n pala/mh|si: “at the hands.” cf. 564.
kate/ktaqen (ktei/nw): gnomic aorist. This is the point of comparison; cf. kappese/thn 560.
toi/w: as such fearless fighters. Emphatic. — xei/ressin [xersi\n] u(/po: on 4.479.

kappese/thn (pi/ptw): for the ‘apocope,’ cf. karre/zousa 424. — e)la/th|sin ktl.: a new comparison is added. § 2 e. This indicates the stature, and the fall at full length. cf. *d 482, o( d' au)=t) e)/pesen meli/h (ashtree) w(/s,| h(/ t' o)/reos korufh=| ktl. *n 178 f., h)/ripe d' , w(s o(/te tis dru=s h)/ripen h)\ a)xerwi\s (white poplar)| h)e\ pi/tus blwqrh/ (slender pine), th/n t' ou)/resi te/ktones a)/ndres| e)ce/tamon pele/kessi *n 389 ff., w(s d' o(/q) u(po\ plhgh=s patro\s *dio\s e)ceri/ph| dru=s *c 414, concidit: ut quondam cava concidit aut Erymantho| aut Ida in magna radicibus eruta pinus Verg. Aen. v. 448 f.
a)rhi/filos: cf. 4.150. This epithet is applied 21 times to *mene/laos, forming a convenient verse-close. § 40 d.
de/: introduces an explanation. On 505.
tou=: const. with me/nos.

ta\ frone/wn: with this thought, this design. Cf. *i 493, *o 603, *r 225. — Followed by a final clause, as *k 491. — xersi
 ktl.: i.e. u(po\ xersi
 *ai)nei/ao. cf. 559, xersi
 u(p' *)argei/wn fqi/menos *q 359, xersi
 u(p) *ai)/antos qane/ein *o 289, *thlema/xou u(po\ xersi/ s 156.
cf. *n 400, *r 653. — *)anti/loxos: on 4.457.
peri\ ga\r ktl.: always in the same position in the verse.
poime/ni ktl.: dat. of the object for which fear is felt. cf. peri\ ga\r di/e nhusi\n *)axaiw=n *i 433, comitique onerique timentem Verg. Aen. ii. 729.
mh/ ti pa/qoi: “lest something befall him.” Euphemism.
me/ga: adv. with a)posfh/leie.
sfa/s: with short a only here.

a)posfh/leie (sfa/llw) ktl.: “lest their toil (their expedition) should be rendered vain by the death of Menelaus, on which the Greeks would return.” cf. 4.170-175. — The personal const. is natural in view of the close connexion of the two clauses of the verse.
tw/: i.e. Menelaus and Aeneas.
dh/: const. with e)xe/thn, marking the situation in which Antilochus found the two.
xei=ras: cf. 506.
o)cuo/enta: cf. 50.
poime/ni ktl.: i.e. Menelaus, as 566.
cf. 15.585, where, curiously, *)anti/loxos takes the place of *ai)nei/as.
para\ ktl.: cf. 16.721.
oi( de/: i.e. Menelaus and Antilochus.
nekrou/s: i.e. ui(=e *dioklh=os.
meta\ lao/n: into the midst of the soldiery. Cf. 324, 589, *h 306, *q 76.
tw\ me\n ktl.: so these two unfortunate men.
deilw/: cf. yuxh\ *patroklh=os deiloi=o *y 65, tw=n deilw=n e(ta/rwn oi(\ qa/non e)n pedi/w| i 65 f.
strefqe/nte: conversi. As Menelaus and Antilochus dragged the corpses into the Greek ranks, they had turned their backs to the Trojans. — For the passive, see on 497.
maxe/sqhn: “were continuing the conflict.”
*pulaime/nea: cf. *paflago/nwn d' h(gei=to *pulaime/neos la/sion kh=r *b 851. The ‘ultima’ is treated as long, before the verse-pause. § 41 p.

e(le/thn: slew. Cf. 50. Both Greek warriors, standing side by side (570), threw their spears at the same time. The one hit Pylaemenes, and the other hit the charioteer. — This passage is inconsistent with 13.658 f., where Pylaemenes is alive and follows the corpse of his son from the battlefield.
e(stew=ta: prob. not on his chariot, since the emphatic position of the partic. seems explained only by the contrast between the chieftain and his charioteer. On 581.
nu/ce: cf. 46. Coïncident with tuxh/sas hitting.
tuxh/sas: with kata\ (klhi=da), as 12.189; cf. 98, ou)/thse tuxw\n kata\ decio\n w)=mon t 452. Elsewhere used absolutely.
*mu/dwna: a Paeonian ‘homonym’ is slain by Achilles, 21.209.
