h(ni/oxon: adjectival, rein-holding, as *q 119, *m 111, *n 386. — The preceding diaeresis, after the third foot, is not disliked when the third foot has a distinct caesura. § 40 l.

*)atumnia/dhn: his father *)atu/mnios is to be distinguished from his Lycian ‘homonym,’ slain by Antilochus *p 317. — o( de\ ktl.: equiv. to u(postre/fonta. Pylaemenes seems to have been separated from his chariot, but now to have summoned it in order to flee, like Aeneas, 571. But as the charioteer was about turning, he was slain.
xermadi/w|: cf. 302.
a)gkw/na me/son: in partitive appos. with *mu/dwna.
tuxw/n: on 4.106. Much like tuxh/sas 579.
leuka\ e)le/fanti: the leather reins were adorned with thin plates of ivory. cf. 4.142.
e)n koni/h|sin: a more definite statement of xamai/. — For the ‘dat. of rest’ see on 446. cf. 4.482.
ko/rshn [ko/rrhn]: cf. 4.502.
585 = 13.399 (part of a similar achievement of the same Antilochus); cf. 16.743.
ku/mbaxos: pred., “head-foremost.” Explained by the second half-verse.
e(sth/kei: remained standing. His head and shoulders were fixed in the sand, while his feet leaned against the chariot.
tu/xe: happened upon, i.e. fell upon.
a)ma/qoio: partitive genitive. Aristarchus distinguished a)/maqos sand of the plain from ya/maqos sand of the shore.
plh/cante: striking him with their hoofs, as Antilochus lashed them and drove them away, 589.
i(/mase: cf. i(ma/s, i(ma/sqlh.
590-626. Hector and Ares approach. Diomed withdraws. Ajax.
tou/s: i.e. Menelaus and Antilochus.
kata\ sti/xas: along the ranks, i.e. as they appeared here and there in the line.
au)tou/s: opposed to strato/s which is implied in kata\ sti/xas.
keklhgw/s: such perfs. of ‘verbs signifying to make a noise’ seem ‘never to have expressed completed action.’ H. 849 b.
a(/ma ei(/ponto: cf. 551.
*)/arhs: of course in the form of a mortal. cf. 604.
*)enuw/: cf. 333.
e)/xousa: holding, wielding.
kudoimo/n: tumult. Apparently thought of as a weapon or shield, like the aegis of Zeus.
a)naide/a: on 4.521.
e)nw/ma: a partic. is expected, which should correspond to h( me\n e)/xousa 593. For the transition to the finite const., see § 1 e.
foi/ta: sc. *)/arhs.
r(i/ghse: sc. because he must yield before Ares. cf. 127 ff. — Nothing more is said here about Menelaus and Antilochus, against whom Hector seems to have gone. cf. 590.
a)pa/lamnos: without device (pala/mh), helpless. Equiv. to a)mh/xanos. Pred. after sth/h|.
pedi/oio: cf. 4.244.
sth/h| [sth=|]: stops.
e)pi/: at, on the bank.
w)kuro/w|: cf. 88. — For the r not doubled in composition, cf. e)/rece 373.
a)frw=|: with foam. Const. with mormu/ronta. cf. r(o/os *)wkeanoi=o| a)frw=| mormu/rwn r(e/en *s 402 f., (*ska/mandros) mormu/rwn a)frw=| te kai\ ai(/mati kai\ neku/essin *f 325.
i)dw/n: gives the cause of sth/h|. The traveller sees the impossibility of advancing.
a)na\ ktl.: an independent addition. cf. 6.509 f., *b 148, *i 324, g 497, *x 94. — This gnomic aor. contains the point of comparison.
o)pi/ssw: repeats the idea of a)na/.

oi)=on: neut. cognate acc., with dh/, introducing an exclamation of vexation. G. 155; H. 1001 a. “How we have been wont to admire Hector, and say” etc. Cf. (*zeu= pa/ter) oi(=on dh\ a)/ndressi xari/zeai u(bristh=|sin *n 633, (*(/ektor) oi(=on dh\ *mene/laon u(pe/tresas *r 587, w)\ po/poi, oi(=on dh/ nu qeou\s brotoi\ ai)tio/wntai a 32.
ai)xmhth/n: on korusth/n *d 457. The spearman is tacitly contrasted with the bowman, who required less strength, courage, and presence of mind.

de/: adversative. “But he well may be fearless since at least one (ei(=s ge)” etc. Cf. *d 129, 390, w)= *)axileu<*>, peri\ me\n krate/eis . . . ai)ei\ ga/r toi a)mu/nousin qeoi\ au)toi/ *f 214 f. — pa/ra: pa/resti. § 37 c a.
kai\ nu=n: on 4.12.
kei=nos: equiv. to e)kei=<*> there. Cf. o(/de 175, *g 391.
e)oikw/s: Ares had assumed the form of Acamas, cf. 462; but Diomed had received from Athena the power to distinguish the gods.

pro\s *trw=as ktl.: “retreat, but keep your face toward the foe,” that the Achaeans might not seem to flee. cf. e)pi\ po/da a)nexw/roun Xen. An. v. 2. 32. Contrasted with protropa/dhn fobe/onto *p 304; cf. 700 f.
meneaine/men: inf. as imperative.
au)tw=n: i.e. *)axaiw=n.
ei)do/te: without the usual prefixed e)u/. cf. du/w ku/ne ei)do/te qh/rhs *k 360, ei)dw\s pugmaxi/hs *y 665. For the fg. gen., cf. also 549.
*mene/sqhn ktl.: only here.
tw\ de\ ktl.: cf. 561.
me/gas ktl.: cf. *m 364, *n 321, *c 409, etc.
*)/amfi_on: to be distinguished from his ‘homonymous’ countryman, 2.830.
ui(o/n: for the short penult, cf. 4.473.

*paisw=|: near Lampsacus. cf. trapo/menos pro\s ta\s e)n *(ellhspo/ntw| po/lis ei(=le me\n *da/rdanon, ei(=le de\ *)/abudo/n te kai\ *perkw/thn kai\ *la/myakon kai\ *paiso/n Hdt. v. 117. The form is *)apaiso/s in 2.828.
polukth/mwn: rich in flocks and herds. — For the lack of conjunction, cf. 194, 295, 639, 1.99. § 1 o.
polulh/ios: rich in fields of grain. Cf. a)lh/ios *i 125, baqulh/ion *s 550.
moi=ra: “his fate,” which was recognized after the event. cf. 83, 629, *d 517, *t 87, *f 83.
h)=ge: cf. kh=res ga\r a)/gon me/lanos qana/toio *b 834.
meta/: “to.”
zwsth=ra: on 4.132.
neiai/rh|: cf. 539.
pa/gh: cf. 4.185.
dolixo/skion: cf. 3.346.
dou/phsen ktl.: cf. 540.
teu/xea ktl.: cf. 6.70 f., 15.583.
e)pi\ e)/xeuan: showered upon. On i)oxe/aira 53. cf. telorum effundere contra| omnegenus Teucri Verg. Aen. ix. 509 f.

sa/kos: this renowned shield of Ajax (from which his son was named *eu)rusa/khs) is described 7.219 ff.: *ai)/as d' e)ggu/qen h)=lqe, fe/rwn sa/kos h)u/te pu/rgon,| xa/lkeon, e(ptabo/eion, o(/ oi( *tuxi/os ka/me teu/xwn,| skutoto/mwn (workers in leather) o)/x' a)/ristos <*>lh| e)/ni oi)ki/a nai/wn:| o(/s oi( e)poi/hsen sa/kos ai)o/lon e(ptabo/eion| tau/rwn zatrefe/wn (well-fed) e)pi\ d' o)/gdoon h)/lase xalko/n.
la\c pro/sbas: “setting his foot upon him.” cf. *z 65, do/ru xa/lkeon e)c w)teilh=s| ei)/ruse (drew), la\c pro/sbas *p 862 f.
la/c: on gnu/c 68.
a)/lla: teu/xea follows, after the versepause, in apposition. cf. 709 f., e)/ktoqen (apart from) a)/llwn| mnhsth/rwn a 132 f., e)/nqa per a)/lla| e)/gxe) *)odussh=os i(/stato a 128 f.
w)/moiin: for the ‘quantity’ of the ultima, cf. i(/ppoiin 13.
o(/ ge: emphatic repetition of the subj.; “he feared — he did!” cf. *a 97, a 4, multum ille et terris iactatus et alto Verg. Aen. i. 3.

a)mfi/basin *trw/wn (sc. nekrou=): equiv. to tou\s a)mfibai/nontas *trw=as. cf. 299, 4.532, (*)aka/mas) a)mfi\ kasignh/tw| bebaw/s *c 477. Ajax feared the vigorous action of the Trojans in defense of the fallen warrior.
a)gerw/xwn: “brave in battle.”
e)/gxe) e)/xontes: “with outstretched spears.” cf. 4.533. — This verse is half-parenthetical, serving as another adj. to *trw/wn 623. The rel. clause of 625 carries further the principal action.
627-678. Tlepolemus slain by Sarpedon. Seven Lycians slain by Odysseus.
w)=rsen e)pi/: cf. 765.
e)pi/: upon, against.
moi=ra ktl.: on 613.
ui(wno/s: i.e. Heracles's son Tlepolemus.
cf. 276, *n 306, p 460, r 74. — to/n: i.e. Sarpedon.
kai/: also. Not found directly after the formula, 630; cf. *z 122, g 177, etc.
pro\s e)/eipen: for the two accs., to/n and mu=qon, cf. 329, 689.
“Why should you come here to play the coward?”

e)o/nti: thrown with e)nqa/de by the rhythm of the verse. “Now that you are here in the Troad.” cf. e)lqo/nt' e)k *luki/hs 645. — This participial clause stands in an adversative relation to the principal thought, since ‘coming to Troy’ is equiv. to ‘coming to fight’; while ma/xhs ktl. is pred. with ptw/ssein.
a)dah/moni: const. with toi/ above.
*yeudo/menoi: pred., as liars, falsely. “Men lie when they say.”
e)pei/: refers to yeudo/menoi. — pollo/n [polu/]: adv. acc., — originally of ‘extent of space.’ cf. 6.479.
a)ndrw=n: ablatival gen. after a verb of ‘want.’
*dio/s: gen. with e)c in the fg. verb. cf. 6.100.
e)pi/: in the time of. Cf. to\ pri\n e)p' ei)rh/nhs *x 156.
prote/rwn: on 4.308.
a)lla/: marks the contrast to Sarpedon.
oi(=o/n tina: exclamation of admiration. cf. 601, a)ll' oi(=on to/d) e)/rece d 242, l 519. — “But what a man was Heracles!”
oi(=on: masc. in spite of the fem. bi/hn. § 2 s.
bi/hn ktl.: on 4.386.
ei)=nai: corresponds to the impf. (oi(=o/s tis h)=n *(hraklh=s) of dir. discourse. cf. a)/llon d' a)/llh| a)/eide po/lin kerai:ze/men ai)ph/n (lofty) q 516, 181. — qrasume/mnona ktl.: cf. Od. 11.267.
qumole/onta: Cœur de Lion.

e(/nek' i(/ppwn: Laomedon had promised to Heracles the horses which Zeus had given to Tros (265 ff.), as a reward for the rescue of his daughter Hesione from a sea-monster. Heracles slew the monster, and, when the king failed to make good his word, sacked Troy. Then he gave Hesione as a ge/ras to his comrade Telamon, to whom she bore Teucer (6.31). cf. 648 ff., Od. 3.145 ff.
oi)/h|s: only.
paurote/roisi: sc. than Sarpedon.
xh/rwse (xh/ra): cf. tam multis viduasset civibus urbem Verg. Aen. viii. 571.
soi/: contrasted with Heracles.
kako/s: cowardly.
a)pofqinu/qousi: sc. through Sarpedon's worthlessness. A contrast to the success of Heracles.
ou)de/ ti: and not at all, nor by any means.
de/: const. closely with e)lqo/nt' e)k *luki/hs. “Thy coming from Lycia.”
ei) ma/la ktl.: cf. A 178. Physical strength alone could not compensate for the lack of courage.

cf. du=nai do/mon *)/aidos ei)/sw *g 322, qa/pte me o(/tti ta/xista: pu/las *)ai/dao perh/sw *y 71, e)xqro\s ga/r moi kei=nos o(mw=s *)ai/dao pu/lh|sin *i 312. Hades was preëminently the ‘gatekeeper’ (pula/rths); cf. 8.367.
kei=nos: i.e. Heracles.
“Laomedon's fault and folly gave the victory to Heracles.”
a)ne/ros: the man. Explained by a)gauou= *laome/dontos. On 313, 4.194.
a)fradi/h|sin: dat. of cause. cf. pare/dramen a\fradi/h|sin *k 350, tri\s d' e)/kpien a)fradi/h|sin i 361. For the pl., cf. 4.409.
eu)= e)/rcanta: concessive.
kakw=|: harsh, offensive. Cf. a)lla\ kakw=s a)fi/ei *a 25.
h)ni/pape ktl.: cf. *b 245, *g 427, u 17, 303. Laomedon scolded when he was reminded of his promise to give the horses.
h)ni/pape (e)ni/ptw): for the redup., see § 25 k.

ou)d' a)pe/dwke: nor did he give as was due. The a)po/ implies a debt, an obligation. Thus a)pagge/llw is carry a message where it belongs; a)pofe/rw is deliver as required. Cf. reddo, reporto. — The following half-verse strengthens the idea of indebtedness, since thlo/qen emphasizes the trouble taken by Heracles to perform the service for Laomedon. cf. 478.
soi\ de/: in contrast to kei=nos 648, — though with a reference to soi/ 643.
e)gw/ fhmi: refers to o)i/omai 644, and asserts more strenuously than that. — Obs. the repetition and prominence of e)gw/, e)me/qen [e)mou=], e)mw=|, e)moi/. See on 812.
e)nqa/de: “here, before Troy.”
teu/cesqai: will befall, “will be thine.” Const. with soi/.
u(po\ doupi/: cf. 4.479.
dame/nta: const. with se/, implied in soi/, as subj. of dw/sein. For the form, cf. dmhqe/nta 646. § 33 f.
eu)=xos: glory. Cf. eu)/xomai, eu)xwlh/ *d 450.
dw/sein: has two heterogeneous objects. cf. e)/gxea kai\ me/ne) a)ndrw=n *d 447.
klutopw/lw|: with glorious horses. Why Hades should be represented with a chariot (hardly one in which he might convey the dead), has not been clearly made out.
tw=n me/n: Sarpedon, too, had raised his lance at the last threatening words.
o(marth=|: at the same time.
h)/ican (a)i/ssw): pl. verb with neut. subj., as freq.
o( me/n: for the asyndeton, cf. 4.491.
diampere/s (dia/, a)na/, pera/w): cf. 284.
h)=lqe: for the personification in this, in h)/ican, and in 661, see on 4.125.
a)legeinh/: painful, i.e. pain-causing; cf. dakruo/enta 737. Only here as epithet of ai)xmh/. cf. pikro/s 99.
kat' o)fqalmw=n: down over the eyes. Cf. 696.
nu\c ktl.: on 4.461.
a)/ra: seems to mark a transition.
beblh/kein: on 696, 4.492. For the final n, cf. 4.301.
die/ssuto (diaseu/w): rushed through, sc. mhrou=. — For the form, cf. e)pe/ssuto 438.
maimw/wsa: eagerly. Cf. 15.542.
o)ste/w| ktl.: drawing near to the bone, i.e. grazing it, and not checked by it.
path/r: i.e. Zeus. cf. 635, 6.198 f. Sarpedon is the only warrior before Troy who is Zeus's own son. The later generations of men were further removed from the gods.
e)/ti: still, now as before. Sarpedon was to fall four days later, slain by Patroclus. cf. 16.502 ff. — For a similar intimation of the future, cf. 674 f., 686 ff., 12.402 f.
me/n: correl. with de/ 668.
a)/ra: so, as a result of the preceding act.
e(lko/menon: dragging after him. Const. with do/ru.

to\ me/n: while this. Explained by the fg. inf. e)ceru/sai. cf. ta/ 564, to\ ga\r me/ne mhti/eta *zeu/s,| nho\s kaiome/nhs se/las (blaze) o)fqalmoi=sin i)de/sqai *o 599 f., to/ min ou)/ pote e)/lpeto qumw=|| teqna/men *r 404 f.
e)pefra/sato (e)pifra/zw) ktl.: noticed and thought of. Synonymous. § 1 s. Cf. Od. 8.94, 533.
e)ceru/sai: this is not done until 694.
o)/fr' e)pibai/h: “that he might get upon his feet,” sc. to walk, instead of being carried. cf. ou)de/ ph| ei=xon| ou)/te sthri/cai posi\n e)/mpedon ou)/t' e)pibh=nai m 433 f.

speudo/ntwn: “since they were in eager haste.” In later Greek this would be construed as gen. abs., but here (as the const. of the gen. abs. is not fully developed in Homer, § 3, e, f) it is prob. equiv. to Attic tw=n speudo/ntwn, partitive gen. with ou)/ tis 665.
po/non: cf. 517.
a)mfie/pontes: busy about him. Sarpedon's comrades were obliged to shield him and themselves from attack, while carrying him from the field.
no/hse: sc. that Sarpedon was borne from the conflict.

tlh/mona: daring. Cf. h)/qele d' o( tlh/mwn *)oduseu\s katadu=nai o(/milon| *trw/wn: ai)ei\ ga/r oi( e)ni\ fresi\ qumo\s e)to/lma *k 231 f., a)ll' oi(=on to/d) e)/rece kai\ e)/tlh kartero\s a)nh/r (i.e. *)odusseu/s) Od. 4.242. A freq. epithet of Odysseus is polu/tlas. — mai/mhse: raged, sc. with eagerness to display his courage. cf. maimw/wsa 561.
prote/rw: further. Cf. 4.507.
e)rigdou/poio: cf. dou/phsen 617. For the g, see § 12 j.

tw=n pleo/nwn: of the greater number, of the mass. Cf. the later oi( polloi/. The dem. tw=n marks the contrast with the leaders; cf. oi( ple/ones kaki/ous b 277. — The gen. depends on a)po\ e(/loito. cf. 691. — cf. plhqu
 *luki/wn 676, (e)/spete, mou=sai, oi(/ tines h(gemo/nes *danaw=n h)=san,) plhqu
 ou)k a)
 e)gw\ muqh/somai *b 488, *l 305.
*luki/wn: partitive gen. with tw=n pleo/nwn. cf. 679.
ou)d' a)/ra: but, as it seems, it was not, etc. This prepares the way for 676.
ou)d' *)odush=i: sc. but to Patroclus. cf. 16.477 ff.
plhqu/n: on 673.
qumo/n: sc. *)odussh=os.
Six out of these seven Lycians have good Greek names.
*koi/ranon: a ‘homonym’ is esquire of Meriones, 17.611.
ei(=len: cf. 4.457.

*)ala/stora ktl.: cf. 4.295. — Obs. the ‘polysyndeton’ with te/. — cf. quid Lycii referam Sarpedonis agmina ferro| devastata meo? cum multo sanguine fudi| Coeranon Iphitiden et Alas toraque Chroniumque| Alcandrumque Haliumque Noëmonaque Prytaninque Ovid. Met. xiii. 257 ff.
678 = Vergil Aen. ix. 767.
*noh/mona: ‘homonyms’ are a companion of Antilochus, 23.612, and an Ithacan who lends his boat to Telemachus, b 386, d 630.
*pru/tanin: Foremost. — For subordinate persons, the poet does not always take the trouble to invent new names.
679-710. The Achaeans yield before Hector and Ares.
dei=ma: only here. Strictly, an object of terror; but here hardly different from de/os. — xa/rh [e)xa/rh]: inceptive aorist.
oi(= prosio/nti: dat. of cause. “Delighted at his approach.” cf. 644. — Evidently Sarpedon was borne in the direction from which Hector was coming.
o)lofudno/n: doleful.
mh\ dh/: with subjv., as 457; with imv., in 218; with inf. used as imv. in 17.501.
e(/lwr: predicate. cf. au)tou\s de\ e(lw/ria teu=xe ku/nessin *a 4. — “Let me not fall into the hands of the Greeks.”
Sarpedon is ready even to die, if it but be among friends.
kei=sqai: not a description of the present situation, since Sarpedon was in the arms of his friends, but rather an expression of anxious foreboding in contrast with happy escape.

e)/peita: after that, refers to e)pa/munon. — kai/: even, with concessive optative. cf. e)n de\ fa/ei (light) kai\ o)/lesson *r 647, i)do/nta de\ kai\ li/poi ai)w\n (life)| kth=sin e)mh/n h 224 f. — Sarpedon expected to die of his wound. cf. a)/ra 686.
e)n po/lei ktl.: “though in a foreign land,” “far from home.” The contrast is in 687.

ou)k a)/ra ktl.: I was not fated, as I see. Cf. ou)d' a)/r) e)/mellon pei/sein *x 356, Achilles's words au)ti/ka teqnai/hn, e)pei\ ou)k a)/r' e)/mellon e(tai/rw|| e)pamu=nai *s 98 f., ta\ frone/ont' a)na\ qumo\n a(/ r() ou) tele/esqai e)/mellon *b 36.
nosth/sas: const. with eu)frane/ein. cf. u(mei=s d' au)=qi me/nontes e)ufrai/noite gunai=kas n 44.
oi)ko/nde: explained by the second ‘hemistich.’
cf. 480, eu)frh=nai a)/loxo/n te fi/lhn kednou/s te tokh=as *r 28.
to/n, ti\: for the two accs. (direct obj. and cognate acc.), cf. 632.
parh/icen (a)i/ssw): sc. thus disregarding Sarpedon's request.
o)/fra w)/saito: equiv. to w)/sasqai. cf. 4.465.
w)/saito: thrust from himself. Cf. 626. — pole/wn [pollw=n] ktl.: cf. 673.
ei(=san: seated. Cf. 4.392.

fhgw=|: this oak (with edible acorns) or chestnut stood near the city, and not far from the Scaean Gate. It was tall and beautiful, and formed a prominent landmark. cf. *z 237, *h 22, 60, *i 354, *l 170, *f 549 (?).

e)k mhrou=: forth from his thigh. Const. with w)=se qu/raze. The spearpoint had passed through the leg, and a violent wrench was needed to extract it by a single pull, which would cause less protracted suffering.
qu/raze: has entirely lost its original meaning.
*pela/gwn: a ‘homonym’ is found among the comrades of Nestor, 4.295; cf. 677.
e)/lipe yuxh/: of a swoon (lipoyuxi/a). cf. a)po\ de\ yuxh\n e)ka/pussen (gasped) 22.467. On 310.
ke/xuto (xe/w): plpf. of the ‘immediate or sudden occurrence of a past action.’ GMT. 52. cf. 661, 6.495.
a)mpnu/nqh: from a)napne/w. — peri/: adv. with e)pipnei/ousa (pne/w, § 29 i. cf. pnoih/).
de/: introduces the cause of a)mpnu/nqh.
zw/grei (zwh/, e)gei/rw): revived. To be distinguished from zw/grei (zwo/s, a)gre/w) take captive, 6.46.

qumo/n: obj. of kekafho/ta, which is const. with (*sarph/dona) the obj. of zw/grei. cf. mh/ me . . . dama/sh| kekafho/ta qumo/n e 467 f., 22.467 (quoted on 696). Contrast (h( d' e)pei\ ou)=n a)/mpnuto) kai\ e)s fre/na qumo\s a)ge/rqh *x 475.
Return from the description of the single combats to that of the general battle. The Greeks slowly retreat, as Diomed had directed, 605 f.
u(p' *)/arhi: under the might of Ares, i.e. before Ares.
protre/ponto: cf. 605, terga dantes ruebant. — For the vowel remaining short before tr, see § 41, i b. — e)pi/: toward. Cf. pe/tontai e)p' *)wkeanoi=o r(oa/wn *g 5.

a)ntefe/ronto: sc. *trw/essi, or, more definitely, *)/arhi kai\ *(/ektori. cf. a)rgale/os ga\r *)olu/mpios a)ntife/resqai *a 589. — The rhyme between the first ‘hemistichs’ of 700 f. is doubtless accidental. On 440; § 2 a.
ma/xh|: local. cf. 507.
o)pi/ssw: cf. 599 f.

w(s e)pu/qonto ktl.: sc. from Diomed, who had the gift to discern. cf. *)odush=a meta\ *trw/ess' a)nafh=nai d 254. — For the omission of the partic. o)/nta, cf. ma/la ga/r s' o(ro/w kalo/n te me/gan te a 301.

e)/nqa ktl.: indicates the large number of slain who are included between the two extremes (prw=ton, u(/staton). cf. ti/ prw=to/n toi e)/peita, ti/ d' u(sta/tion katale/cw; i 14, quem telo primum, quem postremum, aspera virgo| deicis? Verg. Aen. xi. 664 f. For the question as introductory to a narration, cf. also ti/s t' a)/r sfwe qew=n e)/ridi cune/hke ma/xesqai; *a 8.

xa/lkeos: bronze, with reference to his arms; cf. 859, 866, *h 146, *p 543. cf. (*)/iwna/s te kai\ *ka=ras) e)kba/ntas de\ e)s gh=n kai\ o(plisqe/ntas xalkw=|, a)gge/llei tw=n tis *ai)gupti/wn e)s ta\ e(/lea a)piko/menos tw=| *yammiti/xw|, w(s ou)k i)dw\n pro/teron xalkw=| a)/ndras o(plisqe/ntas, w(s xa/lkeoi a)/ndres a)pigme/noi a)po\ qala/sshs lehlateu=si (plunder) to\ pedi/on Hdt. ii. 152. cf. also xruse/hn *)afrodi/thn 427.
e)pi\ de/: adv., in addition, after him.
*)ore/sthn ktl.: these Greeks are not mentioned elsewhere. Orestes and Oenomaus are names of Trojans in 12.139 f.
ai)olomi/trhn: on 4.137.

<*>lh|: a height by Lake Copaïs. In 2.500 the first syllable is long, while here and 7.221 it is short. See § 41 f b. — plou/toio: gen. after a word of ‘mental action.’ cf. a)lkh=s *d 418, me/ga ptole/moio memhlw/s *n 297.
li/mnh|: for dat., see on 4.523.
keklime/nos: “on the shore.” cf. a)ll' e)n ga\r *trw/wn pedi/w| . . .| po/ntw| keklime/noi, e(ka\s (far) h(/meqa patri/dos ai)/hs *o 740.

*khfisi/di: earlier name of Lake Copaïs, derived from the Boeotian river Cephisus which rises on the north slope of Parnassus and empties into this lake. cf. li/mnhn th\n *khfisi/da, oi( de\ *kwpai+/da o)noma/zousi th\n au)th/n Paus. ix. 24. 1; *kafisi/dos e)n teme/nei Pindar, Pyth. xii. 27.
pa\r de/ oi(: while (but) by his side, near him.
a)/lloi: on 621.
dh=mon: land, district, as is clear from the epithet. cf. pi/onas a)grou/s d 757.
711-909. Hera and Athena descend to the field of battle, with the approval of Zeus, in order to aid the Achaeans. Ares is wounded. All the gods return to Olympus.
711-791. The descent of Hera and Athena. This is Athena's fourth descent during the action of the Iliad, and she comes again at 7.19.
tou\s de/: i.e. Ares and Hector.
*)argei/ous: obj. of o)le/kontas. — e)ni\ ktl.: cf. 4.462.
h)= r(a: truly, as it seems.
a(/lion: “was idle.” cf. 4.26, 158, 498.

to\n mu=qon: “that promise,” defined more exactly by the next verse. Here alone does Homer mention a special promise to Menelaus (that belongs to the earlier part of the story), but this serves as a motive for the action of the goddesses. — cf. h)pei/lhsen mu=qon *a 388, u(po/sxesin h(/n per u(pe/stan *b 286.
e)kpe/rsanta: naturally would agree with *menela/w|, but the const. of the acc. with the inf. is already in mind. i is sometimes, but seldom, elided in the dat. singular.
e)a/somen: ‘even the fut. ind. with ei) may be used in a present cond., if it expresses merely a present intention or necessity.’ GMT. 407.
ou)d' a)pi/qhse: “she readily consented.” A common ‘litotes.’ § 2 r.
xrusa/mpukas: cf. 358.
pre/sba: on 4.59.

ku/kla: equiv. to troxou/s. cf. 6.42. — The poet makes his hearer see the chariot come into being. Each act of preparation is enumerated. Thus also ‘When Homer wishes to tell us how Agamemnon was dressed, he makes the king put on every article of raiment in our presence: the soft tunic, the great mantle, the beautiful sandals, and the sword,’ Lessing's Laocoön xvi. — This passage — but this alone — implies that the Homeric chariots were taken to pieces when out of use.

xa/lkea: for the following hiatus, cf. au)ta\r o( e)/gnw *a 333, au)ta\r o( au)=te *b 105, a)/stude e)/lqwmen z 296; see § 9 b. — This chariot of the gods was all of metal, — even the parts which were generally of wood in the chariots of men. cf. the ‘silver bow’ and ‘golden lyre’ of Apollo. The Homeric chariots were very light, and the metal need not have been very thick.
o)kta/knhma: eight-spoked. The wheel had four felloes, and each felloe was supported by two spokes.
a)/coni a)mfi/s: lit. at the axle on both sides, — defines o)xe/essi 722. — Hiatus is allowed here as freq. after i of dat. singular.
i)/tus: on 4.486.
a)/fqitos: so Agamemnon's staff, wrought by Hephaestus, is a)/fqiton ai)ei/ *b 46.
prosarhro/ta: fitted to it, i.e. fastened with nails. — For the redup., see § 25 k.
qau=ma ktl.: a wonder to behold. Cf. teu/xea de\ xru/seia pelw/ria, qau=ma i)de/sqai *k 439, (Aetna) te/ras me\n qauma/sion proside/sqai, qau=ma de\ kai\ pareo/ntwn a)kou=sai Pindar Pyth. i. 26.
plh=mnai: hubs.
ei)si/: the pres. is used of an unchanging quality. cf. 2.448.
peri/dromoi ktl.: turning on both sides of the chariot.

di/fros e)nte/tatai: the footboard (or platform) of the chariot is strung (or plaited). cf. pole/sin d' e)/ntosqen i(ma=sin| e)nte/tato (sc. kune/h helmet) sterew=s *k 262 f., e)n (sc. le/xei) d' e)ta/nuss) i(ma/nta boo\s foi/niki faeino/n y 201. — doiai\ [du/o] de\ ktl.: i.e. one on either side. The numeral is explained by peri/dromoi, on both sides and in front, which follows after the versepause. The back of the chariot was open.

tou= d' e)c: but from this chariot. Const. with pe/len. — pe/len: the tense of narrative follows the pres. of description, apparently because the pole was fastened to the chariot on each occasion of its use.
e)p' a)/krw|: sc. r(umw=|, at the front end of the pole. cf. *z 40, *p 371, kai\ to\ me\n (sc. zugo/n) eu)= kate/qhkan e)uce/stw| e)pi\ r(umw=|| pe/zh| e)/pi prw/th| *w 271 f.
dh=se (sc. *(/hbh): she bound, i.e. fastened by means of the long zugo/desmon or yoke-strap. cf. 24.270 ff.
e)n: adv., thereon, with e)/bale.

le/padna ba/le: laid the broad breaststraps. The Homeric horses drew only by means of the yoke, without ‘traces.’ Hence their relation to the pole and chariot was much freer than that of modern times, and when the pole was broken, the horses were free.
xru/seia: adorned with (thin plates of) gold.
e)/ridos ktl.: synonyms. cf. 475, 665. — For the gen., cf. memao/te qou/ridos a)lkh=s *n 197, a)lkh=s ma/la per memao/ta *r 181.
au)ta/r: correl. with me/n 720.
pe/plon: i.e. Athena's robe, fastened at the side and shoulder with brooches (cf. 425). Evidently this woman's pe/plos corresponded in the main to the man's xitw/n which Athena donned.
kate/xeuen (xe/w): let fall, sc. by removing the brooch at the shoulder.
e(a_no/n: when this is used as a noun, the penult is short. cf. 3.385.
patro/s: Athena, the muchloved daughter of Zeus, seems to dwell in her father's palace, though each of the other gods had his own home on Olympus (cf. 1.606 f.).
ka/me xersi/n: wrought with her hands, i.e. wove skilfully, as Athena *)erga/nh. cf. 338, a)mbro/sion e(ano\n (robe) e(/saq) (put on), o(/n oi( *)aqh/nh| e)/cus' a)skh/sasa *c 178 f.
*dio/s: const. with xitw=na.— nefelhgere/tao: on 4.30.
teu/xesin: i.e. the armor which Athena had as goddess of war.
dakruo/enta: tearful, i.e. tear-causing. cf. a)legeinh/ 658.

ai)gi/da: the ‘aegis’ belonged to Zeus, but Athena was allowed to borrow it occasionally, and used it to inspire terror. cf. *s 204, *f 400, x 297. It seems to have been a symbol of the thundercloud, and the Gorgon's head upon it represented the thunder-storm. cf. *foi=bos *)apo/llwn| ei(me/nos (clad) w)/moiin nefe/lhn, e)/xe d' ai)gi/da qou=rin| deinh\n a)mfida/seian a)riprepe/), h(\n a)/ra xalkeu\s| *(/hfaistos *dii\ dw=ke forh/menai e)s fo/bon a)ndrw=n *o 307 ff.

qusano/essan: tasselled. Cf. th=s (sc. ai)gi/dos) e(kato\n qu/sanoi pagxru/seoi h)ere/qontai,| pa/ntes e)upleke/es, e(kato/mboios de\ e(/kastos *b 448 f. In later times, the aegis was surrounded by serpents instead of tassels.
deinh/n: see on mh/thr 313.
fo/bos: flight. Cf. 4.440.

e)stefa/nwtai: is crowned, i.e. surrounded. cf. th=| (i.e. the shield of Agamemnon) d' e)pi\ me
 *gorgw\ blosurw=pis (grim-eyed) e)stefa/nwto| deino
 derkome/nh, peri\ de\ *dei=mo/s te *fo/bos te *l 36 f., nh=son, th
 pe/ri po/ntos a)pei/ritos e)stefa/nwtai k 195.
e)n de/: and thereon.

e)/ris: of this conflict, a)lkh/ (defence) and i)wkh/ (attack) are the two sides. All these, as well as fo/bos, are the effects of the action of the aegis, but are here described as represented upon it.
cf. Od. 11.634. — Here begins the description of a new member of the company.

pelw/rou: in appos. with the gen. *gorgou=s, which is implied in the adj. *gorgei/h. cf. au)tou= *z 446, *nestore/h| parx\ nhi\ *puloigene/os basilh=os *b 54. — The Gorgon's head was placed on the middle of the shield. In early art, this was a round female face with glaring eyes, broad nose, and distorted mouth. Later, it had tusky teeth and a protruding tongue. Finally, it was a beautiful sad face, — no longer fitted to awaken terror, but pity and sympathy. — Homer knows but one Gorgon and has no other name for her.
*dio\s te/ras: portent of Zeus, since he uses it. cf. (ai)o/lon o)/fin) *dio\s te/ras ktl. *m 209, p 320.
a)mfi/falon: i.e. with double ridge of metal, from front to back, strengthening the helmet.
tetrafa/lhron: with four bosses.
e(kato\n ktl.: i.e. adorned with a scene of a conflict in which allies take part. cf. the representation of the beleaguered city on the shield of Achilles, 18.509 ff.
e(kato/n: a poetic ‘round number.’ cf. 2.448 f., quoted on 738.
flo/gea (fle/gw): gleaming, sc. with metallic plates. — For the short ‘ultima,’ treated as long before the caesura, see § 41 p.
posi/: a picturesque addition. cf. 770, o( d' u(yo/se possi\n e)ph/da (leaped) 21.269, ‘O Lord, we have heard with our ears.’
= Od. 1.100 f. — For the accumulation of epithets, see § 1 n.
tw=|, toi=sin: relatives.
h(rw/wn: in appos. with a)ndrw=n. See on 313. — kote/ssetai [kote/shtai]: has conceived wrath. For the subjv., see on 4.259.
de/: for the ‘quantity,’ cf. 840; see § 41 k.
au)to/matai (‘automata’) ktl.: cf. ‘till at the gate| Of Heaven ar rived, the gate self-opened wide,’ Milton Par. Lost v. 253 f.

pu/lai mu/kon: the gates are clouds (cf. 751), but yet they creak as if of brass. cf. ta\ (sc. doors) a)ne/braxen (roared) h)u/te tau=ros *f 48, ‘and on their hinges grate| Harsh thunder,’ Milton Par. Lost ii. 881 f. — cf. ‘till Morn,| Wak't by the circling hours, with rosy hand| Unbarr'd the gates of Light,’ Milton Par. Lost vi. 2 f.
e)/xon: kept, had in charge. The tense is assimilated to the narrative in which the description is interwoven.
*(=wrai: here the attendants of the gods.
me/gas ktl.: cf. 1.497.
e)piqei=nai: put to, close. — This verse explains e)pite/traptai.
th=|: defined by di) au)ta/wn. — kentrhneke/as: goaded. Cf. ke/ntores i(/ppwn *d 391. — For the length of the last syllable, see on be/los *d 129.
a)/ter: without, follows its gen. only here in Homer, but freq. in tragedy.
754 = *a 499, *q 3. cf. summo sedet altus Olympo Verg. Aen. xi. 726.
poludeira/dos: epithets borrowed from men are often applied to objects of nature. cf. ‘mouth’ and ‘head’ of a river, ‘shoulder’ and ‘foot’ of a mountain.
e)/nqa: there.
*zeu pa/ter: Zeus's wife-and-sister, as well as the rest of the gods, gives him this conventional title. So Poseidon, Od. 13.128. cf. 426.
o(ssa/tion [equiv. to o(/son] ktl.: an exclamation in explanation of kartera\ e)/rga. cf. 638. — cf. ma\y ou(/tw toio/nde toso/nde te lao\n *)axaiw=n *b 120, qualis quantusque Verg. Aen. iii. 641.
ma\y ktl.: cf. *b 214, g 138.
e)moi\ ktl.: but to my grief. Cf. 3.50 f.
tou=ton: istum. Contemptuous. cf. 831, 8.299.
a)ne/ntes (a)ni/hmi): the reason for te/rpontai. This was true of Apollo, cf. 455 ff., but no such act is ascribed to Aphrodite. — cf. 422.
ou)/ tina ktl.: knows no law.
cf. 421; but here Hera asks for information.
*zeu= pa/ter ktl.: the repetition of the address and the r(a/ mark this question as in close connexion with that of 757.
peplhgui=a: equiv. to plh/ssousa. cf. Odysseus's words to Thersites, au)to\n de\ klai/onta qoa\s e)pi\ nh=as a)fh/sw| peplhgw\s a)gorh=qen *b 263 f. See on keklhgw/s 591.
e)ca_podi/wmai: drive away (a)po/) out of (e)c). — For the length of the second syllable, cf. a_\pone/esqai 716.
a)/grei ma/n [a)/ge dh/]: well, go to! With fg. imv., or inf. as imperative. cf. *h 459, *l 512, *c 271, f 176, a)grei=te u 149.
oi(=: after e)pi/. cf. *menela/w| *d 94.
e)/porson: rouse against him.
a)gelei/hn: cf. 4.128.
o)du/nh|si ktl.: cf. 397. — Athena as goddess of war was the special rival of Ares. cf. 430. She was mightier than he. cf. 853 ff., 21.391 ff.
769 = 8.46. — cf. terras inter caelumque volabat Verg. Aen. iv. 256.
a)stero/entos: for the standing epithet, see § 1 p.
o(/sson ktl.: how far (as far as) a man sees into the dim distance.
h)eroeide/s: prob. attrib. with o(/sson. Acc. of extent.
i)/den: gnomic aorist.

o)fqalmoi=sin: on posi/ 745. — cf. to/sson ti/s t' e)pi\ leu/ssei (sees), o(/ssn t' e)pi\ la=an i(/hsin *g 12. — Of course the poet could not say ‘half a mile’ or ‘twenty rods’ or even a ‘stade.’ He was obliged to measure by the reach of the eye or the voice, or the cast of a spear or discus, or a bowshot, or a furrow's length.
This verse simply draws the poetic picture. It has nothing to do with the comparison. — cf. 4.275.
leu/sswn ktl.: cf. 1.350.
to/sson: sc. at a single bound. So Poseidon's horses needed but four strides to pass from Thracian Samos to Aegae. 13.12-21.
u(yhxe/es: cf. arrectis fremit cervicibus Verg. Aen. xi. 496.
i(=con [a)fi/konto]: for the form, cf. 6.172; see § 30 j.
potamw\ ktl.: equiv. to potamw=n r(oa/s. cf. 6.4.
A closer definition of the preceding half-verse.

sumba/lleton: dual although but one subj. has preceded. This position of a dual or plural verb, between two sing. subjs., is called sxh=ma *)alkmaniko/n. cf. *ka/stwr te pw/lwn w)ke/wn dmath=res, i(ppo/tai sofoi/,| kai\ *pwludeu/khs kudro/s Alcman 2, ei) de/ k' *)/arhs a)/rxwsi ma/xhs h)\ *foi=bos *)apo/llwn g 138.
h)de/: for the ‘quantity’ of the last syllable, before *sk, cf. 49; see § 41 i e.
peri/: adv. round about.
h)e/ra ktl.: sc. in order to conceal the horses from the sight of mortals. cf. 356. — poulu/n [polu/n]: as fem. See § 20 a.
toi=sin: for them.
a)mbrosi/hn: only here as fodder for the steeds of the gods.
*simo/eis: perhaps the horses were nearer the Simoïs than the Scamander.
ne/mesqai: explanatory inf. of purpose, “for them to feed.” — cf. toi=si d' u(po\ xqw\n di=a fu/en neoqhle/a poi/hn *c 347.
tw/: for fem. See G. 78 N. 2; H. 272 a. cf. profane/nte *q 378, plhge/nte *q 455, both of the same pair of goddesses.
trh/rwsi ktl.: perhaps a reference to the short quick steps of women, as compared with the strides (makra\ biba/s) of men.
peleia/sin: dat. after a ‘word of likeness.’
a)ndra/sin: for the dat., cf. w)/ressin 486, toi/ *d 129.
a)lece/menai: a)le/cein.
a)mfi\ ktl.: Diomed seems to be included. — cf. 6.436 f., oi( d' a)mfi\ *pri/amon ktl. *g 146.

cf. *h 256, *o 592. — For the comparison, cf. 299, *d 253, *l 324, 414, *m 42, 146, *p 823, *r 281. — ei)lo/menoi: crowded together, since the Achaeans were forced back. cf. 791. — lei/ousin [le/ousin] e)oiko/tes: const. closely with e(/stasan. sc. since they did not turn to headlong flight. cf. the command of Diomed, 605 f.
h)/: in a comparison, where the poet leaves the choice to the hearer. cf. 2.800, Od. 17.36 f.

susi\ ka/proisin: the species is in appos. with the genus. § 1 u. Cf. seu/h| (sc. ku/nas) e)p' a)grote/rw| sui+\ kapri/w| h)e\ le/onti *l 293, ou)/t) ou)=n parda/lios (pard) to/sson me/nos ou)/te le/ontos| ou)/te suo\s ka/prou *r 20 f., i)/qusen de\ dia\ proma/xwn sui+\ ei)/kelos a)lkh\n| kapri/w|, o(/s t' e)n o)/ressi ku/nas qalerou/s t) ai)zhou\s| r(hidi/ws e)ke/dassen *r 281 ff.
a)lapadno/n: cf. 4.330.
e)/nqa ktl.: cf. *l 10, *s 217.
*ste/ntori: Stentor is mentioned only here in Homer, but he has given an adjective to the English language.
xalkeofw/nw|: cf. (ei)) fwnh\ d' a)/rrhktos, xa/lkeon de/ moi h)=tor e)nei/h *b 490, o)/pa xa/lkeon *ai)aki/dao *s 222, ferrea vox Verg. Aen. vi. 626.
to/son: so loud. Cf. 860, 863.
ai)dw/s: nom. as an exclamation. “Shame upon you.” cf. 403, 406, *d 242, *n 95, *o 502, *p 422.
ka/k' e)le/gxea: “coward caitiffs.” cf. 2.235. The expression seems exaggerated, when compared with 782 f.
ei)=dos ktl.: in contrast with ka/k' e)le/gxea. cf. 3.39, 44.
po/lemon: equiv. to ma/xhn. — pwle/sketo: cf. of Achilles, ou)/te pot' ei)s a)gorh\n pwle/sketo kudia/neiran| ou)/te pot) e)s po/lemon *a 490 f.
ou)de/ pote: not even once, not a single time.

*dardania/wn: cf. 22.194, 413. “Gate of the Dardanian city.” Elsewhere called the Scaean Gate; 6.237. — For the thought, cf. Achilles's words, o)/fra d' e)gw\ met) *)axaioi=sin pole/mizon,| ou)k e)qe/leske ma/xhn a)po\ tei/xeos o)rnu/men *(/ektwr,| a)ll) o(/son e)s *skaia/s te pu/las kai\ fhgo\n i(/kanen:| e)/nqa pot) oi)=on e)/mimne, mo/gis de/ meu e)/kfugen o(rmh/n (onset) 9.352 ff.
koi/lh|s e)pi\ nhusi/: in appos. with e(ka\s po/lios. cf. 687, 804; see on i(erh=s *d 103. — An exaggeration.
792-863. Athena both rebukes and encourages Diomed. The two wound Ares.
e)po/rouse: hastened to. Here in a friendly sense, without the usual idea of hostility (as in 432).
eu(=re ktl.: the situation in which Diomed is found, away from the press of battle, near his chariot, seems to be different from that in the poet's mind at 781.
a)nayu/xonta: explained by 798. cf. i(drw= a)peyu/xonto xitw/nwn| sta/nte poti\ pnoih\n para\ qi=n' a(lo/s 11.621 f., i(drw= a)peyu/xonto, pi/on t' a)ke/onto/ te di/yan *x 2.
to/: ‘acc. of effect.’ See on o(/ 361.
ba/le *pa/ndaros: cf. 95 ff.
e)/teiren: i.e. the sweat irritated the wound.

u(po\ ktl.: under the weight of the broad strap which supported the shield. On works of art, this telamw/n is sometimes made to pass over one shoulder, and sometimes over the other. In this case it was over the right shoulder (cf. 98), as would seem most convenient for the support of the shield. cf. Agamemnon's words, i(drw/sei me/n teu (many a one's) telamw\n a)mfi\ sth/qessin| a)spi/dos a)mfibro/ths, peri\ d' e)/xxei+ xei=ra kamei=tai:| i(drw/sei de/ teu i(/ppos e)u/coon a(/rma titai/nwn *b 388 ff.
eu)ku/klou: cf. 453.
tw=| (i.e. sweat) tei/reto: to this repetition of the thought of 796, is joined ‘paratactically’ ka/mne de\ xei=ra as a result.
xei=ra: i.e. the right arm which wielded the spear, his ‘sword arm.’
a)/n [a)na/]: adv. with i)/sxwn [e)/xwn].
i(ppei/ou: equiv. to i(/ppwn. cf. *gorgei/h 741, *(hraklhei/hn 638.
zugou= h(/yato: Athena laid her hand upon the yoke, assuming the attitude of a friend and familiar toward Diomed. who seems now to be upon the chariot or immediately beside it.
“The son of Tydeus is not like him.” cf. 4.370 ff., 400, where the same story is told by Agamemnon.
o)li/gon: adv. with e)oiko/ta, little like.
oi(=: reflexive. § 24 c.
Explanatory ‘asyndeton.’ § 2 m.
*tudeu/s: obs. the repetition of the last word of the preceding verse at the beginning of this.
toi/: “you may know.”
de/mas: prob. refers to stature. In general it corresponds nearly to the Attic use of sw=ma. § 2 v.
maxhth/s: fighter. See on korusth/n *d 457 for similar nouns.

kai/ r() o(/te: even when. — In this general ‘protasis,’ the speaker adds with animation a second ‘protasis’ (o(/te te ktl. 803; cf. 6.132) which introduces a special example of the characteristics of Tydeus. This second protasis gains the upper hand, and the former is forgotten.
ou)k ei)/askon: forbade.
ou)de/: nor.
e)kpaifa/ssein: distinguish himself, make himself prominent in word or deed (cf. prokali/zeto, e)ni/ka 807), in contrast to a quiet reserve (e(/khlon 805).
no/sfin *)axaiw=n: equiv. to mou=nos e)w/n *d 388.
cf. 4.384 ff. — pole/as [pol- lou/s, § 20 f] ktl.: in appos. with e)s *qh/bas. cf. 791, e)s *)wkeano\n met' a)mu/monas *ai)qioph=as *a 423.
*qh/bas: pl. here, though sing. in 4.378. See on *fhrh=| 543.
This does not seem to begin an ‘apodosis,’ but to repeat in positive form the thought of the second half-verse of 802.
dai/nusqai: has a prominent place in contrast with polemi/zein 802, and prepares the way for the contrast in prokali/zeto 807.
au)ta/r: adversative to a)/nwgon 805.
qumo\n ktl.: “with his own brave heart.”
kou/rous *kadmei/wn: cf. *kadmei+/wnas 804, kou=roi *)axaiw=n *g 183, ui(=es *)axaiw=n *z 255.
soi\ d' h)= ktl.: in contrast with 802 f.
para\ ktl.: cf. Od. 13.301.
profrone/ws: with all my heart, downright. This emphasizes ke/lomai, in contrast with ou)k ei)/askon.
seu=: placed before h)/, as if it belonged to both clauses, — but it is replaced by se/ in 812.
polua=ic: cf. to\ me\n plei=on polua/ikos pole/moio *a 165.
Obs. the repetition of the pron., soi/, se/, seu=, se/, su/. See on 652.
e)/peita: “to judge from your actions.”
*oi)nei+/dao: on 4.399.
gignw/skw: recognize, sc. though in human form. cf. 824.
tw=|: therefore.
profrone/ws: willingly. pro/frwn is more freq. in this use.
ou)d' e)pikeu/sw: parallelism, stating the same thing in a negative form. cf. neike/sw, ou)d' e)pikeu/sw *k 115, u(poqh/somai, ou)d) e)pikeu/sw e 143.
de/os: cf. 812.
o)/knos: hesitancy as the result of weariness, faintness. Cf. ka/matos 811. — cf. o)/knw| ei)/kwn ou)/t' a)fradi/h|si no/oio *k 122.
se/wn: monosyllabic. § 7 a.
a(\s e)pe/teilas: ‘epexegesis’ of se/wn.
ou)ta/men [ou)ta=n]: sc. e)ke/leues from ou)/ m' ei)/as 819.
a)lh/menai [a)lh=nai]: to gather in close order, i.e. not to be scattered. cf. ei)lo/menoi 782, a)olle/es 498.
ma/xhn a)na/: cf. 167, 332. — a)na/ does not suffer anastrophe. On 4.230.
825 = Od. 1.44, 80, 314, Od. 13.329, 392, 420. The first half-verse introduces a reply more than seventy times in Homer; the second occurs more than forty times.
*)/arha: for the length of the last syllable, cf. flo/gea 745.
to/ ge: in this, on this account, i.e. because Athena had warned Diomed (cf. 818) against attacking other gods than Aphrodite.
prw/tw|: first of all, before all others.
e)/xe: hold, guide.

sxedi/hn: near, i.e. in the handto-hand conflict. — An adv. acc., sc. plhgh/n. On 220. cf. au)tosxedi/hn *m 192, a)mfadi/hn *h 196, a)ntibi/hn 220, a)pria/thn *a 99. — Obs. the repetition of the name ‘Ares’ in 827, 829 f., showing much more feeling than a pronoun would have done.
tou=ton: cf. 761.
tukto/n: well-made. Const. with kako/n, “a perfect curse,” with reference to the sufferings of war.
a)llopro/sallon: the fortunes of war are ever-changing, and its god is fickle. Cf. *z 339, cuno\s (impartial) e)nua/lios, kai/ te ktane/onta kate/kta *s 309, e)pi/mic de/ te mai/netai *)/arhs l 537.
prw/hn: cf. prwiza/ *b 303.
e)moi\ ktl.: const. with steu=t' a)goreu/wn, taken together.
steuto: made show, acted. Cf. *b 597, *g 83, r 525.
a)goreu/wn: “in his words.” — The promise is not acknowledged by Ares in Homer, but cf. 21.412 ff. See on 715. — The whole thought is suggested by a)llopro/sallon, which 832 f. explains.
maxh/sesqai, a)rh/cein: depend on steu=to. — a)rh/cein: cf. 507.
o(milei=: here in a friendly manner.
tw=n: i.e. his promises to aid the Achacans.
w(\s fame/nh: with these words. Cf. 290.

a)f' i(/ppwn: see on kaq' i(/ppwn 111. — cf. Iuturna virago| aurigam Turni media inter lora Metiscum| excutit et longe lapsum temone relinquit,| ipsa subit manibusque undantis fleetit habenas Verg. Aen. xii. 468 ff.
pa/lin e)ru/sasa: drawing him back, out of the open back of the car.
a)po/rousen: cf. 20.
Athena herself takes the place of Diomed's charioteer. — parai/ [para/, § 37 d b]: (to a place) beside. — This second half-verse defines e)s di/fron. cf. 446, 791, 804, 857.
e)mmemaui=a: full of eagerness for the fray. cf. 142.
me/ga: adverbial.

fh/ginos: oaken. Cf. fhgw=| 693. — cf. e)/lakon a)co/nwn briqome/nwn xno/ai Aesch. Septem. 138, gemuit sub pondere cymba Verg. Aen. vi. 413, nitens sub pondere faginus axis| instrepat Verg. Georg. iii. 172 f.
deinh/n, a)/riston: both receive prominence from the ‘chiastic’ order of the sentence (§ 2 o).
la/zeto: elsewhere only in the fourth foot of the verse, forming a dactyl before the ‘Bucolic diaeresis.’
ma/stiga: an essential part of the Homeric charioteer's equipment.
au)ti/ka: for the ‘asyndeton,’ see § 2 n.
842-863. Ares wounded by Athena and Diomed.
*peri/fanta: a ‘homonym’ is a herald of Anchises, 17.323.

e)cena/rizen: was stripping off the armor (e)/nara, *z 68, 480), sc. when Athena and Diomed came up. — Nowhere else in Homer does a divinity slay a mortal. Elsewhere the gods satisfy themselves with encouraging their friends and dismaying their enemies.
me/n: a repetition of me/n 842, correl. with au)ta/r 844. On 4.227.
au)ta\r *)aqh/nh: for the transition at the ‘Bucolic diaeresis,’ see § 40 h.

*)/aidos kune/hn: this helmet of Hades made the wearer invisible (a)idh/s). cf. *)/aidos kune/h nukto\s zo/fon ai)no\n e)/xousa Hesiod Shield 227, skotodasupukno/trixa/ tin' *)/aidos kunh=n Arist. Acharnians 390. It is not mentioned elsewhere in Homer. It is needed here only on Ares's account, — not for mortals. — cf. the ‘Tarnkappe’ of the Teutonic epos. — Artists represented this as a Phrygian felt cap (‘fez’) with the top inclining to the front like a horn.
au)to/qi: explained by the following clause with o(/qi, just as e)/asen is explained by kei=sqai.
*diomh/deos: for the gen. with i)qu/s, cf. bh= d' i)qu\s *teu/krou *q 322. G. 182, 2; H. 757.
See on 14.
pro/sqen: sooner, first, correl. with deu/teros 855.
w)re/cato: cf. 4.307.
i(/ppwn: sc. of Diomed. Ares was on foot; he had lent his chariot to Aphrodite; cf. 363.
e)/gxei+: const. with w)re/cato. — a)po/: const. with e(le/sqai. cf. 317, 673, 691.
kai/: in close connexion with w)re/cato, adds the sequel to that action.
e)tw/sion: predicate. cf. (e)/gxos) h)i/xqh pala/mhfin e)tw/sion *g 368, a(/lion 715. — Athena gave Ares's spear such a push that it passed uselessly under the chariot.
nei/aton ktl.: cf. *l 381, *p 821.
mi/trhn: 4.137. For the acc. (after a ‘verb of clothing’), cf. *murmido/nessi ke/leusen| xalko\n zw/nnusqai *y 129 f. G. 166, N. 4; 164; H. 724 a.
th=|: adv. there.
dia/: const. with e)/dayen. cf. (e)/gxos) i)qu\s e)meu= w)=sas, dia\ de\ xro/a kalo\n e)/dayas *f 398, e)mo\n do/ru makro/n, o(/ toi xro/a leirio/enta (lily)| da/yei *n 830 f.
= 14.148 f., of a shout of Poseidon.
o(/sson: cf. 786.
e)pi/axon: gnomic. Used esp. of joyous shouts of exultation over the foe.
deka/xiloi: mu/rioi. — cf. tu miser exclamas, ut Stentora vincere possis,| velpotius quantum Gradivus Homericus Juvenal xiii. 112 f.
e)/rida ktl.: cf. *c 149, cuna/gwmen *)/arha *b 381, su/nagon kraterh\n u(smi/nhn *p 764.
dei/santas: “as fear came over them.” The cause of the fear is given by the rest of the verse.
*)/arhs ktl.: cf. 388.
864-909. Return to Olympus of Ares, Athena, and Hera. Ares complains to Zeus and is rebuked by him. The wound is healed.
cf. oi(=os d' e)k nefe/wn a)nafai/netai ou)/lios a)sth\r| pamfai/nwn *l 62 f.
e)k nefe/wn: out of the clouds, which the wind (865) appears to have gathered.
a)h/r: air, mist, i.e. the lower visible layer of the atmosphere.
kau/matos e)/c: “in consequence of the sultry heat,” before a thunderstorm, of which the wind is viewed as a result. Const. with a)ne/moio ktl. cf. e)c a)ndrw=n 384.
toi=os: i.e. so dark.
o(mou= nefe/essin: the rhythm of the verse indicates that this is to be const. with fai/neto. Ares wrapped himself in a thick cloud as he ascended.
qumo/n: cf. kh=r 399.
a)/mbroton ai(=ma: cf. 339 f.
nemesi/zh|: with causal participle. cf. te/rpesqon ei)soro/wsai *d 9 f. — Ares makes the same complaint as Hera, and applies to Athena the same epithet (a)/frwn, 875) which Hera applied to him, 761.
r(i/gista: adv. — tetlho/tes ei)me/n [e)sme/n]: periphrastic perfect. Equiv. to te/tlamen. cf. *d 211, *z 488, peprwme/non e)sti/n *g 309.
a)llh/lwn: equiv. to a)/llos a)/llou. cf. 384. Const. with i)o/thti.
xa/rin fe/rontes: cf. 211.
a)/ndressi: equiv. to brotoi=si. cf. 839.
Ares turns from his general complaint to the special matter in hand.
soi\ ktl.: with thee we all quarrel, etc.

maxo/mesqa: for this term used of contention in thought and word, cf. *z 329, *a 8, maxhsame/nw e)pe/essin *a 304, e)gw\n *)axileu/s te maxhsa/meq' ei(/neka kou/rhs *b 377, Diomed's words *)atrei+/dh, soi\ prw=ta maxh/somai *i 32.
te/kes: on 4.515.
ou)lome/nhn: destructive. Cf. 1.2. Equiv. to a)i/dhlon 880. — For the position, see on 313.
a)h/sula: unseemly. Opposed to ai)/sima (cf. 6.62).
me/mhlen: cf. 430.
me\n ga/r: while, introduces a case in point. — “Your indulgence to your daughter is to blame for all the trouble.”
o(/soi qeoi\ ktl.: equiv. to tw=n e)n *)olu/mpw| qew=n.

soi/ te: the te/ is loosely placed after the pron. instead of after e)pipei/qontai. — dedmh/mesqa (da/mnhmi): we are subject, we are obedient. For the change of person from e)pipei/qontai, cf. 7.159 f., 17.250, ou) ga\r *ku/klwpes *dio\s ai)gio/xou a)le/gousin,| ou)de\ qew=n maka/rwn, e)pei\ h)= polu\ fe/rteroi/ ei)men i 275 f.
e(/kastos: in partitive appos. with the subj. of the verb.
tau/thn: on tou=ton 761.
e)/pei+ ktl.: Ares does not utter distinctly, but rather assumes as evident, the thought implied in contrast to 877 f., that Athena had been disobedient.
e)/pei+, e)/rgw|: for the pair, cf. h)\ e)/pei w)/nhsas kradi/hn *dio\s h)e\ kai\ e)/rgw| *a 395.
“You let her do as she pleases, since she is your own daughter.”
a)niei=s: cf. a)niei=sa 422, a)nh=ke 405, a)ne/ntes 761.
e)gei/nao: cf. 875.
h(\ ktl.: she who, etc. An independent sent. as an exclamation.
nu=n: refers to ai)e/n 876.
u(perfi/alon: the epithet shows Ares's bitterness. It is not a ‘standing epithet’ of Diomed.
*diomh/dea: for the ‘synizesis,’ cf. sa/kea *d 113, *diomh/dea *d 365.
a)ne/hken: urged on. With a different meaning from a)niei=s 880; on 228.
e)pi\ qeoi=si: against the gods. Cf. e)pi\ *trw/essi ma/xesqai 124.
h)= te ktl.: cf. h)= te/ ken h)/dh| la/inon e(/sso xitw=na *g 56 f.

ph/mat' e)/pasxon: although the god Ares could not die, yet he assumes that he might have lain as dead. Hence the contrast with zw/s 887. cf. Ares's words, ei)/ pe/r moi kai\ moi=ra *dio\s plhge/nti keraunw=|| kei=sqai o(mou= neku/essi meq' ai(/mati kai\ koni/h|sin *o 117 f.
e)n ktl.: cf. 16.661. The second half-verse defines au\tou=.
zw/s: zwo/s. Concessive.
a)menhno/s: powerless. Only here in the Iliad. Cf. neku/wn a)menhna\ ka/rhna k 521.
Reply to 872-874.
a)llopro/salle: cf. 831.
891 = 1.177. Here the verse seems in place, while in A (applied by Agamemnon to Achilles), it seems better fitted to be an honor than a reproach.
fi/lh: the pred. adj. regularly agrees with the preceding noun, and the rest of the verse is in a sort of appos. with e)/ris.
Reply to 875 ff. — “Athena and I are not to blame; — your mother is responsible for your sufferings.”
toi/: let me tell you.
me/nos: spirit, fury.
a)a/sxeton: the opposite of 878.
ou)k e)pi/eikton: not to be overcome. Cf. oi)=sqa me\n oi(=on e)mo\n me/nos e)/mpedon ou)d' e)pieikto/n,| e(/cw d) w(s o(/te tis stereh\ li/qos h)e\ si/dhros t 493 f.
*(/hrhs: with emphasis at the close of the sentence and beginning of the verse. In appos. with mhtro/s 892; see on 313.
th\n me/n: demonstrative.
spoudh=|: with difficulty, scarcely. — The thought is general. Zeus refers to no particular instance.
tw=|: therefore.
kei/nhs: const. with e)nnesi/h|sin. — e)nnesi/h|sin: for the pl., cf. a)tasqali/h|sin *d 409. — Hera cannot have urged Ares to enter the battle on this occasion! Or, is the reference to 762 f.?
a)ll' ou) ktl.: cf. *r 41, *y 441.
e)/xonta: supplementary partic. with a)ne/comai.
ge/nos: cf. ge/nos 544.
teu=: tino/s. § 24 r.
kai\ dh\ pa/lai: even long ago, i.e. not just now.
h)=sqa: the fg. hiatus is justified by the pause.
e)ne/rteros: comparative of e)/neros. Lower than the Uranions.

*ou)raniw/nwn: here, at variance with ordinary Homeric usage, the *ou)rani/wnes are not the inhabitants of heaven (373, § 21 a), but the Titans, Cronus, Iapetus, etc., sons of *ou)rano/s, the race that (acc. to later story) ruled before Zeus, and were hurled by him into Tartarus. cf. 8.13 ff., 479 ff., *c 279, *o 225, Hesiod Theog. 720.
*paih/ona: on 401.
a)nw/gein: cf. 509.
o)po/s: sap of the fig-tree used instead of rennet. cf. fici sucus lacteus aceti naturam habet; itaque coaguli modo lac contrahit Pliny Nat. Hist. xxiii, 63.
leuko/n: for the ‘standing epithet,’ see § 1 p.
e)peigo/menos: (hastily,) speedily. Cf. *c 519, *y 119.
u(gro/n: in immediate contrast with sune/phcen. cf. u(gro\n u(/dwr d 458.

peritre/fetai: (the milk) is curdled around, as it is stirred. cf. yuxrh/ (cold), kai\ sake/essi peritre/feto kru/stallos (ice) c 477, nhxo/menoi, pollh\ de\ peri\ xroi+\ te/trofen a(/lmh (crust from the brine) Od. 23.237. — For the pres. used in comparisons, cf. 4.434.
kuko/wnti: for the one who stirs it, i.e. as it is stirred.
karpali/mws: one of the points of the comparison; cf. e)peigo/menos 902, w)=ka 903.
lou=sen: i.e. prepared the bath.
e(/ssen (e(/nnumi): sc. mi/n. — For the hiatus, see § 14 a.
a)ndroktasia/wn: cf. 717, 762 f., 842.

div.head: Book 6 (*z)
div.p: The beginning of the Sixth Book seems to be closely connected with the last verses of the Fifth Book. Diomed is still the mightiest and most feared of the Achaean chieftains although he is not mentioned among the combatants in the early part of the Book, and finally disappears in the interest which is excited by Hector. The latter's visit to the city of Ilios assumes the ‘Bravery of Diomed’ in E.

On the departure of the divinities from the field of battle, the Trojans are hard pressed by their foes. Helenus advises his brother Hector to go to the city and urge the matrons to offer sacrifices and vows to the goddess Athena, in the hope that she may be propitiated and break the spear of Diomed. The action soon passes to quieter scenes. The time occupied by Hector in traversing the Trojan plain, is occupied by the meeting of Glaucus and Diomed, which emphasizes the sanctity of friendship and the tie between guest and host (so sadly wronged by Paris). The visit of Priam's great son to Ilios affords the poet the opportunity to take up the story of the Third Book and give the hearer a view of the homes of the royal family of Troy and a glimpse of their relations to each other. At the close of the Book, Hector's loving wife and infant child are introduced in an episode which has given its name to the Book, ‘The Meeting of Hector and Andromache.’ Paris suggests a contrast to the sanctity of both Diomed's friendship and Hector's love.
1-60. Victorious conflict of the Achaeans, after the departure of the divinities.
oi)w/qh (oi)=os): was left alone, was deserted, by the gods. e)monw/qhsan oi( maxo/menoi. cf. the closing verses of the preceding Book.
polla/: often. Originally cognate acc., with i)/quse. — e)/nqa ktl.: cf. 5.223.
i)/quse: cf. i)qu\s fe/ron ktl. *e 506. — The following caesura is unusual. § 40 m.
pedi/oio: local gen. with i)/quse. G. 179, 2; H. 760.
a)llh/lwn: gen. after i)qunome/nwn. cf. *menela/ou *d 100.

i)qunome/nwn: sc. maxhtw=n. cf. peri\ sth/qessi de\ xalko\s | smerdale/on kona/bize (rang) tituskome/nwn (aiming) kaq' o(/milon | a)llh/lwn *n 497 ff. In later Greek, this would be considered as gen. abs., but here the implied noun is prob. a limiting gen. with ma/xh. § 3 f.
This verse defines the scene of the conflict. cf. 5.774.
*simo/entos: connected directly with messhgu/s by the rhythm of the verse. cf. to/ssa meshgu\ new=n h)de\ *ca/nqoio r(oa/wn | . . . pu/rx fai/neto *)ilio/qi pro/ *q 560 f.
*ca/nqoio: i.e. the Scamander, not the Lycian Xanthus of 5.479. cf. (potamo\s) o(\n *ca/nqon kale/ousi qeoi/, a)/ndres de\ *ska/mandron g 74.
prw=tos: sc. after the departure of the gods.
e(/rkos *)axaiw=n: cf. 3.229, (Achilles) o(\s me/ga pa=sin | e(/rkos *)axaioi=sin pe/letai pole/moio kakoi=o *a 283 f. Ajax is called a pu/rgos (“tower of strength”) Od. 11.556.
r(h=ce ktl.: cf. r(hch/nwr as an epithet of Achilles, 7.228.

fa/lagga: only here in the sing.; of the troop nearest Ajax. — fo/ws [fa/os, fw=s]: figurative. This metaphor is freq. in the Old Testament, as well as its opposite (darkness) as a figure for trouble.
e)/qhken: equiv. to e)poi/hse. cf. *e 122, *)axaioi=s a)/lge) e)/qhken *a 2.
balw/n: cf. 5.346. — e)ni\ *qrh/|kessi [*qra|ci/]: equiv. to *qrh|kw=n.
*)aka/manta: see on 5.462.
*teuqrani/dhn: in appos. with *)/aculon. An Achaean named Teuthras is mentioned 5.705.
*)ari/sbh|: near Abydus. cf. 2.836.
a)fneio\s ktl.: cf. 5.544. The adj. is attracted (as freq.) to the const. of the preceding rel. clause.

file/esken: of hospitable reception, as is made clear by the following half-verse. cf. tou\s d' e)gw\ e)cei/nissa kai\ e)n mega/roisi fi/lhsa *g 207, xai=re, cei=ne, par' a)/mmi filh/seai a 123, xrh\ cei=non pareo/nta filei=n, e)qe/lonta de\ pe/mpein (“welcome the coming, speed the parting guest”) Od. 15.74. Obs. the play on fi/los 14.
o(dw=| ktl.: living upon a highway, Axylus had special opportunities for the exercise of hospitality.
oi)ki/a: the ‘quantity’ of the ultima marks the declension, — if any such help is needed.
cf. 5.53, nec tibi Thessalicos tunc profuit, Ornyte, reges
div.l: hospitiis aut mente moras fovisse benigna Val. Flacc. Arg. iii. 173 f.
div.p: tw=n ge: refers to pa/ntas, to whom he had shown hospitality.
h)/rkese ktl.: cf. *b 873, g 289.
pro/sqen u(pantia/sas: opposing him (i.e. Diomed) first. — The neg. of 16 is const. with this partic. as well as with the verb. “No one of these met Diomed and warded him off from Axylus.”
a)phu/ra: sc. *diomh/dhs. Followed by two accusatives.
au)to\n ktl.: cf. *n 331, *p 279. — In appos. with a)/mfw.
u(fhni/oxos: not ‘under-charioteer,’ but charioteer under the authority of Axylus. cf. u(podmw/s d 386, u(podrhsth=res o 330.
tw\ d' a)/mfw: emphatic repetition of a)/mfw 17.
gai=an e)du/thn: i.e. their souls descended to Hades. cf. ti/ paqo/ntes e)remnh\n (gloomy) gai=an e)/dute w 106, a question addressed by the shade of Agamemnon to the souls of Penelope's suitors.
*eu)ru/alos: associated with Diomed and Sthenelus in the command of the men of Argos. 2.565.
*)ofe/ltion: an Achaean ‘homonym’ is slain by Hector, 11.302.
*ai)/shpon: this warrior (mentioned only here) received his name from the Trojan stream Aesepus. cf. 4.91. See on 4.474.
*ph/dason: named from the town of the same name. cf. 35.

nhi/s: naiad, fountain-nymph. In appos. with nu/mfh. — cf. tw\ *gugai/h te/ke li/mnh *b 865. — For ‘orestiads,’ see 420. cf. th=| (i.e. Artemis) de/ q' a(/ma nu/mfai, kou=rai *dio\s ai)gio/xoio | a)grono/moi pai/zousi z 105 f. ‘Dryads’ and ‘hamadryads’ are not mentioned in Homer. The Homeric nymphs who become enamored of mortals, all dwell in. Asia Minor, and for the most part in its northwest corner. Nymphs apparently did not abound in the Homeric times.

*)abarbare/h: i.e. the nymph of the pond near which Bucolion tended his flocks. The name is thought to refer to the clearness of the water. — These episodes in the poem served to relieve the monotony of long lists of warriors.
A parenthetical remark.

sko/tion: pred. adj., in secret, i.e. without marriage. cf. furtim in Helenor | Maeonio regi quem serva Licymnia furtim | sustulerat Verg. Aen. ix. 546; also, *)eu/dwros parqe/nios *p 180, sko/tioi pai=des Eur. Alc. 989.
poimai/nwn ktl.: cf. 11.106. — It was one of the patriarchal customs of the Homeric times that kings and kings' sons should tend their flocks and herds. cf. 424, 5.313.
e)p' o)/essi: cf. 5.137.
mi/gh: sc. *boukoli/wn nu/mfh|. — filo/thti ktl.: cf. 3.445.
diduma/one: cf. 5.548.
u(pe/luse: loosed beneath, with reference to the knees (on 4.314). cf. *o 581, *y 726, 16.341.
fai/dima: a standing epithet of the gui=a. — gui=a: in this connexion is interchangeable with gou/nata.
*mhkisthia/dhs: i.e. Euryalus. cf. 2.566. For the formation, cf. *phlhia/dew *a 1. § 21 d.
teu/xea ktl.: cf. 5.164. — Seven Trojans now have been slain by three Achaeans. In the next eight verses, seven Trojans are slain by seven Achaeans.
a)/ra: marks a new member in the enumeration.
*polupoi/ths: king of the Lapithae. cf. *b 740, *m 129 ff.
*)oduseu/s: cf. 5.519, 669 f.
*perkw/sion: from Percote, on the south shore of the Hellespont.
e)cena/ricen: here plainly equiv. to slew. Cf. e)nh/rato 32.

*teu=kros: son of Telamon (father of Ajax) and Hesione (on 5.640). He was famed as an archer. cf. 8.266 ff., *teu=kro/s q' , o(\s a)/ristos *)axaiw=n | tocosu/nh|, a)gaqo\s de\ kai\ e)n stadi/h| u(smi/nh| *n 313 f., 23.859 ff.
e)nh/rato (e)nai/rw): cf. e)/nara spoils, 68.
*)anti/loxos: cf. 4.457.
*satnio/entos: a stream in the territory of the Trojan Leleges.
e)urrei/tao: strictly a substantive.

par' o)/xqas: on the banks. Cf. *c 445, par' o)/xqas *saggari/oio *g 187, *d 487, te/menos nemo/mesqa me/ga *ca/nqoio par) o)/xqas *m 313, *s 533, *f 337. para/ with the acc. sometimes in Homer, as regularly in the later Boeotian dialect, is used where para/ with the dat. is expected. The acc. with preps. tended to supplant the dative.
*ph/dason: home of king Altes, who gave his daughter Laothoë in marriage to Priam. 21.85 ff. The city was destroyed by Achilles. Od. 3.92. A part of the surviving Leleges fought under Hector.
*fu/lakon: a Trojan. A ‘homonym’ was more noted; *b 705, *n 698, o 231.
*lh/itos: a Boeotian leader. 2.494.
feu/gonta: in flight.
*eu)ru/pulos: on 5.76.
*mela/nqion: mentioned only here. — Both names of this verse appear in the Odyssey.
*)/adrhston: mentioned only here. To be distinguished from the son of Merops (2.830), from the famous Argive king (on 5.412), and from another Trojan (slain by Patroclus, 16.694).
oi(=: const. with i(/ppw, “his horses.”
a)tuzome/nw: “fleeing in fright.” cf. 41, 18.7.

blafqe/nte: hindered, i.e. entangled. This is antecedent to, and cause of, a)/cante. — muriki/nw|: tamariskshrubs on the Trojan plain are mentioned also *k 466, *f 18, 350. They are common in modern Greece.
a)gku/lon: on 5.231.

a)/cante: from a)/gnumi. — e)n prw/tw| r(umw=|: at the front end of the pole. Cf. *p 371, *e 729, e)uce/stw| e)pi\ r(umw=| | pe/zh| e)/pi prw/th| *w 271 f. The pole broke in the same place at 16.371. — The horses were held to the chariot only by the yoke, which was fastened to the pole. Thus when the pole was broken, the horses were free. On 5.730.
au)tw/: themselves, in contrast with the deserted chariot.
oi( a)/lloi: those others.
au)to/s: i.e. Adrastus.
prhnh/s: pred., explained by e)pi\ sto/ma on his face, in the second half-verse. cf. pronusque magister | volvitur in caput Verg. Aen. i. 115 f., ka\d' d) a)/r) e)pi\ sto/m) e)/wse *p 410.
sto/ma: cf. Lat. os.
e)/sth: inceptive; took his stand.

e)lli/sseto (li/ssomai): sc. *mene/laon. For the doubling of the l after the augment, see § 25 f. — gou/nwn [gona/twn]: const. with labw/n. cf. pare/zeo kai\ labe\ gou/nwn *a 407, e(lw\n e)lli/sseto gou/nwn *f 71.
zw/grei: sc. me/. On 5.698. cf. zwgrei=t' au)ta\r e)gw\n e)me\ lu/somai *k 378.
a)/cia: worthy. Equiv. to Attic a)nta/cia. It seems never to mean ‘deserving’ in Homer.
a)/poina. the ransom was the strongest motive for sparing a prisoner's life.
e)n patro/s: sc. do/mw|. cf. 378 f., e)s *)axillh=os e)lqei=n *w 309, ei)s *)ai/dao *q 367, ei)n *)ai/dao *x 389, *)/ai+dos ei)/sw 284.
keimh/lia: connected with kei=mai lie, stored up. Explained by the fg. verse.
polu/kmhtos: the poet was well aware of the difficulty of working iron as compared with copper, the more usual metal for tools and weapons.
tw=n: of these. Ablatival genitive. cf. xarizome/nh pareo/ntwn a 140.
a)perei/sia ktl.: cf. 1.13.
ei)/ ken: ‘It is difficult to see any essential difference between these protases with ei)/ ke and those with the simple ei) and the optative.’ GMT. 460.

zwo/n: pred. to e)me/, that I was alive. Cf. au)ta\r *)odussh=os talasi/fronos ou)/ pot' e)/fasken | zwou= ou)de\ qano/ntos e)pixqoni/wn teu a)kou=sai r 114 f., 527. — This thought is repeated in e)pi\ nhusi\n *)axaiw=n, i.e. in the Greek camp (to which Menelaus would have sent him; cf. 52). cf. ei) d' h)/dh teqna=si kai\ ei)n *)ai/dao do/moisin *x 52. — For the ‘acc. of the person’ with pepu/qoito, cf. 5.702.
e)/peiqen: parallel to fa/to.
kai\ dh\ ktl.: and he was just about. Cf. 393.
ta/x' e)/melle: cf. *l 181, *y 773, i 378.
katace/men [katagagei=n]: on 5.26. For the ‘mixed’ aorist form, cf. i(=con *e 773, a)/cete de\ *pria/moio bi/hn *g 105.
a)nti/os: predicate. cf. e)nanti/oi *e 497.
qe/wn: running. Much like the adv. qow=s. — o(moklh/sas: on 5.439.
w)= pe/pon: my good fellow. Spoken with a kind of condescension.
w)= *mene/lae: the repetition of the address marks the speaker's strong feeling. cf. *r 238, w)= daimo/nie, ti/ xrh=ma pa/sxeis, w)= pa/ter; Ar. Clouds 816.
de/: marks a contrast, i.e. an objection, to the deed of the person addressed. cf. *c 264, *o 244, *r 170.
ou(/tws: thus, sc. as Menelaus was doing, in sparing the life of Adrastus. cf. Od. 4.543.
a)ndrw=n: a general form of statement, instead of a)ndro/s. cf. pro\s *trw/wn 57.
h)= soi ktl.: an ironical question, with reference to the crime of Paris. — “You, I suppose, have been excellently treated by the Trojans.”
soi/: always emphatic in Homer. Here it marks the identity of person with su/ 55.
a)/rista: corresponds to the Attic eu)=.
tw=n: demonstrative.
u(pekfu/goi: cf. *e 318, kh=ras u(pece/fugen qana/toio *x 202.
mhd' o(/ntina: not even whomever. — This clause, in passionate excitement, is added to mh/ tis 57.
kou=ron e)o/nta: as boy. Added simply to mark the sex.
fe/roi: the verb is attracted to the mood of the principal clause. cf. 3.299. G. 235, 1; H. 919 a.
mhd' o(/s: ne is quidem. Resumption of the principal thought of 57.
a)ll' a(/ma pa/ntes: the affirmative contrast to the preceding.
*)ili/ou: const. with the fg. e)c. cf. qea=s 100, ma/xhs *e 763.
a)kh/destoi: unburied. Cf. sw/mat' a)khde/a w 187, khdemo/nes *y 674.
a)/fantoi: leaving no trace behind. — Both adjs. are ‘proleptic.’ “May they perish and be” etc.
pare/peisen: with reference to e)/peiqen 51. “Wrought a change in the mind of his brother.”
a)delfeiou=: cf. 5.21. The form a)delfo/s is not Homeric. kasi/gnhtos is more than twice as freq. as a)delfeo/s.
ai)/sima ktl.: here only does the poet seem to approve of a deed of cruelty.
pareipw/n: cf. 337. — For the length of the first syllable, see § 41 m.
o( de/: i.e. Menelaus, who had now left Adrastus to Agamemmon.
a)po/: for the length of the ‘ultima,’ see on 5.343.
a)netra/peto: equiv. to u(/ptios e)/pesen. cf. 4.108.
*)atrei+/dhs: i.e. Agamemnon.
la\c ktl.: cf. *n 618, *p 503.
e)ke/kleto ktl.: a standing verse-close of the Iliad. Cf. 110, *q 172, *l 285, *o 346, 424, 485, *p 268, *r 183.
a)u/sas: cf. 4.508.
w)= fi/loi ktl.: an honorable address to all warriors.
qera/pontes ktl.: applied to the two Ajaxes in *q 79, *k 228.
The Greeks are first to make sure of the victory and to follow it up, and not to delay the pursuit by gathering the spoils.
e)na/rwn: made emphatic by the verse-pause. Gen. after e)piballo/menos, laying hands upon.
plei=sta: “more than any one else.”
ke/n: in a final clause. See G. 216, 1 N. 2; II. 885 c.
fe/rwn: the partic. contains the more important thought. § 3 v.
kai\ ta/: sc. e)/nara from 68. “The booty too.”
a)\m [a)na\] pedi/on: along the plain.

sulh/sete: fut. of positive assurance, after the command. cf. nu=n me\n pausw/mesqa, . . . u(/steron au)=te maxhso/meqa *h 290 f., ei)/cate/ moi dielqe/men: au)ta\r e)/peita | a)/sesqe klauqmoi=o *w 716 f., Od. 12.23 ff. — The speaker included himself in the subj. of ktei/nwmen, but, with indifference, he leaves the plunder to the inferiors. For the change of person, cf. ei)/domen h)/ ken *)axilleu\s | nw=i kataktei/nas e)/nara broto/enta fe/rhtai | . . . h)/ ken s w=| douri\ damh/h| *x 244 ff.
sulh/sete: followed by two accusatives. cf. a)phu/ra 17.
72-118. On the advice of Helenus, Hector goes to the city, in order to bid the Trojan matrons supplicate Athena's mercy.
e)/nqa au)=te: on 5.1.
u(p' *)axaiw=n: gen. of agent, since the connexion implies a passive idea. See *p. 820.
ei)sane/bhsan: a)na/ is used of approach to the city (on a height), as kata/ for going to the camp (cf. 53).
a)nalkei/h|si: for the dat. of the agent, cf. khri\ damei/s z 11, a)ndri\ damei/s *g 429. — For the pl. of the abstract, cf. *d 409, *e 649.

*ai)nei/a|: Aeneas is made prominent here as in E. As commander of the Dardanians, he is next in rank to Hector in the Trojan army. cf. 2.819. Little more is heard of him until the last of the four days of battle, when he meets Achilles, Od. 3.158 ff., but is saved by Poseidon.

*(/elenos: has here and 7.44 ff. decisive influence on the course of action. He takes part in the conflict, 13.576, but is not prominent as a warrior. He is the prophetic son of Priam, corresponding to Priam's daughter Cassandra, who does not exercise the seer's gifts in Homer.
oi)wnopo/lwn ktl.: cf. 1.69, of Calchas.
e)pei\ ktl.: the address is followed immediately by the reason for it. cf. 7.327 ff.
po/nos: i.e. the battle, and the care and responsibility for it. On poneu/menon *d 374. — u)/mmi [u(mi=n] ktl.: (is leaned) rests upon you.

*trw/wn ktl.: partitive gen. with ma/lista. — *luki/wn: cf. 4.197. These here represent the whole body of allies. This is esp. fitting since Sarpedon had been prominent in the preceding Book, and the other Lycian leader, Glaucus, is to have an important place in this Book.
pa=san e)p' i)qu/n: cf. Od. 4.434.
i)qu/n: course, enterprise.
ma/xesqai ktl.: “in battle and in council.” A freq. pair. — The second half-verse is parallel to e)p' i)qu/n. cf. 6, 60, 82, 106 f., 115.
sth=te: take your stand, halt. Cf. sth=te/ moi, a)mfi/poloi| z 199. — au)tou=: right here.
e)ruka/kete: for the redup., cf. h)ni/pape *e 650.
au)=te: again. Uttered in a reproachful tone.
e)n xersi/: in the arms, sc. for shelter and protection. cf. e)n xersi\ ti/qei *a 441, e)n nh/essi peso/ntes *b 175. Const. with pese/ein. On 5.370.
gunaikw=n: sc. who have come even before the Scaean Gate. cf. 238.
feu/gontas: const. with laou/s, implied in lao/n 80.
dhi/oisi ktl.: cf. dusmene/sin me\n xa/rma *g 51. — Either h is shortened here before i, or the antepenultimate i is pronounced as y.
xa/rma (xai/rw): an object of joy, a delight. — Cf. *k 193, *r 636, *y 342.
fa/laggas: not yet used as a technical term, in Homer.
e)potru/nhton: aor. subjunctive.
h(mei=s me/n: we others, the rest of us. Correl. with a)ta\r su/ 86.
a)nagkai/h [a)na/gkh] ktl.: cf. Od. 19.73.
*(/ektor: the voc. in Greek poetry is often placed for emphasis before the clause with which it is connected. Of course it has no syntactical construction.
a)ta/r: follows the voc., as 429, 22.331; cf. w)= *fi/ntis, a)lla\ zeu=con h)/dh moi sqe/nos h(mio/nwn Pind. Ol. vi. 22.
po/linde: the locative force of -de is repeated in the prep. of mete/rxeo. — ei)pe/: say, i.e. bid.

sh=| kai\ e)mh=|: marks the relationship of the two brothers with more feeling than h(mete/rh|. More than half of Hector's brothers were only half-brothers. cf. the same feeling in (Joseph) ‘saw his brother Benjamin, his mother's son,’ Genesis xliii. 29.
h( de/: subj. of the imperatival qei=nai 92. The commission is given in direct discourse.
cuna/gousa: leading together, gathering; i.e. calling by messengers. cf. 286 ff. — geraia/s [grau=s]: fem. of ge/rontas.
nho/n [new/n]: acc. of ‘limit of motion’ after cuna/gousa. On 5.367. cf. o(/soi keklh/ato boulh/n *k 195.
e)n po/lei a)/krh|: e)n a)kropo/lei.
oi)/casa: the Greek does not require that the act be done in person, and, in fact, the priestess Theano opened the temple (298). cf. 270 with 287. On 4.260.
i(eroi=o ktl.: i.e. nhou=.
oi(= au)th=|: e(auth=|.

qei=nai: on h( de/ 87. — For the inf. as imv. of the third person, cf. ei) me/n ken e)me\ kei=nos e(/lh| . . . sw=ma de\ oi)/kad' e)mo\n do/menai *h 77 ff., a)lla\ to\ me\n fa/sqai, to\ de\ kai\ kekrumme/non ei)=nai l 443.

e)pi\ gou/nasin: on the lap of the sitting statue. The robe was placed on the knees of the goddess as if for actual use. The worshipper desired to adorn the image of the divinity. Thus, in modern times, robes and jewels are given to figures of the Virgin and the Holy Child. — This is the only distinct reference in the Homeric poems to a graven image (here, prob. of wood) of a divinity, and temples do not seem to abound. — Strabo, xiii. 601, says that very many of the early statues of Athena represented her in a sitting posture.
u(posxe/sqai: vow.

h)/nis: cf. (iuvencum) candentem Verg. Aen. ix. 628. — h)ke/stas [a\kenth/tous]: ungoaded (kente/w), i.e. not used for menial labor and thus rendered unfit for sacrifice. cf. soi\ (i.e. Athena) d' au)= e)gw\ r(e/cw bou=n h)=nin eu)rume/twpon, | a)dmh/thn, h(\n ou)/ pw u(po\ zugo\n h)/gagen a)nh/r g 382 f. ‘All the firstling males that come of thy herd and of thy flock, thou shalt sanctify unto the Lord thy God: thou shalt do no work with the firstling of thy bullock. . . . And if there be any blemish therein, as if it be lame or blind, or have any ill blemish, thou shalt not sacrifice it unto the Lord thy God,’ Deuteronomy xv. 19, 21; ‘a red heifer, without spot, wherein is no blemish, and upon which never came yoke,’ Numbers xix. 2; ‘take two milch kine, on which there hath come no yoke,’ 1 Sam. vi. 7.
ai)/ ke: if haply, in the hope that. GMT. 487, 1; *p. 907.
ai)/ ken ktl.: explains the preceding clause. cf. no/stou dh\ mnh=sai . . . mh\ kai\ pefobhme/nos e)/lqh|s, | mh/ pou/ tis kai\ *trw=as e)gei/rh|sin qeo\s a)/llos *k 509 ff., Od. 19.81 ff.
*tude/os ui(o/n: Diomed is the chief terror of the Trojans, after his exploits in the preceding Book.
mh/stwra ktl.: cf. *q 108, *m 39, *y 16.
mh/stwra: cf. 4.328.
ka/rtiston: cf. 5.103.
gene/sqai: “proved himself.” cf. e)n tou/tw| tw=| po/nw| (sc. at Marathon) o( pole/marxos *kalli/maxos diafqei/retai, a)nh\r geno/menos a)gaqo/s Hdt. vi. 114.
ou)de/: not even.

pote/: ever, i.e. during the time when the Trojans remained within their walls in fear of Achilles, and ventured out of their gates only with caution (5.788 ff., 15.721 ff.), while some were captured or at least pursued (11.104 ff., Od. 3.89 ff., 21.35 ff.); and all were in dread of his reappearance (18.261 ff.).
w(=de: thus, sc. as we now fear Diomed.
o)/rxamon ktl.: only here of Achilles.
o(/n per ktl.: “although men say.”
qea=s: const. with the following e)c. cf. 5.637; see on *)ili/ou 60. — The caesura falls, as usual, in the the third foot, after qea=s. Here it is no musical rest, but a hold, making qea=s prominent.
a)lla/: in contrast to the preceding rel. clause, leads back to the thought of 98.
mai/netai: cf. 5.717.
me/nos: acc. of specification. cf. o(/ti moi me/nos i)sofari/zeis *f 411.
w(\s ktl.: cf. 2.807. — Hector follows his brother's advice at once.
fo/noio: gen. of separation.
fa\n [e)/fasan, § 26 w] ktl.: explains the retreat of the Achaeans.
a)qana/twn ktl.: sc. as Ares had done, 5.594 ff.
a)stero/entos: the Homeric heavens are starry even in broad daylight. § 1 p.
w(/s: thus, so boldly, refers to 108. cf. 4.157. — e)le/lixqen [e)leli/xqhsan]: sc. *trw=es.
111 = 9.233; cf. 11.564. For another form of address, cf. *trw=es kai\ *lu/kioi kai\ *da/rdanoi a)gximaxhtai/ *q 173.
*trw=es ktl.: cf. *r 276, g 366.
thlekleitoi/: cf. 5.491.
112 = *q 174, *l 287, *o 487, 734, *p 270, *r 185; cf. *e 529, *d 234, 418. — The second half-verse is parallel to the first.
o)/fra: while.
bh/w: bw=.
ei)/pw: cf. ei)pe/ 86. Const. with o)/fr' a)/n. Followed by dat. and inf.; cf. o)/fra ei)/ph|si *poseida/wni a)/nakti . . . i(ke/sqai *o 57 f., Od. 1.37 ff., Od. 3.427 f.

bouleuth=|si: in appos. with ge/rousin. The word is not found elsewhere in Homer. It corresponds to dhmoge/rontes *g 149. — These senators are not mentioned in the account of what Hector actually did in Troy.
h(mete/rh|s ktl.: cf. 240 ff., 297 ff. — This speech of Hector is less definite than that of Helenus, 86 ff.
e(kato/mbas: a general expression for the duokai/deka bou=s of 93. The pl. is used of a single large sacrifice also in *a 315, *b 306, 321.
a)mfi/: adv., “at both extremities,” i.e. above and below. This is explained by sfura\ kai\ au)xe/na. — The whole thought marks Hector's haste.
a)/ntuc ktl.: (the leather) which ran as outermost rim of the shield. The rel. h(/ is attracted to the gender of the pred. a)/ntuc. H. 631. The metal rim of the shield was covered with leather.
o)mfaloe/sshs: cf. 4.448.
119-236. Glaucus and Diomed discover that their ancestors were bound by the ties of friendly hospitality. They exchange arms.
*glau=kos: one of the two leaders of the Lycians. From him the later kings of Lycia were said by Herodotus to derive their descent. Hdt. i. 147.
e)s me/son: into the midst. — me/son is used as a subst., like to\ metai/xmion. cf. e)n kairi/w| *d 185.
a)mfote/rwn: i.e. of both armies.
suni/thn (ei)=mi): sc. on chariots. cf. 232.

ti/s de\ ktl.: cf. *o 247, *w 387. A lively question of surprise, for which the explanation is given by the following sentence. For the meaning of the question, cf. 145. — For the force of de/, see on 55.
fe/riste: a friendly form of address.

ou) me
 [mh
] ktl.: correl. with a)ta me
 nu=n ge. cf. ou) me
 nh/pios h)=sqa . . . to\ pri/n: a)ta me
 nu=n ge d 31 f.

o)/pwpa: sc. se/. — polu\ ktl.: thou dost stand far in advance, i.e. as champion. cf. pro/maxos. — Why had not Diomed met Glaucus before? One answer is that many words and deeds are reported from this tenth year of the war which would have been expected earlier. cf. the ‘View from the Scaean Gate,’ 3.161 ff., and the arrangement of the Greek forces into definite divisions, 2.362 ff. Possibly, however, Glaucus and the Lycians were not among the early allies of the Trojans, but have only recently arrived at Troy. Thus Rhesus and his Thracians came late, 10.434, and Memnon with his Aethiopians, and the Amazons, came to the help of the city after the action of the Iliad.
o(/ [o(/ti] te: in that. This clause explains the opinion expressed in the first words of the verse.
e)mo/n: receives emphasis from the following verse-pause.
127 = 21.151. — This verse is closely connected in thought with the preceding.

dusth/nwn: emphatic from its position. “Unhappy are they whose sons meet my might”; i.e. the parents have to mourn their sons' death. cf. pe/pnusai/ te no/w|, maka/rwn d' e)/cessi tokh/wn *w 377, z 154 ff.
a)ntio/wsin: from a)ntia/w.

cf. Od. 7.199. — “If thou art an immortal.” The thought that Glaucus may be a god, was suggested possibly by the splendor of his golden armor, 236, in connexion with the fact that his face was not familiar; or it may be a commonplace remark suggested by kataqnhtw=n. — Diomed seems to have lost his ability to distinguish divinities (5.127 ff.), and his daring in attacking them (5.362).
tis a)qana/twn: pred. to the subj. of ei)lh/louqas. — The spondaic close (§ 39 h, i) seems to be intentional here, after the light dactylic rhythm.
e)gw/: strongly contrasted with qeoi=sin, which is emphasized by the verse-pause.
qeoi=sin: the pl. shows that the determination of Diomed is general.
e)pourani/oisi: contrasted with e)pixqo/nioi, *d 45.
maxoi/mhn: a ‘potential opt.’ as a conclusion to a condition of the first form. GMT. 403, 503; H. 901 b.
ou)de) ga\r ou)de/: cf. 5.22.
*dru/antos: the preceding e is not lengthened. See § 41 i a, b. — ui(o/s: for the short penult, cf. 4.473.

*luko/orgos: a Thracian king. — This story seems to be the result and trace of an opposition to the introduction of the Bacchic worship in Thrace. cf. the story of Pentheus at Thebes, as represented in the Bacchantes of Euripides. — Dionysus is not a Homeric divinity, and this mention of him is thought to indicate a later origin for this passage.
dh\n h)=n: for the adv. with h)=n, see on 4.22. — For the thought, cf. 5.407.
o(\s ktl.: the rel. clause is causal, as it is frequently. cf. 165, 235.
o(/s pote ktl.: this rel. clause gives a special instance, after the general statement of 131.
mainome/noio: raving, with reference to the mad revelry of the Bacchic festivals. cf. the name ‘maenads,’ maina/des. — *diwnu/soio [*dionu/sou]: the Boeotian dialect preserves the w in this name.
tiqh/nas: nurses, attendants; corresponding to the later Bacchantes.
kata\ *nush/ion: down the Nysēan height. Prob. here a Thracian district. For the subst. use of the neut. adj. *nush/ion, cf. me/son 120.
qu/sqla: doubtless the later qu/rsoi carried in Bacchie processions, — wands wound about with ivy, and with a pine-cone at the top.
kate/xeuan: poured down, i.e. dropped. cf. kate/xeuen *e 734.
bouplh=gi: cf. ‘after him was Shamgar, the son of Anath, which slew of the Philistines six hundred men with an ox-goad,’ Judges iii. 31.
fobhqei/s: taking to flight before Lycurgus.
du/seto: equiv. to e)/du, just as bh/seto *e 745 is to e)/bh. — kata\ ku=ma: down into the wave.

ko/lpw|: to her bosom. For the dat., see on e(ta/roisi *d 523. — Thetis lived with her father, in the Aegean Sea, not far from Thrace. On another occasion she gave similar refuge to Hephaestus; 18.398.
deidio/ta: added in order to form an introduction to the rest of the verse. cf. mh/thr *e 313.
e)/xe: sc. *diw/nuson. — tro/mos: cf. *e 862, u(po/ te tro/mos e)/llabe gui=a *g 34.
tw=|: i.e. Lycurgus.
