r(ei=a zw/ontes: in contrast with the hard lot of men; cf. o)izuroi=si brotoi=sin *n 569. cf. ‘to that new world of light and bliss, among | The gods who live at case,’ Milton, Par. Lost ii. 867 f.
tuflo/n: blind. Only here in Homer; elsewhere a)lao/s. — e)/qhke: cf. 6.
*kro/nou pa/is: sc. as chief of the gods.
e)/ti: for the length of the ‘ultima,’ see § 41 j b.

ou)d' a)\n e)gw\ ktl.: resumes the thought of 129, as a logical inference from the fate of Lycurgus. cf. *(/hfaist' , ou)/ tis soi/ ge qew=n du/nat) a)ntiferi/zein, | ou)d) a)\n e)gw\ soi/ g) w(=de puri\ flege/qonti maxoi/mhn *f 357 f., Od. 9.275 ff. — “I, too, should not live long, if I should fight with the gods,” is implied.
brotw=n: made prominent not only by the caesura but also by the repetition of the idea in the second half-verse.

oi(\ a)rou/rhs ktl.: a standing expression for men, from their principal food, as contrasted with gods who live on ambrosia and nectar (5.341). cf. o(\s qnhto/s t' ei)/h kai\ e)/doi *dhmh/teros a)kth/n *n 322, o(/soi nu=n brotoi/ ei)sin e)pi\ xqoni\ si=ton e)/dontes q 222, ou)de\ e)w/|kein | a)ndri/ ge sitofa/gw| i 190 f., quicunque terrae munere vescimur Hor. Carm. ii. 14. 10.

a)=sson ktl.: sarcastic. cf. ei) de/ tis e)kpa/glws e)qe/lei oi)ko/nde ne/esqai, | a(pte/sqw h(=s nho\s . . . o)/fra pro/oq' a)/llwn qa/naton kai\ po/tmon e)pi/sph| *b 357 ff. — The poet seems to play on the words a)=sson and qa=sson. cf. 5.440.
o)le/qrou pei/rata: “net of destruction.” cf. e)kfuge/ein me/ga pei=rar o)izu/os e 289.
i(/khai: i(/kh|. cf. pu/qhai *e 351.

geneh\n ktl.: this shows Glaucus's understanding of the question of 123. — “Why should you ask of my family? No family enjoys distinction long. All pass away.” — Glaucus recognizes Diomed. Doubtless he had seen some of his exploits in E.
oi(/h per: “just as.”
de/: in apodosis. § 3 n; GMT. 564.

a)ndrw=n: here equiv. to a)nqrw/pwn. — For the thought, cf. (brotw=n) deilw=n, oi(\ fu/lloisin e)oiko/tes a)/llote me/n te | zaflege/es (full of fire and life) tele/qousin, a)rou/rhs karpo\n e)/dontes, | a)/llote de\ fqinu/qousin a)kh/rioi *f 464 ff., h(mei=s d' oi(=a/ te fu/lla fu/ei polua/nqemos w(/rh | e)/aros, o(/t) ai)=y) au)gh=|s) au)/cetai h)eli/ou, | toi=s) i)/keloi ph/xuion e)pi\ xro/non (“for a span of time”) a)/nqesin h(/bhs | terpo/meqa Mimnermus ii. 1 ff., e(\n de\ to\ ka/lliston *xi=os e)/eipen a)nh/r: (this is the best thing that Homer ever said) | oi(/h per fu/llwn ktl. Simonides 69. 1 f., a)/ge dh\ fu/sin a)/ndres a)mauro/bioi, fu/llwn genea=| proso/moioi Ar. Birds 685, ‘As of the green leaves on a tree, some fall and some grow; so is the generation of flesh and blood, one cometh to an end and another is born,’ Wisdom of the Son of Sirach xiv. 18; ut silvae foliis pronos mutantur in annos, | prima cadunt, ita verborum vetus interit aetas Hor. Ars Poet. 60 f.
fu/lla: anticipates its parts, ta\ me/n, a)/lla de/. Placed first for contrast with a)ndrw=n 149.
e)/aros ktl.: ‘paratactic’ for “when the spring-time comes.” § 3 q.
e)pigi/gnetai: comes on (e)pi/).
fu/ei: here intrans., grows up.
ei) d' e)qe/leis ktl.: this protasis is left without an apodosis. After the final clause (o)/fr' e)u\ ei)dh=|s) and the parenthetical polloi\ ktl., the story follows immediately, in 152.
kai\ tau=ta: this too, of which you ask. — “But I am not ashamed of my family.”
h(mete/ rhn: with emphasis, after the general preface, 146-149.
mi/n: i.e. geneh/n. — The second half-verse is parenthetical.

e)/sti: a favorite epic beginning for a story. cf. *e 9, e)/sti de/ tis nh=sos ktl. d 844, e)/sti de/ tis pe/trh g 293, urbs antiqua fuit Verg. Aen. i. 12, est locus, Hesperiam Grai cognomine dicunt ib. iii. 163.
*(efu/rh: the old name of Corinth. The name *ko/rinqos is not put into the mouth of any Homeric speaker, though the poet uses it in his own narrative (2.570).
muxw=| *)/argeos: in the recess of Argos, i.e. in the Corinthian Gulf. cf. the same expression of Mycenae (on the Argolic Gulf), Od. 3.263.

*si/sufos: the name seems to be formed by reduplication (cf. di/-dwmi) from the stem of sofo/s (cf. ke/rdistos). Glaucus does not show any familiarity with the story which set Sisyphus to work, rolling a huge stone up hill, in Hades (Od. 11.593 ff.); and Pindar enumerates among the glories of Corinth *si/sufon me\n pukno/taton pala/mais (devices) w(s qeo/n Pind. Ol. xiii. 50. — Later stories made Sisyphus an ancestor of Odysseus.
*si/sufos: for the repetition, ‘epanalepsis,’ cf. 396. § 2 p.
e)/tikten: impf. as 206, 5.547, without any emphasis on the tense.

*bellerofo/nthn: acc. to the later story (which may have been built largely upon what Homer tells), he was first called Hipponoüs, and gained his Homeric name by killing Bellerus, a Corinthian prince, on whose death he fled to King Proetus at Tiryns in order to secure purification from the guilt (an un-Homeric idea) and security against vengeance. The Corinthian tradition laid special stress on Bellerophon's capture of the winged horse Pegasus. His exploits occupy a large part of Pindar's Thirteenth Olympian Ode, in which the poet refers also to Glaucus, e)k *luki/as de\ *glau=kon e)lqo/nta tro/meon *danaoi/ Ol. xiii. 58.
156-159. A brief outline of the fortunes of Bellerophon, which is followed in 160 (with the same introductory tw=| de/) by the more detailed story. cf. Od. 14.337, 339.
ka/llos te: obs. the force of the position. — Both qualities seem to be mentioned with reference to the following story.
kaka\ mh/sato: sc. in consequence of the calumny of 164 f.
e)k dh/mou ktl.: i.e. sent him to Lycia. cf. 168.
e)pei\ ktl.: cf. 7.105. — The second half-verse shows why Bellerophon was obliged to obey Proetus, — not the reason for his exile.
Nearly parenthetical.
*)argei/wn: added to explain dh/mon, and to make distinct the place of Bellerophon's sojourn. Without it, the hearer might think of him as in his home at Corinth.
e)da/massen: sc. dh=mon. — *zeu/s: the king of the gods is the special patron of the mortal kings, and gives to them their authority. They reign Iovis gratia.
tw=| de/: sc. *bellerofo/nth|. The verses since 155 have been parenthetical. — Dat. after the prep. in e)pemh/nato (mai/nomai) “became madly enamored.”
di=a: without moral quality. The same epithet is applied to Clytaemnestra, Od. 3.266.
*)/anteia: called Stheneboea by the Attic tragedians.
migh/menai [migh=nai, § 26 m): explanatory inf. in loose const. after e)pemh/nato. G. 265; H. 951.
a)gaqa\ frone/onta: i.e. the right-minded. Perhaps nowhere else in Homer has a)gaqo/s so much of the modern meaning of ‘good.’
*bellerofo/nthn: in appos. with to/n 161.
*yeusame/nh: contrived a falsehood and said.

teqnai/hs ktl.: “I hope you may die if you do not” etc. The opt. here clearly approaches the force of an imperative. GMT. 725. cf. a)ll' e)/celqe qu/raze . . . h)\ ta/xa kai\ dalw=| (firebrand) beblhme/nos ei)=sqa qu/raze t 68 f.
ka/ktane: kata/ktane. § 11 b.
moi/: for the elision of oi, see § 10 a. — Dat. with migh/menai. — ou)k e)qelou/sh|: added in contrast with e)/qelen. cf. par' ou)k e)qe/lwn e)qelou/sh| e 155.
oi(=on a)/kousen: “at what he heard.” Strictly an indirect exclamation. G. 155; H. 1001.
ktei=nai: obj. of a)le/eine. cf. 266, a)lece/menai a)le/einen *n 356.

seba/ssato ktl.: i.e. his conscience would not allow Proetus to kill his guest with his own hand (cf. 179 ff.), but he did not shrink from asking his father-in-law to do the deed. Similarly, David would not kill Uriah himself, but put him where he would be slain by the enemy. — For the expression, cf. 417.
o(/ ge: calls attention to the identity of the subject. cf. 5.623. He gave, — he did.

sh/mata lugra/: destructive tokens. A kind of tessera hospitalis, with symbols previously agreed upon between the separated friends. cf. 176, 178. — This has been thought by some to imply acquaintance with the art of writing. Perhaps it was a kind of ‘picture-writing’ resembling that of the ancient Mexicans.
gra/yas: cutting. gra/fw notably is used for cutting, carving, scratching (*d 139, *r 599), and painting, as well as for writing.

e)n pi/naki: in a tablet (‘diptych’). Two plates of wood (covered with wax, in later times, and joined by a hinge) were tied together so that the inner surfaces should not be seen by the bearer. This, rather than gra/yas, indicates the form of an epistle.
qumofqo/ra: life-destroying, death-bringing, i.e. directing that the bearer should be put into a place of danger.

penqerw=|: the Homeric language was not so poor as to have but one word for ‘father-in-law,’ but distinguished penqero/s wife's father from e(kuro/s husband's father. Cf. galo/ws husband's sister, ei)na/teres husband's brothers' wives, 378. — Antea's father was called Iobates, acc. to the later story.
a)mu/moni pomph=|: (blameless) safe conduct. This forms a contrast to o)/fr' a)po/loito.
*ca/nqon: cf. *e 479, thlo/qen e)k *luki/hs, *ca/nqou a)/po dinh/entos *b 877. — For the form of the verse, cf. 5.773.
The ‘asyndeton’ is natural, since this verse is virtually in appos. with the preceding profrone/ws ti=en. cf. 219.

e)nnh=mar: freq. as here with following deka/th. cf. *a 53, *w 610, 664, 784, h 253, k 28, etc. — Only after a guest had received hospitality, was he questioned about his errand. Bellerophon, as coming from the court of the king's son-in-law, received a royal welcome. The king made a great feast each day.
sh=ma i)de/sqai: doubtless Bellerophon had mentioned his ‘letter of introduction’ on his arrival, but was not expected to present his credentials immediately.
i)de/sqai: for the mid., see § 32 a.
fe/roito: brought with him. For the opt. ‘expressing the previous thought of another,’ see GMT. 700.
kako/n: cf. 169.
parede/cato: the poet does not think it necessary to state explicitly that the Lycian deciphered the tablet's contents.
me/n: correl. with au)= 184.
r(a/: i.e. in accordance with Proetus's injunction.

*xi/mairan: here a proper name. — This is the only ‘composite’ monster of Homer; — dragons, mermaids, and satyrs being unknown, and Scylla (Od. 12.85 ff.), though deformed, not being made up of woman, fish, and wolf. Acc. to Hesiod, the Chimaera was (like Cerberus and the Lernaean Hydra) the offspring of Typhon and Echidna, h( de\ *xi/mairan e)/tikte, pne/ousan a)maima/keton pu=r, | deinh/n te mega/lhn te. podw/kea/ te kraterh/n te. | th=s d' h)=n trei=s kefalai/: mi/a me
 xaropoi=o le/ontos, | h( de\ ximai/rhs, h( d) o)/fios, krateroi=o dra/kontos. | . . . th
 me
 *ph/gasos ei(=le kai\ e)sqlo\s *bellerofo/nths Theog. 319 ff.

a)maimake/thn: impetuous, fierce. Cf. *)amiswda/rou, o(/s r(a *xi/mairan | qre/yen a)maimake/thn pole/sin kako\n a)nqrw/poisin *p 328 f. — cf. ‘Gorgons, and Hydras, and Chimaeras dire,’ Milton Par. Lost ii. 628.
qei=on: clearly the adj. is equiv. to qew=n, for it is contrasted with a)nqrw/pwn. cf. *gorgei/h *e 741.
ge/nos: offspring. Cf. di=on ge/nos *i 538, *sqene/loio pa/is | so\n ge/nos *t 124.
dra/kwn: serpent. Equiv. to o)/fis, as in the passage from Hesiod quoted on 179.

xi/maira: kid. Here a common noun. — This verse is translated, ante leo, postrema draco, media ipsa Chimaera, by Lucretius, v. 905, not only preserving the exact order of words but also making the last clause more distinct even than it is in the Greek.
deino/n: cognate acc. (adv.) with a)popnei/ousa. With this, the second half-verse is in apposition.
a)popnei/ousa (pne/w): const. with h( 180, the intervening verse being parenthetical.
puro\s me/nos: cf. a)ll' *(/ektwr puro\s ai)no\n e)/xei me/nos *r 565, e)n de\ puro\s me/nos h(=ke sidh/reon *y 177.
qew=n ktl.: cf. 4.398. Here an expression of confidence.
*solu/moisi: ancient inhabitants of Lycia. Hdt. i. 173. The Greeks confounded this name with ‘Salem,’ and called Jerusalem *so/luma and *(ieroso/luma. cf. Josephus Arch. i. 10. 2.

karti/sthn: predicate. cf. 326, *e 635, to\n dh\ mh/kiston kai\ ka/rtiston kta/non a)/ndra *h 155, (*(rh=sos) tou= dh\ kalli/stous i(/ppous i)/don h)de\ megi/stous *k 436, oi)ktrota/thn d' h)/kousa o)/pa *pria/moio qugatro/s l 421, oi)/ktiston dh\ kei=no e)moi=s i)/don o)fqalmoi=sin m 258.
a)ndrw=n: const. with ma/xhn.—“This was the hardest battle he ever fought.”
to\ tri/ton: this, too, by the Lycian king's command.

*)amazo/nas: Priam, 3.189, refers to his serving the Phrygians as an ally against the invading Amazons.—The later story gave to Bellerophon the assistance of the winged-horse Pegasus in these conflicts. cf. su\n de\ kei/nw| (i.e. Pegasus) kai/ pot' *)amazoni/dwn | ai)qe/ros yuxra=s a)po\ ko/lpwn e)rh/mou | toco/tan ba/llwn gunaikei=on strato/n, | kai\ *xi/mairan pu=r pne/oisan kai\ *solu/mous e)/pefnen Pindar Ol. xiii. 84 ff.
tw=|: i.e. Bellerophon.
a)nerxome/nw|: returning. Cf. *d 392.— pukino\n ktl.: shrewd device.
u(/fainen: sc. a)/nac *luki/hs. For the change of subj., see § 1 b.
For the ‘asyndeton,’ cf. 152, 174.
eu)rei/hs: cf. 210.
e<*>se ktl.: cf. *d 392, d 531.

gi/gnwske: was coming to know, recognized, sc. from his achievements. Clearly, no guilty mortal,—none but one of the race of the gods and enjoying their favor, could have overcome such difficulties and escaped such dangers.
qeou=: indefinite. In Pindar, this god is Poseidon.
e)o/nta: supplementary participle, as after a verb of seeing or hearing.
di/dou: offered in marriage.
qugate/ra: for the ‘quantity’ of the last syllable, see on 5.343.
timh=s ktl.: i.e. the king shared with Bellerophon the control of the people, the tribute, and the invitations to the common feasts.
oi(=: dat., as is shown by the length of me/n.
te/menos: here, royal domain. Cf. *i 578, *m 313, *s 550, *u 184, 391, z 293. Elsewhere, as in later Greek, of the land set apart for sacred uses. cf. templum. Connected in derivation with te/mnw.
ta/mon: i.e. set apart, marked off.

e)/coxon a)/llwn: sc. in size and fertility. As in later times, much land was held in common, esp. for pastures, but private property in land seems to have been recognized.—cf. e)/dwke (sc. Lycurgus to the Spartan kings) de\ kai\ ge/ra a)po\ tw=n quome/nwn lamba/nein, kai\ gh=n de\ e)n pollai=s tw=n perioi/kwn po/lewn a)pe/deicen e)cai/reton Xen. de Rep. Lac. xv. 3.
kalo/n: const. with te/menos. See on *e 413.— futalih=s: appositional gen. with te/menos. futalih/ includes vineyards as well as orchards.
ne/moito: cultivate. —Cf. (te/menos) penthkonto/guon, to\ me\n h(/misu oi)nope/doio, | h(/misu de\ yilh\n (cleared) a)/rosin *i 579 f.
h(: sc. qugath\r basilh=os. cf. 192. 193-195 contain only details of the marriage settlement.
For the ‘asyndeton,’ cf. 5.270 ff.

*laodamei/h| me/n: correl. with *)/isandron de/ 203, *(ippo/loxos de/ 206. The daughter is mentioned first naturally, as being the last mentioned in the previous verse, and thus in the front of the poet's mind. § 2 o. She is also the mother of the mightiest of Bellerophon's descendants.
Acc. to Hdt. i. 173, Sarpedon was brother of Minos of Crete, and son of Europa.
a)ll' o(/te dh/: here appears for the fourth time in this narrative. cf. 172, 175, 191.
kai\ kei=nos: even he, i.e. even Bellerophon, who had received such signal proofs of the gods' care.

a)ph/xqeto: cf. 140. sc. as appeared from his morbid melancholy (on the death of his children?). The later form of the myth said that Bellerophon attempted to rise to heaven by the aid of Pegasus, but the rider was thrown off, and the horse returned alone to the stalls of Zeus.

Homer only intimates the insanity of Bellerophon.—cf. qui miser in campis maerens er rabat Aleis, | ipse suum cor edens hominum vestigia vitans Cic. Tusc. iii. 26. 63, ‘Lest . . . as once Bellerophon, on th' Aleian field I fall, | Erroneous there to wander and forlorn,’ Milton Par. Lost vii. 17 ff.
ka/p: kata/.
to\ *)alh/ion: in appos. with pedi/on. Clearly connected in derivation by the poet with a)la=to, as the ‘Plain of Wandering.’ Herodotus, vi. 95, mentions an *)alh/ion pedi/on in Cilicia.
pa/ton ktl.: parallel to oi)=os above.
pa/ton: footsteps.

*)/arhs kate/ktane ktl.: i.e. Isander fell in battle. cf. 205, 428, tw=| i)/kelos o(/n t' a)rguro/tocos *)apo/llwn | oi(=s a)ganoi=s bele/essin e)poixo/menos kate/pefnen (i.e. one who has had a peaceful death) 24.758 f.
a)=tos pole/moio: cf. 5.388.
xolwsame/nh: “in a burst of rage,” sc. because Laodamia had yielded to Zeus, 198.
xrush/nios: gold-gleaming, with reference to hunting-equipment and dress.

e)/kta: cf. e)/ktane 204. § 35.—“Laodamia died suddenly and quietly.” Artemis sent sudden and peaceful death to women, as Apollo to men. cf. 203 f., 428, e)pei/ se le/onta gunaici\n | *zeu\s qh=ken, kai\ e)/dwke katakta/men h(/n k' e)qe/lh|sqa *f 483 f. (Hera's words to Artemis).
e)me/: emphatic, in contrast with Sarpedon, 199, while the enclitic me/ is suited to the thought of 207.— The second half-verse repeats the first, in a different form. cf. 208.
po/ll' e)pe/tellen: cf. 4.229.
208 = 11.784, where it is the parting injunction given to Achilles by his father. A famous and noble verse.
a)rlsteu/ein: equiv. to a)/riston ei)=nai.
cf. mh/ ti kataisxu/nein pate/rwn ge/nos w 508.
me/ga: as adv., modifies all three degrees of comparison.
i.e. as well the early generations, Sisyphus and Glaucus, at Corinth, as the later generations in Lycia, who were descended from Bellerophon.
211 = 20.241, where Aeneas speaks.
tau/ths: in thought is const. with both nouns.
toi/: “since you ask the question”; with reference to 123. Glaucus ends as he began.
geneh=s: ablatival gen. of source. cf. 5.265.
e)/gxos me\n ktl.: correl. with au)ta/r 214.—Diomed abandoned at once all thoughts of a contest. His action shows his thought sooner than his words do. “Guest-friends must not fight with each other.”
kate/phcen: cf. e)n gai/h| kate/phkto *l 378, e)/gxea de/ sfin | o)/rq' e)pi\ saurwth=ros (i.e. the spike at the butt of the spear) e)lh/lato *k 152 f.
meilixi/oisi: cf. 4.256.
h)= r(a ktl.: truly you are, then. Inference from what Glaucus had said.
cei=nos: one of the few (unwritten) laws of the Homeric age made the tie of hospitality almost as strong as that of blood.
patrw/ios: of the fathers, i.e. of the family.
*oi)neu/s: on 4.399.
e)ni\ mega/roisin: i.e. in Calydon. cf. 2.640 f.
e)ni/: for the length of the last syliable, see § 41 j; cf. *e 270.
e)ru/cas: coincident in time with cei)/nise.
ceinh/ia [ce/nia]: explained by 219 f., and introductory to 230.
cf. 7.305.—For the asyndeton, cf. 174.
zwsth=ra: on *d 132.— foi/niki: cf. *d 141, y 201.
kai/ min ktl.: parenthetical. “Which I still have at home.” The rel. const. is deserted. The grandfather had given the goblet to his grandchild, and told him how he received it.
mi/n: i.e. de/pas.
i)w/n: sc. e)s *troi/hn. cf. 5.198.

*tude/a ktl.: the mention of the grandfather reminds the speaker of his father, who had died in his son's infancy.—“I was but a child when my father went to Thebes, and I have no recollection of him.”—The acc. after me/mnhmai is remarkable. Perhaps the ‘person’ is treated as a ‘thing.’ cf. me/mnhmai to/de e)/rgon *i 527, pi=ne, kai\ a)/lla pare\c memnw/meqa c 168, me/mnhmai ta/de pa/nta w 122.
tutqo\n e)o/nta: all the emphasis rests on the partic. and its predicate.
ka/llipe: kate/lipe.
e)n *qh/bh|sin: i.e. near Thebes. The first expedition was repulsed, and did not enter the city. cf. 4.409.
tw=|: so, therefore, i.e. on the ground of this friendship of their ancestors.
cei=nos: host.
*)/argei: local, in Argos, in the strict sense.—“I shall receive you to my home when you come to Argos, and you will be my host in Lycia.”
o(/te ktl.: takes the place of e)moi/.
tw=n: i.e. *luki/wn, easily supplied from e)n *luki/h|.
a)llh/lwn: cf. a)llh/lois 230 (equiv. to a)/llos a)/llw|) and *e 874.— di) o(mi/lou: contrasted with the single combat of champions (pro/maxoi). cf. 120 f.
polloi\ me/n, polloi\ de/ (229): for the repetition (‘anaphora’), see on *d 415.
e)moi/: sc. ei)si/n, have I. Contrasted with soi/ 229.

ktei/nein: explanatory (or final) infinitive. cf. migh/menai 161. This thought is carried on also with po/rh|.—o(\n ktl.: gives the necessary limitation to the preceding expression. It is parallel to o(/n ke du/nhai 229.
qeo\s po/rh|: placed before posi\ kixei/w because of its precedence in thought.
kixei/w: kixw=.
a)llh/lois: on 226.

oi(/de deictic, pointing to the armies on either side. It would be prosaic to ask what these warriors had been doing since 122,—whether they had continued the battle, or had stopped fighting and listened! But the poet almost assumes that the Greeks and Trojans were as much interested as his hearers in this meeting of Glaucus and Diomed.
kaq' i(/ppwn ktl.: cf. *l 423, *u 401.
pistw/santo: gare each other assurance, pledged each other. ‘Reciprocal’ middle.
*glau/kw|: dat. of disadvantage.
fre/nas e)ce/leto: took the senses from. Cf. *r 470, *t 137, *i 377, *s 311, *h 360.—Any unaccountable act was ascribed to a god's interposition.
o(\s ktl.: for the causal force of the rel., cf. 131.

This verse became proverbial of an uneven exchange. cf. a)ll' a)nti\ do/chs a)lh/qeian kalw=n kta=sqai e)pixeirei=s kai\ tw=| o)/nti xru/sea xalkei/wn diamei/besqai noei=s Plato Symp. 219 a, habes ad omnia, non, ut potulasti, xru/sea xalkei/wn, sed paria paribus respondimus Cic. ad Att. vi. I. 22, aut si disparibus bellum incidat, ut Diomedi | cum Lycio Glauco, discedat pigrior, ultro
div.l: muneribus mis sis Hor. Sat. i. 7. 16 ff.—Obs. the apposition of the second half-verse to the first.
div.p: e(kato/mboia: having the worth of a hundred cattle. Cattle were the standard of value in the Homeric times. A tripod might be worth twelve cattle (Od. 23.703), and a woman slave from four (Od. 23.705) to twenty cattle (Od. 1.431); while Achilles sold a captured son of Priam for one hundred cattle (21.79). cf. pecunia and ‘chattels.’—e(kato/n and e)nne/a are round numbers. The inference that gold was worth only eleven times as much as bronze, would be unreasonable.
237-311. Hector and Hecaba. The Trojan matrons offer prayers and vows to Athena.
*(/ektwr de/: here the poet returns to the story of 116.
w(s: for the position, after the emphatic word in making the transition in the story, cf. a)ll' i)/qi, mh\ e)re/qize, saw/teros w(/s ke ne/hai *a 32.
fhgo/n: on 5.693.—Doubtless Hector reached the tree before he came to the gate, but the latter is named first as more prominent and important, by a sort of ‘hysteron proteron.’ § 2 u.

a)mf' a)/ra min: only here is mi/n separated by a)/ra from its preposition.—The women of Troy had come to the tower at the Scaean Gate, in order to watch the conflict. cf. 386 ff., 3.145 ff., 420, 22.79, 450 ff.
ei)ro/menai ktl.: i.e. inquiring of the fate of their friends on the field of battle.
kasignh/tous ktl.: cf. *p 456, o 273.—For the acc. of the person for whom inquiry is made, cf. fu/lakas d' a(\s ei)/reai, h(/rws *k 416, ei)/reai *(/ektora di=on *w 390.
po/sias: the last syllable is treated as long before the pause. § 41 p.
Hector told the women what he could, but the sum of the whole matter was that their hope rested only on the gods.—e(cei/hs [e(ch=s]: one after the other, as they met him.
de/: here introduces a cause.
kh/de) e)fh=pto: cf. *trw/essi de\ kh/de) e)fh=ptai *b 15, polloi=si de\ kh/de) e)fh=ken *f 524.
a)ll' o(/te dh/: correl. with e)/nqa 251.
do/mon: i.e. the palace as a whole, including the court.
cesth=|s ai)qou/sh|si: with polished corridors, i.e. with corridors of polished stone. One of these seems to have been in front of the building.
e)n au)tw=|: within the palace itself, in contrast to the gate and the corridors.—The prep. is repeated in e)/nesan 244.

penth/konta: Priam, like other Oriental princes, had several wives and many sons. 24.493 ff. All (with two or three exceptions) lived together in patriarchal fashion. Priam's is the only instance of downright polygamy mentioned in the Homeric poems.—cf. quinquaginta illi thalami, spes ampla nepotum | barbarico postes auro spoliisque superbi Verg. Aen. ii. 503 f.
li/qoio: gen. of material.
plhsi/oi ktl.: i.e. built one next the other.
a)llh/lwn: for the gen., cf. *)axaiw=n 106.
dedmhme/noi: from de/mw.
koura/wn: daughters.
e(te/rwqen ktl.: “on the other side, opposite the former, in the courtyard.”
e)nanti/oi: explains e(te/rwqen.
e)/nqa: the protasis, 242, was interrupted by the description, and then forgotten. So the poet takes a fresh start, with an independent sentence.
h)pio/dwros: with kindly gifts.
e)nanti/h: predicate. cf. 54.—Hecaba was on her way from one apartment to another.
cf. *g 124.—*laodi/khn ktl.: conducting Laodice, i.e. accompanied by Laodice.
e)n: const. with fu= [e)/fu]. “She grew to him in his hand,” i.e. she grasped his hand.—cf. excepitque manu dextramque amplexus inhaesit Verg. Aen. viii. 124.
ti/pte: const. both with lipw/n (the principal idea) and ei)lh/louqas.
h)= ma/la dh/: surely now. Hecaba answers her own question by a conjecture. cf. *a 203, *h 26, *r 445.
tei/rousi: cf. 387.
dusw/numoi: (of unhappy name,) accursed. Cf. *kakoi+/lion ou)k o)nomasth/n t 260.
peri/: local. cf. 327.
se\ de/: introduces the result of tei/rousi ktl. cf. g 252, r 379.

e)nqa/de: only roughly can it be said that this is to be construed with e)lqo/nta. The order of words is significant, and connects it with a)nh=ken, while e)lqo/nta ktl. is added in explanation. “Thy heart urged thee hither,—to come and lift thy hands” etc.
e)c a)/krhs ktl.: prominent as contrasted with the battle-field. Const. with xei=ras a)nasxei=n. cf. tw\ d' au)=t) e)k di/frou gounaze/sqhn *l 130.

xei=ras a)nasxei=n: equiv. to eu)/casqai, since this was the usual attitude in prayer. cf. *e 174, polla/ ken a)qana/toisi fi/las a)na\ xei=ras a)ei/rai (“he would pray fervently”) 7.130. Thus the phrase takes an indirect object.
o)/fra ke e)nei/kw [e)ne/gkw]: until I bring. o)/fra is used like e(/ws.
melihde/a: cf. meli/frona 264.

prw=ton: the position of the word shows that this verse is added as an afterthought, and o)nh/seai is not under the influence of w(s. prw=ton serves to mark the distinction of the ideas. cf. nu=n me\n pau/swmen po/lemon kai\ dhio/thta | sh/meron: u(/steron au)=te maxh/sontai *h 29 f.
au)to/s: by its position is contrasted with *dii\ patri/ 259.
ai)/ ke pi/h|sqa: e)a\n pi/h|s.
a)ndri/: dat. of interest.
de/: the English idiom would use ‘for.’
kekmhw=ti: for the so-called 2d pf. partic., while ke/kmhkas 262 is 1st pf., see § 31 a.
me/ga: pred. to me/nos, after a)e/cei [au)/cei] increases. Cf. me/ga pe/nqos a)/ecen r 489.

w(s: refers to kekmhw=ti, the closing word of the first half-verse of 261, which is repeated in ke/kmhkas, the closing word in the first halfverse of 262. cf. a)ne/ri khdome/nw|, w(s nu=n e)me\ kh=dos i(ka/nei *p 516.
tu/nh: cf. *e 485.
e)/th|sin: clansmen, people.
a)/eire: “bring.” Lit. of lifting the beaker.
meli/frona: cf. e)u/frona *g 246.—Hector replies first to 260262.
Hector fears that the wine will affect him too much.

la/qwmai: forget, i.e. lose. cf. o)/fra s' u(podei/sas me/neos ktl. *x 282, and the converse pantoi/hs a)reth=s mimnh/skeo *x 268. In general, in Homer, to remember a thing is to do it. cf. (*mene/laos a)nw/gei) no/stou mimnh/skesqai e)p' eu)re/a nw=ta qala/sshs g 142 “to enter upon their return.” See on 4.222.
Reply to 259.—The versepause throws emphasis upon a)ni/ptoisin.—For the thought, cf. *g 270. *w 302 ff., and Od. 2.261, where water is poured upon the hands before prayer.
ou)de\ ktl.: “and it is by no means allowed for one who is” etc. —Cf. tu, genitor, cape sacra manu patriosque penates;
div.l: me bello et tanto digressum et caede recenti | attrectare nefas donec me flumine vivo | abluero Verg. Aen. ii. 717 ff., ‘Whosoever toucheth the dead body of any man that is dead, and purifieth not himself, defileth the tabernacle of the Lord,’ Numbers xix. 13; ‘When they go into the tabernacle of the congregation, they shall wash with water, that they die not; or when they come near to the altar to minister, to burn offering made by fire unto the Lord,’ Exodus xxx. 20.

div.p: lu/qrw|: with gory filth.
pepalagme/non (pala/ssw): agrees with the indefinite subj. of the infinitive.— Hector had no time for ablutions.
su\ me/n: correl. with e)gw\ de/ 280.
a)gelei/hs: cf. 4.128.

su\n que/essin: with burnt sacrifices,—only, not of animals, but of some kind of incense. cf. tou\s (i.e. qeou\s) que/essi kai\ eu)xwlh=|s a)ganh=|sin | loibh=| te kni/sh| te paratrwpw=s' a)/nqr(:)poi | lisso/menoi *i 499 f.
a)olli/ssasa: cf. 87, 296.
271-278 = 90-97, mutatis mutandis.
Repeated from 269, in order to mark the coincidence in time. “While you go to the temple, I will go to the home of Paris.”—For the repetition, cf. 183 (with me/n), as resuming 179, and 5.134 and 143.
meteleu/somai: will go after, sc. to fetch him, as is made more definite by o)/fra kale/ssw.
ai)/ ke: cf. 94.
ei)po/ntos (sc. mou=): “my voice,” i.e. my words.
w(s: introduces a wish.

ke/: unusual in a wish; but cf. *thle/max' , ei) ga/r ken su\ polu\n xro/non e)nqa/de mi/mnois o 545.—This wish follows immediately after Hector's statement of his purpose, almost as if he corrected himself, and desired Paris to go to Hades rather than to the field of battle.
xa/noi: cf. *d 182.
me/ga ph=ma: pred. to mi/n.
*)olu/mpios: cf. *d 160.

e)/trefe: bred, i.e. suffered to grow up. cf. diotrefe/essi *e 463.—This is strong language for Hector to use of his own brother, but cf. 325 ff., ai)/q) o)/feles a)/gono/s <*>) e)/menai a)/gamo/s t) a)pole/sqai *g 40 (Hector to Paris), and the wish of the old herald Idaeus w(s pri\n w)/fell' a)pole/sqai (of Paris) 7.390.
kai\ *pria/mw|: “and chiefly to Priam.”
toi=o: on toi=o *d 28.

i)/doimi katelqo/nta: pieturesque for kate/lqoi, as fai/hn e)klelaqe/sqai for e)klela/qoito. cf. 330, 4.98 f. A still more prosaic form would be, ei) e)kei=nos a)poqa/noi. The aor. partic. here differs from the pres. partie. only as the aor. inf. would from the pres. infinitive. cf. ei)po/ntos 281.— *)/aidos: the gen. is to be const. not with the adv. ei)/sw, but with the implied do/mon. On e)n patro/s 47.
fai/hn ke: I would say.
h)=top: subj. of the infinitive.
me/gara: the house, as distinguished from the courtyard, where Hecaba met Hector.
ke/kleto: cf. *d 508.
a)/ra: “as she bade.”
a)o/llissan: i.e. the servants went through the town, and summoned the matrons.
qa/lamon: the storeroom, in a remote part of the palace, in or near the women's apartments.
khw/enta: fragrant. Perhaps because of cedar chests.
oi(=: prob. the pers. pron., although the force of its initial v is lost here.

*sidoni/wn: not in direct agreement with gunaikw=n, but added in appos., introdueing 290 f.—Homer mentions Sidon but not the younger Tyre.—The Phoenicians were the skilled workmen and traders of early times. cf. 2 Chronicles ii., ix. 21. Ezekiel xxvii., Hdt. i. 1.

*sidoni/hqen: acc. to the story which seems to have been more fully developed in post-Homeric times, Paris and Helen on leaving Sparta were driven by a storm to Egypt, and went to Troy by way of Phoenicia. Hdt. ii. 117. In the Odyssey, Homer tells of the visit of Helen and Menelaus to Phoenicia and Aegypt, and of the gifts there received, on the voyage home from Troy. Od. 4.83 ff., 125 ff., 228 ff.
e)piplw/s: 2d aorist. § 35.
eu)re/a: eu)ru/n. § 20 d.

th
 o(do/n: on that voyage. Cognate acc. with h)/gage. cf. h)=lqon ga kai\ kei=se . . . th
 o(do/n, h(=| dh\ me/llen e)moi\ kaka\ kh/de) e)/sesqai z 164 f., a)/llhn o(do
 a)/lla ke/leuqa | h)/lqomen i 261 f.
a)nh/gagen: led home. Cf. gunai=k' e)ueide/) a)nh=ges | e)c a)pi/hs gai/hs *g 48 f.
eu)pate/reian: daughter of a noble father. Leda is nowhere named as Helen's mother in Homer.
293-295 = Od. 15.106-108 (with *(ele/nh for *(eka/bh).
fe/re: sc. from the qa/lamos.
dw=ron: as a gift.
poiki/lmasin: colored embroidery, or woven borders. cf. 5.735.
w(/s: here allows elision before it. On *d 482.
nei/atos: predicate. As most precious and magnificent, this robe was least used, and so came to lie at the bottom of the pile.

a)/llwn: of all. This const. with a)/llwn is specifically Homeric. cf. w)kumorw/tatos a)/llwn *a 505, ‘Adam the goodliest man of men since born | His sons, the fairest of her daughters, Eve,’ Milton Par. Lost iv. 323 f. See on 1.505.

metesseu/onto (seu/w): hurried after her. For the doubling of s after the augment, see § 25 f; cf. a)pe/ssuto 390.—cf. interea ad templum non aequae Palladis ibant | crinibus Iliades passis peplumque ferebant | suppliciter tristes et tunsae pectora palmis Verg. Aen. i. 470 ff.
*qeanw/: on 5.70.
*kisshi/s: for the patronymic, see § 21 g. Hecaba also was daughter of Cisses, acc. to Eur. Hec. 3.

e)/qhkan: the priestess, then, was chosen by the people. Her sacerdotal duties did not interfere with her family relations. In general Greek priests were not exclusively devoted to their priestly work.

o)lolugh=|: these pious shrieks (cf. Od. 3.450) were intended as responses in the liturgical service; just as xei=ras a)ne/sxon (cf. 257) corresponded to the modern posture of devotion, kneeling. cf. doke/ei d' e)/moige kai\ h( o)lolugh\ e)p) i)roi=si e)nqau=ta (i.e. in Libya) prw=ton gene/sqai: ka/rta ga\r tau/th| xre/wntai ai( *li/bussai Hdt. iv. 189.
Doubtless Theano alone entered the a)/duton (5.512).

r(usi/ptoli: defender of the city. This name is applied to Athena in Ilios although she is one of the two divinities most bent on the destruction of the city. cf. *)aqhna= *polia/s (polia/oxos) at Athens, and poliou=xos *)aqa/na at Sparta; su/ t' , w)= *diogene\s filo/maxon kra/tos, | r(usi/polis genou=, | *palla/s Aesch. Septem 120 f.—From the stem of r(u/omai, cf. *i 396.
qea/wn: partitive genitive. cf. 5.381.
a)=con: cf. a)/cante 40.
dh/: gives urgency to the imperative.

au)to/n: sc. as contrasted with the spear. cf. e)/klagcan d' a)/r) o)istoi\ e)p) w)/mwn xwome/noio, | au)tou= kinhqe/ntos *a 46 f.—cf. armipotens, praeses belli, Tritonia virgo, | frange manu telum Phrygii praedonis et ipsum, | pronum sterne solo Verg. Aen. xi. 483 ff.
prhne/a: cf. 43, *d 544. *e 58.
e)/fat' eu)xome/nh: equiv. to eu)/xeto.

a)ne/neue: even now in Greece, negation is indieated by an upward motion of the head. The contrary is kataneu/w. cf. 4.267.—The poet knew Athena's refusal to grant the matrons' prayers from the outcome; the Trojan women knew it from the lack of favorable omen.
312-368. Hector at the home of Paris and Helen.

This verse, with a beginning similar to that of the preceding, forms a transition to the following action, which was contemporary with the prayers to Athena. cf. *e 84, *r 424, *y 1, n 185.—“While these were praying.”—For the ‘parataxis,’ cf. 148.
dw/mata ktl.: Paris, like Hector (365, 370), had a house of his own, near Priam's palace (317).
*)aleca/ndroio: the Greek name of Paris is used in Homer four times as freq. as the other. The gen. *pa/rios is found only 3.325.

au)to\s e)/teuce: so Odysseus built his own house, and made his own bedstead. The occupations of Homeric princes were not very different from those of Homeric peasants. —Verses 314-317 are added as a sort of afterthought.
te/ktones a)/ndres: artificers; here, carpenters, as is shown by the connexion. te/ktwn was not limited to the meaning of ‘carpenters,’ in Homer. cf. te/xnh (found only once in the Iliad, 3.61).
oi(/: these.

qa/lamon: i.e. apartments for the women. These with dw=ma (the great hall or me/garon of the men) and au)lh/n were the three chief divisions of the home. cf. eu)= dieqei/wsen (fumigated) me/garon kai\ dw=ma kai\ au)lh/n x 494.
te/: for the position, cf. *e 878.
*pria/moio: const. with e)ggu/qi. G. 182, 2; H. 757. (Or, it may be, with dwma/twn to be supplied. cf. 47.)
e)/nqa: local, there. This resumes 313.

e)/gxos e(ndeka/phxu: a long spear! But only about the length of the Macedonian pikes (sa/rissai), which were 14-18 feet long. The lance of the Prussian Uhlan is about ten feet in length. Ajax wielded a boarding pike of twenty-two cubits, 15.678. The Chalybes had lances fifteen cubits long, acc. to Xen. An. iv. 7. 16.—douro/s [do/ratos, § 18 f]: const. with pa/roiqe, at the head of the spear.—This description does much to bring the scene before the mind of the hearer or reader.
peri/: adv. Const. with qe/e.
po/rkhs: the ferule, which bound the lower part of the spear-point to the upper part (kaulo/s) of the shaft.
e)n qala/mw|: cf. 316.
perikalle/a ktl.: just as a hunter enjoys busying himself about his gun, for which he has a personal affection.
Explanatory of 321,—the nouns being a more definite and detailed statement of teu/xea.
*)argei/h: a standing epithet of Helen.—Helen seems to be in the same apartment as Paris.
a)mfipo/loisi: equiv. to dmwh=|si ktl. above.
e)/rga: i.e. weaving and spinning. cf. 490 f., ai( d' i(stou\s u(fo/wsi kai\ h)la/kata strwfw=sin h 105. Thus Helen spins as she sits in the hall of her husband Menelaus at Sparta, Od. 4.123 ff.
ai)sxroi=s: reproachful.

Hector assumed anger at the Trojans as the cause of his brother's absence from the field of battle. Of course he knew nothing of Aphrodite's interference to save Paris when he was worsted in the single combat with Menelaus (3.380 ff.), and to carry him back to his home; and being assured that his brother was no coward (cf. 522), he supposed that he had withdrawn from the conflict simply in vexation at the Trojans' lack of sympathy with him and his cause (i)=son ga/r sfin pa=sin a)ph/xqeto khri\ melai/nh| *g 454).
daimo/nie: strange man! sir!
ou) kala/: ‘litotes.’ Predicate; adverbial.
e)/nqeo: e)ne/qou.

laoi\ me/n: correl. with su\ de/. Hector begins as if he would say, “While the people are fighting and dying for your sake, you sit idle at home.” But after the parenthetical se/o d' ei(/neka ktl. 328 f., he continues his thought in a new form.
peri\ pto/lin: cf. 256.
se/o d' ei(/neka: emphatic, at the beginning of the sent., and just before the verse-pause. The fact that Paris was the cause of all this trouble, heightened the shame of his indifference.
a)uth\ ktl.: cf. 1.492.

a)mfide/dhe: cf. *b 93, *m 35.— su\ de\ ktl.: “You should be ashamed of withdrawing. You would be angry at any one else who should act thus.” The thought that Paris has left the battlefield is passed over the more easily here since it is implied in the whole reproach.
maxe/saio: on 5.875. Here not much more than blame sererely.
cf. *d 240.—o(/n tina ktl.: a more prosaic form would be, o(/s tis [ei)/ tis] meqiei/h ktl. cf. 284.
a)/na (sc. sth=qi): Up! § 37 c.
puro\s dhi/oio: cf. prh=sai de\ puro\s dhi/oio qu/retra *b 415. For the gen. of place with qe/rhtai, see H. 760; cf. e)pei/ ke puro\s qere/w r 23.
tou/neka: resumes e)pei/ 333.
Reply to 326.
toi/: “believe me,” “let me tell you.”

to/sson: has its correl. in e)/qelon de\ ktl. 336, where o(/sson e)qe/lwn is expected. cf. 21.275 f., ou)de/ nu tw=n e)/ti to/sson o)du/romai . . . a)lla/ m' *)odussh=os po/qos ai)/nutai c 142 ff.—neme/ssi [neme/sei]: just blame. Cf. *e 757, *(/hrh| d' ou)/ ti to/son nemesi/zomai ou)de\ xolou=mai *q 407.
h(/mhn: was sitting, i.e. tarrying.
a)/xei+ ktl.: give myself up to my grief, sc. at the defeat by Menelaus.
pareipou=sa: cf. 62. This can hardly refer to Helen's ironical advice to Paris to try another bout with Menelaus, 3.432; but, rather, implies a conversation which has not been reported.
ni/kh ktl.: Paris had consoled himself with the same thought before. cf. 3.439 f.
nu=n e)pi/meinon: Hector stood at the door (354), and seemed on the point of departure.
a)rh/ia: of war, martial.

du/w: subjunctive. I will put on. No final or temporal particle is to be supplied here. This is a survival of the old construction. GMT. 257. cf. deu=te, du/w moi e(/pesqon, i)/dwm' o(/tin) e)/rga te/tuktai *x 450, 418, qa/pte me o(/tti ta/xista: pu/las *)ai/dao perh/sw *y 71.—The verb du/w is distinguished from the numeral by the quantity of the penult.
342 = 5.689; cf. 1.511.—Hector is too much vexed at Paris to reply, and not much was to be said. He assents to his brother's last proposition, and is about to depart.
to/n: i.e. Hector.
Helen rarely misses an opportunity to express penitent consciousness of her guilt. cf. *g 173, *w 764, d 260 ff.
w(s o)/fele: cf. *d 315.
h)/mati tw=| o(\te: cf. *e 210.—o(/te ktl.: cf. Od. 19.355. “As soon as I was born.”

oi)/xesqai ktl.: had carried me off. Cf. Penelope's prayer, h)\ e)/peita/ m' a)narpa/casa qu/ella | oi)/xoito profe/rousa kat) h)ero/enta ke/leuqa, | e)n proxoh=|s de\ ba/loi a)yorro/ou *)wkeanoi=o u 63 ff.
qu/ella: stormy blast.
ei)s o)/ros: sc. where she would have perished.

a)po/erse: a past tense of the ind., without a)/n, like h)/|dh 351, of the impossible result of the accomplishment of the wish introduced by o)/fele 345. This verb is ‘assimilated’ to o)/fele. GMT. 528; H. 919 b.
pa/ros: const. with the inf. (but not with the other moods), like pri/n. GMT. 656; H. 955 a.
ta/de e)/rga: a general expression for all the battles and sorrows of which Helen had been the cause or occasion.
w(=de: i.e. such as the kaka/ really are.—“If I were fated to leave Menelaus and bring all this trouble upon Troy.”
o(/s: long by ‘position.’ On pareipw/n 62.
h)/|dh: knew, appreciated, felt.
ne/mesin: cf. 335.
ai)/sxea: reproaches. Cf. 325, 524.
tou/tw|: contemptuous, is tum, of Paris. cf. 363, *e 761.
ou)/t' a)\r nu=n ou)/t) a)/r) o)pi/ssw: i.e. never.
e)/mpedoi: firm, i.e. prudent. cf. o( d' e)/mpedos ou)d) a)esi/frwn g 183 of Priam, *thle/max' , ou)ke/ti toi fre/nes e)/mpedoi ou)de\ no/hma s 215.
tw=|: therefore.
kai/: also, belongs to the whole thought.
e)paurh/sesqai: shall reap the fruits of it. Always ironical in Homer. cf. 1.410.
di/frw|: a low seat, without a back. cf. 3.424.
“The toil of battle rests heavily on thy soul.” cf. 77.
a)mfibe/bhken: stands about, surrounds.
a)/ths: blind infatuation.
e)ti/: const. with qh=ke, laid upon.
pelw/meqa: subjv. in a final clause, though after an aorist. cf. *a 158, *b 206.

a)oi/dimoi: sung of, theme of song. Cf. qeoi\ e)peklw/santo d' o)/leqron | a)nqrw/pois i(/na h)=|si kai\ e)ssome/noisin a)oidh/ q 579 f., teu/cousi d' e)pixqoni/oisin a)oidh\n | a)qa/natoi xari/essan e)xe/froni *phnelopei/h|: | ou)x w(s *tundare/ou kou/rh kaka\ mh/sato e)/rga . . . stugerh\ de/ t) a)oidh\ | e)/sset) e)p) a)nqrw/pous w 197 ff.
e)ssome/noisin: amplifies o)pi/ssw 357.
mh/ me ka/qize: ask me not to be seated.
file/ousa per: though thou art very hospitable. For the meaning, cf. file/esken 15.—ou)de\ ktl.: but (i.e. yet) you will not etc.
e)pe/ssutai (seu/w): is eager.
o)/fr' e)pamu/nw: an ‘object-clause,’ equiv. to e)pamu=nai. cf. 4.465 f.
me/ga: modifies poqh\n e)/xousin, which is equiv. to poqe/ousin and is followed by the gen. e)mei=o.
tou=ton: cf. 352.
kai\ au)to/s: i.e. without the admonitions.
w(s ktl.: refers to the first half-verse of 363.
katama/ryh|: equiv. to kixh/sesqai 341. cf. 5.65.
kai\ ga/r: etenim.
oi)ko/nde ktl.: am going to my house. See on po/linde 86.
oi)kh=as: cf. 5.413. In the sense of oi)kei/ous, tou\s e)n oi)/kw|. It is explained by the rest of the verse.— The length of the last syllable is explained by the following slight pause.
u(po/tropos: reversus. Predicate. cf. 501; e)nanti/h 251.
damo/wsin: fut., cf. i(/comai 367. For the form, see § 30 b.
369-502. Parting scene between Hector and Andromache. One of the most charming episodes of the Iliad.
e)u\ naieta/ontas: “comfortable.” cf. 4.45.
The second half-verse of this and the two following lines, is simply picturesque,—not necessary for thought or construction.
leukw/lenon: this epithet is generally reserved for Hera.

pu/rgw|: i.e. that tower at the Scaean Gate whence Andromache could look forth toward the Achaean camp and upon the plain with the opposing armies.—Andromache had set out for the Tower, apparently, after Hector reached the city, and while he was at the home of Priam or of Paris. So she had missed meeting her husband. But she learned at the Tower that Hector was in the city, and hastened home to greet him.
e)/ndon: at home.
te/tmen: equiv. to eu(=ren. cf. 4.293.
e)p' ou)do/n: const. with e)/sth which is inceptive and implies motion (cf. 43).—Apparently the threshold of the women's apartments.
meta\ ktl.: cf. 323.
nhmerte/a: neut. as subst., the truth. Cf. li/ssesqai o(/pws nhmerte/a ei)/ph| g 19, dei/dw mh\ dh\ pa/nta qea\ nhmerte/a ei)=pen e 300, l 96, o 263. cf. a)lhqe/a 382.
*)androma/xh ktl.: Hector uses his wife's full title, as a gentleman of to-day would say ‘Mrs. Blank,’ rather than ‘my wife,’ in speaking to an inferior.
e)s galo/wn: cf. e)n patro/s 47.
galo/wn, ei)nate/rwn: glores, ianitrices. On penqerw=| 170.
e)s *)aqhnai/hs: ad Minervae.
e)/nqa ktl.: cf. 286 ff.
e)uplo/kamoi: a standing epithet,—without reference to color, quality, or abundance of the hair, but only to the neatness of the braids.
deinh/n: cf. *e 839.
i(la/skontai: are propitiating, i.e. are striving to appease.
e)pei/: cf. 3.59.
e)pi\ pu/rgon: cf. 373. me/gan *)ili/ou is added in apposition.
kra/tos: strength, hence victory (which is gained by strength).
e)peigome/nh: in haste.
a)fika/nei: pres. with pf. meaning; is come, has reached. Cf. ti/pte deu=r' a)fika/neis *c 43, c 159.—The maid judges from the speed with which Andromache left her home.

mainome/nh| ktl.: sc. in her anxiety. This repeats in more energetic form the thought of e)peigome/nh. cf. (also of Andromache) mega/roio die/ssuto maina/di i)/sh, | pallome/nh (quirering) kradi/hn *x 460 f.
fe/rei ktl.: “accompanied by her child and maid.”
tiqh/nh: cf. a)mfi/polos 399.
h)=: on 4.192. Here the subj. is expressed. cf. *x 77, g 337, x 292.
gunh\ tami/h: tami/h is used as an attrib. adj.; cf. te/ktones a)/ndres 315, a)/ndres strathgoi/, ktl.

th
 au)th
 o(do/n: that same road by which he had come. Cognate acc. with a)pe/ssuto. On th
 o(do/n 292.
th\n au)th/n: equiv. to Attic tau/thn th\n au)th/n, the Homeric art. being demonstrative.
eu)=te: just when. Always with asyndeton.
*skaia/s: in appos. with pu/las in the first half-verse of 392, and added in order to form a close connexion with the following clause. On *e 313.
th=| a)/ra: “where naturally.”—e)/melle dieci/menai [-ie/nai]: was about to pass out. Cf. 52 f.
e)/nqa: there, introduces the ‘apodosis’ to eu)=te 392.
polu/dwros: cf. h)pio/dwros 251.—e)nanti/h ktl.: cf. 15.88. On a)nti/os 54.—For the situation, see on 373.
*)heti/wn: attracted to the case of the following relative. For the repetition, cf. 154.
*pla/kw|: prob. a spur of the range of Mt. Ida, in Mysia.
*qh/bh|: local.
u(poplaki/h|: distinguishing this Thebes from Boeotian (seven-gated) Thebes and Egyptian (hundred-gated) Thebes.
*kili/kessi: dat. of interest.—Not to be confounded with the historical Cilicians on the northeast corner of the Mediterranean.
e)/xeto: “was the wife.” cf. (*laodi/khn) th\n *)anthnori/dhs ei)=xe *g 123.
*(/ektori: the personal dat. of the agent with the passive is more freely used in Homer than in later Greek.
h(: demonstrative.
e)/peita: points to 394 f.
au)th=|: herself, as contrasted with the maid. cf. au)to/n 306.
a)tala/frona: merry hearted. Cf. a)tala\ frone/ontes *s 567.
nh/pion au)/tws: a mere infant. For the force of au)/tws, see § 24 h.
a)li/gkion ktl.: cf. sidere pulchrior Hor. Carm. iii. 9. 21. “Like a fair angel.”
*skama/ndrion: named from the chief river of Troy, which was a local divinity (5.77). Rivers were thought to have a close relation with the blessing of children.—On 4.474.

*)astua/nakta: Protector of the City. The people gave to the son the name which was appropriate to the father. This child never reigned, and a)stua/nac cannot have meant ‘crown prince.’ So the son of Odysseus is called Telemachus (*d 354, thlou=, ma/xomai);—not because the boy fought far away from home, but because the father was fighting at Troy while the son was a child. cf. *megape/nqhs (pe/nqos) Od. 4.11, son of Menelaus; *eu)rusa/khs (sa/kos), Soph. Aj. 340, son of Ajax; *neopto/lemos, son of Achilles, l 506; *)alkuo/nhn kale/eskon . . . ou(/nek' a)/r) au)th=s | mh/thr a)lkuo/nos polupenqe/os oi)=ton e)/xousa | klai=e *i 562 ff.; (and Zipporah bare Moses a son,) ‘and he called his name Gershon [a stranger here]: for he said, I have been a stranger in a strange land,’ Exodus ii. 22.—The original meaning of a)/nac seems to have been ‘protecting lord,’ with no more emphasis upon the privilege of the power than upon the duty of defence. cf. 478. This meaning alone gives point to the close of this verse; e)ru/eto repeats the thought of a)/nac.
h)= toi ktl.: returns to the story after the brief digression about Astyanax.
siwph=|: const. with i)dw\n e)s pai=da.—This second half-verse pictures the father's joy.
407-439. Andromache begs Hector to remain within the walls. He can direct from the tower the defence of the city.
daimo/nie: cf. 326, and note the difference in meaning marked by the speaker's tone.
fqi/sei: placed first, with emphasis.

to\ so
 me/nos: this courage of thine. Cf. h)=lqon e)gw\ pau/sousa to\ so
 me/nos *a 207, ou)/ pot' e)ni\ plhqui= me/nen a)ndrw=n, | a)lla\ polu\ proqe/eske, to\ o(
 me/nos ou)deni\ ei)/kwn *x 458 f. (Andromache of Hector).
ou)d' e)leai/reis: a reproach for not considering the fate of wife and child in case of the husband's death.
a)/mmoron: equiv. to du/smoron. Andromache calls herself and her husband dusa/mmoroi *x 485. cf. ka/mmore, of Odysseus, Od. 5.160.
seu=: gen. of separation, with xh/rh e)/somai. cf. seu= 411.
ei)/h: potential opt. between two futures. cf. 452, 4.171.
seu= a)famartoush|: “bereft of thee.” cf. (of Astyanax) fi/lou a)po\ patro\s a(martw/n *x 505.—This clause is secluded by the verse-pause.

xqo/na du/menai: cf. 19.—cf. (Tecmessa to Ajax) oi)/ktire d' , w)=nac, pai=da to
 so/n, ei) ne/as | trofh=s sterhqei\s sou= dioi/setai mo/nos | u(p' o)rfanistw=n mh\ fi/lwn, o(/son kako
 | kei/nw| te ka)moi\ tou=q), o(/tan qa/nh|s, nemei=s. | e)moi\ ga ou)ke/t' e)sti
 ei)s o(/ ti ble/pw | plh
 sou=. su\ ga/r moi patri/d) h)/|stwsas dori/, | kai\ mh/ter' au(th\ moi=ra to
 fu/santa/ te | kaqei=len *(/aidou qanasi/mous oi)kh/toras. | ti/s dh=t' e)moi\ ge/noit) a)
 a)nti\ sou= patri/s; | ti/s plou=tos; e)n soi\ pa=s' e)/gwge sw/|zomai. | a)ll' i)/sxe ka)mou= mnh=stin. Soph. Aj. 510 ff.
e)/stai: sc. moi/.
su/ge: on this lies all emphasis. cf. 429 f.
po/tmon e)pi/sph|s (e)fe/pw): cf. o)/fra pro/sq' a)/llwn qa/naton kai\ po/tmon e)pi/sph| *b 359.
a)ll' a)/xea: but only griefs.

kai/: though after ou)de/. This makes but one thought of path\r kai\ mh/thr. cf. nihil usquam prisci et integri moris Tacitus Ann. i. 4; ou) me/n soi/ ge path\r kai\ po/tnia mh/thr | o)/sse kaqairh/sousi *l 452.
a(mo/n: h(me/teron. cf. u(mh/n *e 489. § 24 a, d.
e)u\ vaieto/wsan: cf. 370.
kata\ ktl.: repeated from 414, after a parenthetical clause, with the name instead of pate/ra (on *menela/ou *d 177) in order to form a better contrast with po/lin.
ou)de\ ktl.: but he did not, etc.
e)cena/rice: in the literal sense. cf. 30 with *e 842.—seba/ssato ktl.: cf. 167.
to/ ge: i.e. e)cenari/cai.—Achilles respected the old king too much to treat his body with despite, and so gave him an honorable burial (su\n e)/ntesi).
su\n e)/ntesi ktl.: cf. *n 331, 719, au)ta\r e)pei\ nekro/s te ka/h kai\ teu/xea nekrou= | tu/mbon xeu/antes ktl. m 13.
e)pi/: over him. Adv. with e)/xeen (xe/w).
peri/: adv., round about.
o)restia/des: of the mountains. On 22.
oi(/: rel., referring to oi( 422, as its antecedent.
i)w=| h)/mati: on a single day. For the form i)w=|, cf. i)/a *d 437.
*)/aidos ei)/sw: cf. 284.
e)pi/: “as they were keeping watch over.” cf. 25, *e 137, 313.— ei)lipo/dessi: trailing-footed,—because of the peculiarly awkward gait of oxen and cows.
basi/leuen: was queen. Equiv. to basi/leia h)=n. This implies no political authority. cf. (the wife of Neleus) h( de\ *pu/lou basi/leue, te/ken de/ oi( a)glaa\ te/kna l 285.
u(po\ *pla/kw|: cf. 396.
th/n: her, resumes mhte/ra.— deu=ro: hither, i.e. to the Greek camp before Troy.
h)/gage: on *d 239.— a(/m) a)/lloisi ktl.: the captive queen may have been counted as part of the kth/mata, but this may be taken as “with her treasures, too.” cf. 5.621.
o(/ ge: prominent in contrast to Artemis 428. “Achilles released her but Artemis slew her.”
labw/n: sc. from her father.
a)perei/sia ktl.: cf. 1.13.
patro/s: i.e. Andromache's grandfather, who had ransomed his daughter and brought her back to his home. Eëtion's house of course had been destroyed.
ba/l' *)/artemis: i.e. the old queen died a peaceful death. On 205.

*(/ektor, a)ta\r su/: cf. 86.— Hector—Andromache's all—is contrasted with the preceding. This thought prepares the way for the urgent request of 431, that Hector should remain within the walls.— cf. genou= de\ toi=sde suggenh/s, genou= fi/los, | path\r, a)delfo\s, despo/ths Eur. Heraclidae 229 f., h(/d' a)nti\ pollw=n e)sti/ moi parayuxh/,— | po/lis, tiqh/nh, ba/ktron, h(gemw\n o(dou= Eur. Hec. 280 f., Hel. 277 ff., tot tamen amissis te compensavimus unum: | tu dominus, tu vir, tu mihi frater eras Ovid Her. iii. 51 f., te isti virum do, amicum, tutorem, patrem Terence And. i. 5. 60.
nu=n: sc. as he had not been doing.
au)tou=: right here, made definite by e)pi\ pu/rgw|, where Andromache had been (373). From that commanding position, Hector could direct the defence of the city.
cf. 408.—Obs. the ‘chiastic’ order,—pai=da and gunai=ka being separated. § 2 o.
o)rfaniko/n: predicate.
qh/h|s: qh=|s. cf. bh/w 113.
gunai=ka: is more pathetic than e)me/, and forms a better contrast to pai=da.
This advice is not out of place in the mouth of the general's wife, who doubtless had taken more interest than most Trojan women in the details of the plans for the safety of the city.

e)rineo/n: on a height near the walls and the Scaean Gate (else Hector could not have stood upon the tower to direct operations). cf. *l 167, *x 145.—Acc. to the later story, Poseidon and Apollo called Aeacus to their aid in building the wall of Troy. The work of the gods could not be overthrown by mortals; but what Aeacus had built could be destroyed by his descendants (Achilles, Ajax, Neoptolemus). Pindar Ol. viii. 31 ff. Homer nowhere else intimates that there was such an accessible or vulnerable place, at which the city should be captured.
a)mbato/s: a)nabai/nw.
kai\ e)pi/dromon (e)/dramon, dro/mos): i.e. exposed to attack. This gives the result of experience.
e)/pleto: used as present.
e)lqo/ntes: Homer is fond of a participle which completes the picture, but is not strictly necessary to the sense.
e)peirh/santo: intrans., made an attempt, sc. to scale the wall. No other mention is made in Homer of such an assault.
a)mf' *ai)/ante ktl.: including the Ajaxes. See H. 791; cf. *b 445, *g 146. Obs. that Achilles is not mentioned.
Two possible explanations of the assaults made at this particular spot.
qeopropi/wn: for the gen., cf. to/cwn *d 196. This refers to some such prophecy as that of Apollo, *pe/rgamos a)mfi\ teai=s, h(/rws (i.e. Aeacus), xero\s e)rgasi/ais a(li/sketai Pindar Ol. viii. 42.
h)/ nu kai/: or possibly too.
au)tw=n qumo/s: their own hearts, as opposed to oracles and omens.
e)potru/nei: after the aor., the pres. expresses the general truth which doubtless still abides.
440-465. Hector's reply. “I am not unmindful of thee, but I cannot play the coward and remain within the walls.”
ta/de pa/nta: all this that Andromache had just said, but esp. 432. cf. 5.490.
*trw=as: for the acc., see G. 158, N. 2; H. 712 a.
e(lkesipe/plous: with trailing robes. Only in this phrase. cf. *(ele/nh tanu/peplos *g 228, and *)ia/ones e(lkexi/twnes *n 685.
Reply to 433.
kako\s w(/s: cf. ku/nes w(/s *e 476.
vo/sfin pole/moio: Hector uses this expression of the safe position on the tower which Andromache had suggested. cf. 5.253.
A second reason against adopting the suggestion of 431.— “And my own courage forbids it.”
a)/nwgen: pf. as present.

ma/qon: I learned. To know was to do; cf. 265. cf. a)qemi/stia h)/|dh he had a lawless heart i 189, kedna\ i)dui=a trusty-hearted a 428, a)/gria oi)=den he has a cruel heart 24.41,— in all of which expressions, corresponding action is implied.
e)/mmenai e)sqlo/s: equiv. to a)risteu/ein 208.
Hector feels that he cannot save the city, but he will save his father's fame and his own.
a)rnu/menos: striving to gain. Cf. *a 159, a 5, *x 160.
patro/s: patri/ might have been used, with little difference of meaning.
au)tou=: intensive, agreeing with e)mou= implied in e)mo/n. cf. 490, 5.741.
447-449 = 4.163-165. The verses are more impressive here than in *d.
Reply to 429 f.
*trw/wn: objective gen. with a)/lgos. Contrasted with seu= 454.—Obs. that *trw/wn, *(eka/bhs, and kasignh/twn all come immediately before the verse-pause.
ou)/t' au)th=s *(eka/bhs: “not for my own mother.”—Hector's living mother, father, and brothers are offered to balance the dead relatives of Andromache.
oi(/ ken pe/soien: who doubtless will fall. The potential opt. is freq. used where the English idiom would use the future. cf. 410.
u(p' a)ndra/si: for u(po/ with the dat., cf. 4.291.
seu=: const. with a)/lgos 450.
a)/ghtai: sc. se/, into captivity. cf. 426.
e)leu/qeron h)=mar: equiv. to e)leuqeri/an, which is not Homeric. § 2 s. Cf. 463.—For the second half-verse, cf. *p 831, *u 193.
Hector sees with his mind's eye the time when Andromache will be put to menial service.
e)n *)/argei+: i.e. in Peloponnesus.
pro\s a)/llhs: i.e. as a slave, “at the bidding of another.”

u(/dwr: ‘fetching water’ is an important duty of women in Oriental countries. cf. ‘Let them live; but let them be hewers of wood and drawers of water unto all the congregation,’ Joshua ix. 21; ‘from the hewer of thy wood unto the drawer of they water,’ Deut. xxix. 11; ‘at the time of the evening, even the time that women go out to draw water,’ Genesis xxiv. 11 (Rebekah at the well).
*messhi/dos: sc. krh/nhs. Ablatival gen., from Messeïs. A spring of this name is mentioned by Pausanias, iii. 20. 1, as near Therapne, the old seat of the Dioscuri, not far from Sparta.

*(uperei/hs: mentioned as a spring in Thessaly, 2.734.—Perhaps the poet thus intimates the possibility that the captive Andromache may be given as a prize to Menelaus or Achilles. Later tradition made her the ge/ras of Achilles's son Neoptolemus. At any rate, this verse makes e)n *)/argei+ more definite.—That the Homeric poet should make Hector speak as if familiar with the names of springs in Greece, is not strange.
polla\ ktl.: much against thy will. Explained by the following half-verse.
ei)/ph|sin: subjv. as future. G. 213, 2 R.; H. 868. Obs. the repetition of the thought in e)re/ei 462.
h(/de ktl.: “see there the wife of Hector.”

ma/xesqai: cf. 5.536. The inf. follows the verb easily since a)risteu/eske is equiv. to a)/ristos h)=n. cf. 208.—cf. (Tecmessa to Ajax, see on 411) ei) ga qa/nh|s su\ kai\ teleuth/sas m' a)fh=|s, | tau/th| no/mize ka)me\ th=| to/q' h(me/ra| | bi/a| cunarpasqei=san *)argei/wn u(/po | cu
 paidi\ tw=| sw=| douli/an e(/cein trofh/n. | kai/ tis pikro
 pro/sfqegma despotw=n e)rei= | lo/gois i)a/ptwn: i)/dete th
 dmeune/tin | *ai)/antos o(\s me/giston i)/sxuse stratou= Soph. Aj. 496 ff.
a)mfema/xonto: sc. ‘they’ in a general sense, ‘our army.’
w(\s e)re/ei: for this repetition of ei)/ph|sin (both just before the versepause), cf. 4.182 with 4.176.
xh/tei+ ktl.: cf. *t 324.
toiou=de: “such a one as I am.”
a)mu/nein: equiv. to o(\s a)\n a)mu/noi, depends on toiou=de. GMT. 760.
dou/lion h)=mar: on 455. doulosu/nh is not Homeric.
“But may I be dead and buried.”
xuth\ (xe/w) gai=a: cf. *c 114, *y 256, g 258.
kata\ kalu/ptoi: cf. 4.182.
pri/n: const. with puqe/sqai. Natural in English as in Greek, “before I hear” instead of “before the time when I should hear.”

boh=s, e(lkhqmoi=o: both after puqe/sqai, but in different relations; sh=s is ‘subjective,’ while sou= is ‘objective.’ “Hear thy cry of distress and learn that thou art dragged into captivity.” sh=s boh=s is nearly equiv. to sou= bow/shs.— e(lkhqmoi=o: cf. Priam's words, kaka\ po/ll' e)pido/nta,— | vi(=a/s t' o)llume/nous, e(lkhqei/sas te qu/gatras, | . . . e(lkome/nas te nuou\s (sons' wives) o)loh=|s u(po\ xersi\n *)axaiw=n *x 61 ff.
paido/s: for the gen., cf. *menela/ou *d 100.

patro\s ktl.: parenthetical, giving the cause of e)kli/nqh i)a/xwn. It is explained by the following verse, which is further explained by 470. The partics. in 468-470 might be translated in reverse order: the child e)no/hse, then e)ta/rbhse, then h)tu/xqh, and then e)kli/nqh i)a/xwn.
xalko/n: the bronze, esp. of the helmet. cf. 473.
i)de/: for the length of the ‘ultima,’ see § 41 j.
deino/n: cognate acc. with neu/onta. cf. *d 420.
neu/onta: supplementary partic. after noh/sas. cf. noe/w kako\n u)/mmin | e)rxo/menon u 367 f.
e)k e)ge/lasse: laughed out, i.e. burst into a laugh. cf. p 354, s 35.
au)ti/ka: for the ‘asyndeton,’ see § 2 l, n.
kra_to/s: cf. 5.7. For the inflection, see § 18 f.

e)pei/: is expected at the beginning of the clause. On w(s 237.— ku/se: the Homeric warriors were not ashamed to express their emotions, but they seem to have done little kissing. Such salutation of adults is mentioned only as greeting after a long absence, or as an act of homage. KISSING is mentioned in but two other passages of the Iliad (*q 371, *w 478), both of which refer to the acts of suppliants.
e)peuca/menos: cf. fwnh/sas *d 312, o(moklh/sas *z 54.

With this prayer, cf. that of Ajax, w)= pai=, ge/noio patro\s eu)tuxe/steros, | ta\ d' a)/ll) o(/moios: kai\ ge/noi) a)\n ou) kako/s Soph. Ajax 550 f.; Aeneas's prayer for Ascanius, disce, puer, virtutem ex me verumque laborem, | fortunam ex aliis Verg. Aen. xii. 435 f.; ‘My son! my son! may kinder stars
div.l: Upon thy fortune shine; | And may those pleasures gild thy reign | That ne'er wad blink on mine,’ Burns's Lament of Mary Queen of Scots; ‘Bright as his manly sire the son shall be | In form and soul, but ah! more blest than he,’ Campbell, Pleasures of Hope.

div.p: kai/: correl. with kai/ 476, marking the close relation between to/nde and e)gw/. The English idiom omits it. H. 1042.
*trw/essin: “in the eyes of the Trojans.” ‘Dat. of interest in looser relations.’ H. 771. Originally this seems to have been ‘dat. of the agent.’
w(=de: points back to w(s kai\ e)gw/.
te/: in free position. See on 317.

a)na/ssein: correl. with bi/hn. For the meaning of the verb, see on *)astua/nakta 403.—Here Hector thinks no longer of the destruction of Troy (cf. 448 f.),—forgetting the war and its dangers at the sight of his child.
ti\s: many a one.
ei)/poi: opt. of wish.
patro\s ktl.: a verbal quotation of the desired praise.
o(/de: deictic.
pollo/n: originally ‘acc. of extent,’ and then adverbial. pollw=| might have been used.—“May many a one say of him as he returns from the war.”

a)nio/nta: as if to/nde patro\s a)mei/nw had preceded. The acc. depends on ei)/poi. G. 165; H. 725 a. The clause patro\s ktl. is the other obj. of the verb.—For the thought cf. pau=roi (few) ga/r toi pai=des o(moi=oi patri\ pe/lontai, | oi( ple/ones kaki/ous, pau=roi de/ te patro\s a)rei/ous b 276 f.
fe/roi: sc. e)k pole/moio. This aids in making the situation vivid.
xarei/h: sc. as a result of fe/roi ktl. The mother is to rejoice in the bloody spoils with which her son returns as a proof of his bravery.

a)lo/xoio: this is a delicate touch of the poet,—that Hector does not return the child to the nurse (from whom he took him, 466 ff.), but gives him into the arms of his wife, thus entrusting him to her care.
khw/dei+: fragrant, sc. because of her perfumed clothing. cf. 288.
ko/lpw|: cf. 136.
dakruo/en: “through her tears.” For the const., cf. deino/n 470.
e)le/hse: inceptive aorist. “Pity came over him.”
daimoni/h: “my poor wife.” cf. 407.
moi/: ‘ethical.’
ti li/hn: a common order. cf. *n 284, *c 368, *f 288.
The most distinct expression of fatalism in Homer. “I shall not die if death is not appointed for me now, nor can I escape death if that is decreed.”
u(pe\r ai)=san: cf. *p 780, *r 321.—*)/aidi ktl.: cf. 5.190.
moi=ran: fate, i.e. death.
pefugme/non e)/mmenai: pefeuge/nai. cf. *e 873.
a)ndrw=n: const. with ou)/ tina.
ou)de\ me/n: nor indeed, even not.
ta\ prw=ta: “once.” cf. 1.6.

490-493. cf. a 356-359, f 350-353. These verses are intended to quiet Andromache. She is to return to her home, and attend to her regular duties, assured that the men will do their part for the safety of the city.
au)th=s: cf. au)tou= 446.
i(sto\n ktl.: in appos. with e)/rga. Contrasted with po/lemos.

po/lemos ktl.: cf. *u 137.— melh/sei: cf. 5.430.—cf. a)ndrw=n ta/d' e)sti/, sfa/gia kai\ xrhsth/ria | qeoi=sin e(/rdein, polemi/wn peirwme/nwn: | so\n d) au)= to\ siga=n kai\ me/nein ei)/sw do/mwn Aesch. Septem 212 ff., a)ndrw=n ga\r a)lkh/: soi\ de\ xrh\ tou/twn (i.e. children) me/lein Eur. Heraclidae 711. The second half-verse is quoted in Aristophanes, Lysistrata 520, as a common admonition of husbands to wives, that they should mind their own business.
pa=sin ktl.: cf. c 138.
pa=sin: in appos. with a)/ndressi. On *e 313.— toi\ ktl.: cf. 17.145. Added after the verse-pause, making pa=sin more definite.

e)ggega/asin: cf. *e 477, *d 41.— This seems to have been planned by the poet as the last meeting of Hector and his wife. In the Twentysecond Book, Andromache is following her husband's directions, and is engaged in weaving when she hears the shriek from the women on the tower which announces Hector's death. 22.437 ff. She appears in a third scene in the Homeric poems, when the body of Hector is brought back to Troy. 24.723 ff.
ei(/leto: the poet does not need to say that Hector proceeded to don his helmet. cf. 178.—Andromache does not trust herself to speak again. The leave-taking is brief and simple.
i(/ppourin: cf. oi)kh=as 366.— bebh/kein: cf. 313. She was gone, i.e. she went quickly.
e)ntropalizome/nh (tre/pw): turning again and again, sc. in order to take another look at her husband.— The second half-verse adds an important trait to the picture. cf. 3.142.

*ektoros: does not limit do/mous directly, as if the end of a verse had not intervened, but is added in a sort of apposition. “She came to the house,—the house of Hector.” Similarly, polla/s at the close of this verse does not agree directly with a)mfipo/lous 499, which follows in apposition.
th=|sin pa/sh|sin: dat. with the prep. in e)nw=rsen.
e)nw=rsen: sc. by her tears.
zwo/n: obs. the force of the verse-pause, in giving emphasis and in separating this adj. from attrib. const. with *(/ektora.
go/on: lamented. This lament for the yet-living Hector, forms a prelude to the dirges sung at his death. 22.416 ff., 24.725 ff.
w(=|e)ni\ oi)/kw|: in his own home. Cf. *h 127, *q 284.
u(po/tropon ktl.: cf. 367. This prepares the way for the next verse.
me/nos kai\ xei=ras: might and arms. Not very different from me/nos xeirw=n *e 506. cf. *h 309, *n 105, 287, *c 73; and xei=ra/s te me/nos te *h 457, *o 510.

503-529. Paris joins Hector, and both return to the field of battle. Resumption of the story of 312-368, esp. 340 f.—This scene forms a sharp contrast with the preceding. Paris goes forth to battle without Hector's premonitions of disaster, and with no fears for the safety of his family.
ou)de/: nor.
seu/ato: rushed forth. Cf. *h 208, *c 227, e 51.—For the form, cf. e)xeu/ato *e 314.
a)na\ a)/stu: clearly not of ascent, since the home of Paris was near that of Hector, and the latter rushed kat' a)guia/s 391. cf. *d 209.
pepoiqw/s: cf. 5.299.
stato/s: “kept in a stall.”

a)kosth/sas: “high-fed on grain.”— cf. (Turnus) fulgebatque alta decurrens aureus arce | exultatque animis . . . qualis ubi abruptis fugit praesepia vinclis | tandem liber equus campoque potitus aperto
div.l: aut ille in pastus armentaque tendit equarum | aut adsuetus aquae perfundi flumine noto | emicat arrectisque fremit cervicibus alte | luxurians lu duntque iubae per colla, per armos Verg. Aen. xi. 490 ff.; ‘Contention, like a horse | Full of high feeding, madly hath broke loose,’ Shakspere 2 Henry IV. i. 1. 9 f.; ‘But like a proud steed reined, went haughty on, | Champing his iron curb,’ Milton Par. Lost iv. 858 f.— Paris is a well-fed, comfortable creature, without cares, and with a very good opinion of himself.

div.p: qei/h| [qe/h|]: for the subjv. in comparisons (general conditions), cf. *d 131.
pedi/oio: cf. 38.
e)urrei=os (r(e/w): gen. of e)urre/hs. e)urre/eos here contracts to e)urrei=os instead of to e)urre/ous.
potamoi=o: for the gen., cf. *)wkeanoi=o *e 6.
kudio/wn (ku=dos): cf. ku/dei+ gai/wn *e 906. In a prominent position as important for the comparison (cf. kagxalo/wn 514), and amplified by the succeeding clauses.
a)mfi/: adverbial. It is made more definite by w)/mois on the shoulders 510.

o( de/: the const. is changed, and this is left without a verb. For the ‘anacoluthon,’ cf. 5.135 f., 11.833 f., ‘The eye that mocketh at his father, and despiseth to obey his mother, the ravens of the valley shall pick it out, and the young eagles shall eat it,’ Proverbs xxx. 17.
h)/qea: haunts. Always of brutes, in Homer. Later, it was used of the character of men (‘ethies’), and in Herodotus (vii. 75) of the home of a nation.
nomo/n (ne/mw): pasture. Not to be confounded with no/mos law, which is not found in Homer.—Obs. the light rhythm.
w(/s: the point of comparison lies in the swift motion and eminent self-satisfaction of both the horse and Paris.
h)le/ktwr: lit. the beaming, i.e. the sun.
e)bebh/kein: cf. 495.
kagxalo/wn: laughing aloud, jubilant.
taxe/es ktl.: corresponds to r(i/mfa ktl. 511.
e)/tetmen: cf. 374.
eu)=te ktl.: cf. 52.
h)qei=e: honored brother, implies both respect and affection. cf. *x 229, 239.
kai\ e)ssu/menon: even in thy haste. Cf. *n 315, 787, *p 9. Elsewhere with pe/r, and without kai/.
ou)d' h)=lqon ktl.: repeats the preceding thought in slightly varied form.
e)nai/simon (e)n ai)/sh|): at the right time. Cognate accusative.

w(s e)ke/leues: cf. 331, 364.—Paris evidently is in high spirits, and plumes himself on overtaking Hector, as he had said that he would do, 341. These two verses are ironical. Paris forms an admirable foil for the heavy heart of Andromache.
e)nai/simos: in his right mind, refers to the same word in 519, though in a different sense.
ei)/h: for the opt., cf. i)/dois 330.
e)/rgon ma/xhs: “thy deeds in battle.”
e(kw/n: cf. o(/s tis e(kw\n meqi/h|si ma/xesqai *n 234.
meqiei=s: sc. a)lkh=s. cf. 330.
ou)k e)qe/leis: sc. ma/xesqai.
to\ e)mo\n kh=r: cf. to\ so\n me/nos 407.
e)n qumw=|: i.e. in its very depths.
ai)/sxea: cf. 351.

a)kou/w: subjunctive. ‘In general conditions which take the subjunctive, Homer commonly uses the relatives without ke/ or a)/n. This corresponds to his preference for the simple ei) in general conditions.’ GMT. 538.
pro\s *trw/wn: on the part of the Trojans, from the Trojans. cf. pro\s a)/llhs 456.
i)/omen: hortatory.
ta/: this, i.e. all that has disturbed their brotherly relations.
o)/pisqen ktl.: cf. *d 362.
qeoi=s: to the gods, in honor and gratitude. Indirect obj. of sth/sasqai.
krhth=ra sth/sasqai ktl.: “set up a bowl of freedom,” i.e. pour a rich libation in return for the gift of freedom.
sth/sasqai: explained by the following verse.—cf. a)=ra/ ge/ pa| toio/nde *fo/lw kata\ la/i+non a)/ntron | krath=r' *(hraklh=i ge/rwn e)sth/sato *xei/rwn; Theoc. vii. 149 f.
e)la/santas: agrees with h(ma=s, implied as the subj. of sth/sasqai.
